A small contingent of urdefhans usually stands guard here. Two Urdefhan Lashers block the entrance, while two Urdefhan Death Scouts hide amid the gruesome displays of skulls and body parts. They’ve been directed to shout an alarm in the face of powerful or numerous foes, but they jump eagerly into a fight as soon as they detect any enemies. If any three urdefhans are defeated, the survivor suddenly realizes they should have called for help sooner and flees to area @UUID[JournalEntry.1vlzl3NJsftNB9Dc.JournalEntryPage.rnPlOrzXgNElSkPN]{I34} to raise the alarm.

Replacements: If these guards are defeated, they’re first replaced with death scouts and lashers from area @UUID[JournalEntry.1vlzl3NJsftNB9Dc.JournalEntryPage.rnPlOrzXgNElSkPN]{I34}, then with a pair of nervous urdefhan warriors from area @UUID[JournalEntry.1vlzl3NJsftNB9Dc.JournalEntryPage.rnPlOrzXgNElSkPN]{I34}.

Heading West

@UUID[Scene.kxMIly2TCSidrRf1]{I - Urdefhan Camp}

When we created the VTT-ready maps for this floor, we chose to divide it into three sections. Our goal was to provide the same resolution as the other maps without having any impact on performance. We hope this will ensure that all users would have the best possible experience.

When your players have defeated the urdefhan guards in area I33, if they would like to continue deeper into the Urdefhan compound, you should activate the next scene and place down their tokens near the entrance.

You can find the scenes for the rest of the Hunting Grounds and the Yldaris outpost in the 09: On The Hunt folder of the scenes tab in your sidebar.

Urdefhan Horde.name: Urdefhan Horde
Urdefhan Horde.text:
This massive cavern holds a jumble of low-lying tents made of stitched-together pelts and blood-streaked leather. Most of the tents surround a natural stone pillar decorated with strange symbols in brown and red paint, amid skulls tied or spiked to the pillar. Hides cover the entrances to three large caves to the southeast, each with a narrow wooden door.

Drow to the Rescue

The party might face significant danger in the Hunting Grounds. If the characters have earned Yldaris’s aid and indicated they were going against Khurfel, the drow might follow at a distance to keep an eye on them. If the characters are in over their heads, a group of three @UUID[Actor.OqoWbYOyHDGHEeHV]{Drow Hunters} and a @UUID[Actor.rArZ2y5xqSWeUU0G]{Drow Shootist} comes to their aid. The drow won’t enter melee if they can avoid it, but they’re happy to pick off urdefhans at a distance. If the characters have truly shown their worth to Yldaris, @UUID[Actor.JrowrtDilEG8dN2s]{Quara Orshendiel} might come to their aid as well.

Most urdefhans in the Abomination Vaults dwell in this enormous cavern. They sleep in small, cramped tents but spend their time awake eating, sparring, or working with their weapons. Other accouterments to support their camp, such as food storage and mundane supplies, are in the tents.

Traversing this war camp to face Khurfel is difficult. With their craving for destruction, the urdefhans are always ready for battle. As they spend so much time sparring and fighting among themselves, the denizens of the adjacent caves (areas @UUID[JournalEntry.1vlzl3NJsftNB9Dc.JournalEntryPage.6P5Lw4eeNrBQKv9O]{I35}, @UUID[JournalEntry.1vlzl3NJsftNB9Dc.JournalEntryPage.w0VMeGekcaakkCSk]{I36}, and @UUID[JournalEntry.1vlzl3NJsftNB9Dc.JournalEntryPage.ODRXDNm2Z9BgXmTM]{I37}) don’t respond to the sounds of combat here. The characters might have an easier time bypassing these forces if they use stealth or trickery, but keep in mind the daemons here have Truesight, and so can see Invisible creatures. Among other options, the characters can slip from tent to tent by succeeding on a group [[/check skill=stealth dc=15]] check.

Encounter

@UUID[Actor.NW1Ax1QGE9W4DmiN]{Ceustodaemon}, and Urdefhan @UUID[Actor.e5yE4RkwLQojRYHm]{Warriors}, @UUID[Actor.tZCFmJonHkhGg1Vs]{Death Scouts}, @UUID[Actor.Sbxt8YT0AOFfVCPX]{Lashers}

Nearly 20 urdefhans can be found here at almost all times. Outside of the tents are two Urdefhan Lashers, an Urdefhan Death Scout, eight Urdefhan Warriors, and a Ceustodaemon eagerly stoking the urdefhan bloodlust.

About a third of the urdefhans are sleeping, but they’re quick to grab their weapons and join in a fight if other urdefhans raise a hue and cry. They emerge from their tents after 2 rounds. They include an Urdefhan Death Scout and four Urdefhan Warriors. All emerge without their armor.

The urdefhans fight with growling whoops and revel in the battle, even if they’re losing. If the characters defeat all the urdefhans other than warriors, the warriors break and flee together.

If the characters retreat from this battle, most of the urdefhans let them go; [[/gmroll 1d6]] urdefhan warriors follow, screaming for the characters’ blood.

If the urdefhans defeat the characters, they don’t kill them, but rather take them alive and hand them over to the urdefhans in area @UUID[JournalEntry.1vlzl3NJsftNB9Dc.JournalEntryPage.6P5Lw4eeNrBQKv9O]{I35}, where they might have a chance to escape before being slain as sacrifices.

Summoning Cavern.name: Summoning Cavern
Summoning Cavern.text:
This cavern slopes upward to a flat area on the far side. A metal box about three feet across sits against the northern wall, its lid pressed against the wall to prevent it from opening. A bloody circle surrounded by runes is painted on the floor to the north.

Dedicated to bringing more daemons into their midst, urdefhans use this chamber for vile summoning rituals. They currently have one prisoner they intend to sacrifice: a deep gnome Scout named @UUID[Actor.0hnnwyqLfYVIenzd]{Calinth Narogblom}. The unfortunate Calinth came to the Abomination Vaults searching for evidence that an offshoot of his people were still living here. He never even met up with the Children of Belcorra—whose current state would horrify him—before being captured by an urdefhan raiding party. They keep Calinth in the metal box pushed against the wall, as he’s not strong enough to push it aside on his own.

Encounter

@UUID[Actor.OTT7CCkonkfwhJ8Y]{Urdefhan Blood Mage}, @UUID[Actor.FJr7Rc9MQEwxjAcz]{Urdefhan Cult Fanatics (2)}

Three urdefhans chant and wail, casting a long-duration summoning ritual. The urdefhans hope to empower their ritual to bring in a more powerful daemon; whether or not they ultimately succeed is up to the GM. The Urdefhan Blood Mage and two Urdefhan Cult Fanatics are quick to attack any intruders that interrupt their rite. They fight to the death.

Side Quest

Calinth has no gear, but he nevertheless still wants to find out about the deep gnomes living here. If the characters show him evidence of the Children of Belcorra—even their corpses from past fights—Calinth is sad but his curiosity is satisfied. If the characters lead him to one of the exits to the Darklands, he can make it back to his people. A week later, Calinth sends them a token of his appreciation: a jet and opal complete set of the @UUID[Item.X7VwwcQ63ScaDI2j]{Dark Chase} board game, worth [[/award 120gp]]. If the characters told Calinth that they are friendly with the Yldaris drow, he sends it by the caravan route between the outpost and Lozardyn. Otherwise, he searches the characters out himself, even braving the surface world if he must.

XP Award: Award the characters [[/award 1800xp]] if they satisfy Calinth’s curiosity and escort him safely out of the Hunting Grounds.

The Blood Temple.name: The Blood Temple
The Blood Temple.text:
A raised platform with a bloody altar stands toward the east side of this roughly triangular cavern.

A constant orgy of bloodletting goes on in this chamber, all part of the strange and gory urdefhan religion. If interrupted, the participants are anxious to cover their altar with fresh blood.

Encounter

@UUID[Actor.FJr7Rc9MQEwxjAcz]{Urdefhan Cult Fanatics (2)} @UUID[Actor.Sbxt8YT0AOFfVCPX]{Urdefhan Lashers (2)}

Two Urdefhan Lashers are led in the rites by two Urdefhan Cult Fanatics. All of them attack nonbelievers who interfere with the bloodletting.

Khurfel’s Tent.name: Khurfel’s Tent
Khurfel’s Tent.text:
At this cavern's center sits a single fur-and-skin hovel. A path to the hovel is flanked with skull-topped spears.

It’s the tradition of this urdefhan cult that the war champion dwells apart and lives in a home no more elaborate than that of other urdefhans. The skulls all belong to rivals that Khurfel defeated to obtain and maintain his position as war champion. Their teeth are gone, having been used for the shauth weapons these urdefhans use.

Encounter

@UUID[Actor.Np787X9Z4aQxOdCg]{Khurfel}, @UUID[Actor.FJr7Rc9MQEwxjAcz]{Urdefhan Cult Fanatic}, @UUID[Actor.OTT7CCkonkfwhJ8Y]{Urdefhan Blood Mage}

Once Khurfel notices the characters, he looks pleased, his face contorting in a vicious grin. He calls out, “We meet on a good day to kill,” in Undercommon as he draws his rhoka sword and strides forward. As his blood visions have foretold his fight with the characters, he doesn’t shy away from it, and he neither offers nor accepts quarter. He keeps the Emerald Fulcrum Lens on his person at all times, strapped across his back so it doesn’t get in the way during a fight. He’s attuned to the lens, and the lens’s magical properties are included in his stat block. Should Khurfel somehow survive being separated from his magic items, his Challenge Rating is reduced to 8 ([[/award 3900xp]]).

An Urdefhan Cult Fanatic and an Urdefhan Blood Mage advise Khurfel and join any battle with him. They’re careful not to get in their war champion’s way during combat. They cast Shield of Faith to keep him in the fight while casting Fear and Hold Person on foes that seem especially dangerous. They flee if Khurfel is defeated.

Treasure: In addition to the Emerald Fulcrum Lens, Khurfel wields a Rhoka Sword of Wounding, which Quara Orshendiel desires (see her Side Quest @UUID[JournalEntry.1vlzl3NJsftNB9Dc.JournalEntryPage.F3CmB9Q0LVQ8NOpD]{here}).

XP Award: Award the characters [[/award 1800xp]] for recovering the Emerald Fulcrum Lens.

Treasure

@UUID[Item.omCfoLL1QfzyWjcL]{Urdefhan Tribute}

Inside the hovel are mounds of treasure given to Khurfel as tribute: [[/award 190gp 1320sp]], five moonstones worth [[/award 50gp]] each, and two chrysoberyls worth [[/award 200gp]] each.

Guard Post.name: Guard Post
Guard Post.text:
The urdefhans use this passageway to come and go from the lakeshore.

Encounter

@UUID[Actor.Sbxt8YT0AOFfVCPX]{Urdefhan Lashers (3)}

The three Urdefhan Lashers assigned to guard this little-used entrance are itching for a fight. Unwilling to accept the shame of admitting defeat, they fight to the death.

Reinforcements: If these guards are defeated, they’re replaced by the ceustodaemon and cult fanatic in area @UUID[JournalEntry.1vlzl3NJsftNB9Dc.JournalEntryPage.rnPlOrzXgNElSkPN]{I34}. If those creatures are also defeated, the urdefhans leave this area unguarded.

Deadly Lake.name: Deadly Lake
Deadly Lake.text:
The murky waters of this massive lake shift ominously.

Though not covered with a cloying, sickly mist like the large lake in the Farm level, this lake is hundreds of feet deep in its center and harbors strange aquatic life.

Encounter

@UUID[Actor.78Vf1Lk9ph2RGDgL]{Deepwater Dhuthorexes}

Four Deepwater Dhuthorexes swim in this lake. Two of them quickly investigate any disturbance in the water. This attack should occur the first time the characters venture into the lake, but the GM can choose to have another pair of dhuthorexes attack during later excursions. The dhuthorexes attack singly or in pairs and are shockingly aggressive; they pursue foes on land and fight to the death. More might repopulate the lake from elsewhere in the Darklands even if the characters defeat all the ones currently dwelling here.

Crystal Shore.name: Crystal Shore
Crystal Shore.text:
The stone along the shore here sprouts large growths of pale-green crystals. The crystals hang from the ceiling, climb up the wall, and reach toward the water in long strands.

While some of these crystals are pointed, they aren’t hazardous. However, if a creature touches one of the crystals, it begins to vibrate, which starts a chain reaction of resonant, ringing sounds among the crystals. The sound is loud but not unpleasant. The noise piques the attention of the cauthooj nesting in area @UUID[.zRyrXydUmCGSSpzo]{I41}, which swims over to investigate.

Island Nest.name: Island Nest
Island Nest.text:
A mix of green crystals and grayish stone make up the mass of this island. A few patches of fungus grow across the rocks, with a particularly thick patch near the island’s eastern shore.

The thick patch is a cauthooj nest holding two eggs.

Encounter

@UUID[Actor.FHfrIJCdKTzy2rrR]{Cauthooj}

A Cauthooj recently came to this island to lay its eggs and stockpile corpses to feed the hatchlings. When the cauthooj detects the characters, it attacks immediately to secure their corpses as a better source of food. If reduced to fewer than 20 Hit Points, the cauthooj flees the island and abandons its eggs. It’s wary of a trap and doesn’t pursue anyone who flees into a narrow passage, such as those leading to areas @UUID[JournalEntry.1vlzl3NJsftNB9Dc.JournalEntryPage.nWev8MFPqA7hd0lz]{I38} or @UUID[JournalEntry.1vlzl3NJsftNB9Dc.JournalEntryPage.vnlVep65rXXsVyLP]{I43}.

Exploration

Quara’s late father dropped the Ochre Fulcrum Lens in the water near the eastern shore of this island during his battle with Khurfel. Spells like Detect Magic locate it easily; otherwise, a character who searches the water can attempt a [[/check skill=perception dc=18]] check every 15 minutes to find it. If the characters haven’t already encountered the deepwater dhuthorexes in area @UUID[JournalEntry.1vlzl3NJsftNB9Dc.JournalEntryPage.wHieR95y1h9tQrGc]{I39}, those monsters might harass anyone spending a lot of time searching this area.

XP Award: Award the characters [[/award 1800xp]] for recovering the Ochre Fulcrum Lens.

Treasure

@Item[1qGzZwhFICVJbNFK]{Cauthooj Eggs}

The two cauthooj eggs are worth as much as [[/award 200gp]] each, but finding the right buyer can be difficult. Worliwynn at Stone Ring Pond just outside of Otari has contacts among naturalists who will buy the eggs, and these eager contacts offer either gold coins or a valuable item for them. The characters can accept [[/award 400gp]] for the eggs, or arrange a trade for any uncommon permanent magic item.

Steep Exit.name: Steep Exit
Steep Exit.text:
This rubble-filled passage slopes steeply downward. The passage’s ceiling undulates as an echoing chitter fills the air.

The passage leads deeper into the Darklands, but the going isn’t easy. The steep and rocky decline slopes downward for 80 feet before reaching a sheer, 300-foot drop. Several disused natural passages radiate outward from its base, but where these passages might lead is beyond the scope of this adventure.

Hundreds of tiny subterranean bats lair here. They don’t pose a threat to high-level characters, even with their staggering numbers and tendency to swarm around the heads of intruders. The bats sometimes hunt in the Hunting Grounds, or in deeper Darklands caverns, but are just as often food for larger creatures.

Sanctuary.name: Sanctuary
Sanctuary.text:
A thick growth of fungus blocks this narrow cave entrance.

The harmless fungus can easily be pushed aside. It conceals an out-of-the-way cavern with a small spring of fresh water. This cavern is a perfect place for the characters to rest, as wandering monsters ignore the cave. A character who makes a successful [[/check skill=survival dc=16]] check recognizes that the cavern has been untouched for a long time.

Digger’s Cavern.name: Digger’s Cavern
Digger’s Cavern.text:
A jumble of fungus grows in the center of this roughly square cave. A large lizard’s corpse lies amid the fungus.

The giant frilled lizard barely escaped the roper in area @UUID[.rclYw8nugZgu0z5Q]{I45} but collapsed and died in this harmless fungus patch.

Encounter

@UUID[Actor.fxYMucI5b2IUoBpw]{Shuln}

When the characters examine the lizard or the fungus, the entire cavern starts to shake as a shuln chews its way through the north wall. The enormous, rodent-like shuln scented the dead lizard and was coming to eat it, but it’s more excited for living prey. It’s hungry and fights until slain. It pursues foes that run away but doesn’t like the water, so it gives up chasing anyone that flees into the lake.

Dead Roper.name: Dead Roper
Dead Roper.text:
A rocky depression at the south end of this chamber contains a thick stalagmite toppled over in a pool of dark ichor.

Exploration

The stalagmite is, on closer inspection, a dead roper. The shuln in area @UUID[JournalEntry.1vlzl3NJsftNB9Dc.JournalEntryPage.nhkChhX6MdhDuLQo]{I44} burrowed up from beneath it and bit off its lower third before deciding its taste was wholly unpleasant and leaving the rest of the body behind. A character who makes a successful [[/check skill=nature dc=12]] check realizes that a Huge burrowing beast came up beneath the roper and bit it. The tunnel connects to area @UUID[JournalEntry.1vlzl3NJsftNB9Dc.JournalEntryPage.nhkChhX6MdhDuLQo]{I44}.

Pudding Wallow.name: Pudding Wallow
Pudding Wallow.text:
A pool of thick, tar-like goo coats a large patch of the floor in this cave.

A black pudding stripped most of the fungus in this room clear before it was defeated by another predator. Its gooey remains are smeared across the floor. It is inert and therefore harmless.

Corrupted Garden.name: Corrupted Garden
Corrupted Garden.text:
An ancient and crumbling stone bridge stretches across the water to an island teeming with reeking fungus.

The old stone bridge is still stable enough to traverse safely, though it’s slick with slime and moist lichen that make it Difficult Terrain. The island used to be a tended garden, but now it too is Difficult Terrain, as the fungus is so dense and slick. The slime growing on the fungus emits a terrible smell, but one overwhelmed by the stench of the island’s denizen.

Encounter

@Actor[jP8CO6z7bNIhOuqQ]

An Otyugh dwells on the island, wallowing in a layer of filth produced by the strange fungus. It doesn’t treat the fungus as Difficult Terrain. The otyugh is wary of intruders and lurks among the fungus, but if it smells anything rotten on the characters, such as any items retrieved from a corpse, it telepathically asks (without emerging) to smell the item. If attacked, the otyugh fights until it is reduced to 40 Hit Points, at which point it flees to area @UUID[JournalEntry.1vlzl3NJsftNB9Dc.JournalEntryPage.nhabEoBxFslXb39s]{I46}.

In exchange for any stinky item, such as a corpse from anywhere in the Abomination Vaults, the otyugh is happy to share (in few, simple words) the basic contents of areas @UUID[JournalEntry.1vlzl3NJsftNB9Dc.JournalEntryPage.8Rzvwjps769qMdK5]{I40} through @UUID[JournalEntry.1vlzl3NJsftNB9Dc.JournalEntryPage.ih4G2q4q9sJ699qR]{I48} and @UUID[JournalEntry.1vlzl3NJsftNB9Dc.JournalEntryPage.Yl8uOEPJOagzzcaa]{I52} (including the “sticky spike beast” in area @UUID[JournalEntry.1vlzl3NJsftNB9Dc.JournalEntryPage.rclYw8nugZgu0z5Q]{I45}, which it doesn’t know is dead), as well as the fact that it recently saw a pair of humanoids headed this way from area @UUID[JournalEntry.1vlzl3NJsftNB9Dc.JournalEntryPage.8Rzvwjps769qMdK5]{I40} when they were caught and killed by a “skeleton man” (Khurfel) in area @UUID[JournalEntry.1vlzl3NJsftNB9Dc.JournalEntryPage.zRyrXydUmCGSSpzo]{I41}. (The “humanoids” in question here were Quara’s father and sister.) If the characters ask about the bodies, the otyugh knows the man took the bodies as trophies. It doesn’t know about the Ochre Fulcrum Lens, but if asked it recalls that one of the dying creatures tossed something in the water somewhere near area @UUID[JournalEntry.1vlzl3NJsftNB9Dc.JournalEntryPage.zRyrXydUmCGSSpzo]{I41}.

Horrid Carnage.name: Horrid Carnage
Horrid Carnage.text:
Bones and discarded viscera are strewn across this cavern as if some horrifying battle recently occurred here somewhat recently. A trail of the gruesome remains winds to the northeast, up a narrow tunnel.

The carnage is the result of gogiteth feeding. The gnashing, nightmarish aberration lairs in area @UUID[JournalEntry.1vlzl3NJsftNB9Dc.JournalEntryPage.PUv8ghWFABFTz3ej]{I49} but sometimes lurks in the passageway to ambush prey. When the characters approach this area, roll [[/gmroll 1d20]]. On a 16 or higher, the gogiteth is watching from the passageway and is prepared to strike.

Gogiteth Cave.name: Gogiteth Cave
Gogiteth Cave.text:
Exploration

If the characters haven’t already defeated the gogiteth lairing here, as they approach, they hear its clacking and popping legs as it moves about. Any character who succeeds on a [[/check skill=arcana dc=22]] check recognizes the sound as that of a gogiteth.

Encounter

@UUID[Actor.IXen98RbUlbxDWBD]{Gogiteth}

If the Gogiteth is here, it’s tearing up an urdefhan corpse. It drops the dead urdefhan with a sickening plop to skitter forward and feast upon the characters. It fights until slain, but it doesn’t pursue creatures out of areas @UUID[JournalEntry.1vlzl3NJsftNB9Dc.JournalEntryPage.ih4G2q4q9sJ699qR]{I48} and @UUID[JournalEntry.1vlzl3NJsftNB9Dc.JournalEntryPage.PUv8ghWFABFTz3ej]{I49}.

Coins and Ooze.name: Coins and Ooze
Coins and Ooze.text:
Hanging streamers of mold dangle from the ceiling here. Several coins protrude from a shelf of stone to the north.

A traveler left the coins in the wall here long ago, hoping to keep them safe, though they never returned. A patch of green slime grew from the streams of mold, particularly over the coins, where it could fall upon greedy treasure-seekers, dissolve them, and slither up the ceiling to await a new victim.

Hazard

@UUID[Actor.mmGrayOoze000000]{Gray Ooze}

The Gray Ooze is hard to spot amid the wet stalagmites. It drips upon anyone who tries to pull the coins free.

Treasure

There are only [[/award 15sp]] stuck in the wall, and breaking out each coin requires a few minutes of chiseling or magic such as a Stone Shape spell (which is how the coins got stuck in the stone in the first place). One of the coins is caked with old blood and bits of flesh; a character who touches it is exposed to blueblisters.

Ravirex’s Fen.name: Ravirex’s Fen
Ravirex’s Fen.text:
A morass of mud sprouting thick fungus and clinging vines makes up the floor of this large cavern. A few boulders protrude from the mud.

Not long ago, a black dragon named Ravirex moved into the swampy cavern at the edge of the Hunting Grounds to make his lair. He initially thought to dominate the area but soon ran afoul of powerful creatures like the derghodaemon in area @UUID[.sJbJvBLnTcfcPRLs]{I31}, the gogiteth in area @UUID[.PUv8ghWFABFTz3ej]{I49}, and the drow hunters who have proven impossible to pin down. Ravirex quickly realized the need to be much more circumspect in the Hunting Grounds, and these days he primarily works on sculpting the growth in his wide cavern to his liking. He’s too arrogant to consider defense, assuming that even the other dangerous creatures of the Hunting Grounds know better than to attack a dragon.

Belcorra appeared to Ravirex a short time ago to open negotiations about aiding an attack on a surface city that Ravirex doesn’t know, and the dragon awaits her next visit to learn more. She mentioned something about entrusting a colored magical lens to Ravirex, so he’s keeping an eye out for those in the hopes of currying favor with Belcorra.

Two passages lead out of this area to wild Darklands areas to the west. Swamp water floods the southern passage entirely, while the northern passage is clear but very narrow.

Encounter

@UUID[Actor.irrXrWxJ0LYSUCQB]{Ravirex}

While not working to sculpt the fungus in his lair or out hunting, Ravirex the Adult Black Dragon rests upon his hoard in the alcove to the north. He defends his lair ferociously and works hard to drive intruders away so he can preserve his privacy. If he learns that the characters have any of the magic lenses he believes Belcorra is looking for, he targets the characters who carry them and tries to take them.

Treasure

@UUID[Item.mCqiQas8jcHqRjQl]{Ravirex's Hoard}

The dragon’s large hoard consists of [[/award 110pp 460gp 1412sp 4303cp]], a golden goblet worth [[/award 200gp]], a Mace of Disruption, a Potion of Psychic Resistance, and a Spell Scroll of Ectoplasmic Expulsion.

Vault Ledge.name: Vault Ledge
Vault Ledge.text:
The lake’s water laps lazily on a wide stone ledge surrounding a structure built into the cavern wall. The ledge is thick with lichen and barely wide enough to stand on. A single vault-like iron door with a metal handle and a keyhole leads into the structure.

Belcorra built this secure vault as a place to gather the treasures she planned to use to fund her assault on Absalom. Beneath the profusion of lichen, the ledge has several cleats for securing boats.

The vault door looks formidable but is, surprisingly, unlocked. The vaults’ only intelligent occupant, a graveknight named Caliddo, recently traveled to the third level of the Abomination Vaults to recover some books Belcorra wanted, and he neglected to lock the door when he returned.

Blast Tumbler

Hazard

The vault door isn’t locked, but it is still trapped. A hard-to-reach rune has been placed on the lock’s tumbler. It emits a blast of force when the door or lock are jostled.

A character can notice the strange runes on the inside of the lock mechanism with successful [[/check skill=arcana/investigation dc=22]] check. Using a spell or other effect that can sense the presence of magic finds nothing, as Belcorra has protected the trap against detection using a permanent @UUID[Compendium.dnd5e.spells24.Item.phbsplNystulsMag]{Arcanist’s Magic Aura} spell.

When a creature other than an Undead opens the door or fails an ability check to bypass the trap by 5 or more, a 30-foot Cone of force erupts from the lock. Each creature in the area makes a [[/save strength dc=18]] saving throw. On a failed save, the creature takes [[/damage 6d10 force average]] damage and is pushed 10 feet directly away from the door and knocked &Reference[prone]. On a success, the creature takes half as much damage only.

Once triggered, the rune vanishes, but it returns after 1 minute. A character can scratch out the rune without triggering it with a successful [[/check dex thief dc=22]] check. The magic rune can also be removed with a successful @UUID[Compendium.dnd5e.spells24.Item.phbsplDispelMagi]{Dispel Magic} spell (DC 15).

XP Award: Award the party [[/award 900xp]] for disabling the trap.

Vault Antechamber.name: Vault Antechamber
Vault Antechamber.text:
The dust is thick in this room, save for footprints that lead to and from the southernmost of three iron doors, which looks similar to the vault’s entrance.

On the south side of the chamber is a hardened clay statue sculpted to resemble Belcorra. Each door leads to another vault. The doors to areas @UUID[JournalEntry.1vlzl3NJsftNB9Dc.JournalEntryPage.uyABiql2hjVpN6UO]{I54} and @UUID[JournalEntry.1vlzl3NJsftNB9Dc.JournalEntryPage.jEIagL8TU2V9x3ST]{I55} are both locked, and Caliddo has the keys. The locks each require a successful [[/check dex thief dc=21]] check to open, and they can’t be forced open. The door to area @UUID[JournalEntry.1vlzl3NJsftNB9Dc.JournalEntryPage.iV9RReXcTyfDbDRq]{I56} is unlocked; this is where Caliddo went.

Encounter

@UUID[Actor.skz8n8N9GEQY2c90]{Shield Guardian}

The statue is a Shield Guardian charged with attacking any creature other than Belcorra or Caliddo. Once, Belcorra wore its amulet, but Caliddo retrieved it recently and now wears it. It fights until destroyed, its old clay grinding as it attacks. The sound quickly brings Caliddo to fight as well. Together, they are a very difficult encounter for level 9 characters.

Coin Vault.name: Coin Vault
Coin Vault.text:
Three iron chests, all in different sizes, are lined up against the north wall of this room.

The boxes hold a mass of treasure that Belcorra accumulated in life to aid in her assault on Absalom.

Treasure

The largest box has [[/award 7000sp]]. The second largest holds [[/award 600gp]]. The smallest has [[/award 100pp]]. All these coins were minted centuries ago.

Alchemical Vault.name: Alchemical Vault
Alchemical Vault.text:
This door is difficult to open, even once unlocked, because the door’s interior side has been warped by an explosion.

Hazard: Forcing open the door requires a successful [[/check ability=strength dc=20]] check. Opening the door releases a cloud of toxic fumes trapped inside the room. Each creature within 10 feet of the door when it is opened makes a [[/save constitution dc=15]] saving throw. On a failed save, the creature has the &Reference[Poisoned] condition for 1 hour. While Poisoned in this way, the creature also has the @UUID[Compendium.dnd5e.content24.JournalEntry.phbAppendixCRule.JournalEntryPage.uDogReMO6QtH6NDw]{Blinded} condition. Once released, the fumes dissipate and are no further threat.

>Inside this room is a tangle of splintered wood, shattered glass, and broken pottery. Scorch marks scar the stone walls, floor, and ceiling.

Belcorra stored a variety of alchemical bombs in this vault. As the centuries passed, the wooden shelves that held some of them collapsed, creating a chain reaction of explosions and leaving the room and its vault door in its current state. Nothing of value remains.

Caliddo’s Vigil.name: Caliddo’s Vigil
Caliddo’s Vigil.text:
Exploration

This small, bare room has more vault doors, just as in area @UUID[JournalEntry.1vlzl3NJsftNB9Dc.JournalEntryPage.vV1UI5ww3NEtLe0o]{I53}; Caliddo Haruvex carries these two keys as well. There’s also a remarkably well-hidden secret door here; a character searching this room discovers the hidden latch to open it with a successful [[/skill 22 inv]] check.

Encounter

@UUID[Actor.oXnpdJVN6NIE58W3]{Caliddo Haruvex}

A Graveknight in archaic armor stands in this room, clutching a greatsword. This is Caliddo Haruvex, a skilled mercenary who came to serve Belcorra when he heard how powerful his distant relative had become. Belcorra accepted Caliddo’s offer of aid and promptly killed him, raising him as a graveknight eternally bound to serve her. Despite his unanticipated reanimation, Caliddo proved his worth and loyalty to Belcorra many times over, so she entrusted him with one of her most important duties: guarding her vault. Caliddo kept his silent vigil here for centuries.

When Belcorra returned, she put Caliddo to work fetching several books she needed, and which she wanted out of the hands of others who might use them against her. For the first time in centuries, Caliddo left the vault. He ascended to the display room more recently taken over by the Cult of the Canker (area @UUID[JournalEntry.KeWKr2yd8dbppeS5.JournalEntryPage.wAoRY1yKOiu1ocVU]{C34}) and recovered the texts Belcorra mentioned. He didn’t gather all of the important texts from the Library level, however; the characters might have recovered Belcorra’s journals and The Whispering Reeds from the hidden study next to the display room. Upon Caliddo’s return here, he locked the books he acquired in area @UUID[JournalEntry.1vlzl3NJsftNB9Dc.JournalEntryPage.ydFyUm2uTgteYviW]{I58} and returned to his vigil.

Caliddo remains at his post and is quick to assault anyone who enters. The characters likely face him as they confront the shield guardian in area @UUID[JournalEntry.1vlzl3NJsftNB9Dc.JournalEntryPage.vV1UI5ww3NEtLe0o]{I53}, but he’s otherwise encountered here. Caliddo fights until destroyed, but he doesn’t leave his post in the vault unless Belcorra expressly orders him to.

Treasure: Caliddo’s armor is Plate Armor of Cold Resistance, but it also carries his Graveknight’s Curse. As normal for a cursed item, the characters can’t discover the curse via an @UUID[Compendium.dnd5e.spells24.Item.phbsplIdentify00]{Identify} spell or other methods of identifying magic items. Only an @UUID[Compendium.dnd5e.spells24.Item.phbsplLegendLore]{Legend Lore} spell or a successful [[/check skill=religion dc=20]] check to remember the connection graveknights have to their armor reveals its cursed nature.

Caliddo’s Return

Destroying Caliddo for good is difficult because his armor rebuilds him over time. If he rejuvenates after the characters have plundered the vault and left, he pursues them in an attempt to recover and return the items to this vault. He doesn’t have any special connection to the treasures, though, so he might have to search around to find them. He might find the characters while they’re resting somewhere in the Abomination Vaults, or even when they’re in a fight with other denizens of the dungeon.

Caliddo is most interested in reclaiming his keys and returning the books to the vault (as those were the last things Belcorra expressed particular interest in and, he assumes, are the most valuable to her). Characters who turn over the keys and books to Caliddo might avert the graveknight’s implacable retribution.

Derelict Armory.name: Derelict Armory
Derelict Armory.text:
Ancient weapon racks have collapsed over time, leaving numerous swords, spears, and axes jumbled on the floor with a few toppled armor stands.

Belcorra hoarded dozens of weapons for her impending campaign against Absalom in this room, intending to arm the humanoid warriors who fought alongside the aberrant monsters when she made her attack. While most of the weapons are merely well- made, a few of them are genuinely superior.

Treasure

@UUID[Item.UHLrb8ZwznVpvSWo]{Derelict Armory}

Amid the weapons are a single silvered warhammer and a +2 Battleaxe. A fallen armor stand is tangled up with the Glamoured Studded Leather that was once displayed on it. At the GM’s discretion, the characters might find other mundane weapons that are useful to them, even though they’re not particularly valuable.

Vault of Secrets.name: Vault of Secrets
Vault of Secrets.text:
The shelves of this room contain several old books and various odds and ends. In the center of the room is a dusty mechanism of copper and silver. It’s missing its lenses, but otherwise looks like the framework of a lantern that belongs in the top of a lighthouse. The dust in this room has been recently disturbed.

This is Belcorra’s most protected vault, holding her treasures and secrets of her past. The books that have been most recently shelved here—as evidenced by the trails in the dust—are research journals Belcorra penned when she was alive. They are centuries old, but careful magical preservation has kept them from falling apart. These journals describe four @UUID[JournalEntry.67686KaEPc6XAlKJ.JournalEntryPage.azMqL6C2NvazTcRE]{Fulcrum Lenses} (in crimson, ebon, emerald, and ochre) that focus Nhimbaloth’s soul-extinguishing gaze across space and time.

Belcorra’s personal journals detail how she built Gauntlight and created a special framework called the Fulcrum Lattice to fit the four lenses and harness their power. A diagram of the Fulcrum Lattice makes it clear that the device is the very one sitting here. Belcorra expresses some trepidation at using the Fulcrum Lenses; they each contain a sliver of Nhimbaloth’s essence, and bringing them in close proximity can be dangerous. More specifically, the lenses impart Nhimbaloth’s essence into those who use or are touched by them. Having all four essences imbued at once is sure to bring Nhimbaloth’s dreadful scrutiny. Belcorra had her talented apprentice, Volluk Azrinae, fashion mundane lenses that would allow Gauntlight to function at a diminished capacity until the Fulcrum Lattice and the Fulcrum Lenses could be installed, on the eve of Belcorra’s assault on Absalom. The Fulcrum Lattice allows all four of the large, heavy lenses to be carried with ease.

Belcorra’s journals explain that she used only the Ebon Fulcrum Lens in the Empty Vault at Gauntlight’s base, deeming the essence within one fulcrum lens a minimal risk. She gave the other lenses to trusted groups in the lower Abomination Vaults: the emerald lens to the urdefhans, the ochre lens to the drow, and the crimson lens hidden where her undead gnome minions could protect it. She trusts that the groups won’t work together, much less learn that bringing the lenses together to imbue a single creature with all four splinters of Nhimbaloth’s essence would impart complete annihilation.

XP Award: Award the characters [[/award 1800xp]] for uncovering the lore of the Fulcrum Lenses and learning how to destroy Belcorra.

Other Books

The rest of the books are all aging tomes full of occult knowledge; they’ve been in the Haruvex family for generations. They hold a wealth of occult lore about ghosts, Nhimbaloth, and the Haruvexes. A character who peruses these tomes during downtime gains a +2 bonus on Intelligence checks to research those subjects.

Treasure

@UUID[Item.RlUOMtYuvoLeTqty]{Vault Contents} @UUID[Compendium.dnd-abomination-vaults.av-items-5e.Item.B4ZOpqh9JMDbktaF]{Fulcrum Lattice}

Belcorra keeps many valuables here, including a skull-shaped key that unlocks the doors to the Gate of Nhimbaloth (area @UUID[JournalEntry.1vlzl3NJsftNB9Dc.JournalEntryPage.0UMcuMR7KSoCWHkz]{I60}) and a signet ring that bears the symbol of a tentacle wrapped around a skull with a moss-filled mouth. It is a Ring of Spell Storing. The Fulcrum Lattice is also here, and it is surprisingly lightweight for its size. If the characters have discovered any Fulcrum Lenses so far, they fit neatly into the lattice, and the lattice grows no heavier for their weight.

Level 9 Portal Chamber.name: Level 9 Portal Chamber
Level 9 Portal Chamber.text:
Teleportation Network

Some of the @UUID[Compendium.dnd5e.spells24.Item.phbsplTeleportat]{Teleportation Circles} within the Abomination Vaults form a part of a larger network. By tracing specific patterns on the wall runes, someone could transport everyone in any one of these chambers to one of nine other portal chambers in the Abomination Vaults- so long as the teleportation circles in both the departure chamber and destination have been awakened by the @UUID[Compendium.dnd-abomination-vaults.av-items-5e.Item.H0KYIrtDeeV2pSyC]{Awaken Portal} ritual (area @UUID[JournalEntry.KeWKr2yd8dbppeS5.JournalEntryPage.8X4xF40k06MW0X7q]{C35}).

The nine chambers are areas @UUID[JournalEntry.uMZ0RiCcPSqsx1Nm.JournalEntryPage.537bzfVUpq6XbR9a]{B17}, @UUID[JournalEntry.KeWKr2yd8dbppeS5.JournalEntryPage.vEiow4kU961XNOJp]{C16}, @UUID[JournalEntry.Os5bHdzCDiXgJBQ6.JournalEntryPage.RJf3BCpcVW6d68s7]{D05}, @UUID[JournalEntry.JT0zCcIwsSpKnbB5.JournalEntryPage.LJhOoRqYjj38YWl8]{E18}, @UUID[JournalEntry.KI33EAGPVHP4zyFZ.JournalEntryPage.mDFVGUXY6YDuQWF3]{F13}, @UUID[JournalEntry.OyNcqrpRClyhr8BJ.JournalEntryPage.zTpatmyyb4JvgNCo]{G02}, @UUID[JournalEntry.FwWmtOBFHhvM2gtf.JournalEntryPage.Nak2hUmVOHXBkcR5]{H33}, @UUID[JournalEntry.1vlzl3NJsftNB9Dc.JournalEntryPage.DJKWR2KLTPUi3w6T]{I59}, and @UUID[JournalEntry.yn21bNM6kpV4xRol.JournalEntryPage.JinYTJeYVFBE1uky]{J05}

Spiraling runes filled with silver cover this chamber’s curved walls. Silvery metal also covers the floor and ceiling.

This room contains another inactive Teleportation Circle that the characters might connect to others in the Abomination Vaults with the Awaken Portal ritual.

XP Award: Award the characters [[/award 500xp]] for using the Awaken Portal spell to reactivate the Teleportation Circle here.

Ebon Doors.name: Ebon Doors
Ebon Doors.text:
This massive double door is made of black and green stone. An oxidized bronze lock at the center has a single keyhole but no handles.

This door leads to a structure called the Gate of Nhimbaloth, an ancient temple made of black stone streaked with a greenish, nauseating hue. Belcorra didn’t build this place; she found it and incorporated it into her ever-expanding dungeon. Whether the Gate of Nhimbaloth always existed underground or was once cast down from the surface is a mystery, as are the cultists who once inhabited it. In any case, its entry is now seamless with the stone of the Abomination Vaults. The Gate of Nhimbaloth includes not only the rooms beyond this door, but most of the lower level as well.

The ancient lock on the door is incredibly complex. A successful [[/check dex thief dc=26]] check is required to pick the lock, and it can’t be forced open. The skull-shaped key in area @UUID[JournalEntry.1vlzl3NJsftNB9Dc.JournalEntryPage.ydFyUm2uTgteYviW]{I58} opens this door.

Hall of Priests.name: Hall of Priests
Hall of Priests.text:
This large chamber is made of the same black stone as the imposing ebon doors to the north. Eight alcoves, four on each side, line the east and west walls. Each alcove contains the remains of jade-colored statues. All of the figures have been defiled; none have any heads remaining, most are missing hands, and one is just a pair of bare feet upon a pedestal. An enormous stone throne carved to resemble swamp reeds and swirling mist stands in a domed chamber opposite the black doors.

Well before Belcorra’s time, this served as a semipublic area of worship for a cult of Nhimbaloth. Those seeking vengeance, an enemy’s obliteration, or assurance that a lost loved one would return as a ghost left offerings and sacrifices around the throne and the creature sitting on it, who was called Lady’s Whisper— the creature that sits there still. Aspirants hoped the shrouded skeleton would rise and lead them through one of the three doorways to take the tests to become an initiate in the cult. Lady’s Whisper sometimes remained still for years, or ushered in new cultists for days on end. Although even the senior cultists never understood the connection between Lady’s Whisper and Nhimbaloth, none questioned the skeleton’s role as gateway to cult membership.

The cult did know, however, that only those Lady’s Whisper ushered into the eastern door would join the cult. The western doors lead to grim fates reserved for those unworthy to even be tested for admittance to the cult.

Encounter

@UUID[Actor.dWOK0nzGWyc5NkNz]{Lady's Whisper}

The skeletal Lady’s Whisper rises and holds forth both hands, gesturing for peace. They then point to the western door and whisper the names of each character, one by one. If given a chance, they step to the door, gesturing for the characters to follow.

If the characters attack, Lady’s Whisper lashes out with their claws to teleport characters away, preferably into adjacent chambers with dangerous wisps and traps. The undead guardian flees if they take more than 50 damage, but they try to lure the characters deeper into the Gate of Nhimbaloth as they do.

Treasure: One of the statues loosely holds a @UUID[Compendium.dnd-abomination-vaults.av-items-5e.Item.IOkTpCymE92GViuG]{War Flail} that can be easily drawn free. As the flail is imbued with Nhimbaloth’s essence, it deals Force damage to creatures in the Gate of Nhimbaloth. Outside the Gate of Nhimbaloth, it loses this property.

Oblivion Fall.name: Oblivion Fall
Oblivion Fall.text:
Made of the same dark stone as the rest of the temple, this passage opens into a rectangular chamber.

The chamber at the end of the hall has no floor. It’s a bottomless pit that has no trapdoor; nevertheless, because it’s set into reflective black stone, it’s still difficult to notice. Lady’s Whisper led aspirants whom she judged to be useless to Nhimbaloth’s cause into this pit—forcefully, when necessary.

Bottomless Pit

Hazard

An infinitely deep pit is set seamlessly into the black stone.

A creature that makes a successful [[/check skill=perception dc=16]] check notices that the floor in the room is absent, opening into a pit filled with a black void. A spell or effect that can sense the presence of magic reveals an aura of Conjuration magic on the floor.

When a creature steps into the pit, they fall, potentially forever. A creature can use its Reaction to grab on to the edge by making a successful [[/save dexterity dc=16]] saving throw. Since the lip of the pit repeats over and over again within the pit, a falling creature can try to escape again every round, but once the creature grabs an edge lower in the pit, it must climb out—generally at least 400 feet per round that they fell. Nothing prevents a falling creature from resting or even preparing spells in midair, although any items dropped are generally lost until the pit is destroyed.

The magic defining the lip of the pit can be ended with a successful @UUID[Compendium.dnd5e.spells24.Item.phbsplDispelMagi]{Dispel Magic} spell (DC 15), which causes anything in the pit to spill across the ground. A falling creature doesn’t slow down, so it takes [[/damage 20d6 bludgeoning average]] damage from the impact. A dozen skeletons from rejected supplicants are all that was falling before the characters arrived, and they scatter to dust if the pit is destroyed.

Garden of Failures.name: Garden of Failures
Garden of Failures.text:
A black-stoned passage opens into this octagonal chamber. The room is a riot of foul-smelling swamp weeds.

Creatures who made it into the Gate of Nhimbaloth but were, in their hearts, too afraid to undertake the initiation tests below were brought here. Often, Lady’s Whisper gave them comforting words about how they could simply rest and depart in peace, but this was a lie—creatures were brought here to be killed, their blood and essence used to fuel the sunless garden.

Encounter

@UUID[Actor.2TOXR7nKS6xPng2Y]{Dread Wisp}

A single Dread Wisp floats in this room. It attacks anyone who enters, desperate to feed for the first time in many years. It’s bound to this room and can’t leave.

Initiates’ Chamber.name: Initiates’ Chamber
Initiates’ Chamber.text:
The walls of this room are carved from black stone and feature four large alcoves, two to the east and two to the west. Three contain large, stone basins filled with reeds, moss, and other swamp plants. The basin in the fourth alcove is empty. Stairs lead downward to the north.

The stairs lead down to area @UUID[JournalEntry.yn21bNM6kpV4xRol.JournalEntryPage.GZNjyAZgRDgPx68z]{J1}.

Encounter

@UUID[Actor.wRQ7TZdd0n5UIIao]{Will-o'-Wisps (3)}

Three Will-o’-Wisps hover over three of the stone basins (the fourth was slain long ago, and its basin now contains only desiccated soil). If the characters are accompanied by Lady’s Whisper, the wisps simply hover in place and don’t trouble the characters, although two of them follow Lady’s Whisper and the characters at a distance when they depart, ready to intervene if the characters become violent.

If the characters aren’t with Lady’s Whisper, the wisps attack. If they can, they herd foes to the staircase to the north, hoping to drive them down into the Temple level where more powerful creatures await.

Introduction.name: Introduction
Introduction.text:
Chapter Synopsis

The Hunting Grounds contain aggressive urdefhans, insular drow, and some of the most powerful monsters the characters face in this dungeon. It’s key for the characters to learn about the @UUID[JournalEntry.67686KaEPc6XAlKJ.JournalEntryPage.azMqL6C2NvazTcRE]{Fulcrum Lenses}, such as from the drow leader Quara.

The Hunting Grounds

As any explorer of the Darklands can tell you, the farther you descend, the wilder and stranger things become. As Belcorra dug the Abomination Vaults, she found an extensive system of caverns. Unlike the self- contained Farm level, these caverns were truly wild. At first, she fought against the fierce denizens and tried to close off the passages to deeper places, but the task was futile. She dubbed the place the Hunting Grounds and left it mostly alone, save for building alliances with the communities there. Belcorra established only a few strongholds in the area, including a lodge, a vault, and the entrance to the Gate of Nhimbaloth, the subterranean temple holding the Empty Vault.

Environmental Cues:

Creeping mold, echoing roars, patches of slick slime, rough stone walls, strange tracks

Features

The interconnecting caverns in the Hunting Grounds are mostly dark, but patches of glowing fungus illuminate enough areas to give anyone a sense of the caverns’ great size. Ceiling height varies widely: large caverns are 40 feet high, smaller caverns are 20 feet high, and the several areas of stone worked for humanoid habitation— such as Yldaris, the calignis’ lodge, and Gate of Nhimbaloth—are 12 feet high. Doors in most areas are made of stone or sturdy fungal wood, with entrances to inhabited areas often being thicker or otherwise reinforced for defense.

Factions of the Hunting Grounds.name: Factions of the Hunting Grounds
Factions of the Hunting Grounds.text:
The Urdefhan Cult

Urdefhans are vampire-like humanoids who largely pursue lives of violence and slaughter. As brutal killers obsessed with ending life and existence itself, the urdefhans who regularly emerged from their caves to raid the caverns and lake of the Hunting Grounds were precisely the kind of soldiers Belcorra needed for her campaign. She made a calculated, overwhelming attack to awe the urdefhans, and when the sorcerer called for a parley, the urdefhan war champion listened. Belcorra swore the urdefhans would be the vanguard of her eventual assault on the surface and gave the Emerald Fulcrum Lens to the war champion as a token of her favor until then. Generations passed, and the war champions passed down the Fulcrum Lens as their symbol of leadership.

Drow Allegiance

With the deep gnomes cowed and the urdefhans awed by her power, Belcorra next turned to the drow of Hunting Grounds. From their secure stronghold of Yldaris, the drow ranged through the caverns like deadly apparitions, retreating in the face of significant danger. Belcorra knew that she must trap the drow into an alliance, so she captured more and more of their hunters until Yldaris’s leader agreed to meet with her. She traded the captives for a promise that the drow would keep the Ochre Fulcrum Lens safe and provide aid in her attack on the surface. The granddaughter of that leader is in command of Yldaris today.

Belcorra’s Return

When Belcorra arose as a ghost, she first visited the Hunting Grounds. She checked on her treasure vault to ensure its most important contents remained secure, then sent the vault’s graveknight guardian to retrieve the valuable books she’d left on an upper level when she died. She next visited the urdefhans, who still told vague legends of the quasi-mythical sorcerer. Their new war champion, Khurfel, carried the Emerald Fulcrum Lens and agreed to follow their Ghost Queen to raze the surface world. The urdefhans have since stepped up their summoning of daemon allies, preparing for the assault on the surface.

Belcorra’s visit to the drow of Yldaris went less well. Quara Orshendiel, the granddaughter of the leader from whom Belcorra extracted a promise to serve, had little idea who Belcorra was. Belcorra nevertheless accepted Quara’s hastily given (and not entirely genuine) renewal of her grandfather’s promise.

Attacking the Drow

If the characters unwisely attack, the drow call for backup. The noise warns Quara to retreat to area @UUID[JournalEntry.1vlzl3NJsftNB9Dc.JournalEntryPage.sOpC75joa7ldQh6s]{I15}, where she plans to make a stand with the wardens there. She attempts to talk down the characters should they confront her. Quara sees the usefulness in the characters even if they are belligerent, and orders her drow to capture them alive for questioning (and potentially serving her interests under terms she dictates).

A Cavern Vast.name: A Cavern Vast
A Cavern Vast.text:
Most of the Hunting Grounds is a wilderness of rock formations, crystal growths, mineral springs, and vast swaths of towering fungi. The creatures dwelling here have plenty of room to hunt and feed, and they aren’t always found in their respective encounter areas. Every 15 minutes the characters spend traversing the cavern, roll a d20. On a 6 or higher, the characters come across one of the following random encounters. If the result would be a creature from an encounter the party has already faced, treat it as no encounter.

[[/gmroll 1d12]]

Encounter

1

A single escaped @UUID[Actor.QRjjE4TJNfaDhhQC]{riding lizard} from area @UUID[JournalEntry.1vlzl3NJsftNB9Dc.JournalEntryPage.2cFmSYlOwwY8on21]{I30}

2

@UUID[Actor.bif3iQcDPi27rx6x]{Salaisa Malthulas} from area @UUID[JournalEntry.1vlzl3NJsftNB9Dc.JournalEntryPage.G6wHEAz23uGrMSdy]{I14} and [[/r 1d4]] wardens from area @UUID[JournalEntry.1vlzl3NJsftNB9Dc.JournalEntryPage.iCO37ywz53IDWfVH]{I12}

3-4

Two @UUID[Actor.rArZ2y5xqSWeUU0G]{drow shootists} from area @UUID[JournalEntry.1vlzl3NJsftNB9Dc.JournalEntryPage.hrtuHLKfA1LGeODQ]{I10}

5

Two @UUID[Actor.gWxpeqOQ54Jd4HTG]{caligni hunters} from area @UUID[JournalEntry.1vlzl3NJsftNB9Dc.JournalEntryPage.8iE1bRgAOvwLTzmw]{I23}

6-7

Urdefhan warband: two @UUID[Actor.tZCFmJonHkhGg1Vs]{death scouts} and two @UUID[Actor.Sbxt8YT0AOFfVCPX]{lashers} from area @UUID[JournalEntry.1vlzl3NJsftNB9Dc.JournalEntryPage.rnPlOrzXgNElSkPN]{I34}

8-9

Urdefhans and daemons: four @UUID[Actor.e5yE4RkwLQojRYHm]{warriors} and two @UUID[Actor.NW1Ax1QGE9W4DmiN]{ceustodaemons} from area @UUID[JournalEntry.1vlzl3NJsftNB9Dc.JournalEntryPage.rnPlOrzXgNElSkPN]{I34}

10

Sacrifice seekers: one @UUID[Actor.OTT7CCkonkfwhJ8Y]{blood mage} and three @UUID[Actor.FJr7Rc9MQEwxjAcz]{cult fanatics} from area @UUID[JournalEntry.1vlzl3NJsftNB9Dc.JournalEntryPage.6P5Lw4eeNrBQKv9O]{I35}

11

The @UUID[Actor.FHfrIJCdKTzy2rrR]{cauthooj} from area @UUID[JournalEntry.1vlzl3NJsftNB9Dc.JournalEntryPage.zRyrXydUmCGSSpzo]{I41}, which returns to its nest after 2 rounds

12

@UUID[Actor.irrXrWxJ0LYSUCQB]{Ravirex} from area @UUID[JournalEntry.1vlzl3NJsftNB9Dc.JournalEntryPage.cwYDvlHWV3sCAa1r]{I51}

Roll Tables

@RollTable[kdLt3tL3kPhFOl5Y]{Hunting Grounds Encounters}

You can choose one of the encounters from the list above, or you can determine the outcome randomly using the included rolltable. If the result is a creature the heroes have already faced, treat it as no encounter.

If you'd like the roll's result to be hidden, make sure to change your roll mode first in the dropdown menu above your chat box!

Befriending the Drow.name: Befriending the Drow
Befriending the Drow.text:
If the characters have dealt peacefully with the drow and earned an audience with Quara, wary drow escort them here and ask them to wait for Quara to arrive. Various residents bring in chairs from the common area (area @UUID[.sOpC75joa7ldQh6s]{I15}) and food and fungus wine from the kitchen (area @UUID[.o1v9itp6Cep45ZOE]{I16}). The drow escorts are curious and talkative, as they have little experience with surface-dwellers, but they diplomatically avoid conversation that would color their questions as an interrogation—that’s Quara’s prerogative. If the heroes are reticent or rude, the drow simply watch over them in silence.

Before long, Quara arrives to great the characters, radiating calm command and curiosity. She’s joined by the stern-looking Salaisa Malthulas, commander of the outpost’s wardens, and the strange twin cavern seers, Bhazrade and Klathor. Quara does the talking.

“You have the look of surface dwellers. I’ve never met any of your kind, but I’ve seen artwork. Strange, you are not nearly as ugly as our art makes you out to be. I am Quara Orshendiel, leader of this outpost. Let’s figure out whether or not we can help each another.”

If the characters rescued Falxi, Quara adds her thanks for rescuing her cousin from “one of the scrapes he keeps getting himself into.”

Quara is sincere in her words and her goals. The seers had already foretold that surface dwellers would come as potential allies, and Quara wants to believe it.

Quara invites the characters to tell their story. She sympathizes with hardships, laughs at humorous parts, and asks questions when she doesn’t understand something. If the characters mention the Fulcrum Lenses, or show her one of them, she takes an obvious interest. Quara overlooks petty slights or rudeness, but she chastises any overt aggression calmly—once. Her patience is not infinite, and insistently rude characters are asked to leave Yldaris and not return.

At the end of the conversation, Quara says, “You’ve given me some things to think about. Thank you.” She then invites the characters to stay in the overflow lodging (area I13) until she makes up her mind about them. Quara spends a few hours thinking, then gambles on an alliance.

She calls the characters back into this room, either a few hours later or the next time they return to Yldaris. Bhazrade and Klathor are, as before, lurking at the edges of the room. Quara explains the following.

“I believe you’ve been truthful with me, so I’m going to be truthful with you. Yldaris only exists at Belcorra’s pleasure. It was here when she first created her vast dungeons; at the time, my grandfather was its leader. Belcorra made allies of several groups, including ourselves, the urdefhans to the west, and a group of deep gnomes above, who have embraced undeath. To each, she gave a magical lens of strange powers. For safekeeping, I believe. Ours was the Ochre Fulcrum Lens, and it could manipulate emotions.
“But there was more to the lens. My grandfather told my father, Larathols, who became Yldaris’s leader after him. But my father never told me.” Quara sighs. “I was never meant to lead. My older sister was to succeed our father. They both embarked on a secret expedition a few years ago. On an island in the great lake, the urdefhan warlord Khurfel caught and killed them. Their expedition had something to do with the lens, I believe, and I suspect my father had it with him. Perhaps he hid it someplace; perhaps Khurfel took it. I don’t know.
“Belcorra came to me as a ghost shortly afterward. She insisted I swear Yldaris’s support and aid in a surface invasion that drives her even in death. For the good of Yldaris, I renewed the vows my grandfather made. But I’ve never felt bound my mere words. I won’t help her. I’ll help you. You are welcome in Yldaris as long as you’d like.”

The characters can ask Quara more questions if they’d like, but she knows little more than she’s already told them. Before the conversation winds down, however, Bhazrade and Klathor speak.

“There is more…” One of the twins starts. They move their mouths in unison, making it hard to tell which is speaking.
“…you should know.” The other drow continues.
This plainly piques Quara’s interest, and she motions for the brothers to go on.
“The ochre lens lies in a dark and wet place. Khurfel did not claim it. Larathols dropped it in the water to deny it to his enemy. He died attempting to learn more of its purpose, more than the partial truth we know.
“We have seen in a vision that the stones both empower the Ghost Queen and hold the key to her demise. They are slivers of something ancient, alien, evil, and hungry.”
In unison, they cry, “We saw eyes of Empty Death!”
They continue. “She separated the lenses because, together, they draw the baleful attention of the Empty Death. Even the Ghost Queen cannot withstand the Empty Death. The secrets to the lenses are in the old treasure vault, which overlooks the lake.
“Find the lenses and the answers Larathols sought.”

The twins fall silent again, and Quara looks back to the characters. She explains, “I would say you get used to Bhazrade and Klathor, but one never does. Let me assure you that when they do speak, it’s important. This is all news to me, but when the cavern seers speak, it’s to the benefit of Yldaris. Perhaps to yours as well.”

XP Award: Award the characters [[/award 9000xp]] for allying with Quara and the Yldaris drow rather than fighting them.

Consulting The Whispering Reeds

The characters might have recovered a book of Nhimbaloth’s lore called The Whispering Reeds from higher in the Abomination Vaults. A character who consults this tome finds references to the @UUID[JournalEntry.jy8D1VcANmdjWuci.JournalEntryPage.7YxJpSUob5bGyOcE]{Fulcrum Lenses} automatically and without suffering from the book’s curse. The Whispering Reeds speaks of slivers of Nhimbaloth’s essence existing in the Fulcrum Lenses, perhaps as a means to contact the Outer God. The Fulcrum Lenses have different and powerful (but, in the text, unspecified) abilities. Yet the Fulcrum Lenses are dangerous in close proximity, and even Nhimbaloth’s worshippers fear to have more than two or three together at one time. Using their powers draws Nhimbaloth’s scrutiny and, ultimately, invites utter annihilation.

Side Quest

Finding the Fulcrum Lenses and using them against Belcorra is the primary task of this adventure. But Quara has a side task that’s personally important to her: she’d like Khurfel killed and his rhoka sword brought to her as a trophy. As pragmatic as Quara is, vengeance is a common drow vice. She emphasizes to the characters that Khurfel would never part with his lens while he draws breath, so defeating him is necessary in any case.

XP Award: Award the characters [[/award 1800xp]] if they bring Khurfel’s sword to Quara.

Overgrown Stairs.name: Overgrown Stairs
Overgrown Stairs.text:
The smell of rot and mildew pervades the air of this enclosed staircase. At the base, a moist carpet of fungus, slime, and mold grows thickly on the walls.

Exploration

The western wall of the passage contains a secret door leading into Gauntlight’s footprint (area @UUID[JournalEntry.FwWmtOBFHhvM2gtf.JournalEntryPage.rVwX8eSwEBHWEjcg]{H37}) that is magically locked and can’t be broken open. A character spots the door’s faint outline with a successful [[/check skill=perception dc=11]] check. It has a concave indentation, and it only opens when touched with a Fulcrum Lens.

Hall of Eyes.name: Hall of Eyes
Hall of Eyes.text:
Six alcoves line the walls, three to the north and three to the south. The four easternmost alcoves each contain a large stone planter filled with muddy water that reeks like a dismal swamp. Two scorch marks on the ground near the eastern door surround a pile of dark rags. The pommel of a blade peeks out from underneath one of the rag piles.

The basins are magically connected to the eldritch swamp in the Temple level far below (area @UUID[JournalEntry.yn21bNM6kpV4xRol.JournalEntryPage.1Ov1191GpaTDBaAE]{J15}). They remain filled with the swamp’s waters, and the will-o’-wisps here can use the basins to transmit images directly to Belcorra. Spells such as Detect Magic reveal an aura of Divination around the basins.

The scorch marks and rags are the remains of two calignis who ran afoul of this room’s denizens.

Encounter

@UUID[Actor.wRQ7TZdd0n5UIIao]{Will-o'-Wisps (4)}

Four Will-o’-Wisps wait here for Belcorra’s orders, one hovering over each basin and appearing, at first, to be merely decorative lights. They telepathically report on the characters’ actions until they’re attacked or until the characters try to leave this chamber. At that point, the will-o’-wisps spring into action and fight until destroyed. A character can recognize the wisps for what they are with a successful [[/check skill=investigation/religion dc=12]] check.

Once the wisps are revealed to be creatures, simply run the @Macro[C3op8ZzoCDxheaO0]{H02 - Wisp Reveal} macro to make them visible, while hiding the scene's ambient lights.

Belcorra should attack the characters (see @UUID[JournalEntry.FwWmtOBFHhvM2gtf.JournalEntryPage.em5wJ44hCXP8mGGG]{Belcorra Attacks}) sometime shortly after this encounter.

Treasure

@UUID[Item.WLLJXJVaC7M6mpBj]{+1 Shortsword}

One of rag piles has a +1 Shortsword in it. The other has a bag containing 24 GP.

Hazy Shrine.name: Hazy Shrine
Hazy Shrine.text:
An unusual scent, as of burning fungus, is apparent to anyone approaching any of the doors to this chamber.

A haze of smoke with a pungent but not entirely unpleasant scent emanates from a large copper cauldron atop a bed of coals on a dais to the east. A metal rack over the basin holds several brown and purple eggs, each about the size of a human head, cooking in the smoke. The walls are painted with sweeping lines and whorls.

Belcorra crafted these chambers centuries ago as both a shrine to Nhimbaloth and as a base to study the strange visionary effects of the island caves (area @UUID[JournalEntry.FwWmtOBFHhvM2gtf.JournalEntryPage.f02YPQGkiBbZ0Ijt]{H12}). Calignis of the @UUID[JournalEntry.FwWmtOBFHhvM2gtf.JournalEntryPage.E91vlj3metWEl6BC]{Cult of Urthagul} now use this room for prayer and meditation, and to cook the chuul eggs they harvest from the lake. The ones being cooked now are the last of the cult’s current store.

Encounter

@UUID[Actor.gWxpeqOQ54Jd4HTG]{Caligni Creepers (6)}

Half a dozen Caligni Creepers of the Cult of Urthagul meditate here. When their devotions are disturbed, they rise to attack. They believe their death flares empower Urthagul, so they fight tenaciously to the death.

Exploration

A secret door to the lodge on the lower level is hidden amid the abstract patterns painted on the west wall. The calignis know about the secret door, but they’re reluctant to reveal its presence. A character who searches this room finds the door and the hidden knob to open it with a successful [[/check skill=investigation dc=16]] check. The door’s other side has an obvious latch mechanism; it’s not secret from that side.

Storage.name: Storage
Storage.text:
This square chamber is filled with a jumble of open boxes, casks, bundles of torches, and faintly glowing plants.

This storage chamber is a mess because calignis have haphazardly thrown supplies in here over the years. The plants are bioluminescent reeds that retain their glow for several weeks after being harvested, and they provide dim light in this room. Most of the casks contain meaty, dried mushrooms calignis favor, although their gritty and earthy taste makes them practically inedible to other creatures.

Treasure

@Item[GHomhFNgseTb75OX]{Beautiful Amethysts}

A character who searches through the casks of mushrooms in this room and makes a successful [[/check skill=perception dc=12]] check uncovers a small wooden case containing three beautiful amethysts worth [[/award 200gp]] each.

Cult Barracks.name: Cult Barracks
Cult Barracks.text:
This drab chamber contains a few bedrolls and a box with several earthen mugs atop it. A desk holds stacks paper.

Rank-and-file members of the Cult of Urthagul all sleep in the eight bedrolls here. Some are mapping the Abomination Vaults, in the hopes of finding an easy way around the wisps to reach Urthagul again. This map is on the desk. They’ve mapped out areas @UUID[JournalEntry.FwWmtOBFHhvM2gtf.JournalEntryPage.0EtecMBSYJDok7n7]{H2} to @UUID[JournalEntry.FwWmtOBFHhvM2gtf.JournalEntryPage.FAKz5eIbbUUifBrV]{H14}, and drawn several lobster-like shapes in the water between areas @UUID[JournalEntry.FwWmtOBFHhvM2gtf.JournalEntryPage.cm5dvw5Lw46nAhBe]{H13} and @UUID[JournalEntry.FwWmtOBFHhvM2gtf.JournalEntryPage.FAKz5eIbbUUifBrV]{H14} to represent the chuuls. Several angry ball-like shapes in areas @UUID[JournalEntry.FwWmtOBFHhvM2gtf.JournalEntryPage.0EtecMBSYJDok7n7]{H2} and @UUID[JournalEntry.FwWmtOBFHhvM2gtf.JournalEntryPage.tXdibKRkxLO9wGnz]{H10} represent the new wisps. They’ve also mapped out @UUID[JournalEntry.1vlzl3NJsftNB9Dc.JournalEntryPage.g1OFd8Mt0UAghDjX]{I22} to @UUID[JournalEntry.1vlzl3NJsftNB9Dc.JournalEntryPage.eR8zzQKxdR0jU0zH]{I26} and the connecting staircase. They aren’t aware of the secret door in area @UUID[JournalEntry.FwWmtOBFHhvM2gtf.JournalEntryPage.LyqYciAwy0l9vyed]{H8}, so it isn’t noted.

Padli’s Chamber.name: Padli’s Chamber
Padli’s Chamber.text:
This room is a jumble of pillows, furs, blankets, and rugs. Several empty and stoppered jugs litter the floor.

While Dulac is studious and intense, her second-in-command Padli is a selfish, gregarious hedonist. He favors mushroom wine, and the jugs around this room once held this earthy, intoxicating beverage.

Encounter

@UUID[Actor.qw2pk1zjvgxbeGBO]{Padli}, @UUID[Actor.gWxpeqOQ54Jd4HTG]{Caligni Creepers (2)}

For all his hedonism, Padli is no less devout than Dulac, and he sees any intrusion here as an assault on the faithful. Padli is a Caligni Priest. He and his two Caligni Creeper companions deal with any interruption violently. Padli lets his companions take the brunt of melee attacks and hangs back to cast spells. The calignis here have no interest in parley or quarter.

Treasure: Padli carries the key to area @UUID[JournalEntry.FwWmtOBFHhvM2gtf.JournalEntryPage.xPn64Lh3sQATKcYS]{H7} on his belt. Each creeper carries [[/award 4d10gp]]; Padli carries [[/award 40pp 10gp]]. Amid the comforts of the room is a @UUID[Item.2w4Hoa1X9K0LFlkh]{small pouch} with [[/award 10pp]] and [[/award 25gp]]. A small ceramic flask contains a Potion of Clairvoyance.

Prison.name: Prison
Prison.text:
This room is locked from the outside; Padli has the only key. A character can open it with a successful [[/check dex thief dc=23]], or a successful [[/check ability=strength dc=25]] check to force it open.

A single prisoner waits inside: an Urdefhan Death Scout named Huglu, whom the calignis captured a few weeks ago. They’ve denied him food and water to get information out of him, but the stubborn warrior would rather die than tell his captors anything. He’s currently pretending to be dead to catch his captors off-guard, but characters who succeed on a [[/check skill=insight/medicine/investigation dc=11]] check see through his ruse.

Getting any information out of Huglu is virtually impossible, as the evil warrior’s only desire is to inflict as much death and destruction as he can before oblivion. Attempts using Charisma (Persuasion) to improve Huglu’s Hostile attitude don’t work, though the characters might get information out of him with a [[/check skill=deception dc=11]] check to lie or a [[/check skill=intimidation dc=12]] check. On a success, Huglu relays his name, that he was caught near the door in area @UUID[JournalEntry.FwWmtOBFHhvM2gtf.JournalEntryPage.SXr3Fbi3jae09RT1]{H9}, that he serves a great war champion named Khurfel, and that his people control great swaths of territory at the bottom of a nearby chasm (area @UUID[JournalEntry.FwWmtOBFHhvM2gtf.JournalEntryPage.0DvO7vVIbYZAhm3R]{H34}). He sprinkles this information with threats against the characters and promises to drink their blood. If the characters free Huglu, he turns on them as soon as he thinks he can kill one of them before being killed himself.

XP Award: Award the characters [[/award 800xp]] for getting information about the urdefhans on the Hunting Grounds level from Huglu.

Dulac’s Chambers.name: Dulac’s Chambers
Dulac’s Chambers.text:
This sparsely appointed chamber contains a single mat in the far corner of the room and a small desk on the south wall with an iron strongbox sitting under it. A bowl with some gray gruel and a spoon are the only items on the desk.

This chamber serves as quarters for a severe caligni woman named Dulac, the head of the Cult of Urthagul. She refuses to be acknowledged with any reverence or title beyond that of “custodian,” to demonstrate her humble subservience to Urthagul. Once a very active and vital leader, Dulac drew the attention of wraith with a penchant for manipulating caligni communities from the shadows. The wraith spends his time in the secret chamber off this room, learning what he can of the cult and deciding how to twist the cult’s beliefs to his own ends. For now, all he’s done is make Dulac a more reclusive and despondent woman, which has allowed the hedonistic Padli time to indulge in his vices more frequently and more openly.

Dulac’s control and self-confidence took a severe blow when Belcorra stationed the will-o’-wisps around the cultists’ domain. Cut off from Urthagul’s bizarre babblings and eldritch insights, Dulac isn’t sure what to do now. The wraith offers vague assurances, but he secretly enjoys seeing the cult crumble and works against any plan that might succeed in restoring contact with Urthagul.

Encounter

@UUID[Actor.h0Ztbh36be4rpJCz]{Dulac}, @UUID[Actor.JkJRKxuIGJ3DOD9L]{Wraith}

When the characters arrive, they find Dulac and the Wraith here, in close conversation. They fight intruders, but if the characters give any indication that they’re willing to talk, Dulac ceases hostilities to hear them out. The wraith presses the attack to silence the characters, even if it must do so alone.

If the wraith is defeated and Dulac is reduced to fewer than 30 Hit Points, she surrenders.

Exploration

A character who searches this room and succeeds on a [[/check skill=investigation dc=16]] check discovers the secret door in the east wall, as well as the hidden latch that must be pulled and turned to open it. Other than Dulac’s sparse furnishings, the room is empty— the wraith needs no comforts, only solitude.

Side Quest

If the characters parlay with Dulac, she proposes a deal. If the characters gather more chuul eggs and eliminate the wisps on the fringes of the cult’s territory, Dulac will make them formal allies of the cult. As allies, they can rest in the shrine whenever they’d like. Further, she can grant them safe passage through caligni territory in the lodge on the level below. She warns that the diligent caligni defenders on the lower level aren’t likely to speak with the characters without Dulac’s good word, so helping out Dulac—and thus the cult—is in their best interests.

XP Award: In addition to [[/award 1600xp]] for completing this side quest, award the characters XP for interacting peacefully with Dulac as though they had defeated her in combat.

Treasure

@UUID[Item.1TTwpligP2VZbKY4]{Iron Strongbox}

Dulac carries a @UUID[Compendium.dnd-abomination-vaults.av-items-5e.Item.IOkTpCymE92GViuG]{War Flail}. The iron strongbox contains a pouch of [[/award 130gp 250sp]] mixed together and another pouch holding six large pieces of onyx, each worth [[/award 150gp]]. Carefully wrapped in parchment are three Potions of Greater Healing and a Potion of Heroism.

Barricaded Door.name: Barricaded Door
Barricaded Door.text: This stout, iron-bound door swings open to the north. It used to be barred from the north, but after Huglu sneaked in, the calignis blocked the southern side with rubble for additional security. Moving the rubble to open the door is time-consuming, but not difficult.

Stairs of Urthagul.name: Stairs of Urthagul
Stairs of Urthagul.text:
This long chamber features roughly carved stairs leading upward. Its sides are dotted with nooks, two of which contain stone basins filled with muddy water.

The basins are similar to and serve the same purpose as those in the @UUID[JournalEntry.FwWmtOBFHhvM2gtf.JournalEntryPage.0EtecMBSYJDok7n7]{Hall of Eyes}.

When Belcorra learned that calignis were meeting with Urthagul, she sent a pair of dread wisps here to prevent the calignis’ passage. She doesn’t want the Crimson Fulcrum Lens to fall into caligni hands, as she sees them as less reliable guardians than the gug.

Encounter

@UUID[Actor.2TOXR7nKS6xPng2Y]{Dread Wisps (2)}

The two Dread Wisps attack any creatures other than Belcorra and any Children of Belcorra who attempt to pass. If the characters have not yet encountered Belcorra in or near the Hall of Eyes, the defeat of the dread wisps triggers the “@UUID[JournalEntry.FwWmtOBFHhvM2gtf.JournalEntryPage.em5wJ44hCXP8mGGG]{Belcorra Attacks!}” event.

Carrion Ambush.name: Carrion Ambush
Carrion Ambush.text:
Even before the characters enter this chamber, they can smell a putrid stench of carrion and decay that wafts from it.

This large, smelly cave opens up to a cliff with a large body of murky water about 20 feet below. A heap of reeking, decomposing carrion sits at the edge of the cliff. A stream of water flows from the north, past the heap, and over the edge in a narrow waterfall.

The pile of carrion was once an enormous aquatic reptile that scaled the cliff to escape the predatory chuuls but died here. Its rotting mass hides a group of Children of Belcorra who wait underneath to gain information about—and hopefully capture—Urthagul. They plan to either follow Urthagul if the gug passes this way (which they don’t realize the gug never does) or capture and interrogate calignis (which they don’t realize Belcorra has prevented).

Encounter

@UUID[Actor.vHei0y2PKlXfxQ8Z]{Children of Belcorra (4)}

Two Children of Belcorra are hiding in the carrion. They’re getting restless after several days of inactivity so they attack anyone who comes near the carrion pile. Both of the hideous bog mummies fight until destroyed.

Island Cavern.name: Island Cavern
Island Cavern.text:
Four small streams flow through this chamber, fed by a dark pond against the west wall. The streams divide the chamber into islands, each covered with lichen, mildew, and mushrooms. Bioluminescent fungi and strange motes of light bathe the place in eerie illumination, playing off the water to form odd shapes on the cavern’s walls, like humanoid apparitions gliding through the air. Water flowing along the sides of the islands echoes off the walls in weird ways, like harsh whispers.
“Haruvex has risen. There is nothing you can do,” the overlapping echoes say. The sound is hypnotizing, and strangely calming.

Long-gone cultists used this cavern as a meditation chamber to calm their emotions and clear their minds, but it now echoes with subtle whispers of Nhimbaloth’s alien will. These whispers can be maddening or enlightening, but are usually wholly unintelligible.

The northwestern end of this cavern is a rock wall 10 feet high that leads to a natural bridge 30 feet above the lake. Urthagul used to leave the cavern this way to hunt in the lake every week or two, but hadn’t bothered to do that while the Cult of Urthagul were bringing him offerings.

Distracting Whispers

All creatures are immune to the @UUID[Compendium.dnd5e.content24.JournalEntry.phbAppendixCRule.JournalEntryPage.vLAsIUa0FhZNsyLk]{Charmed} and @UUID[Compendium.dnd5e.content24.JournalEntry.phbAppendixCRule.JournalEntryPage.93uaingTESo8N1qL]{Frightened} conditions while in the cavern, but spending time amid the whispers affects the minds of non-Aberrations. Every minute a creature other than an Aberration spends in the cavern, it must make a [[/save ability=wisdom dc=16]]. On a failed save, the creature’s Wisdom score is reduced by 1d4, to a minimum of 3. The reduction lasts until the creature finishes a Long Rest. The room echoes with a different truth each time a creature’s Wisdom score is reduced by the whispers, as follows:

• First Reduction: “The lenses. She knows the secrets of the lenses. Three are within reach, one very close. Another was lost by Yldaris. The third is held by the blood eaters.”

• Second Reduction: “She keeps them apart while she works her petty vengeance, but the essences shall become one.”

• Third Reduction: “Find the lenses and place their essences together within a host.”

• Fourth Reduction: “Join the essences within Haruvex, and she can fall again. This is a promise of the Empty Death, a promise of empty death.”

The cavern affects Aberrations differently. Instead of suffering a reduction to its Wisdom score, an Aberration that fails its saving throw against the whispers makes Wisdom (Perception) checks with Disadvantage until it finishes a Long Rest. If such creatures stay too long in the cave, they begin involuntarily babbling strange truths that echo in the whispers, which is how Urthagul obtained his reputation as a mystic among the calignis.

Encounter

@UUID[Actor.0jvmec4yJH1ASfRy]{Urthagal}

On the northernmost island, amid a nest of glowing toadstools, lurks Urthagul the Gug. He sits hunched, purring and stroking the Crimson Fulcrum Lens in one of his four hands.
