Urthagul has been here for decades, or perhaps longer. While a formidable creature, his fascination with the whispers and the Crimson Fulcrum Lens have taken a toll. He rarely eats, and does so even less now that the caligni cultists don’t visit him. His glowing treasure commands nearly all of his attention.

When the characters enter, Urthagul takes no more notice other than a glance in their direction. The characters can even explore or pass through the cave without rousing Urthagul’s attention; if they speak to him, he doesn’t respond other than to shift his treasure to the hand farthest from anyone who might try to take it.

If the characters use force against Urthagul or try to touch the Crimson Fulcrum Lens, he attacks with relentless savagery. In combat, he prefers to use his Bite, supplemented with the powers of the lens (to which he has attuned). When Urthagul uses Multiattack, he can make only three Claw attacks instead of four, as he doesn’t let go of the lens even when in a fight. Urthagul fights to the death to protect his treasure, but doesn’t leave this cavern and thus doesn’t pursue foes who flee.

Treasure: Urthagul keeps only the Crimson Fulcrum Lens as treasure.

XP Award: Award the characters [[/award 1600xp]] for recovering the Crimson Fulcrum Lens.

Isolated Cage.name: Isolated Cage
Isolated Cage.text:
This large metal cave stands atop a natural pillar rising 30 feet above the water. The bars have been ripped and bent, and bones lie scattered about the cage’s bottom.

The Children of Belcorra once imprisoned creatures in this cage, though it was hard for them to reach. After Urthagul attacked and ate the creatures within, twice, the deep gnomes realized the cage wasn’t worth the bother and abandoned it.

Rickety Dock.name: Rickety Dock
Rickety Dock.text:
A lone dock, rotten and rickety, juts out from a shelf of rock. It looks long unused, and no vessel is tethered to it.

This dock went unused for many years as the Children of Belcorra withdrew from their duty to maintain this level on Belcorra’s behalf. The dock is still usable, with only the occasional mishap of a collapsing board or splintered mooring. The Cult of Urthagul used to dive for chuul eggs from it, but they haven’t done so since being wracked by the trauma of being cut off from Urthagul.

Encounter

@UUID[Actor.aD76W2uEQhFFUrom]{Chuuls (2)}

A pair of Chuuls hunt here, sometimes together. They prefer to sneak up on their prey, clambering onto the dock near the shore so their victims have nowhere to run except into the water. A chuul reduced to fewer than 20 Hit Points flees and doesn’t return.

Treasure

@UUID[Item.lHkqzOSEO3gQvpOo]{Chuul Nest}

While the chuuls carry nothing of value, characters who search under the water find their hidden nesting nook 15 feet below the surface. This nest holds a cache of six chuul eggs, 90 GP, [[/award 42sp]], and a carved onyx statuette vaguely resembling Belcorra worth [[/award 300gp]].

Fetid Lake.name: Fetid Lake
Fetid Lake.text:
These dark waters may have once been fresh, but are now brackish and silty. Dark clouds of fetid air and grimy mists cling to the surface. Where it laps on the shore, the water leaves trails of glistening muck.

The lake’s water was once potable, fresh, and teaming with schools of subterranean fish stocked and tended by the Children of Belcorra. After Belcorra’s fall, the gnomes allowed and even fostered aberrations and other aquatic monsters in the lake. Despite the lake’s calm, visibility at the water level is poor; the mist makes everything beyond 30 feet Lightly Obscured, while everything beyond 90 feet is Heavily Obscured. Visibility from a higher point (such as the cliff in area @UUID[JournalEntry.FwWmtOBFHhvM2gtf.JournalEntryPage.mXZ6lvqCGglrVRyc]{H11}, the pillar in area @UUID[JournalEntry.FwWmtOBFHhvM2gtf.JournalEntryPage.cm5dvw5Lw46nAhBe]{H13}, or the caves in area @UUID[JournalEntry.FwWmtOBFHhvM2gtf.JournalEntryPage.16A6qnAoRtG9rIH1]{H22}) is unobstructed and gives a better view of the lake cavern. Drinking the water can be hazardous, but not fatal. There’s a 1 in 6 chance that anyone drinking the water is exposed to Sewer Plague. Fish still live in the lake: blind, ugly, spinous things that are poisonous to most creatures. Eating these fish—even when well cooked—is a slimy and sickening affair, and also spreads Sewer Plague. The other foul creatures living in the lake have built a tolerance to its diseased water and fish.

Random Encounters:

Every 15 minutes the characters spend traversing the lake, roll [[/gmroll 1d20]]. On a roll of 6 or higher, the characters come across one of the following random encounters. If the result would be a creature from an encounter the characters have already faced and overcome, treat it as no encounter.

[[/gmroll 1d10]]

Encounter

1-4

One @UUID[Actor.aD76W2uEQhFFUrom]{Chuul}, from area @UUID[.FAKz5eIbbUUifBrV]{H14}

5-6

Three @UUID[Actor.vHei0y2PKlXfxQ8Z]{Children of Belcorra} on a skiff, from area @UUID[.4gMUpcEFebuDe1Tf]{H17}

7

One @UUID[Actor.mmGiantShark0000]{Giant Shark}

8

One @UUID[Actor.WNqPRMjKW0oCHZ8X]{Krooth}

9

One lost @UUID[Actor.78Vf1Lk9ph2RGDgL]{Deepwater Dhuthorex}, from area @UUID[JournalEntry.1vlzl3NJsftNB9Dc.JournalEntryPage.wHieR95y1h9tQrGc]{I39}

10

The @UUID[Actor.RFCxaIS4OkacCpxD]{Froghemoth} from area @UUID[.m8Nz1hyJ9XZxjPAx]{H27}, which only fights for one round before retreating

Roll Tables

@RollTable[68Ly2Z5mTPeVJaLS]{Fetid Lake Encounters}

You can choose one of the encounters from the list above, or you can determine the outcome randomly using the included rolltable. If the result is a creature the heroes have already faced, treat it as no encounter.

If you'd like the roll's result to be hidden, make sure to change your roll mode first in the dropdown menu above your chat box!

Monster Cages.name: Monster Cages
Monster Cages.text:
Seven cages constructed of metal and strange fibrous wood line this beach, each partially submerged in the stinking waters.

The Children of Belcorra use the cages to trap powerful monsters living in the lake, as Belcorra recently commanded them to do. It’s hard going and involves many setbacks. Each cage has a simple latching device—a curved bar leading through metal hoops—that takes an action to open or close. The latch can’t be reached by a creature inside the cage due to its position. The metal gives the cages strength and the fibrous wood allows enough give that they’re particularly difficult to burst open. Forcing open a cage requires a successful [[/check ability=strength dc=28]] check. The cages have wide enough gaps that a Medium creature can squirm through the bars with a [[/check skill=acrobatics dc=16]]. Small or smaller creatures can squeeze through the bars without a check by spending 5 feet of movement.

Encounter

@UUID[Actor.aD76W2uEQhFFUrom]{Chuul} @UUID[Actor.WNqPRMjKW0oCHZ8X]{Krooth} @UUID[Actor.lo4fR4jDVzLdwwkH]{Skeletal Hulk}

The three unmarked cages are empty and open. The populated cells contain a Chuul, a Krooth, and a Skeletal Hulk that was once a giant reptilian humanoid. The creatures are furious at their imprisonment and, if freed, simply attack anyone nearby and flee if reduced to half their Hit Points.

The characters might be able to negotiate with the chuul, although it only understands Aklo and can’t speak. The chuul scratches a crude figure of itself swimming away from an open cage, to indicate it will leave without causing trouble; if the characters seem to need further enticement, the chuul scratches out a crude map of the lake and a few oblong circles in a cluster to represent coins or eggs. If the characters free it, it marks the location of the chuul eggs (area @UUID[JournalEntry.FwWmtOBFHhvM2gtf.JournalEntryPage.FAKz5eIbbUUifBrV]{H14}). Any character can deduce the chuul’s intenti[[/check skill=insight dc=15]] checkssful [[/check skill=insight dc=15]] check; someone who speaks Aklo has Advantage on this check. The chuul goes back on its word only if the characters seem particularly vulnerable.

Dock and Lift.name: Dock and Lift
Dock and Lift.text:
This large, T-shaped dock has four old skiffs moored to it. On the land side, the docks open up to a large wood and iron platform; at each corner, an iron chain climbs upward into darkness. At the south end of this platform sits a large pulley device. Its chains and machinery, as well as the chains on the platform, are crusted with rust.

This dock is the launch point for the Children of Belcorra’s increasingly rare lake excursions. The big lift once brought food and supplies from the Farm level to the upper levels of the Abomination Vaults. While the rusted machinery can still be coaxed to work, it’s slow and often stalls. It’s controlled by an external array of four levers at the mechanism’s front. The controls are unintuitive, as each lever controls a chain pulley on a corner, but each one pulls its chain at a different rate. It takes [[/r 1d4]] hours of tinkering to figure out exactly how to control the lift, and such trial and error might ruin the entire mechanism (there is a 50 percent chance that the mechanism is permanently destroyed). A character proficient with Tinker’s Tools or Thieves’ Tools who operates the lift has only a 20 percent chance of permanently destroying the lift. If such a character first succeeds on a [[/check ability=dexterity dc=16]] check to recalibrate the levers, this chance is reduced to 5 percent.

Encounter

@UUID[Actor.vHei0y2PKlXfxQ8Z]{Children of Belcorra (3)}

Three Children of Belcorra are repairing a skiff here. When they spot intruders, two rush to fight while the third flees to area @UUID[JournalEntry.FwWmtOBFHhvM2gtf.JournalEntryPage.906FDGe5y8f6jJ5H]{H19} for aid. Although there are several caged creatures nearby, the Children don’t release them, because it was such trouble to capture them in the first place. Instead, if in genuinely desperate straits, the undead either flee to area @UUID[JournalEntry.FwWmtOBFHhvM2gtf.JournalEntryPage.906FDGe5y8f6jJ5H]{H19} or launch a skiff to get aid from area @UUID[JournalEntry.FwWmtOBFHhvM2gtf.JournalEntryPage.hD6CSfmfkrSopsaw]{H21}.

Roper Pen.name: Roper Pen
Roper Pen.text:
The entrance to this cave is blocked by a makeshift barricade of wood and iron straps. Its door is barred from the outside and the bar has the words, “Danger! Do not open!” written on it in Gnomish.

The Children of Belcorra keep their largest and most dangerous monsters here. The barricade has obviously been broken and rebuilt many times, but it is sturdy enough to keep its current prisoners contained.

Encounter

@UUID[Actor.ZXbr1ke1vF0ZFKY3]{Ropers (2)}

Two Ropers are in the cave. The Children who discovered the creatures took great care to capture them and move them here. They have no idea how to control the aberrations, but they are sure that Belcorra will want them for her army. The ropers wait in the back of the cave, disguised as nondescript stalactites. If given the chance (such as if the characters open the door and then leave), they creep out of the cave so they can’t be imprisoned again. Otherwise, they wait for creatures to step further inside before striking, and they fight until destroyed.

Game Room.name: Game Room
Game Room.text:
Four small reclining couches circle a small table toward the corner of this L-shaped room. On the table is an elongated game board split into rows of squares. Various pieces sit in place on the board, and a group of pyramid-shaped dice is scattered about the board, along with stacks of gold and silver coins.

Some Children of Belcorra have retreated from their duties after long years and spend their time gambling on a deep gnome board game called “The Dark Chase.” Their set is missing several pieces (although it has all six required four-sided dice), but the incompleteness holds a peculiar attraction to the Children: the missing pieces mean there’s no end state, so the game is never over. The wagers around the board are all colored pebbles that are pretty but not particularly valuable.

Encounter

@UUID[Actor.00s3MhFQ4yOp2rTf]{Elder Child of Belcorra}, @UUID[Actor.vHei0y2PKlXfxQ8Z]{Children of Belcorra (2)}

The three Children in this room are only roused by the call of their companions at the dock or the interruption of the characters. Two are standard Children of Belcorra and one is a more powerful Elder Child of Belcorra. They spring into an active and concerted defense, but avoid disturbing the game in progress. If a character damages the game (such as by moving through the space containing the low table or by casting a spell that deals damage in that area), the mummies focus all their rage upon that character. The undead fight until destroyed.

Treasure

@UUID[Item.m8oDybso1IIOaw7u], @UUID[Item.OroUy85wiTjxpDb5]{The Dark Chase}

A simple iron key to area @UUID[JournalEntry.FwWmtOBFHhvM2gtf.JournalEntryPage.K7CfSFezeDp8yJoj]{H20} is among the pebbles.

The game board is inlaid with semiprecious stones. Even without the missing pieces, the game board is worth 80 GP.

Tomb of the Demilich.name: Tomb of the Demilich
Tomb of the Demilich.text:
The door to this chamber is locked; the key is in area @UUID[JournalEntry.FwWmtOBFHhvM2gtf.JournalEntryPage.906FDGe5y8f6jJ5H]{H19}. The lock requires a successful [[/check ability=dexterity dc=25]] check using Thieves’ Tools to open, or a successful [[/check ability=strength dc=30]] check to break it down. The area before the door is also magically protected with a permanent @UUID[Compendium.dnd5e.spells24.Item.phbsplSpikeGrowt]{Spike Growth} spell. Noticing the camouflaged spikes on the ground before stepping on them requires a successful [[/check skill=perception dc=19]] check.

This chamber is dusty and dry. At its west end sits a stone slab three feet high. Atop it lies a small body covered in funeral wrappings.

Gorsalthith, one of the oldest of the Children of Belcorra, plans to become a demilich. The other Children don’t know where he got this idea; none of them have even seen a demilich, although they’ve all heard stories of the gem-studded undead skulls with phenomenal spellcasting power. But Gorsalthith was adamant that he knew the method: he placed gemstones in his eyes, replaced his teeth with smaller gems, and drilled holes into his head to lodge a crown of crystals there. He then locked himself in this room to lie in repose, patiently waiting for his body to turn to dust and his transformation to take its final form. He’s been here for nearly a century, with no change in his mummified form.

Encounter

@UUID[Actor.6MLpOv7SzAff5xjf]{Gorsalthith}

Gorsalthith is determined to pursue his unrealistic goal. When the characters enter, he views them as a spiritual test on his path to demilichdom; he must defeat them to continue his transformation. He hisses arrogantly about his dedication to his transformation as he attacks the characters, and fights until destroyed.

Treasure: Gorsalthith’s only treasures are the gemstones grafted to his @UUID[Item.WyGETxwtHxrWkTrh]{skull}. His teeth are a variety of semiprecious stones, 30 in total, each worth [[/award 25gp]]. His eye sockets each hold a clear diamond worth [[/award 300gp]], and his crown is nine spikes of semiprecious gemstone worth [[/award 10gp]] each.

Ancients’ Caves.name: Ancients’ Caves
Ancients’ Caves.text:
Four caves atop steep cliffs sit ten feet above the lake’s dark water.

The cliff walls here are particularly easy to climb, requiring no ability check for anyone who is dry. If a climber is coming from swimming, the rock is mildly slippery and a successful [[/check skill=athletics dc=11]] check is required to avoid falling.

Encounter

@UUID[Actor.jCJUvzs1FaL6PAkq]{Empty Death Bodak}, @UUID[Actor.zm3hK6gxpuN6XyIY]{Empty Death Wight}

Three elder Children of Belcorra became far too interested in the lore of Nhimbaloth and were blasted with a powerful glimpse of the Outer God, transforming them into different undead. Nursing their pain and resentment, the creatures retreated to these caves. The other Children acknowledge the ancients’ power and knowledge, but rarely approach them; the ancients nurse their peevish hatreds for decades at a time. They dwell individually in areas H21a, H21b, and H21d. When any of these undead are disturbed, the others come clambering across the walls to help, so anyone fighting one soon fights them all.

Two of the ancients are Small Wights, while their leader in area H21d became an Empty Death Bodak.

Treasure

@UUID[Item.QEZ25X3A8uoqHbiE]{Bodak Treasure}

While two of the ancients have no treasure, the bodak that dwells in area H21d has valuables scattered about its cave. One sack contains [[/award 80pp 200gp]]. A set of Eyes of the Eagle lies discarded at the back of the cave, and an onyx worth [[/award 150gp]] is wedged in a crack in the wall.

Quiet Lake.name: Quiet Lake
Quiet Lake.text: On this western side of the large lake on this level, the foul water and obscuring mist are identical to that in the lake to the east (area @UUID[JournalEntry.FwWmtOBFHhvM2gtf.JournalEntryPage.EzERYV4NkVvzZeSR]{H15}), but this side is far less populated, predominantly due to the appetite of the froghemoth lairing here. Every 15 minutes the characters spend in this stretch of the lake, roll a [[/r d20]]. On an 11 or higher, the characters have a random encounter.

Shadowed Dock.name: Shadowed Dock
Shadowed Dock.text:
This T-shaped dock has been recently repaired, and a single skiff is moored on its north side. Beyond the dock, a masonry structure juts out from the cavern walls, the drifting mist creating strange shadows on the stonework. At its center is a single iron-bound door.

This dock lay abandoned for several decades until Belcorra’s return. Vethris, the spirit naga Belcorra recently put in charge of the Children of Belcorra, now claims it. The door is unlocked.

Encounter

@UUID[Actor.ZGEf08j9q4fIPDFd], @UUID[Actor.HNEUSYnInffvGPHK]{Specter}

The strange shadows playing on the masonry are more than just a trick of the water. A Wraith haunts this area, acting as a lookout. Characters can spot the wraith with a successful [[/check skill=perception dc=13]] check. Note that Wisdom (Perception) checks that rely on sight are generally made with Disadvantage here, as the mist makes the area Lightly Obscured.

When it spots strangers, the wraith silently moves to the inner complex to warn Vethris. Vethris peevishly dismisses the wraith, commanding it to “take care of the problem.” The wraith then hunts down the characters wherever they have since gone, eager to make specters out of them. When the wraith attacks, its Specter minion emerges from underneath the docks below the door to area @UUID[JournalEntry.FwWmtOBFHhvM2gtf.JournalEntryPage.0XtDnInFWYOLNUOX]{H24}.

Mud Room.name: Mud Room
Mud Room.text:
This damp room has a recessed floor filled with mud.

The mud is only a few inches below the doors’ thresholds, but is two feet deep and is Difficult Terrain.

Encounter

@UUID[Actor.vHei0y2PKlXfxQ8Z]{Children of Belcorra (2)}

Two Children of Belcorra lurk in the mud in the eastern part of this room, bitter at being stationed here under the command of the lazy Vethris. They’re quick to attack when anyone disturbs this room but, being beneath the mud, they don’t notice when the wraith flits overhead to warn the naga of intruders and aren’t likely to know the characters are present until they enter the mud.

Naga Lair.name: Naga Lair
Naga Lair.text:
This room is filled with rugs, tapestries, and pillows. Most are stained with mud.

This is the lair of the scheming spirit naga Vethris. Vethris convinced Belcorra she’d do a good job of getting the Farm level back in good order and keep the Children in line, but she’s done nothing of the sort. Vethris spends her days lounging about and ordering her new minions to bring her food and treasures. While the undead are dissatisfied with her, they’re loyal to Belcorra, so they either grudgingly follow the naga’s orders or find ways to ignore her.

Encounter

@UUID[Actor.h4SZ3U9at7aT0ASv]{Vethris}

Vethris the Spirit Naga is lazy, but she snaps into action against any who dare intrude on her relaxation. She screams curses at her foes while casting spells at them. She prefers to use Hold Person on strong-looking foes, but she follows up with Lightning Bolt as often as possible. Vethris surrenders or casts Dimension Door and tries to slither away if reduced to fewer than 25 Hit Points.

If the characters managed to get here without disturbing the mud in area @UUID[JournalEntry.FwWmtOBFHhvM2gtf.JournalEntryPage.0XtDnInFWYOLNUOX]{H24}, the Children there rise up and fight alongside the naga.

Exploration

Vethris brought the pillows and other trappings, but good hygiene is not one of the naga’s priorities. One tapestry, depicting a stylized nest of intertwining snakes, covers the secret door on the south wall. Anyone removing the tapestry or searching the room locates the secret door with a successful [[/check skill=perception dc=15]] check. It’s opened by pressing the proper stone on the eastern wall.

Secret Treasury.name: Secret Treasury
Secret Treasury.text:
A glittering mass of treasure sits at the south end of this small room.

Treasure

@UUID[Item.aNubzm6dLNmdLHkX]{Secret Treasury}

This is the bulk of treasure Vethris has accumulated, as well as that she tasked the undead to gather.

A porcelain teapot that sits near the front of the hoard is slathered with @UUID[Compendium.dnd5e.equipment24.Item.dmgOilOfTaggit00]{Oil of Taggit} poison.

The teapot is worth [[/award 40gp]] once the poison is washed off. Scattered about the room are [[/award 25pp 330gp 210sp]], a Wand of the War Mage +2, a Potion of Speed, and a Javelin of Lightning. A small sack contains 20 saltwater pearls worth [[/award 90gp]] each.

Shores of Death.name: Shores of Death
Shores of Death.text:
At this southern terminus of the foul underground lake, a small wooden dock juts out from a stone and masonry building. The dock is in ruin; the front of it has been ripped away with massive force, leaving the rest of it sloping down into the water. The building had a door at the dock’s end, but it’s been ripped off its hinges, with a chunk of the door partly submerged and leaning against the cavern wall. South of the structure, the lakeshore gives way to a forest of massive fungi. The water near the dock occasionally bubbles, as if something massive dwells somewhere below the surface.

A froghemoth attacked the Children of Belcorra in this outpost, damaging the dock and driving the bog mummies away. It’s the source of the bubbles in the water. A character who succeeds on a [[/check skill=perception dc=25]] spots its eyestalk peeping above the fetid water.

Encounter

@UUID[Actor.RFCxaIS4OkacCpxD]{Froghemoth}

The Froghemoth is a terrifying abomination of tentacles, teeth, and unbridled rage, capable of devouring even dragons. How it came to the lake is a mystery, but in the short time it’s been here, it’s damaged this building and driven nearly all the aberrations and creatures away from the southern lake. It sometimes makes its way northward to hunt, but it’s usually lurking under the water by the shattered dock.

A sluggish hunter, the froghemoth tends to attack from the water and rarely pursues those who find shelter within the fungus garden. However, if the froghemoth is reduced to 155 Hit Points or fewer, there’s a chance it becomes enraged and follows its attackers onto dry land.

Ruined Outpost.name: Ruined Outpost
Ruined Outpost.text:
The remains of a table and some chairs are scattered around the room. While the western door has been ripped off its hinges, the southern door is still intact but open. Two torn, soggy corpses are slumped in the doorway.

Exploration

The corpses are Children of Belcorra who were destroyed in the froghemoth’s rampage. While there’s nothing of value in the abandoned room, there is a secret door on the east wall. A hero who searches the room and makes a successful [[/check skill=perception dc=15]] check spots the fake flagstone and can open it. Beyond the door is a narrow passage heading east and then turning north, leading to another secret door of similar design. The Children of Belcorra used this passage to quickly access to the fungus garden’s northern reaches.

West Garden.name: West Garden
West Garden.text:
While the fungal forest grows high in this area, there are also signs that the area was recently tended. Rocks outline sections of healthy growth, and the paths are clear of all the but the occasional bits of mold and fungus. Bioluminescent moss provides a low, even glow throughout the area, as though intentionally cultivated for the effect. To the east, a wide stone bridge spans a massive chasm. A gigantic iron ladder snakes down into the darkness of the chasm from its other side. Beyond the bridge and the ladder, the fungal forest becomes even more overgrown.

The Children of Belcorra long ago limited their efforts from tending the entire fungus garden to only this western end. With the recent arrival of the froghemoth, they’ve stopped their efforts here as well. The fungi here are harmless; in fact, they are good sources of food, fungus-wood lumber, and glowing moss. A character proficient with Carpenter’s Tools recognizes the lumber quality, while a character proficient in the Survival skill recognizes the many edible fungi. There is enough edible fungus here to feed dozens of creatures indefinitely. If removed, a patch of glowing moss casts Dim Light in a 10-foot radius for 1 week.

Lumber Shed.name: Lumber Shed
Lumber Shed.text:
This squat stone building looks like a storage room.

One of three storage rooms in the fungal garden, this building was used to store wood formed from tough fungus fibers. Inside, a pile of fungus wood still sits, along with a bundle of axes and saws used to collect the fungus and cut the boards into shape.

Treasure: The bundle includes two sets of @UUID[Compendium.dnd5e.equipment24.Item.phbtulCarpenters]{Carpenter’s Tools} in surprisingly good condition.

Tool Shed.name: Tool Shed
Tool Shed.text:
This shed has a small hole where a lock would be, but traces of rust around the hole are all that remain there.

The tools once stored here have met the same fate as the lock and are nothing more than a piles of rust around axe handles, wooden shims, and other non- metallic materials. The shriveled corpse of a fat rust monster lies in the center of the room; the Children of Belcorra killed it years ago when it got into their tools, and they never bothered to remove it.

Inhabited Shed.name: Inhabited Shed
Inhabited Shed.text:
This simple storage shed is filled with small, gnawed bones, discarded scales, and a pungent caustic reek.

The gibtanius lairing here doesn’t know that there’s a secret door in the west wall, although it has figured out how to open the main door latch with its mouth. A character who searches the room automatically discovers the false flagstone that opens the secret door, as the flagstone has shifted slightly out of place.

Encounter

@UUID[Actor.T6vOuhM1KV5Fr75F]{Gibtanius}

The Gibtanius escaped from the Laboratory level far above and fled all the way here some time ago. It’s found more than enough to eat in the surrounding fungus garden, so it never ranges far, although it prefers living prey. As it’s recently learned to avoid the nearby lake because of the lurking froghemoth, it hasn’t had more than a few small bats or rodents in months and it’s eager for larger flesh. It rushes characters who open this door and attacks with a single-minded hunger until slain.

Treasure

@UUID[Item.YT39pQ1Q7BdmZTLk]{Gold Armlets}

The gibtanius has spat up a pair of armlets from a gladiator it ate. The gold armlets are studded with sapphires and worth [[/award 125gp]] each once the gibtanius’s stench is washed off them.

Level 8 Portal Chamber.name: Level 8 Portal Chamber
Level 8 Portal Chamber.text:
Teleportation Network

Some of the @UUID[Compendium.dnd5e.spells24.Item.phbsplTeleportat]{Teleportation Circles} within the Abomination Vaults form a part of a larger network. By tracing specific patterns on the wall runes, someone could transport everyone in any one of these chambers to one of nine other portal chambers in the Abomination Vaults- so long as the teleportation circles in both the departure chamber and destination have been awakened by the @UUID[Compendium.dnd-abomination-vaults.av-items-5e.Item.H0KYIrtDeeV2pSyC]{Awaken Portal} ritual (area @UUID[JournalEntry.KeWKr2yd8dbppeS5.JournalEntryPage.8X4xF40k06MW0X7q]{C35}).

The nine chambers are areas @UUID[JournalEntry.uMZ0RiCcPSqsx1Nm.JournalEntryPage.537bzfVUpq6XbR9a]{B17}, @UUID[JournalEntry.KeWKr2yd8dbppeS5.JournalEntryPage.vEiow4kU961XNOJp]{C16}, @UUID[JournalEntry.Os5bHdzCDiXgJBQ6.JournalEntryPage.RJf3BCpcVW6d68s7]{D05}, @UUID[JournalEntry.JT0zCcIwsSpKnbB5.JournalEntryPage.LJhOoRqYjj38YWl8]{E18}, @UUID[JournalEntry.KI33EAGPVHP4zyFZ.JournalEntryPage.mDFVGUXY6YDuQWF3]{F13}, @UUID[JournalEntry.OyNcqrpRClyhr8BJ.JournalEntryPage.zTpatmyyb4JvgNCo]{G02}, @UUID[JournalEntry.FwWmtOBFHhvM2gtf.JournalEntryPage.Nak2hUmVOHXBkcR5]{H33}, @UUID[JournalEntry.1vlzl3NJsftNB9Dc.JournalEntryPage.DJKWR2KLTPUi3w6T]{I59}, and @UUID[JournalEntry.yn21bNM6kpV4xRol.JournalEntryPage.JinYTJeYVFBE1uky]{J05}

The round walls of this chamber are deeply carved with flowing runes. The runes are filled with silver and dust.

This is another portal chamber containing an inactive Teleportation Circle. The characters can connect it to those on other levels of the Abomination Vaults with the Awaken Portal spell.

XP Award: Award the characters [[/award 500xp]] for using Awaken Portal to reactivate this Teleportation Circle.

Eastern Wilds.name: Eastern Wilds
Eastern Wilds.text:
Across the bridge’s span, fungus growths rise to greater heights—some reaching nearly to the high ceiling of the cavern, fifty feet overhead. The remains of old paths are here, but most are covered with clumps of smaller fungus or patches of pale slime. Spores drift through the air and huge red blooms on the fungi shift as though in a wind, although there is no wind here. An enormous iron ladder hangs down into the deep chasm the bridge crosses. Each link of the chains that hold it up are as large as a human, but the rungs are spaced to give even small creatures an easy climb.

The east side of the fungus garden has gone a long time without proper cultivation, which has resulted in it becoming both overgrown and dangerous. The paths are somewhat clear, if overgrown, but the rest of the cavern is Difficult Terrain, where it is passable at all.

A Detect Magic spell or similar effect reveals an aura of Divination magic on the semicircular section of stone wall to the south about 30 feet above the ground, although there is no way to interact with it from this side. From area @UUID[JournalEntry.FwWmtOBFHhvM2gtf.JournalEntryPage.4QXTuClUwtKkEjHA]{H45}, it is a one-way window.

The gigantic iron ladder leads more than 100 feet down to area @UUID[JournalEntry.1vlzl3NJsftNB9Dc.JournalEntryPage.f4ruwhy1Yy1fliNH]{I27}.

Encounter

@UUID[Actor.55SmPtsUXsridUjJ]{Dragon's Blood Puffballs (2)}

The massive patch of fungus closest to the bridge has grown two Dragon’s Blood Puffballs. These deadly puffballs resemble overgrown flowers, but they soon detach and float toward the characters to attack with their deadly blooms. They follow characters who flee and fight until destroyed in an explosive puff of poisonous spores.

Webbed Crossroads.name: Webbed Crossroads
Webbed Crossroads.text:
The towering fungi around these overgrown paths are laced in thick webbing. Within are a few humanoid figures, too shrouded in webs to see clearly.

Encounter

@UUID[Actor.T5CUuPsMPb17d6Qy]{Ogre Spider}, @UUID[Actor.mmGiantSpider000]{Juvenile Ogre Spiders (2)}

The hungry ogre spiders that have made their webs here are not on the ground, but hiding in a crevasse in the ceiling 60 feet above, where they have Three-Quarters Cover. In addition to the adult Ogre Spider, there are two juveniles which have the same statistics as standard Giant Spiders. The spiders begin their assault by dropping onto the soft mushroom canopy to catch its prey off guard. The mushrooms allow the spiders to drop to within 30 feet of the ground without taking falling damage; from there, the spiders climb along the fungi to reach prey. If reduced to fewer than half its Hit Points, a spider retreats for the safety of its ceiling crevasse high above.

Treasure

@UUID[Item.z6JFHol9OCIGCuIJ]{Hanging Treasure}

The webbed figures are a desiccated urdefhan and two much-more-recently killed drow from Yldaris. It takes about a half an hour to clear the thick webbing from each corpse.

The dead urdefhan carries [[/award 20gp]] and a fine Shield made of strange fungus wood. One of the drow bodies holds a pouch with three pinches of Dust of Disappearance.

Rounded Wall.name: Rounded Wall
Rounded Wall.text:
This patch of fungus sits lower than the rest, though it bears no signs of cultivation. Bulbous green growths lurk among the other fungi. The back wall of the cavern is visible through a cloud of drifting spores; it isn’t natural rock, but a pale, curved, seamless stone.

The wall is part of the footprint of Gauntlight high above, and is thus impervious to damage.

Exploration

A secret door in the curved wall provides access to the structure’s interior (area @UUID[JournalEntry.FwWmtOBFHhvM2gtf.JournalEntryPage.rVwX8eSwEBHWEjcg]{H37}); like the secret door in area @UUID[JournalEntry.FwWmtOBFHhvM2gtf.JournalEntryPage.L9JdFdozxxuly8RY]{H1}, it’s easy to find. A character who succeeds on a [[/check skill=perception dc=13]] check while searching this area spots the secret door from its slight discoloration. The secret door is magically locked and can’t be broken open. The door has a concave indentation about 8 inches wide that would fit a disc or lens, and it only opens when a Fulcrum Lens is placed into this indentation.

Encounter

@UUID[Actor.czQFet5Qo63IXtHl]{Reaper Skull Puffball}

The spores and green growths belong to a Reaper Skull Puffball lairing here. It attacks any living creatures that approach, floating upward to reveal its hooked tentacles. If reduced to fewer than 20 Hit Points, it ascends to the ceiling and tries to float away to the south—right beneath the crevasse lair of the spiders from area @UUID[JournalEntry.FwWmtOBFHhvM2gtf.JournalEntryPage.b0AhkI9gXf14Ns4p]{H35}. If the characters haven’t dealt with the biggest ogre spider, it darts out, kills the reaper skull puffball, and retreats into its bolt-hole. This might alert the characters that the spider is there!

Upper Pit.name: Upper Pit
Upper Pit.text:
This large, circular room is made of pale stone and covered with dust. At its center is a single stone lipped pit. A twisting ribbon of blue light coils and twists in the air, extending from the ceiling down into the pit. The stone of the ceiling and the walls of the pit undulate in the eerie light as though the stone itself were suffering.

This pit leads down through Gauntlight’s lowest levels. The ribbon of energy shows that Gauntlight is drawing even more power, and the characters might have seen a ribbon of energy like this in the upper levels. A creature that isn’t a Construct that ends its turn within the 5-foot-diameter ribbon of light must make a [[/save ability=constitution dc=17]] saving throw, taking [[/damage 10d6 necrotic average]] damage on a failed save or half as much damage on a successful one. Unlike the violet energy the heroes might have discovered in the Abomination Vault’s upper levels, this energy doesn’t heal Undead creatures.

The pit leads downward over 100 feet to a similar chamber on the Hunting Grounds (area @UUID[JournalEntry.1vlzl3NJsftNB9Dc.JournalEntryPage.NaEg1IQHphXU25Nk]{I28}) and then another 100 feet to the Empty Vault (area @UUID[JournalEntry.yn21bNM6kpV4xRol.JournalEntryPage.a9b40LjI7QwLgirk]{J20}), where Belcorra typically dwells.

Strange Sentry.name: Strange Sentry
Strange Sentry.text:
Toward the end of the fungal path, a masonry structure juts out from the cavern wall, a door at its center.

The structure served as a waypoint where the Children of Belcorra could converse with their Ghost Queen through the wisps. They abandoned this building when they left the eastern fungus garden.

Exploration

A character who investigates the area and makes a successful [[/check skill=investigation/nature dc=20]] check spots a place where the fungus on the wall grows oddly, indicating it is on a hollow surface. The fake flagstone in the wall under the fungus growth can be simply pulled away. Beyond is a narrow passage heading south and then turning west, leading to another secret door of similar design in area @UUID[JournalEntry.FwWmtOBFHhvM2gtf.JournalEntryPage.ornsQb4bCeU89niq]{H28}.

Encounter

@UUID[Actor.mlifDVJJWwjFtUxv]{Murmur}

A powerful seugathi from the arena level moved into the structure, but they left a guardian outside: a Medusa they call Murmur who has been so long exposed to their Mind Fog that her mind has become permanently impaired. Murmur stands in front of the door, her hood up, muttering unintelligible words to herself. Her snake hair writhes beneath her hood. She can’t understand most of what she perceives or use language; she has a Wisdom score of 1 (–5).

Murmur isn’t likely to pose much of a challenge for level 8 characters, but she’s an indication that something strange is afoot. She fights with her bow, which she only barely remembers how to use, if creatures remain at a distance. If foes close in, she drops her bow and flees into area @UUID[JournalEntry.FwWmtOBFHhvM2gtf.JournalEntryPage.MFktSOxcOfKGkbb2]{H39} to join the seugathi.

Side Quest

Restoring Murmur’s mind is a challenge, but it’s not impossible. Doing so requires a Greater Restoration or Heal spell. If the characters restore her, the medusa introduces herself as Moadenn and offers to fight alongside them for a few days before striking off on her own. She’s bossy and cruel, so the characters might not want her aid; she’s perfectly happy to depart sooner if the characters don’t want her around.

XP Award: Award the characters [[/award 1600xp]] for restoring Murmur’s mind.

Lair of the Dreamer.name: Lair of the Dreamer
Lair of the Dreamer.text:
Three alcoves in this square chamber are overgrown with a tangle of thin mushroom stalks and creeping, flowering vines. The air smells sweet and heady.

The alcoves each contain stone basins, like those in areas @UUID[JournalEntry.FwWmtOBFHhvM2gtf.JournalEntryPage.0EtecMBSYJDok7n7]{H2} and @UUID[JournalEntry.FwWmtOBFHhvM2gtf.JournalEntryPage.tXdibKRkxLO9wGnz]{H10}. They used to provide a connection to the swamps below, but the seugathi here didn’t want the interruption. They pulled the muck from the basins, coated their interiors with a fungal resin, and repurposed them as planters to grow vegetation useful for modifying living creatures. If the characters clean them out, they refill with fetid swamp water once again, and a Will-o’-Wisp appears above each. Their observation triggers the @UUID[JournalEntry.FwWmtOBFHhvM2gtf.JournalEntryPage.em5wJ44hCXP8mGGG]{Belcorra Attacks!} event.

Encounter

@UUID[Actor.NmktwpgKDYKT3ZDv]{Seugathi Reality Warper}

The Seugathi Reality Warper scuttles slowly back and forth across this room, idly tending the flowers. They’re bored with Murmur and is looking for other minds and bodies to twist, but they’re willing to engage in conversation first if the characters seem amenable. They talk about how the basins connect to some malignant swamp further down, and proudly shows off how they can warp the clear fresh water back to swamp and cleanse it again to grow this strange garden. As they talk, they try to rank the characters from the weakest mind to the strongest, so they know who to target best with their mental attacks. They might propose puzzles or riddles to find this out, or ask the characters about their recent dreams. If asked about the seugathis on upper levels, the reality warper honestly explains that they broke off from that group, since the deal with Belcorra no longer served their experimental interests in ecology. Belcorra insisted on living weapons and allowed no leeway for other research, which rankled this seugathi.

Eventually, however, the seugathi likely starts a fight to cull the characters. They wield a Scimitar and carry a Staff of the Woodlands. In combat, they call on Murmur from area @UUID[JournalEntry.FwWmtOBFHhvM2gtf.JournalEntryPage.pnTCbvQqpz0arkpz]{H38} if the medusa hasn’t yet been defeated. They can pull their Staff of the Woodlands or Scimitar out of the foliage without using an action, since they know exactly where they are hidden. As soon as they can, they head out into the Farm where they can separate and box in enemies by adding and removing Difficult Terrain using Warp Reality.

Soporific Pollen

Due to the pollen in the air, non- seugathi creatures have Disadvantage on Intelligence, Wisdom, and Charisma saving throws while in the room. Creatures that hold their breath or don’t need to breathe are immune to this effect.

Treasure

@UUID[Item.DSJVbn9MptSHXr8g]{Seugathi's Stash}

A character who makes a successful [[/skill 14 inv]] check to search the alcoves discovers a bag hidden far behind the hanging tangles. The bag contains [[/award 253gp]], three topazes worth [[/award 600gp]] each, and a Potion of Heroism. If the check fails by 5 or more, the character contracts Cackle Fever from an unlucky interaction with the plants growing there.

Between a Rock and a Doorway.name: Between a Rock and a Doorway
Between a Rock and a Doorway.text:
The path ends at a door leading west. A large boulder covered with spidery carvings blocks a cave entrance to the east.

Exploration

@UUID[Compendium.dnd5e.spells24.Item.phbsplGlyphofWar]{Glyph of Warding}

The door to this room is locked and Nyzuros (in area @UUID[JournalEntry.FwWmtOBFHhvM2gtf.JournalEntryPage.UuRy9l7LfCkIWpxT]{H44}) has the key. A character can open it with a successful [[/check dex thief dc=20]] check using Thieves’ Tools or a successful [[/check ability=strength dc=22]] check to force it open.

The boulder seems impassable, but it’s cleverly hinged to open when places on its surface are pressed in the proper configuration. The elvish carvings describe how to move the boulder, but these instructions are intentionally erroneous and trigger the hazard below. Finding the proper way to move the boulder requires a successful [[/check skill=investigation/nature dc=20]] or [[/check int mason dc=20]] check. Alternatively, a character can roll the boulder aside with a successful [[/check ability=strength dc=25]] check, and a Small or smaller creature can squirm past the boulder with a successful [[/check skill=acrobatics dc=20]] check.

Glyph of Warding

The carvings contain an explosive runes version of the Glyph of Warding spell. A character can notice the glyph on a successful [[/check skill=investigation dc=17]] check. The glyph triggers when a creature handles the boulder in the way indicated by the elvish carvings. If the glyph is triggered, each creature within 20 feet of the boulder makes a [[/save ability=dexterity dc=18]], taking [[/damage 6d8 average thunder]] damage on a failed save or half as much damage on a successful one. The noise also alerts the nearby drow, who go on alert.

XP Award: If the characters disable the Glyph of Warding without being noticed, award them 800 XP.

Descent to Yldaris.name: Descent to Yldaris
Descent to Yldaris.text:
Faintly glowing green veins of crystal line the walls of this large cave. To the south, a wide passage spirals into the earth as though created by some massive burrowing creature a long time ago.

The slick, green veins crackle with faint electricity when touched, but they aren’t harmful. A purple worm burrowed out this passageway centuries ago. It leads to the drow outpost of Yldaris far below (area @UUID[JournalEntry.1vlzl3NJsftNB9Dc.JournalEntryPage.f23Brb7jUwBNLvDR]{I1}).

Encounter

@UUID[Actor.OqoWbYOyHDGHEeHV]{Drow Hunters (6)}

This passage is not unguarded; six Drow Hunters are always on alert here. If they detect intruders, they form a firing line to prevent anyone from getting past them. Although they’re quick to attack calignis, urdefhans, or other enemies they recognize, a group of surface-dwellers intrigues them. The hunters keep their weapons at the ready, but they first ask the characters why they’re trespassing in Yldaris territory.

Treasure: The hunters each carry [[/award 3d6gp]].

Negotiations

Their starting attitude to the characters is Indifferent. If the characters improve their attitude with a successful [[/check skill=persuasion dc=16]] check, they agree to escort them to their leader in Yldaris. Three drow escort them through areas @UUID[JournalEntry.1vlzl3NJsftNB9Dc.JournalEntryPage.f23Brb7jUwBNLvDR]{I1}, @UUID[JournalEntry.1vlzl3NJsftNB9Dc.JournalEntryPage.n9gNR5iQE9Dp3Pwf]{I5}, @UUID[JournalEntry.1vlzl3NJsftNB9Dc.JournalEntryPage.bRyY0W8o867mTMNj]{I6}, and @UUID[JournalEntry.1vlzl3NJsftNB9Dc.JournalEntryPage.hcb926Op2PfYoVwj]{I17} to meet @UUID[JournalEntry.67686KaEPc6XAlKJ.JournalEntryPage.PMfMv2GzieXiY1Oo]{Quara Orshendiel}. If the Charisma check succeeds by 5 or more, only a single drow accompanies them because the drow consider them to be especially trustworthy. If they can’t improve the hunters’ attitude, the drow firmly turn them away.

If the characters mention that they rescued Falxi Orshendiel from the Warped Brew kitchen (area @UUID[JournalEntry.KI33EAGPVHP4zyFZ.JournalEntryPage.fcEo2VAIF0ShGLVB]{F12}), the hunters remember that Falxi talked about them. The characters thereafter have Advantage on Charisma (Persuasion) checks to negotiate entry into Yldaris. Returning the bodies and possessions of the drow in area @UUID[JournalEntry.FwWmtOBFHhvM2gtf.JournalEntryPage.b0AhkI9gXf14Ns4p]{H35} also grants the characters this benefit.

The characters might have earned the trust of the drow in areas @UUID[JournalEntry.FwWmtOBFHhvM2gtf.JournalEntryPage.UuRy9l7LfCkIWpxT]{H44} or @UUID[JournalEntry.FwWmtOBFHhvM2gtf.JournalEntryPage.4QXTuClUwtKkEjHA]{H45}; in that case, the characters don’t need to separately win over these hunters.

XP Award: Award the characters [[/award 5400xp]] if they negotiate entry to Yldaris from these drow.

Spider Guard.name: Spider Guard
Spider Guard.text:
Sheets of webbing hang on the south wall of this room, between two wooden doors.

Encounter

@UUID[Actor.E4ctF7Fvi3cdkgQq]{Giant Wolf Spider}

A trained Giant Wolf Spider, the loyal pet of the drow shootist Iribo in area @UUID[JournalEntry.FwWmtOBFHhvM2gtf.JournalEntryPage.UuRy9l7LfCkIWpxT]{H44}, lairs in this room. The spider whistles shrilly when it spots intruders, then springs to attack. The noise alerts all the drow in the area and brings them running immediately; together, this is a very dangerous encounter for level 8 characters. The spider fights to the death, or until Iribo calls it off.

Cell.name: Cell
Cell.text:
This square cell has two pairs of rusted manacles bolted into the wall about six feet from the floor.

The drow captured one of the Children of Belcorra in the fungus garden and brought her here. They’ve been interrogating her for information about the layout and denizens of the level, but the mummy hasn’t yet been forthcoming with any pertinent information.

The Child of Belcorra realizes that the characters aren’t with the drow and asks for release. She’s careful to make only vague promises about what she can do for the party if released, because she’s lying; as soon as they let her go, she flees to warn the other Children of Belcorra that the drow have made significant inroads to the fungus forest (the mummies are unlikely to act on this information anytime soon).

The prisoner can be goaded into sharing more than she intended with a successful [[/check skill=deception/persuasion dc=16]] check or a [[/check skill=intimidation dc=19]] check. She knows the denizens and layout of areas @UUID[JournalEntry.FwWmtOBFHhvM2gtf.JournalEntryPage.EzERYV4NkVvzZeSR]{H15} to @UUID[JournalEntry.FwWmtOBFHhvM2gtf.JournalEntryPage.pWI9SiOcfHx22ezd]{H25} and that there’s a dangerous froghemoth in area @UUID[JournalEntry.FwWmtOBFHhvM2gtf.JournalEntryPage.m8Nz1hyJ9XZxjPAx]{H27}.

Observation Post.name: Observation Post
Observation Post.text:
This small room appears to be a lookout post. Three narrow slits line the north and east walls, giving a view of the overgrown fungus garden beyond.

The Children of Belcorra observed their cultivated and thriving gardens from here, but the post had been abandoned for some time before the drow of Yldaris discovered it.

Encounter

@UUID[Actor.ED06o6gYWCybJfSm]{Iribo}

A Drow Shootist named Iribo serves as a lookout in this room. She investigates any indication that intruders are present, such as her pet spider’s shrill whistle. In a fight, Iribo attempts to quickly incapacitate her foes with poison and calls for the drow in area @UUID[JournalEntry.FwWmtOBFHhvM2gtf.JournalEntryPage.4QXTuClUwtKkEjHA]{H45}. However, she doesn’t foolishly throw herself into combat; if she thinks it’s possible to negotiate with the characters, she does so.

Treasure: Iribo carries [[/award 4d10gp]] along with four doses of @UUID[Compendium.dnd5e.equipment24.Item.dmgLolthsSting00]{Spider’s Sting} poison.

Negotiations

A longtime friend of Yldaris’s leader, Quara, Iribo knows that Quara might have some use for surface dwellers. The characters can attempt to improve her starting attitude of Indifferent just as they can with the hunters in area @UUID[JournalEntry.FwWmtOBFHhvM2gtf.JournalEntryPage.5Fkuvc9hgwKyc4tY]{H41}. If they succeed, she personally escorts them to Yldaris.

XP Award: Award the characters [[/award 5400xp]] if they successfully negotiate Iribo’s escort into Yldaris.

Planning Room.name: Planning Room
Planning Room.text:
This large room may have at one time been richly appointed, but it’s now full of mold and decay. Shattered furniture covers sections of the floor and tattered and mildew-specked tapestries hang from the walls. At the north, curtains obscure a wide bay window made of transparent stone.

The elder Children of Belcorra used to plan their lush gardens from this room, but now the room serves as a staging area for a small drow contingent. The curved, floor-to-ceiling bay window provides a clear view into the garden. The window is made from blocks of enchanted stone that are transparent from this side but resemble ordinary, natural stone when viewed from outside. The drow stationed here might have gotten a good look at the characters passing by in area @UUID[JournalEntry.FwWmtOBFHhvM2gtf.JournalEntryPage.0DvO7vVIbYZAhm3R]{H34}, were it not for the fact they keep the curtains closed most of the time.

Encounter

@UUID[Actor.ZFP8RyQW4SNtJ3AE]{Nyzuros} @UUID[Actor.DawBQWRyrM4cKfGI]{Drow Wardens (4)}

A Drow Hunter named Nyzuros and four Drow Wardens huddle over a map of the gardens. Their main concern is the ogre spider nest at the crossroads, as the largest of the spiders has already feasted on earlier drow explorers. They debate whether to risk attacking the spiders, gaining significant glory for vanquishing such dangerous foes, or to swallow their pride and summon aid from Yldaris. Nyzuros technically commands this contingent, even though Iribo in area @UUID[JournalEntry.FwWmtOBFHhvM2gtf.JournalEntryPage.UuRy9l7LfCkIWpxT]{H44} is their most skilled fighter. The drow wardens defer to both of them.

Whether the characters can make it this far without alerting these drow, or they’re called into battle by noise, the wardens are hotheaded and quick to attack. Nyzuros is more circumspect, however, and wants to know how and why these unusual intruders have come into these areas.

Treasure: Nyzuros carries [[/award 26gp]], a @UUID[Compendium.dnd5e.equipment24.Item.dmgGreaterPotion]{Potion of Greater Healing}, a vial of @UUID[Compendium.dnd5e.equipment24.Item.dmgLolthsSting00]{Spider’s Sting} poison, and the key to area @UUID[JournalEntry.FwWmtOBFHhvM2gtf.JournalEntryPage.AKWFkPkWkrmxW5KC]{H46}. Each warden carries [[/award 3d6gp]].

Negotations

Like the hunters in area @UUID[JournalEntry.FwWmtOBFHhvM2gtf.JournalEntryPage.5Fkuvc9hgwKyc4tY]{H41}, Nyzuros has an Indifferent attitude toward the characters, but his attitude can be improved in the same way (and, if the characters do so, he escorts them to Yldaris personally). The characters have another option to get into Nyzuros’s good graces: if they’ve killed the ogre spiders in area @UUID[JournalEntry.FwWmtOBFHhvM2gtf.JournalEntryPage.0DvO7vVIbYZAhm3R]{H34} and promise to let Nyzuros and his team take the credit with Quara for doing so, his attitude automatically improves to Friendly.

Nyzuros’s forbearance isn’t without limits, however. If the characters have slain other drow, he turns against them.

XP Award: Award the characters [[/award 5400xp]] if they successfully negotiate Nyzuros’s escort into Yldaris.

Provisions Room.name: Provisions Room
Provisions Room.text:
The door to this room is locked. Nyzuros has the key. A character can open it with a successful [[/check dex thief dc=23]], or a successful [[/check ability=strength dc=25]] check to force it open.

This room is plainly used for storage. Casks and bundles are stacked against its north and west walls.

Treasure

@UUID[Item.EJzgk8StVYPSSI6j]{Drow Provisions}

The drow exploring this level keep their supplies here, and they are currently very well stocked. The supplies include six weeks of Rations, three casks of clean water, an additional two casks of fungus wine (worth about [[/award 20gp]] each to an interested buyer), five Longswords, six Hand Crossbows, 60 Bolts, a Poisoner’s Kit, three doses of Stupor Poison, and a small strongbox with a broken lock containing [[/award 150gp]].

Introduction.name: Introduction
Introduction.text:
Chapter Synopsis

The chapter begins with the characters descending into the overgrown Farm level from either entrance in the Prison level above. The primary denizens, other than feral monsters, are listless undead gnomes and addled caligni cultists, both of whom can provide some clues about Belcorra’s return. The characters will likely face Belcorra in person for the first time—but certainly not the last!

The Fulcrum Lenses

The final three levels are where the story of the Abomination Vaults comes to its head. It’s critical that the heroes discover the three fulcrum lenses in the lower levels and learn how they work—specifically, how they can permanently destroy Belcorra. Yet Belcorra has more freedom to harry the heroes throughout these lower levels, and by the time the heroes face her in the Empty Vault, they’ve earned her ire. With luck, the heroes can defeat Belcorra and topple Gauntlight.

@UUID[JournalEntry.67686KaEPc6XAlKJ.JournalEntryPage.efRUYLBH9Kf3CLkX]{Gauntlight} is active, but its true power is yet to be realized. Belcorra penetrated deep underground to build Gauntlight’s foundation, following the psychic pull of the Empty Vault, a place sacred to @UUID[JournalEntry.67686KaEPc6XAlKJ.JournalEntryPage.ohFJrgStEzdvGEEU]{Nhimbaloth} at the heart of an ancient, subterranean temple. Gauntlight draws upon the energies of the Empty Vault as its foundation and the source of its powers. Within the Empty Vault, Belcorra empowered four Fulcrum Lenses that, when installed in the lighthouse high above, focus Nhimbaloth’s attention and unleash the artifact’s full power. However, the Fulcrum Lenses are dangerous; they invite Nhimbaloth’s uncaring gaze, and even Belcorra can’t withstand the close scrutiny of the Outer God. Thus, while they hold great power, the Fulcrum Lenses are also Belcorra’s greatest weakness.

Yldaris Drow

The drow outpost of Yldaris lies on the next level of the Abomination Vaults, but their silent, skilled hunters have established a watch post in an abandoned Children of Belcorra outpost. The characters might ally with the drow here, which makes a peaceful meeting with Yldaris more likely in @UUID[JournalEntry.1vlzl3NJsftNB9Dc.JournalEntryPage.LYgvrg4SI95a4KqP]{Chapter 9}.

The Farm

Belcorra repurposed the massive natural caverns above the Empty Vault for her needs. The eighth level made a lush cavern of fungus growths and freshwater lakes that teemed with subterranean fish, while the ninth level was a wilderness where predators and prey alike could thrive. The characters must descend through these levels to reach the Empty Vault.

Features

Environmental Cues:

Glowing moss, creeping tendrils of mold, decaying wood, distant splashing, foul mists, muddy footprints, smells of earthy rot, towering fungi.

The vast caverns of this level and the many structures and rooms within it are normally dark, although bioluminescent fungus is common in overgrown areas. The caverns reach 50 feet high, but the ceilings in rooms carved out of the stone are much lower. Ceilings in the areas claimed by the Cult of Urthagul (areas H2 to H10) are only 10 feet high. Ceilings in other interior areas are sized for the gnomish Children of Belcorra and are only eight feet high. Sturdy planks of fungal wood form the doors. They’re crusted with mold and give off an unpleasantly earthy, rotten smell.

Belcorra Attacks.name: Belcorra Attacks
Belcorra Attacks.text:
A Watchful Eye

Ghost stories work best when the ghost is an active and terrifying adversary. As soon as any of the will-o’-wisps or dread wisps in this adventure see the characters, they immediately alert Belcorra through the magic of the swampy basins throughout the Abomination Vaults. Belcorra is worried to hear that the characters have penetrated this far, and she resolves to harry them until the other dungeon denizens can overcome them.

XP Award: In Belcorra’s third attack, she’s intent on murder. Award the characters [[/award 3200xp]] for surviving her attempt. Increase this to her full XP value if they manage to defeat her in a confrontation and force her to rejuvenate.

Direct Attacks

During their trek through the lowest levels of the Abomination Vaults, the characters likely face Belcorra several times before they finally acquire the @UUID[JournalEntry.67686KaEPc6XAlKJ.JournalEntryPage.azMqL6C2NvazTcRE]{Fulcrum Lenses} they need to defeat her for good. She learns about them from her @UUID[JournalEntry.FwWmtOBFHhvM2gtf.JournalEntryPage.9rMimhR27dfqSCD5]{wisp allies}, and the GM can thereafter use her whenever it creates the most tension. She should attack at least once on each dungeon level, as often as every couple of days. The GM shouldn’t have Belcorra fight alongside other creatures until the adventure’s finale—she’s tough enough on her own!

Belcorra's Tactics

@UUID[Actor.DDJGNAh3rfyIupAb]{Belcorra Haruvex}

Each time Belcorra attacks, she learns more about how the characters fight and adapts her tactics and her preparations. She might cast Globe of Invulnerability to protect her from the characters’ most effective spells, See Invisibility to keep them in sight, or Dispel Magic to counter their magical defenses. She mocks the characters for their failures and rages at their successes—remember, she’s been aware of them since her test firing of Gauntlight’s beam at Otari in @UUID[JournalEntry.uMZ0RiCcPSqsx1Nm.JournalEntryPage.Jyoads7l6vDaxZyb]{Chapter 2}.

In the Footprint: Belcorra is most effective fighting the characters who enter the Gauntlight footprint (areas @UUID[JournalEntry.FwWmtOBFHhvM2gtf.JournalEntryPage.rVwX8eSwEBHWEjcg]{H37} and @UUID[JournalEntry.1vlzl3NJsftNB9Dc.JournalEntryPage.NaEg1IQHphXU25Nk]{I28}), due to her ability to harness the ambient magic of those areas

Leveraging Agents

Belcorra has several living allies with the Abomination Vaults, including the urdefhans and the Children of Belcorra. She might send these groups after the characters, insisting they let the characters know they’re acting on Belcorra’s orders. Fortunately, neither group can muster large numbers, so an attack against the characters should be hard but manageable.

Killing Allies

Belcorra learns if the characters make alliances, such as with the calignis or the drow. She knows better than to face powerful, entrenched leaders like Galudu or Quara, but she might murder a few guards or direct monsters where they’ll do the characters’ allies the most damage. It’s important to her that she leave some evidence (usually, a single injured survivor) to let the characters know she orchestrated the attack.

First Attack

As soon as Belcorra realizes the characters’ presence, she seeks them out, traveling through the Gauntlight footprint (areas @UUID[JournalEntry.FwWmtOBFHhvM2gtf.JournalEntryPage.rVwX8eSwEBHWEjcg]{H37} and @UUID[JournalEntry.1vlzl3NJsftNB9Dc.JournalEntryPage.NaEg1IQHphXU25Nk]{I28}). She remains at a distance and casts Finger of Death before retreating, moving through walls if necessary so the characters can’t follow.

Second Attack

Belcorra wants the characters to fear her, so she approaches them more closely the second time and uses single-target spells like Finger of Death and Phantasmal Killer while demanding the characters flee her Abomination Vaults. With her message delivered, she retreats after only a few rounds.

Later Attacks

Once the characters have recovered a Fulcrum Lens or the Fulcrum Lattice, Belcorra realizes they’re an actual threat, but her anger overrides her caution. She attacks with her full might, using her Corrupting Gaze and Withering Touch attacks along with her spells. If she defeats a character, she retreats, confident that now they’ll leave her alone.

The Final Attack

If the characters defeat Belcorra shortly before they reach the Empty Vault, she uses the power of the Ebon Fulcrum Lens to hasten her rejuvenation so she can face them in her sanctum.

Belcorra doesn’t ever surrender or flee in the Empty Vault. It’s possible the characters face her there but can’t yet defeat her permanently. In this case, they’ll need to retreat to collect the Fulcrum Lenses and return to face her again. When Belcorra has been infused with two additional Fulcrum Lenses, she becomes desperate and spends a charge from the Ebon Fulcrum Lens to use the lens’s Gain Nhimbaloth’s Power property. But once the characters can focus Nhimbaloth’s gaze upon Belcorra, they can defeat the sorcerer for good.

Children of Belcorra.name: Children of Belcorra
Children of Belcorra.text:
Deep Gnome Thralls

Belcorra repurposed the massive natural caverns above the Empty Vault for her needs. The eighth level made a lush cavern of fungus growths and freshwater lakes that teemed with subterranean fish, while the ninth level was a wilderness where predators and prey alike could thrive. The characters must descend through these levels to reach the Empty Vault.

The Children of Belcorra disbelieved rumors of Belcorra’s death as some sort of trick or test and didn’t waver in their duties. However, as the years passed, more and more feral monsters made their way into the level and made their mission in the farm increasingly difficult. Believing that Belcorra (or, perhaps, some other Haruvex) would return, the Children chose to become undead to combat their dwindling numbers and increasing age. They immured each other in the muddy shore to rise again as bog mummies or undertook difficult transformations into other, more powerful, undead.

Eventually, their timeless lives and lack of direction took their toll. Many Children fell into a torpor or retreated into obsession or isolation. The farm they had carefully tended became infested with monsters and subterranean explorers, such as calignis, drow, and urdefhans.

Even Belcorra’s return as the Ghost Queen couldn’t quite energize all the Children of Belcorra to action, but many realized how much they had failed their charge. Belcorra gave the Children a new mandate: to round up the various dangerous creatures of the farm level to serve her in her assault on the surface. She placed the Children under the command of a new supervisor, a spirit naga named Vethris, but chose poorly; the naga is corrupt, lazy, and more interested in her creature comforts than guiding the deep gnome undead in their tasks. The Children of Belcorra aren’t happy with the naga’s indolence, but are reluctant to contradict their Ghost Queen. The pace of the Children’s work is, at best, plodding, and has done little to reduce the chaos in the garden.

Wisps

Although Belcorra trusts the Children—and their new overseer, Vethris—to put things in order on the Farm level, she still keeps tabs on the area. A few will-o’- wisps and dread wisps can communicate with the Empty Vault. They hover over basins filled with brackish swamp water and reeds that thrive despite the darkness, as they draw nourishment from their connection to the swamp fed by the Empty Vault. The wisps quickly inform Belcorra of any unexpected intruders, such as the characters, and Belcorra shortly thereafter makes an appearance as described in the “Belcorra Attacks!” sidebar.

The Cult of Urthagul.name: The Cult of Urthagul
The Cult of Urthagul.text:
A group of caligni refugees came to the Hunting Grounds years ago, fleeing some deeper calamity. Their two leaders—a spellcaster named Galudu and a warrior named Dulac—led them into the safety of an old lodge in the @UUID[JournalEntry.1vlzl3NJsftNB9Dc.JournalEntryPage.LYgvrg4SI95a4KqP]{Hunting Grounds} level. From there, the calignis explored upward, reaching an abandoned shrine of Nhimbaloth and eventually discovering a gug mystic named Urthagul. Urthagul laired in a cave resonating with strange psychic whispers that awed the calignis. Some of the calignis, led by Dulac, revered the gug and its eerie visions; others remained skeptical of Urthagul’s powers. This ultimately resulted in a schism: the self- named Cult of Urthagul inhabits the shrine and Galudu’s caligni reside in the lodge below. The two groups aren’t enemies, but only rarely interact.

The Cult of Urthagul has grown increasingly insular and zealous. (Urthagul, for his part, hardly even noticed their presence, much less their worship.) The calginis hunt chuul eggs from the lake, ritually cooking and consuming them as part of their strange rites. Dulac and her second-in-command, Padli, have both gained occult powers from meditating on the whispers in Urthagul’s cave, which they use to keep the cult in line.

When Belcorra awakened, she visited the shrine to Nhimbaloth and was surprised to find the calignis there. She visited with Urthagul and found that the gug’s strange behavior was not only due to the psychic emanations of the cave, but also because the gug had found the Crimson Fulcrum Lens and communed with the splinter of Nhimbaloth’s essence inside it. Belcorra realized the lens was probably safe in the gug’s claws, but she didn’t want it to end up in the hands of some interloper cult she didn’t have the time or desire to deal with. She tasked her wisp minions to keep the calignis contained within their shrine.

It frustrates the cult members to be apart from the object of their veneration. Dulac is desperate for a solution, so the characters might find the calignis eager to talk.

Upper Shaft.name: Upper Shaft
Upper Shaft.text:
A crumbling staircase leads to a cracked and badly stained mosaic tile floor. To the south, a walkway encircles a round gaping pit, leading to a spiral stairway that clings to the edge of the pit. A twisted iron banister follows the edge of the walkway and stairs. The acrid smell of chemicals and rot, with just a tinge of sulfur, waft from the darkness of the pit. Strange moaning echoes up the shaft.

The circular pit is 80 feet deep and ringed with walkways and a sweeping spiral staircase. The laboratories level is 40 feet below (@UUID[JournalEntry.KI33EAGPVHP4zyFZ.JournalEntryPage.nywKGONakrYspO83]{F01}), and the prison level is at the bottom (area @UUID[JournalEntry.OyNcqrpRClyhr8BJ.JournalEntryPage.2aDFWQZkq3nA7KPT]{G01}).

You can see a map of the complex in the @UUID[JournalEntry.jy8D1VcANmdjWuci.JournalEntryPage.9tOL2xnmCUTxjxk6]{The Abomination Vaults} handout.

Encounter

@UUID[Actor.dEAneTvoPuQXZoLR]{Gibbering Mouthers (2)} @UUID[Actor.K9Hw43co8fhwmKkM]{Grothluts (2)}

The seugathis deposited some rejected experiments here to keep them out of the way. Two Grothluts lurk around the corners, just out of sight of the stairs, and two Gibbering Mouthers sprawl on the walkway near the door leading east. They attack as soon as they detect any creatures in the area, moaning and gibbering as they do. The gibbering mouthers and grothluts are immune to the others’ Gibbering and Piteous Moan. These creatures fight until destroyed, but they don’t bother pursuing anyone who retreats up the stairs.

Large Monster Holding.name: Large Monster Holding
Large Monster Holding.text:
Rusted iron chains hang from this room’s ceiling, each ending in an oversized manacle. The octagonal eastern end of the room contains a circular pit covered by a rusted iron grate. Torn bolts and scrap metal dangle from the ceiling above the pit. Piles of scrap fill the four alcoves that open off the wide hall that constitutes the room’s west end.

A chain devil named Cratonys once prepared large monsters for fighting in the arena in this part of the dungeon. She kept them in the cells in area @UUID[JournalEntry.JT0zCcIwsSpKnbB5.JournalEntryPage.UgMnFry9Z6qFiRMX]{E3}, where she tortured them to enhance their aggressiveness and scarred them to augment their ferocious appearance using the now-rusted contraptions in the alcoves. When it came time for the creatures to fight, she lowered them into the chamber below (area @UUID[JournalEntry.KI33EAGPVHP4zyFZ.JournalEntryPage.YNHrEKfNsLjjoQhE]{F2}) using a heavy winch in the ceiling, which is now inoperable and unstable.

The characters might have met another chain devil named Vaulgrist on the level above (area @UUID[JournalEntry.Os5bHdzCDiXgJBQ6.JournalEntryPage.u6H893WYAlzxntns]{D11}). Cratonys and Vaulgrist were once as close as sisters, but each has fallen into her own malaise.

Encounter

@UUID[Actor.9Tr4aUNr2wxxMDcg]{Cratonys}

Belcorra’s magic binds Cratonys to this level, preventing the chain devil from leaving. After centuries surrounded by mindless aberrations and the twisted logic of the seugathis, she has gone feral and lost all sense of purpose. She doesn’t speak or respond to any who speak to her, but she lashes out in a desire to inflict pain. She fights from the room’s west end, using the rusty chains to strike her foes.

Vaulgrist's Whip: If any character obviously bears the silver-handled +1 Whip that once belonged to Vaulgrist, Cratonys recognizes it and appears taken aback by its presence. She doesn’t attack anyone carrying it, and anyone holding the whip can use an action to compel her to cease attack for least a few minutes; however, Cratonys doesn’t become any less violent or more prone to speak.

XP Award: If the characters get Cratonys to stand down by displaying Vaulgrist’s whip, award them [[/award 3900xp]] as though they’d defeated her in combat (if they later fight her anyway, they don’t gain additional XP for doing so).

Rusty Grate Pit

The rusty grate collapses as soon as any significant weight is placed upon it. It covers a pit 10 feet in diameter and 40 feet deep. A creature that walks on the grate falls in, and the rusted remains of the dangling winch mechanism follow moments later.

This acts as a 40-foot-deep pit trap. A character can identify the danger with a successful [[/check ability=intelligence dc=10]] check using either the Investigation skill or Smith’s Tools. The triggering creature must, in addition to taking the standard falling damage, attempt a [[/save dexterity dc=15]] saving throw to avoid the falling winch, taking [[/damage 4d10 bludgeoning average]] damage on a failed save or half as much damage on a successful one. Once the trap is triggered, the space into which the winch fell becomes Difficult Terrain. Climbing out of the pit requires a successful [[/skill athletics dc=15]] check.

A character can disable or trigger the trap without falling in by making a successful [[/check ability=dexterity dc=13]] check using Thieves’ Tools or a [[/check ability=dexterity dc=18]] check using Smith’s Tools. On a failed check, the character triggers the trap and must make a successful [[/save dexterity dc=15]] saving throw or fall into the pit, as above.

XP Award: Award the party [[/award 450xp]] for disabling the trap.

Macro: You can use the @Macro[gIgpTvv98hOMoBqU]{E2 - Rusty Grate} macro to reflect the collapse of the grate.

Monster Holding.name: Monster Holding
Monster Holding.text:
Three cells line the south wall, their bars only a few inches apart. Each cell contains a heap of rotted flesh and shattered bone.

The old locks on these cell doors have all seized shut. A character can force open a lock with a successful DC 15 Strength check or disable a lock’s jammed mechanism with a successful [[/check ability=dexterity dc=15]] check using Thieves’ Tools.

The center cell holds the only item of interest: a @Item[MeAZ2aziPTME3UlI]{Copper Key} that glitters within the fleshy muck. The creature in the cell consumed this spare key to the locked supply room (area @UUID[.bsvsBLUT905lHxD8]{E11}) decades ago, but it couldn’t digest copper.

Encounter

@UUID[Actor.qXT1SQDtGqMkVl7Q]{Shanrigol Heaps (3)}

Within each of the three holding cells, the fleshy detritus has coalesced into a strange creature called a shanrigol, a nearly mindless amalgamation of undeath and twitching life. These three Shanrigol Heaps remain motionless until one of them is disturbed, at which point they all slither forward to attack. The shanrigols don’t need to open the cell doors to get out, as they can ooze between the bars with their Undulating Step. They pursue the characters as best they can and fight until destroyed.

Surgical Suite.name: Surgical Suite
Surgical Suite.text:
Lanterns hanging from the ceiling shine bright circles of light over three stone tables topped with metal slabs. A single lightweight chain dangles near each table. The remnants of a dead morlock lie on one of the tables. Dried splatters of blood cover the walls, floor, and ceiling.

The three lights in this room are magical; they illuminate the tables with Bright Light but provide only Dim Light to the rest of the room. The metal slabs at the top of each table are hinged on the sides. A tug on the hanging pull-chain causes the table’s hinged slabs to fold down then back up, dumping anything on the table into a 40-foot-deep shaft to area @UUID[JournalEntry.KI33EAGPVHP4zyFZ.JournalEntryPage.sGI8w7LQqXuwWhHp]{F6}. The slabs easily fold down from the underside, so anyone climbing up a shaft can open the slab and get out. Climbing out of a pit requires a successful [[/check skill=athletics dc=15]] check.

Jafaki previously used this chamber for fleshwarping trials, dumping failed experiments into the pits for the oozes below to devour. He eventually considered this location too inconvenient and practically never uses it anymore.

Encounter

@UUID[Actor.mmWraith00000000]{Wraith}, @UUID[Actor.HNEUSYnInffvGPHK]{Specter}

The last time Jafaki was here, he abandoned a morlock whose arms and legs he’d amputated (and disposed of). The creature died in agony, and its spirit arose as a Small Wraith. The wraith wants only to inflict pain upon others and managed to kill another hapless morlock, who had attempted to escape from other experiments conducted in this location; the second morlock has since risen as a Specter. Both undead still harbor a visceral fear of the operating tables, and the Bright Light shining on the tables activate their Sunlight Sensitivity and Weakness.

Down the Chute

@Macro[0wqqMuak5NsI94E7]{E04 - Surgical Suite}

You can toggle the Teleportation Region with the above macro in a single click.

Medical Supplies.name: Medical Supplies
Medical Supplies.text:
Shelves of dusty bottles and surgical equipment line the walls in this room. Cobwebs and dust hint that this chamber remained untouched for quite some time. At the center of the room stands a solitary pushcart.

Jafaki kept spare parts, alchemical reagents, and surgical tools organized in this room. The seugathi hasn’t visited it in decades, so most of the alchemical reagents have spoiled.

Treasure

@Item[XMNqir7oUGoFemFM]{Round Key} @UUID[Item.wRjDOaAP2OcJSfFX]{Medical Supplies}

A character who searches this room and succeeds on a [[/check skill=intelligence (investigation) dc=10]] check locates an unusual key that fell behind one of the shelves. The key has a round shaft tipped with several teeth of varying lengths; it opens one of the locks in the plinth room (area @UUID[JournalEntry.KI33EAGPVHP4zyFZ.JournalEntryPage.4DSWkmCkIZ8iD20I]{F07}).

The shelves contain two Healer’s Kits, a Herbalism Kit, a Potion of Greater Healing, and preserved herbs worth [[/award 400gp]]. The herbs can be used as raw materials to craft potions and elixirs.

Hallway.name: Hallway
Hallway.text:
A steep staircase descends underneath a footbridge that crosses this hall at 20 feet above the ground. The double doors to the south are barricaded from this side with several bars of twisted metal scrap and a sturdy wooden shelf. The footbridge has a low railing of wrought iron preventing anyone on it from easily falling off. With a successful [[/skill 15 ath]] check, a character can climb up onto (or down from) the footbridge.

Under or Over?

@Macro[m5Crw7ba08oqJdXc]{E06 - Bridge}

Depending on whether your players are approaching from the upper or lower levels, you'll want the bridge to be above their heads or beneath their feet.

You can toggle between the two bridge states with the above macro in a single click.

Security Checkpoint.name: Security Checkpoint
Security Checkpoint.text:
The characters might have some difficulty reaching this area from the east since a closed portcullis flanked by arrow slits blocks the hall, but a character can lift this portcullis with a successful [[/check skill=athletics dc=24]] check. Some of the bars near the north arrow slit have been partially melted and twisted, perhaps by powerful acid. A Small or smaller creature can squeeze through the opening with a successful [[/check skill=acrobatics dc=13]] check, but the opening is too small for larger creatures.

This central octagonal room is flanked on the north and south by single iron doors, each with a narrow viewing port and archery slit. The stone double door to the east features an emblazoned carving of a dripping skull, its mouth stuffed with weeds. The western double door is made of iron pitted with rust.

This area acted as a gateway for Belcorra’s scouts to go out into the world and as an egress point for her army of well-trained champions. The double door to the west leads underground, eventually terminating at a cave-in behind the well-hidden secret door in @UUID[JournalEntry.JT0zCcIwsSpKnbB5.JournalEntryPage.DzqE7ZmPnygrbe34]{Smuggler’s Refuge}. The cave-in and secret door are obvious from this side. Clearing the cave-in requires 40 hours of manual labor, but the characters can divide this time up (five characters can clear it in 8 hours, for example). Once the route is clear, it allows the party to come and go more easily from Otari.

Encounter

@UUID[Actor.OErk9kO3PhYwMXoJ]{Siora Fallowglade}

Belcorra’s chief assassin, Siora Fallowglade, tried to flee the Abomination Vaults during the chaos following Belcorra’s death. She murdered the three guards stationed here to hide the evidence of her flight, but one guard managed to inflict a mortal wound. Siora died before reaching the other end of the tunnel.

At Belcorra’s death, a surge of spiritual energy swept through this area, tethering Siora’s soul to this area as a Shadow Assassin.
