Eager to create minions to serve her, Siora focuses on one enemy at a time to steal away its shadow. Siora retreats if badly injured, but only to set up an ambush later. She’s a vicious and implacable foe who continues her attacks until she’s destroyed.

Exploration

The two guard chambers (areas E7a and E7c) and archer stations (areas E7b and E7d) were looted centuries ago but still bear empty weapon racks.

The east wall in area E7b has a lever that raises and lowers the portcullis. Although rusty, it still works. Any creature squeezing past the gap in the portcullis can see the lever in the archer station.

Area E7c has a secret door in its west wall that opens by manipulating a hook on the room’s weapon rack. With a successful [[/check skill=investigation dc=15]] check, a character searching this room can locate the door and identify the hook that opens it.

A set of @UUID[Compendium.dnd5e.items.Item.qRMQH8lRE42JkugE]{Mithral Half Plate} fell behind a dusty weapon rack in area E7d. Any character who searches the area finds it automatically, as does anyone who succeeds on a [[/check skill=perception dc=13]] check.

Assassin’s Quarters.name: Assassin’s Quarters
Assassin’s Quarters.text:
The secret doors providing entrance to this room—one at the end of the hall that leads north and another at the end of the hall that leads south—are both obvious from this side.

Dust and neglect cover this chamber’s narrow bed, warped wooden wardrobe, and large footlocker.

Siora Fallowglade once lived here, but no one has come here since her death centuries ago. The bedding and clothing have all decayed into threadbare scraps.

Treasure

@UUID[Item.bfehz6DAj2FKC6hV]{Siora's Footlocker}

The footlocker contains a wide-brimmed red hat with a large black feather (a Hat of Disguise), a pouch of emeralds worth a total of [[/award 750gp]], and Siora’s poison codex. This book contains instructions to create the following poisons: Assassin’s Blood, Burnt Othur Fumes, Stupor Poison, and Truth Serum. The book is exceedingly fragile; the first time a creature opens it, that creature must make a successful [[/check skill=sleightOfHand dc=14]] check or some of the pages disintegrate, destroying the instructions for Stupor Poison (the characters might still be able to find instructions for this poison among the drow living deeper in the Abomination Vaults, however). Consulting the book thereafter doesn’t risk further disintegration unless the handler is intentionally careless.

Morlibint isn’t interested in this book due to its subject matter, and indeed it’s illegal for anyone to buy such a text; if the party has the support of Crook’s Nook, then Yinyasmera will purchase the book for [[/award 500gp]] if all four formulas are intact, or for 400 GP if only three are.

Elite Viewing Room.name: Elite Viewing Room
Elite Viewing Room.text:
The curved east and west walls of this room contain tables with small, built-in ovens. Wood fragments, heavily dented pewter serving dishes, silver flatware, and crystal shrapnel litter the floor. A wide alcove to the south ends at a cloudy window overlooking a much larger space. An array of magical glyphs glows next to the window.

This elegant meeting room is where Belcorra’s guests watched arena matches and enjoyed food cooked in the kitchen below (and later kept warm in the ovens).

Most of the debris scattered over the floor is worthless, but it creates Difficult Terrain across the entire room. The staircase leading down to the Warped Brew Tavern (area @UUID[JournalEntry.KI33EAGPVHP4zyFZ.JournalEntryPage.ad2vkPdR6V7Jxymf]{F11}) is so choked with trash that it’s particularly hazardous. In addition to being Difficult Terrain, a creature that moves more than 10 feet on the stairs on a turn must succeed at a [[/check skill=acrobatics dc=13]] check or fall Prone.

The south wall overlooking the arena (area @UUID[JournalEntry.JT0zCcIwsSpKnbB5.JournalEntryPage.gPJ4Hrw4cAGuyDqT]{E26}) isn’t glass, but transparent stone. The glyphs on the wall control the magic infused in this stone. A character who investigates the glyphs and makes a successful [[/check skill=arcana dc=15]] check understands how to use them. A creature manipulating the glyphs can make the wall ethereal (it still resembles transparent stone, but creatures and objects can pass through it), render it opaque, or change it back to transparent stone.

Encounter

@UUID[Actor.FymKMQ5OHmf6PRKk]{Squabbling Poltergeists (2)}

When Belcorra died, two of her guests—a pair of squabbling aristocrat siblings— let their fear of being trapped in the Abomination Vaults overwhelm them. They murdered each other in a panicked rage and arose as Poltergeists. Their hurled accusations against each other invariably escalate into hurled debris, and these frequent rages produced the debris throughout this room. The poltergeists put their differences aside to fight intruders but soon fall back into their endless squabbling if the characters retreat. As they fight, they mutter phrases like “can’t get out” and “trapped here forever.” They fight until destroyed.

Treasure

@UUID[Compendium.dnd5e.equipment24.Item.dmgRingOfMindShi]{Ring of Mind Shielding}

Hidden among the debris is a dented, lead-lined steel box. A character must succeed on a [[/check thief dex dc=20]] to disable the jammed mechanism that keeps it shut. No amount of force can get the box open; the poltergeists have been hurling it about for centuries already. It holds a Ring of Mind Shielding with the symbol of Norgorber, evil god of poisons and secrets, inscribed upon it.

Side Quest

The characters likely consider the ghosts’ ramblings to be threats, but these mutterings hold the key to putting the spirits permanently to rest. Anyone who responds to the ghosts, even during combat, might get them to expand upon their worries with statements like “We have no way out of the arena!” or “There’s no path to escape!” If the party establishes a clear exit path of open doors that leads to the surface and then describe this path to the ghosts, they immediately cease their attacks, concentrate on the avenue of escape the characters describe, and vanish for good.

XP Award: Award the characters [[/award 1000xp]] for putting the ghosts to rest properly, in addition to the XP for defeating them.

Grand Concourse.name: Grand Concourse
Grand Concourse.text:
Under or Over?

@Macro[mUYq876BrjHngmni]{E10 - Bridge}

Depending on whether your players are approaching from the upper or lower levels, you'll want the bridge to be above their heads or beneath their feet.

You can toggle between the two bridge states with the above macro in a single click.

This stately hallway stretches from a single door to the north to a wide exit to the south. Frescoes depicting powerful creatures in battle with each other adorn the walls. Pinpoints of light glimmer in the vaulted ceiling, illuminating the hallway with a pale radiance. Balconies 20 feet above the floor run the length of the hallway, their low railings rusty and twisted in places. A stone bridge connects the balconies across the hallways to each other, providing access to the tunnels out of the hallway to the east and west from the balcony. Several badly damaged statues decorate the south end of the hall.

The vaulted ceiling reaches 20 feet over the balconies and 40 feet over the ground level. The pinpoints of light are irregularly spaced and at first appear to replicate stars in the night sky. A character proficient in Nature realizes that the lights are unlike the night sky from anywhere on the surface of Golarion and instead represent what the night sky looks like on some incredibly distant world.

Exploration

Characters must make a successful [[/check skill=athletics dc=15]] check to climb up onto (or safely climb down from) the footbridge.

A secret door on the eastern balcony is difficult to spot. A character who succeeds on a DC 20 Intelligence (Arcana or Investigation) check locates it, and they also determine the special series of knocks that turns the door ghostly and incorporeal, allowing the characters to pass through. Its magical aura can’t be detected using @UUID[Compendium.dnd5e.spells24.Item.phbsplDetectMagi]{Detect Magic}, as its magic is obscured by a permanent @UUID[Compendium.dnd5e.spells24.Item.phbsplNystulsMag]{Arcanist’s Magic Aura} spell.

Most of the statues at the south end of the hall resemble exceptionally lifelike fleshwarp creatures, such as grothluts, driders, and mulventoks. All have been toppled, and most have been partially eaten. Two statues remain in reasonable condition, as described in “Restoring the Statues,” below.

Treasure: The equipment here is too damaged to be useful, save for the urdefhan’s +1 Tamchal Chakram, which fell from his grasp as he was petrified and is pinned mostly underneath him. Anyone who searches the room finds it immediately, but characters merely scanning the room only notice it with a successful [[/check skill=perception dc=17]] check. The characters can recover this weapon if they restore the smaller statue, destroy the statue, or shift it aside with a successful [[/check ability=strength dc=20]] check.

Encounter

@UUID[Actor.rPHxXClTnoPYHYuZ]{Basilisks (2)}

A mated pair of Basilisks have a nest at the south end of this hall. The seugathis occasionally send a fleshwarped creature to clear them out, or a creature wandering through the area crosses their path. All have thus far fallen to the basilisks’ petrifying gaze. When the characters arrive, the basilisks lurk amid the statues of their victims. They viciously guard their territory but don’t pursue foes who flee.

Restoring the Statues

All but two of the statues are too damaged to be restored (such as by a @UUID[Compendium.dnd5e.spells24.Item.phbsplGreaterRes]{Greater Restoration} spell or by other means available to the party). These two statues both appear to be pale, vampire-like humanoids known as urdefhans, but one is far more muscular than the other and looks ready to explode from its muscular swelling. The larger creature is a type of fleshwarp called a @UUID[Actor.zsgW8hHm3JfZUgwF]{mulventok}. The mulventok lost its connection to the inherent purpose that drives its actions when it became petrified and, if restored, simply attacks in a frenzy until slain. If the characters restore the smaller urdefhan, he shouts, “Warlord Khurfel! Belcorra has need of the eye!” in Undercommon. Then he screams in pain from his internal injuries and dies.

Locked Supply Room.name: Locked Supply Room
Locked Supply Room.text:
Both doors leading into this room are locked. A character without the key (Jafaki carries one; the other is in the debris in area @UUID[JournalEntry.JT0zCcIwsSpKnbB5.JournalEntryPage.UgMnFry9Z6qFiRMX]{E3}) can force open each door with a successful [[/check skill=athletics dc=20]] check or pick a door’s lock with a successful [[/check dex thief dc=20]].

This room’s shelves are well stocked with jars of preserved organs, crates filled with bones wrapped in rags, and surgical tools. Two armor stands flank a weapon rack to the south, upon which hangs a small leather pouch.

Belcorra’s quartermaster once stored valuable supplies here—usually armor and weapons. All were removed in the chaos following Belcorra’s death, and this room sat empty for a long time. Jafaki recently discovered a key and decided to repurpose this room to store spare parts for his experiments as well as magical equipment he doesn’t need. He only visits the room every several months, as needed.

Treasure

@UUID[Item.kRv72waArUJbVkiR]{Supply Room Shelves}

The shelves here contain a Healer’s Kit, an Herbalism Kit, two Antitoxins, and two doses of Crawler Mucus. The leather pouch on the weapon rack contains an Ichthyosis Mutagen and a Potion of Stone Giant Strength.

Sentencing Chamber.name: Sentencing Chamber
Sentencing Chamber.text:
The floor of this room contains several open square pits: one in each of the three alcoves to the north and two larger pits in the middle of the room. A dais at the room’s west end contains a stone throne with two rusty levers jutting from the floor next to it.

In Belcorra’s day, prisoners were brought to this room for the sorcerer to pronounce judgment against them. Nearly always, this judgment involved feeding them to the hydras below. The two levers correspond to the two pits; each lever once released the supports on a false stone trapdoor, dropping anyone standing on it into the water 55 feet below (area @UUID[JournalEntry.KI33EAGPVHP4zyFZ.JournalEntryPage.f7dzsMJc3BAy82zr]{F4}). The hinges to the trapdoor long ago broke away, and the fallen trapdoors now rest at the bottom of the pool below. The rusted levers are currently useless.

The pits in the alcoves never had trapdoors; they simply drop into the water below and were used to dispose of multiple creatures in quick succession. The pits are narrow enough that a Medium creature that falls into them can uses its Reaction to grab the edge of the pit and arrest its fall automatically. Climbing the walls of these pits requires a [[/check skill=athletics dc=15]] check.

A character who falls into a pit and doesn’t arrest their fall lands in area @UUID[JournalEntry.KI33EAGPVHP4zyFZ.JournalEntryPage.f7dzsMJc3BAy82zr]{F4}, awakening the hydra there and potentially getting into a very tough fight. If a gibtas falls into a pit, it briefly fights with the hydra under the water, biting off a head and cauterizing the stump with its acidic saliva before being ripped to pieces by the hydra’s other heads. The heroes likely see only roiling water followed by a cloud of green blood and pieces of the gibtas’s corpse floating to the surface.

Encounter

@UUID[Actor.BJYrYqkV7PkXgSfk]{Gibtas Bounders (3)}

Jafaki trapped three Gibtas Bounders in this room; his efforts to mutate or train them were ineffective, so he’s given up on them for the time being. The gibtas bounders often snap at each other, attempting to assert dominance, but they’re usually skulking in separate parts of the room. They attack intruders, but they don’t coordinate tactics and are just as likely to snap at each other as the characters. They aren’t bright but are smart enough to avoid the pits. A gibtas reduced to fewer than 40 Hit Points realizes its opponents are very dangerous and starts trying to knock them into the pits with its Bouncing Slam.

Treasure

@UUID[Item.0It7AWrS1OoxL86x]{Throne Compartment}

The stone throne contains a secret compartment in the back. A character who searches the throne and makes a successful [[/check skill=investigation dc=13]] check finds the compartment and its contents: [[/award 131pp]], a mithral diadem depicting a mossy skull with emerald eyes (worth [[/award 750gp]]), and a Spell Scroll of Detect Thoughts.

Gladiator Readiness Room.name: Gladiator Readiness Room
Gladiator Readiness Room.text:
Weapon racks stand in the northeast and southeast corners of this room. The southeast rack is empty, but the northeast rack holds a hatchet made of dark crystal. Two alcoves between the racks on the eastern wall each have an open hatch and a ladder leading down. Additional exits lead out to the north, west, and south.

Gladiators readied themselves for aquatic battles in this room, climbing down the ladders to the shallows in the pool below. The exit to the north leads to a supply closet; the door fell off the hinges decades ago, and a mimic has taken the door’s place. The weapon rack with the hatchet is another mimic; the hatchet is merely part of its camouflage.

The hatches leading down into the water below (area @UUID[JournalEntry.KI33EAGPVHP4zyFZ.JournalEntryPage.f7dzsMJc3BAy82zr]{F4}) are open. Several of the ladder rungs are missing, so a character must succeed on a [[/check skill=athletics dc=8]] check to climb either ladder without falling.

Encounter

@UUID[Actor.Br1AtKUHe3nbzjnY]{Mimics (2)}

A pair of Mimics recently entered this room. One settled down in the northeast corner, disguising itself as a weapon rack identical to the one in the southeast corner. The second mimic wedged itself into the northern door frame, disguising itself as the door that collapsed inward into the storage closet.

Treasure

@UUID[Compendium.dnd5e.equipment24.Item.dmgPotionOfWater]{Potions of Water Breathing (2)}, @UUID[Compendium.dnd5e.equipment24.Item.dmgDecanterOfEnd]{Decanter of Endless Water}

Shattered jars fill the supply room in the north. Among the debris, the characters can discover two intact Potions of Water Breathing and a Decanter of Endless Water.

Lounge.name: Lounge
Lounge.text:
A counter wrapped around the northern and northeastern walls bears only a few cracked serving dishes. A dusty and broken display case contains only grime and glass.

Exploration

This room once hosted gladiators looking to compete in the pits, where they fought to eventually become leaders of Belcorra’s army. A character who searches the display case finds the words “They Are Watching You” carved into one of its wooden sides. Anyone examining this carving can attempt a [[/check skill=invesstigation dc=15]] check to realize that the words are near a hidden hinge; the entire case swings aside as a secret door.

Waiting Room.name: Waiting Room
Waiting Room.text:
Padded furniture has blossomed into mounds of white fungus in this small waiting room.

Tiny fungal spores drift throughout this room.

Fungal Rot

Hazard

For each minute a creature spends in this room with any amount of exposed skin, that creature risks contracting fungal rot.

This fast-acting fungal infection causes tiny spores to take root under the skin and blossom in the lungs or in the bloodstream. A character who succeeds on a [[/check skill=nature dc=17]] check realizes the danger the spores pose and that limiting time in the room to less than a minute is the safest way to prevent exposure.

Fungal Rot: A Beast or Humanoid that spends at least 1 minute breathing the fungal spores or with any skin exposed to the air where the spores float must succeed on a [[/save ability=constitution dc=15]] saving throw or become infected with a magical contagion called Fungal Rot. The contagion’s symptoms manifest after 1 hour, at which time the creature becomes easily winded and sluggish. While infected, the creature has Disadvantage on Dexterity checks, and its Speed is reduced by 5 feet.

Each time the infected creature finishes a Long Rest, it makes a [[/save ability=constitution dc=17]] saving throw. On a failed save, the creature’s Speed is reduced by an additional 5 feet. A creature whose Speed is reduced to 0 feet has the Unconscious condition and dies if it fails another saving throw against the contagion. On a success, the creature’s Speed increases by 5 feet. If a successful saving throw restores the creature’s Speed to its full value, the creature recovers from the contagion.

Treasure

@Item[obMfB2T7o4z6WICq]

In the cushions of the sofa are 26 assorted gold pieces, minted in Absalom centuries ago by a long-shuttered mint. They’re worth [[/award 40gp]] each to a collector.

Administrator’s Antechamber.name: Administrator’s Antechamber
Administrator’s Antechamber.text:
This sitting room glows from the light of a fire, crackling pleasantly in a web-choked fireplace on the east wall. A large divan has been pushed up against the door to the northwest. Several pitons have been pounded into the gap between the stone door and its frame to ensure it remains firmly shut.

The magic that sustains this fire has lasted centuries. Several harmless spiders inhabit the fireplace and have filled it with their webs over the years because the light attracts insects.

Removing the divan from the door is simple enough, but the characters must spend 10 minutes with a crowbar or similar tool to pry the pitons out of the door to open it. The door’s stone is magically enhanced and difficult to smash through. A character can force it open with a successful [[/check ability=strength dc=25]] check. The DC drops to 22 if the iron spikes are removed. The party’s attempts to bypass the door using magic fail due to protections placed upon the room beyond (area @UUID[JournalEntry.JT0zCcIwsSpKnbB5.JournalEntryPage.5XJBjPHU2XkIZWtN]{E17}).

Imprisoned Administrator.name: Imprisoned Administrator
Imprisoned Administrator.text:
This room’s occupant placed magical defenses on the room to prevent teleportation effects or ethereal travel from accessing it.

A glowing circle of runes covers the floor in this chamber. Parchment covered with cramped writing sits on a desk situated against the north wall, and the splintered remains of a bed are piled in a corner.

In the chaos following Belcorra’s fall, someone locked the arena administrator, Chafkhem, in his room. As Chafkhem had previously warded his room against interdimensional travel, he was effectively imprisoned. Before he succumbed to starvation, the erudite wizard cobbled together reagents to mummify himself with parchment paper, hoping to one day escape his bounds and inflict revenge on Jafaki, whom Chafkhem believed ordered his imprisonment.

In his isolation, Chafkhem has attempted to devise a means of escape by creating a temporary portal through the wall. A simple mistake in his assumptions has caused all his calculations to be incorrect, and he has failed to get the spell to work—a point of much frustration to the vainglorious man.

Encounter

@UUID[Actor.x0NDgH3EMLTLh02r]{Chafkhem}

When the characters unseal his chamber, Chafkhem holds up his parchment- wrapped arms to show he means no harm. He’s genuinely thankful for his release and quite charming by nature. Unfortunately, he’s as bossy in undeath as he was in life, and he soon starts demanding, rather than requesting, information from the party about the current status of the seugathis and the Abomination Vaults. If the characters don’t indulge Chafkhem, he decides to kill them and animate them as undead who don’t talk back nearly as much.

The magic circle in the center of the room assists Chafkhem with maintaining magical energy. The circle allows him to maintain Concentration on two spells at once. If he leaves the circle or casts a spell that requires Concentration while he already concentrates on two spells, his Concentration on one previous spell of his choice ends.

Side Quest

As long as the characters obey Chafkhem’s demands and suffer his imperious demeanor, he can be a font of information. His initial attitude toward the characters is Indifferent, but they can improve it with a successful [[/check skill=persuasion dc=19]] check.

Chafkem's Information

If the party gets on Chafkhem’s good side, he speaks with open contempt about the seugathis that Belcorra permitted to operate in the fleshwarping laboratory on the next lower level, as they displaced arena functions Chafkhem controlled. He doesn’t know precisely how many seugathis there are, but he describes their leader as an alchemist and fleshwarper named Jafaki, whom he blames for locking him in his room to die several centuries ago. Chafkhem wants revenge against Jafaki, and he suggests that the characters should seek this vengeance on his behalf.

Chafkhem knows Belcorra is long dead, although he expresses concern if the characters let him know she has returned as an undead creature. Chafkhem makes plans to vacate the Abomination Vaults and return to his native Osirion; whether the heroes want to simply let an evil mummy go free is up to them.

Killing Jafaki

Chafkhem takes [[/r 2d4]] days to put his papers in order and carefully replicate the arcane patterns of his magic circle before he leaves. If the characters return in that time with proof that they’ve slain Jafaki or that the imp Szek orchestrated Chafkhem’s imprisonment (which is the truth), the mummy expresses his gratitude and rewards them with information. He sketches out the entirety of the Arena level for them, including all its secret doors and passages, and provides the characters with the magical passphrase to disable the trap in area @UUID[JournalEntry.JT0zCcIwsSpKnbB5.JournalEntryPage.SeCEB4alINSAplfd]{E20}. He doesn’t have any blank parchment, so he writes on his spellbook pages containing @UUID[Compendium.dnd-abomination-vaults.av-items-5e.Item.ackI4Fz5EL0vpMVs]{Sage’s Curse}; the characters can later learn the spell from those pages, in addition to having the useful map.

XP Award: If the characters learn all Chafkhem has to tell them, award them 1,000 XP.

Treasure

Chafkhem’s desk contains the key to area @UUID[JournalEntry.JT0zCcIwsSpKnbB5.JournalEntryPage.LJhOoRqYjj38YWl8]{E18} and hundreds of pieces of parchment with writing covering every bit of space. The papers function as Chafkhem’s spellbook. They contain all the spells in his stat block, as well as Arcane Lock, Animate Dead, Awaken Portal, Create Undead, Glyph of Warding, Mage Armor, and Private Sanctum. He also carries a Staff of Swarming Insects.

Level 5 Portal Chamber.name: Level 5 Portal Chamber
Level 5 Portal Chamber.text:
Teleportation Network

Some of the @UUID[Compendium.dnd5e.spells24.Item.phbsplTeleportat]{Teleportation Circles} within the Abomination Vaults form a part of a larger network. By tracing specific patterns on the wall runes, someone could transport everyone in any one of these chambers to one of nine other portal chambers in the Abomination Vaults- so long as the teleportation circles in both the departure chamber and destination have been awakened by the @UUID[Compendium.dnd-abomination-vaults.av-items-5e.Item.H0KYIrtDeeV2pSyC]{Awaken Portal} ritual (area @UUID[JournalEntry.KeWKr2yd8dbppeS5.JournalEntryPage.8X4xF40k06MW0X7q]{C35}).

The nine chambers are areas @UUID[JournalEntry.uMZ0RiCcPSqsx1Nm.JournalEntryPage.537bzfVUpq6XbR9a]{B17}, @UUID[JournalEntry.KeWKr2yd8dbppeS5.JournalEntryPage.vEiow4kU961XNOJp]{C16}, @UUID[JournalEntry.Os5bHdzCDiXgJBQ6.JournalEntryPage.RJf3BCpcVW6d68s7]{D05}, @UUID[JournalEntry.JT0zCcIwsSpKnbB5.JournalEntryPage.LJhOoRqYjj38YWl8]{E18}, @UUID[JournalEntry.KI33EAGPVHP4zyFZ.JournalEntryPage.mDFVGUXY6YDuQWF3]{F13}, @UUID[JournalEntry.OyNcqrpRClyhr8BJ.JournalEntryPage.zTpatmyyb4JvgNCo]{G02}, @UUID[JournalEntry.FwWmtOBFHhvM2gtf.JournalEntryPage.Nak2hUmVOHXBkcR5]{H33}, @UUID[JournalEntry.1vlzl3NJsftNB9Dc.JournalEntryPage.DJKWR2KLTPUi3w6T]{I59}, and @UUID[JournalEntry.yn21bNM6kpV4xRol.JournalEntryPage.JinYTJeYVFBE1uky]{J05}

The door to this room is locked, and Chafkhem has the only key. A character can force open the door with a successful [[/check ability=strength dc=25]] check or pick the lock with a successful [[/check ability=dexterity dc=25]] check using Thieves’ Tools.

Swirling runes carved into the stone and filled with silver cover the walls of this circular chamber. The floor is polished smooth, as is the ceiling ten feet above.

This room contains yet another inactive Teleportation Circle that the characters can connect to others they’ve already encountered. The characters might have begun restoring the network if they discovered the Awaken Portal spell in the upper levels, though if they didn’t find this spell there, they can find it in Chafkhem’s notes in area @UUID[JournalEntry.JT0zCcIwsSpKnbB5.JournalEntryPage.5XJBjPHU2XkIZWtN]{E17}.

XP Award: Award the characters [[/award 500xp]] for using the Awaken Portal spell to reactivate the magic portal in this room.

Spying Chamber.name: Spying Chamber
Spying Chamber.text:
This unadorned room’s most notable feature is the secret door that leads to the grand concourse (area @UUID[JournalEntry.JT0zCcIwsSpKnbB5.JournalEntryPage.DKiYbkAmfzGL3UgV]{E10}). The secret door isn’t obvious from this side, so a character must succeed on a [[/check skill=arcana/investigation dc=18]] check to locate it. A character who knows the series of knocks that opens the door in the grand concourse can also open the secret door from this side, making the door ghostly and incorporeal.

A window of one-way transparent stone allows anyone within this room to view events in the grand concourse. The stone is opaque from the concourse side, and the window is undetectable. Anyone touching the transparent stone from this side can hear anything in the concourse through a permanent @UUID[Compendium.dnd5e.spells24.Item.phbsplClairvoyan]{Clairvoyance} effect.

Secret Hallway.name: Secret Hallway
Secret Hallway.text:
Bones and dismembered limbs lie scattered throughout this irregular, branching hallway.

Belcorra and Chafkhem spied on gladiators from this secret hall, paranoid about insurrection from within the ranks of their powerful warriors. They activated a deadly trap to protect the hall from intruders when they weren’t present. The severed limbs are those of seugathis, skulks, and several fleshwarped creatures who tried and failed to contend with the trap over the past several years.

The jagged halls contain several blocks of one- way transparent stone peering into the gladiators’ quarters. The stone is opaque from within the rooms and can’t be detected. Anyone touching a transparent stone from this side can hear in the room through a permanent Clairvoyance effect.

The two secret doors in this branching hall (leading to areas @UUID[.FwUjauqbfGI6Fu0b]{E14} and @UUID[.lOKp958Fy3lwvV66]{E24}) are obvious from this side.

Shuffling Scythe Blades

Hazard

Six long blades, hidden in grooves in the walls and floor, zigzag through different parts of this hallway when any pressure plate in the hallway intersection is depressed. The blades retreat into the floor and move through the hidden grooves before swinging out again in a different location.

The 15-foot-by-25-foot area where the branching hallways connect contains dozens of pressure plates that trigger the trap; there aren’t pressure plates in any of the three narrow halls. A character can spot one of the pressure plates and the incredibly fine grooves between many of the nearby stones with a successful [[/check skill=perception dc=23]] check. With a successful [[/check skill=investigation dc=18]] check, a character deduces that the pressure plate causes something to emerge from the walls, but it’s impossible to deduce where, as there are dozens of suitable grooves that branch and connect.

A creature that speaks the magical passphrase (which Chafkhem still knows) upon entering the 15-foot-by-25- foot intersection of area @UUID[JournalEntry.JT0zCcIwsSpKnbB5.JournalEntryPage.SeCEB4alINSAplfd]{E20} doesn’t trigger the trap. Otherwise, a creature that steps anywhere in that area depresses a pressure plate and activates the trap.

When the trap triggers, roll Initiative. The trap rolls Initiative with a +5 bonus to its roll. On each of the trap’s turns, each of its six blades makes an attack with a [[/+9 bonus against every creature in its region. For each of the trap’s six blades, roll [[/r 1d4]] to determine the region where that blade appears.

  • 1. Main intersection (the 15-foot-by-25-foot intersection where the hallways connect)

  • 2. North branch (from the intersection to the secret door to area @UUID[JournalEntry.JT0zCcIwsSpKnbB5.JournalEntryPage.FwUjauqbfGI6Fu0b]{E14})

  • 3. Central hall (from the intersection to the secret door to area @UUID[JournalEntry.JT0zCcIwsSpKnbB5.JournalEntryPage.lOKp958Fy3lwvV66]{E24})

  • 4. South branch (from the intersection to the wall shared with area @UUID[JournalEntry.JT0zCcIwsSpKnbB5.JournalEntryPage.xVfdltaZZguZ35F1]{E25})

On a hit, the target takes [[/damage 2d6 + 4 type=slashing average]] damage. All blades then retract and shuffle positions.

As an action, a character can attempt a [[/check skill=perception dc=17]] check to deduce how many blades will appear in its region on the trap’s next turn. A character in the main intersection can attempt a [[/check dex thief dc=21]] check to disable the trap’s numerous pressure plates. Each success deactivates one of the trap’s blades. A character can also take the Ready action to attack a blade as it emerges in their region. Each blade has AC 20, 17 Hit Points, Resistance to Piercing and Slashing damage, and Immunity to Bludgeoning, Poison and Psychic damage.

The trap resets and can trigger again when it starts its turn with no creatures in area @UUID[JournalEntry.JT0zCcIwsSpKnbB5.JournalEntryPage.SeCEB4alINSAplfd]{E20}.

XP Award: Award the characters [[/award 850xp]] for each blade they destroy or disable (up to [[/award 5100xp]] total).

Staging Area.name: Staging Area
Staging Area.text:
Large, dark discolorations of dried fluids adorn the floor of this oddly shaped chamber. A stone desk stands against the west wall and holds tools, bottles, and jars of a variety of substances.

Here, Belcorra’s agents kept notes about the gladiators they spied upon. Recently, Jafaki’s minions have spent a good amount of time and resources trying to disable the scythe trap in the hallway to the north, and they stage their attempts here. Parchment marked with tick marks indicates how the blades shuffle around the secret hallway when triggered. The seugathis have sought to calculate a pattern from the randomness, without any luck. Any character who sees these notes has Advantage on ability checks to notice the trap in area @UUID[JournalEntry.JT0zCcIwsSpKnbB5.JournalEntryPage.SeCEB4alINSAplfd]{E20} but has no easier time avoiding or disabling it.

The doorway to the southeast opens onto a cramped and steep staircase leading down to the observation gallery around the testing grounds (area @UUID[JournalEntry.KI33EAGPVHP4zyFZ.JournalEntryPage.SEAO53LL3c9WdjdO]{F9}).

Treasure

@UUID[Item.NMeZudbAEPey7qMy]{Alchemist's Table}

In addition to the notes, the table contains Alchemist’s Supplies, two vials of Acid, and two Basic Necrotic Bombs. Among the supplies are alchemical ingredients worth [[/award 200gp]]. The ingredients can be used as raw materials to create alchemical items like Alchemist’s Fire, Necrotic Bombs, or vials of Acid.

Sludge-Filled Room.name: Sludge-Filled Room
Sludge-Filled Room.text:
Several feet of thick, black sludge fill this room, with even more sticking to the ceiling. The sludge conceals two creatures, but that isn’t obvious upon a casual look (such as viewing the room through the one- way stone in area @UUID[JournalEntry.JT0zCcIwsSpKnbB5.JournalEntryPage.SeCEB4alINSAplfd]{E20}). Several weeks ago, Jafaki caught one of Urevian’s devils poking around, lured it into this chamber, and sent in a pair of alchemically modified black puddings after it. The oozes killed the devil and dissolved it completely.

Encounter

@UUID[Actor.5iuvJLceeLJPlR8O]{Black Puddings (2)}

If disturbed, the two Black Puddings rouse from their torpor to feed, pursuing prey relentlessly and fighting until destroyed.

Macro: You can use the @Macro[sgMuWDSwQymmOhIE]{E22 - Black Puddings} macro to toggle the visibility of the tile and tokens in one go.

Empty Gladiators’ Quarters.name: Empty Gladiators’ Quarters
Empty Gladiators’ Quarters.text: These chambers include nothing more than a single bed, an empty footlocker, and a metal chamber pot. Anything of value was stripped long ago, and each room has signs of being used as a prison. The doors each have a metal bolt. A character can open a bolted door with a successful [[/check ability=dexterity dc=15]] check using Thieves’ Tools.

Hall of Heroes.name: Hall of Heroes
Hall of Heroes.text:
A giant mural wraps around this entire chamber. The mural depicts mutated and fleshwarped warriors, grotesque and powerful, standing in a round room within a beam of eerie blue light. The blue light originates from an impossibly tall lighthouse, and the inhuman champions spring forth from the light to slaughter humans, elves, and other surface-dwelling creatures.

The mural depicts how the arena’s greatest warriors would be sent into battle by Gauntlight’s magic. The display was intended to spur the gladiators to fight more fervently and earn the right to fight on the surface in Belcorra’s name.

Exploration

A character searching this room discovers a secret door in the west wall with a successful [[/check skill=investigation dc=15]] check. Poking two buttons in the eyes of a mutated ogre shown in the mural causes a section of the wall to slide upward and reveal a path to area @UUID[JournalEntry.JT0zCcIwsSpKnbB5.JournalEntryPage.SeCEB4alINSAplfd]{E20}.

Gladiators’ Mead Hall.name: Gladiators’ Mead Hall
Gladiators’ Mead Hall.text:
Overturned tables and benches, all made of petrified wood, lie scattered around the edges of this expansive chamber. Pale bones are interspersed with these furnishings. Several preserved monster heads and silver plaques adorn the walls. A glowing circle of runes is etched on the floor of an alcove to the east.

Belcorra’s gladiators spent their leisure time in this room. The preserved monster heads display creatures killed for sport and include a basilisk, a chimera, and three manticores. The plaques commemorate victories in the arena, and many bear dates. All are within a 10-year period, from 4235 AR to 4244 AR. The sturdy furniture, though upended, remains intact.

The door to the south leads to a very steep staircase descending to the testing grounds (area @UUID[JournalEntry.KI33EAGPVHP4zyFZ.JournalEntryPage.SEAO53LL3c9WdjdO]{F9}). Rarely did anyone descend these stairs, though losers from the fights below ascended them.

The circle of runes marks a permanent, active @UUID[Compendium.dnd5e.spells24.Item.phbsplTeleportat]{Teleportation Circle} that connects to the circle in the testing grounds directly beneath it. This Teleportation Circle functions both ways, but it doesn’t connect to the inactive portal chamber network throughout the Abomination Vaults (even if the characters reactivate that network). A creature stepping into the Teleportation Circle appears in the training grounds amid a blast of pale blue fire and a loud clanging noise (the fire is principally for dramatic effect and isn’t bright or hot enough to cause damage). Anyone using the Teleportation Circle to travel to the testing grounds appears with illusory text on their forehead that reads “challenger” in Aklo. Anyone using the Teleportation Circle to return here receives an illusion that reads “victor” instead. A new forehead illusion replaces any old one. The illusion fades after 1 hour. Before then, it can be dispelled with a @UUID[Compendium.dnd5e.spells24.Item.phbsplDispelMagi]{Dispel Magic} spell or overwritten with a @UUID[Compendium.dnd5e.spells24.Item.phbsplDisguiseSe]{Disguise Self} or @UUID[Compendium.dnd5e.spells24.Item.phbsplSeeming000]{Seeming} spell.

Encounter

@UUID[Actor.rketcmqDQJbFFYfq]{Skeletal Hulk}

The scattered bones of gladiators, slaughtered here shortly after Belcorra’s fall, still hold on to the grim memory of death and combat. When a living creature approaches, they rattle and slide across the room, forming a massive Skeletal Hulk made from the assorted bones of several humanoid gladiators. It tries to pursue foes that flee, but it can’t fit through any of the doors leading out of this room and is thus fairly easy to escape. It fights until destroyed.

Macro: When the skeleton begins to reassemble itself, you can use the @Macro[QzesHWK5dtA7QbVH]{E25 - Skeletal Hulk} macro to toggle the visibility of the bones and the skeleton at the same time!

Arena Balcony.name: Arena Balcony
Arena Balcony.text:
This section represents only the top half of a massive arena. The arena floor (area @UUID[JournalEntry.KI33EAGPVHP4zyFZ.JournalEntryPage.pPa93mirtnlxQxlr]{F26}) holds the majority of the threat here.

A wide walkway around this cavernous chamber looks out over a stone arena floor thirty feet below. Six balconies with comfortable built-in seating provide the best view. Each balcony has a bright torch jutting from it, illuminating the entire arena while leaving this viewing level shrouded in shadows. An enormous metal gong on the eastern end of the chamber hangs on thick chains. Two steep staircases lead down from the central balcony on the north side, descending to the portcullises that block off the way to the arena floor.

Belcorra and her guests watched the blood sports from sumptuous seating here, cheering on the gladiators as they faced off against each other or against terrifying monsters. The north central balcony has two large levers and crank wheels to control each of the portcullises at the bottom of the stairs to the arena floor (area @UUID[JournalEntry.KI33EAGPVHP4zyFZ.JournalEntryPage.pPa93mirtnlxQxlr]{F26}). Anyone investigating this balcony is likely to draw the attention of the basilisks lairing in area @UUID[JournalEntry.JT0zCcIwsSpKnbB5.JournalEntryPage.DKiYbkAmfzGL3UgV]{E10}.

The back wall of the west balcony has an inset secret door that’s opened by pushing the wall’s stones in a specific manner. Any character can notice the faint rush of air between this enormous room and the smaller hall on the other side of the secret door with a successful [[/check skill=wisdom (perception) dc=20]] check, which might alert them to something of interest there. A character searching the balcony locates the door and the manner of opening it with a successful [[/check skill=investigation dc=15]] check.

Creatures: The gargantuan @UUID[Actor.mrxDc0fj5t5CvjJQ]{shanrigol behemoth} on the @UUID[JournalEntry.KI33EAGPVHP4zyFZ.JournalEntryPage.pPa93mirtnlxQxlr]{arena floor} is easy to see from here, but unless the characters make an absurd amount of noise or attack it from this high vantage point, it remains dormant (which is probably for the best if the heroes are still only 5th level).

Treasure

@UUID[Item.wJqisLbPb87iAyLf]{Everburning Torch}

The six torches burning at the balconies are all under @UUID[Compendium.dnd5e.spells24.Item.phbsplContinualF]{Continual Flame} spells and take a minimal amount of effort to remove.

Introduction.name: Introduction
Introduction.text:
Chapter Synopsis

The chapter begins with the party seeking the final @UUID[JournalEntry.67686KaEPc6XAlKJ.JournalEntryPage.Gx2mnbeUctXU7XUN]{icons} needed to enter the Abomination Vault’s middle levels, but a theft complicates this task. The characters confront the thief, Carman Rajani, in a @UUID[JournalEntry.JT0zCcIwsSpKnbB5.JournalEntryPage.DzqE7ZmPnygrbe34]{cave}, where they must decide what to do with him—a choice that will have meaningful repercussions later. They can then explore the fifth level of the Abomination Vaults, which contains masterless horrors and malevolent spirits, and can address a @UUID[JournalEntry.JT0zCcIwsSpKnbB5.JournalEntryPage.7amkuLcaZC2gkHFm]{mystery} regarding the mayor’s daughter.

The Arena

Once the party recovers all four of the @UUID[JournalEntry.67686KaEPc6XAlKJ.JournalEntryPage.Gx2mnbeUctXU7XUN]{icons} and place them on the altar in the Upper Temple of Nhimbaloth in area @UUID[JournalEntry.Os5bHdzCDiXgJBQ6.JournalEntryPage.CGaM81kBLtYIxmqu]{D13}), they can enter the fifth level of the Abomination Vaults. Belcorra used this level to test the resolve of her minions and her prisoners, and she hoped to someday establish a premier facility for gladiators, from which she would take the best combatants into her own forces. Presently, Jafaki and the other seugathis use this level as little more than a dumping ground for failed experiments.

Environmental Cues:

Dust with strange tracks in it, gouges along walls, broken links of chains, splintered furniture, unidentifiable bones, rusted scraps of metal, bits of broken claw or carapace.

Features

The ceilings on this level are 15 feet tall unless otherwise indicated. Areas not described as having light are completely dark. Doors are made of wood banded with iron, and virtually all of them bear gouges or scarring from violent beasts smashing their way through this level in the past. The doors are weighted to swing closed after a few moments if they aren’t propped open.

Investigating The Theft.name: Investigating The Theft
Investigating The Theft.text:
Carman's Theft

While the characters braved dangers in the Abomination Vaults, @UUID[JournalEntry.67686KaEPc6XAlKJ.JournalEntryPage.hv8jCTjoKEFVFV4Q]{Carman} crept into the @UUID[JournalEntry.67686KaEPc6XAlKJ.JournalEntryPage.AztvvKcx7K7gOXhN]{Dawnflower Library} and started a small fire in the book restoration room. While the fire distracted the staff, he broke the Cooperative Blade’s display case and fled with the sword.

After an hour, the staff had extinguished the fire without any serious injuries and only a few lost books—a miracle the acolytes attribute to Sarenrae’s protective embrace. By the time anyone discovered the theft, Carman was already making his way to a local cave called @UUID[JournalEntry.JT0zCcIwsSpKnbB5.JournalEntryPage.DzqE7ZmPnygrbe34]{Smuggler’s Refuge}. It didn’t take long for the town guard to realize the missing Carman Rajani was the prime suspect. Not only had he been pestering the mayor about the sword for years, but a few witnesses saw someone matching his description fleeing from the library, clutching his cloak over some long object.

Vandy's Request

Vandy Banderdash, head priestess of the Dawnflower Library, meets with the characters when they come to ask about the sword. She can barely contain her rage, although she seems angrier about the theft than the fire. She asks them to find Carman and bring him in alive to face trial and appropriate punishment.

Finding Carman

Finding Carman shouldn’t be too hard, as he acted hastily and didn’t have time to cover his tracks or prepare a good cover story.

Otari Guard

The @UUID[JournalEntry.67686KaEPc6XAlKJ.JournalEntryPage.St1SBR4xOInfNoPj]{Otari Garrison} can’t provide much help; Captain Longsaddle points out that since Carman isn’t in town or along the roads, the guards don’t have jurisdiction to pursue him. He harrumphs and adds, “Good riddance to that troublemaker. He’ll keep running if he knows what’s good for him.” He doesn’t provide any aid to capture Carman but happily takes him into custody if the characters bring the smith into town.

Blades for Glades

The party finds Carman’s blacksmith shop, @UUID[JournalEntry.67686KaEPc6XAlKJ.JournalEntryPage.5yYs7JNliPnSYLhp]{Blades for Glades}, closed; they won’t find any clues here. If the characters already had the support of Blades for Glades, they recall that Carman had mentioned Smuggler’s Refuge in the past, so it’s a likely hideout.

Combing the Town

If the party asks about Carman’s location in Otari, nearly everyone suggests they go ask around at the @UUID[JournalEntry.67686KaEPc6XAlKJ.JournalEntryPage.sdNti6BHkPTeO5fC]{Crook’s Nook}. On a successful [[/check skill=persuasion dc=15]] check to research the missing blacksmith by canvassing the town, a character finds that several townspeople mention Smuggler’s Refuge and recall that Carman used to head up there in his youth (as did many people in Otari).

Crook's Nook

Asking around at the Crook’s Nook brings the owner, Yinyasmera, over to talk. She brazenly asks for a 10 GP “special fee” for food and drinks; characters who pay up or succeed on a [[/check skill=persuasion dc=15]] check get her to open up about Carman. Any character who speaks Thieves’ Cant automatically knows she means to sell them the information. The blacksmith has been a little too bold to remain in her good graces, and this theft is the last straw. She mentions that Carman is likely hiding out at Smuggler’s Refuge outside of town. If Yinyasmera has a favorable opinion of the characters from their previous actions, she gives them this information for free.

Smuggler's Refuge.name: Smuggler's Refuge
Smuggler's Refuge.text:
Environmental Cues:

Dripping water, mineral tang in the air, broken crates, moldy bedding, old campfires.

This cave is only about an hour outside of town, just a short walk through the forest, north of an abandoned fish camp. Though it’s too far inland for transporting heavy cargo, this cave once saw a lot of use from smugglers moving lighter goods. They hid their loot in one of the cave’s many niches, planning to come back for it later or using the site as a drop point for transactions with a buyer. Today, with a recent decline in smuggling, Otari’s young people camp in the cave when they need a break from the lumber town.

Rotted crates, forgotten clothes, and other debris suggest this cave is occasionally used but rarely cleaned. A cold campfire surrounded by logs sits at the cave’s center. Faint smells of mildew and smoke hang in the still air.

Like many visitors before him, Carman initially built a fire here but put it out when he realized there isn’t a good place for the smoke to vent. A few old cots, heaps of discarded clothes, and empty crates show that this cave is occasionally inhabited. Carman uses the best of the cots and the freshest of the clothes for bedding.

Encounter

@UUID[Actor.tYzzLLUv9WBhHhQY]{Carman Rajani}

If Carman isn’t aware of the characters, he sits on his cot, chewing on some dried fish and turning the Cooperative Blade over and over in his hands while he thinks about what to do next. He wonders whether to return the sword and hope for nothing more than a stiff fine, or to flee for his ancestral homeland of Nidal.

If Carman knows of the characters’ presence, he hides behind a crate, but a character can spot him with a successful [[/skill prc 16]] check.

Carman knows the party by reputation. He assumes they’ve come to take him prisoner, especially if he knows them to already be on good terms with Captain Longsaddle or Oseph Menhemes, and he puts up a fight. While defending himself, he shouts, “You’ll never take me alive!” and “This is my sword! I only took what’s rightfully mine!” He gives up if the characters don’t reciprocate his aggression, or when he’s reduced to fewer than 25 Hit Points.

XP Award: Award the heroes [[/award 500xp]] for capturing Carman alive, in addition to the XP for defeating him.

Exploration

@UUID[Item.fON9GY2MFydaRfnS]{Carman's Supplies}

Carman's Supplies

Apart from the gear that Carman carries on him (most notably, the Cooperative Blade), his Burglar’s Pack near the fire is fully stocked. A character who makes a successful [[/check skill=investigation dc=14]] check while searching the cave discovers a long-forgotten bottle of Old Law Whiskey hidden in a pebble-covered niche. The aged alcohol is worth [[/award 10gp]].

Secret Door

The east wall of the cave contains an exceptionally well-hidden secret door that leads into the fifth level of the Abomination Vaults. A character searching this area must succeed on a [[/check skill=investigation dc=25]] check to find it. Even if discovered, however, the secret door doesn’t open from this side. Its mechanism causes the heavy stone wall to swing inward, and it can’t do so because of a cave-in just on the other side of it. The characters might clear this entrance from the other side later (in area @UUID[JournalEntry.JT0zCcIwsSpKnbB5.JournalEntryPage.BzlXstkevKBkM04H]{E07}).

Talking with Carman.name: Talking with Carman
Talking with Carman.text:
If Carman has a chance to explain himself before the characters take him into custody, he tries to justify stealing the sword. Read or paraphrase the following:

“It’s mine, I tell you! The sword is mine! How can I steal something that already belongs to me? It belonged to Vol Rajani, and I’m her only surviving descendant. That uptight mayor says the sword belongs to his family just because a pack of kobolds had their hands on it for a little while, and his ancestor snatched it from them. He says an heirloom is an heirloom, and he’s right, but it’s my heirloom! Look, I tried to buy it off him, but every time I saved enough coin, he raised the price—fifty gold, then a hundred, then two hundred. Then he said it wasn’t for sale at any price! I had no choice but to steal it. It belongs to Vol—to the Rajani family. It belongs to me!”

Carman pleads for the characters to let him go and steadfastly claims his right to take the sword. He answers their questions as best he can. Likely inquiries and his responses follow.

Why is the sword so important to you?

"It belonged to my family, to Vol. She was the best of the Roseguard and the best of the Rajanis... and I wanted to be mayor. I’ve run four times but always lost to Oseph. If I had the sword, well—people say that it gives the town good luck! If I had it, they’d want me to be mayor so that I could give them luck.”

Why do you want to be mayor?

“To be in charge! There’s no reason a Menhemes should always run this place. Oseph says it’s because his family descended from heroes. Well, so did I, and I can do a much better job than that old bastard.”

Why did you set the fire at the library?

“The fire was just a distraction. I didn’t want to hurt anyone, and all those busybody acolytes should have put it out soon enough. It’s not like I burned anything other than some paper.”

Even if the sword is rightfully yours, you committed arson. Don't you think you deserve to go to jail?

"Arson? Heh. Vandalism, maybe. I’ll pay a fine for starting the fire, sure, but the sword is mine.”

Why should we let you go?

“Because I’ll pay you. Fifty gold coins—a hundred, even. Take it all. But I get to keep my sword.”

How did you get that much gold?

“Saved it, borrowed some. Ok, borrowed most of it. Look, I just had to get my sword.”

If we let you go, what will you do?

“I don’t know. Stay here a while, maybe, and think it out. I can’t really go back to town now. Maybe I’ll head back to Nidal. They say Vol was from there—some say she was royalty, and maybe there, I can get the life that’s due to me.”

If we let you go, can we borrow the sword first?

“As long as you’re not taking it or me back to town, I’ll go with you to do whatever you need to do.”

Carman's Fate

The characters decide what to do with Carman. He likely goes along with any result the characters demand, particularly if they already proved they can beat him in a fight.

Let Him Go

Even if the characters are willing to let him go, they still need the Cooperative Blade to breach the barrier in the Abomination Vaults. Carman goes with them for this excursion since he doesn’t want to let the sword out of his sight, but he doesn’t fight in the Abomination Vaults if the characters get into trouble. After the barrier goes down, Carman retreats to the cave to think about what to do and likely stays there for a few days.

Turn Him In

If the party turns him in to the Otari Garrison, Captain Longsaddle tosses him in a cell and jokes about throwing away the key. Longsaddle lets the mayor know that the characters have the Cooperative Blade, but the mayor is fine with the characters borrowing it for as long as they’d like, just so long as it ends up back with the town. Longsaddle takes Carman’s money as a pool to repay any costs from his crimes but lets the characters keep Carman’s other equipment.

Kill Him

If the characters kill Carman in combat, people in town understand that’s a risk when apprehending a criminal. Oseph arranges for Carman’s burial in the Otari Cemetery and lets the heroes borrow the Cooperative Blade.

The Spectral Seal.name: The Spectral Seal
The Spectral Seal.text:
A spectral barrier blocks the only passage from the fourth level of the Abomination Vaults to the fifth. As the characters learned from the ghost of Otari Ilvashti in area @UUID[JournalEntry.Os5bHdzCDiXgJBQ6.JournalEntryPage.J8ggyg2kxws3Sa1h]{D18}, only icons of all four members of the Roseguard can pierce it.

World State

@Macro[pDzkFlraunFyBL5G]{D12 - Breaking the Seal}

When your players are ready to pierce the barrier, this macro will remove the wall and lighting effects from the corridor in the Ghostwalk, allowing them to pass.

Gathering Information

It shouldn’t take the party too much asking around in town to find out about the Roseguard's icons. After all, the @UUID[JournalEntry.67686KaEPc6XAlKJ.JournalEntryPage.Gx2mnbeUctXU7XUN]{The Roseguard} founded Otari and are the town’s most revered heroes; even the town’s children know who all four members of the Roseguard are. The adventuring group consisted of the rogue Otari Ilvashti, the cleric Aesephna Menhemes, the wizard Zarmavdian, and the fighter Vol Rajani.

The best place to learn about the Roseguard is @UUID[JournalEntry.67686KaEPc6XAlKJ.JournalEntryPage.WirKAYn5ZGirmgjb]{Menhemes Manor}, the residence of the town’s mayor and his family (all of whom are proud to be descendants of Aesephna Menhemes). The manor’s eastern wing contains a public museum of the town’s history. Although this museum contains replicas of the Roseguard’s adventuring gear and even a few common items that the adventurers once owned, the specific icons Otari Ilvashti’s ghost described to the characters aren’t here. Mayor Oseph Menhemes, Vandy Banderdash at the @UUID[JournalEntry.67686KaEPc6XAlKJ.JournalEntryPage.AztvvKcx7K7gOXhN]{Dawnflower Library}, or Wrin Sivinxi at @UUID[JournalEntry.67686KaEPc6XAlKJ.JournalEntryPage.jlb4fsKQC57ZjNQ7]{Wrin’s Wonders} can point the characters in the right direction.

Retrieving the Icons

The icons are described in full in @UUID[JournalEntry.67686KaEPc6XAlKJ.JournalEntryPage.Gx2mnbeUctXU7XUN]{Icons of the Roseguard} The characters should have already recovered Otari Ilvashti’s Shadowed Thieves’ Tools from area @UUID[JournalEntry.Os5bHdzCDiXgJBQ6.JournalEntryPage.J8ggyg2kxws3Sa1h]{D18} but can return for them if necessary.

The Hunter's Brooch

Aesephna Menhemes’s Hunter’s Brooch is in a locked shadowbox in the music room of Menhemes Manor. If the characters are honest and forthright in telling Oseph Menhemes why they need it, he permits them to borrow the brooch for as long as they require it. For being honest with him, the party automatically earns the Menhemes’s support, which allows the characters to work a profession by tutoring the Menhemes children and, more pertinent to this campaign, lets them meet with Oseph’s daughter, Dorianna Menhemes, and aid with her @UUID[JournalEntry.JT0zCcIwsSpKnbB5.JournalEntryPage.7amkuLcaZC2gkHFm]{malady}. If the characters previously earned the Menhemes’s support, he lets them keep the brooch in exchange for all they’ve done for him and the town.

Thresholds of Truth

The bookseller @UUID[Actor.GQE978SzTLS0Sa8B]{Morlibint} keeps Zarmavdian’s spellbook, Thresholds of Truth, in his academic collection at @UUID[JournalEntry.67686KaEPc6XAlKJ.JournalEntryPage.0SO6cXvfRTtHZM6m]{Odd Stories}. If Odd Stories already supports the characters, Morlibint gladly allows them to borrow the book. If not, they must promise Morlibint that they’ll take special care of the spellbook before he loans it to them. Convincing Morlibint might require extensive promises, a demonstration on the proper care of ancient tomes, or both. Either way, Morlibint wants to get a full account of what they do with the book (and, of course, a detailed retelling of any related magical phenomena).

The Cooperative Blade

Vol Rajani’s longsword, the Cooperative Blade, is normally on display at the entrance to Dawnflower Library, but it was stolen the previous night by @UUID[JournalEntry.67686KaEPc6XAlKJ.JournalEntryPage.hv8jCTjoKEFVFV4Q]{Carman Rajani}, Otari’s blacksmith and Vol’s last living descendant. See @UUID[JournalEntry.JT0zCcIwsSpKnbB5.JournalEntryPage.6EE3LBjSntNQeK8i]{Investigating The Theft} for more information.

Deadly Rivalries.name: Deadly Rivalries
Deadly Rivalries.text:
While the upper levels of Belcorra’s massive dungeon were primarily for her personal use, she designed the middle levels for work. Belcorra trawled the Darklands for dangerous predators and bloodthirsty aberrations, but their feral power wasn’t enough for her. She needed to mold them into an army to assault the metropolis of Absalom. In the middle levels, she had these forces forged for battle, in body and in mind. The fifth level thus included a massive arena and training grounds where gladiators would fight for the right to lead her monstrous troops.

In the Darklands, Belcorra encountered wormlike aberrations called seugathis, who had a curious eagerness to serve her. She then repurposed the sixth level—formerly support rooms for her monsters and their trainers as well as a “preserve” where she kept large beasts—as laboratories. There, the seugathis sought to perfect fleshwarping to create flawless monsters under the guidance of their leader, @UUID[JournalEntry.67686KaEPc6XAlKJ.JournalEntryPage.qrb0F1AQ3iIR7Xni]{Jafaki}.

Belcorra constructed the smaller seventh level as a prison. She didn’t intend to keep many captives since creatures who displeased her could serve as raw flesh for Jafaki’s experiments or as food for her monsters. However, one of Belcorra’s chief administrators, the contract devil @UUID[JournalEntry.67686KaEPc6XAlKJ.JournalEntryPage.t9SSGAP5pW2NpkWh]{Urevian}, insisted on building the prison. Before long, the level became a warped mirror of Hell.

Belcorra's Death

A decade into building her dungeon and honing her preparations, Belcorra died at the hands of the Roseguard, who had no idea about these subterranean machinations. The Abomination Vaults fell into disarray almost immediately. Urevian attempted to assert control, but Jafaki’s aberrant creations fought the devil’s forces to a standstill. A sort of stalemate settled over the middle levels, and the borders of control have shifted only slightly back and forth over the centuries. Jafaki merely wanted peace to continue their experiments; Urevian idly prepared for the surface invasion as his contract required him, even though he knew it was almost impossible to complete his contract because Belcorra had died.

Word of the seugathis’ skilled fleshwarping spread. Before long, arrogant or desperate creatures came to the Abomination Vaults seeking remarkable transformations, though few ultimately considered their changes to be improvements. Fleshwarped creatures continue to commonly appear throughout the middle levels.

Belcorra's Return

When Belcorra returned as a ghost only a few years ago, the Abomination Vaults hummed with the power of her return. The significance of this event was lost on the research-focused Jafaki, but not on Urevian; the devil realized he could now finally fulfill his contract with the sorcerer. Yet Urevian had already spent centuries contemplating a well-drafted loophole that would allow him to simply return to Hell without providing her any aid at all. To do so, Urevian needs a specific mortal soul: that of Vol Rajani, one of the Roseguard. Vol is long dead, of course, but the clause can still apply if Urevian receives the soul of Vol’s last descendant, @UUID[JournalEntry.67686KaEPc6XAlKJ.JournalEntryPage.hv8jCTjoKEFVFV4Q]{Carman Rajani}. Urevian couldn’t collect the soul while Belcorra was merely dead, but now that she has returned, Urevian is willing to abandon his extensive preparations if someone can get Carman’s soul for him—and he selects the dungeon delvers from Otari to handle this matter on his behalf.

Dorianna's Dreams.name: Dorianna's Dreams
Dorianna's Dreams.text:
Although the party can find plenty of adventure in the Abomination Vaults, other mysterious events are afoot in Otari. The most significant of these occurrences centers around @UUID[JournalEntry.67686KaEPc6XAlKJ.JournalEntryPage.7WZr8QhFOSrHPTgU]{Mayor Menhemes}’s eldest daughter, the teenaged Dorianna Menhemes. Dorianna is on the cusp of developing psychic powers. While no one on the surface is aware of this, a denizen of Leng named @UUID[Actor.8AVy2qIK6vh13sSj]{Ysondkhelir} (area @UUID[JournalEntry.OyNcqrpRClyhr8BJ.JournalEntryPage.RiUE936phCZx8Hqe]{G18}) has become aware of her power. With the barrier to the lower levels down, he can twist her dreams into nightmares and take on the role of her savior. He intensifies this long plan over weeks of nighttime adventures with her in the Dimension of Dreams. Ysondkhelir intends to eventually thrust Dorianna physically into the Dimension of Dreams to augment other denizens’ sinister plots.

The First Dreams

Two nights after the party opens the seal to the Abomination Vaults’ lower levels, Dorianna Menhemes begins having horrifying nightmares. She awakens several times each night, screaming and clutching a stuffed griffon she hasn’t touched in years. She doesn’t recall the specifics of these nightmares beyond the fear and the appearance of a man shrouded in mismatched fabric who comforts her.

If the characters have earned the support of @UUID[JournalEntry.67686KaEPc6XAlKJ.JournalEntryPage.WirKAYn5ZGirmgjb]{Menhemes Manor}, they’ve met Dorianna and hear about her nightmares from the other children. Otherwise, the mayor seeks out whichever character is best known as a healer or as an authority on occultism. He mentions his daughter’s nightmares and the “motley man” who acts as a protector and savior within them. He asks them to discreetly look into the matter and help his daughter.

Asking Wrin

Mayor Menhemes views @UUID[JournalEntry.67686KaEPc6XAlKJ.JournalEntryPage.raJDQ95RBqeXxV14]{Wrin Sivinxi} of Wrin’s Wonders as an unreliable eccentric, so he doesn’t think to involve her in his family’s troubles. She is, however, an expert at the occult, and she gladly accompanies the characters to help Dorianna if they ask, so long as she doesn’t need to meet with the beleaguered girl indoors. If the party lacks someone proficient in Arcana to get to the bottom of these mysteries, Wrin’s involvement is a possible solution.

Examining Dorianna

Even the first time the characters examine Dorianna, she already appears gaunt and pale as if she’d caught a severe malady. A character who makes a successful [[/skill med 10]] check verifies that she’s nevertheless in good physical health. The characters initially find no evidence of any magic or curse upon her. A search of Dorianna’s room reveals that several of her childhood toys have been brought back out for her to play with. Dorianna states vaguely that she just missed them and wanted to play with them again. Dorianna’s nightmares are tenacious; any magic the characters might employ to help Dorianna get a good night’s sleep fail unless the caster succeeds at a DC 22 spellcasting ability check.

XP Award: Award the characters [[/award 500xp]] for taking the care and time to help Dorianna, even if they can’t figure out what’s wrong just yet.

Dorianna’s Decline

Dorianna’s condition worsens over time. Her nightmares lessen in intensity, but she feels exhausted and anxious during the day. She begins to talk with the Motley Man as an imaginary friend even when awake, eschewing activities with anyone else. Her disposition becomes erratic and childish, and she often scratches absently at her right hand. Her siblings don’t want anything to do with her, and even her parents find her hard to put up with. She has been afflicted by Ysondkhelir’s @UUID[Compendium.dnd-abomination-vaults.av-items-5e.Item.JHbChH3j8d8A8OD7]{Outcast’s Curse} spell, which the party might detect or remove normally. If they do, Ysondkhelir casts it on her again the following night. With a successful [[/skill persuasion dc=18]] check, the characters gain Dorianna’s trust and get her to open up to them. If they have the support of Menhemes Manor, they have Advantage on this check. Only one character can attempt this check each day. If the check fails by 5 or more, they must wait [[/r 1d4]] days to attempt the check again. On a success, Dorianna insists that the Motley Man is real and discusses one of the following two subjects with them. On a second success, or if the initial check succeeds by 5 or more, she reveals both.

Gifts: The Motley Man gives her gifts in the form of her old childhood toys, and the best of them is the stuffed griffon. Even a cursory examination reveals that something hard is sewn inside the stuffed toy; characters who open it up find a @UUID[Item.uoPAVVoQc95sdxTN]{ruby} worth [[/award 500gp]]. Even if the party takes this ruby, the next time Dorianna dreams, it reappears inside another childhood toy from wherever it is. It’s keyed to Dorianna and doesn’t leave her for long.

Wrist Writing: Dorianna absently points out several bruises on her right wrist that she can’t remember getting. A character proficient in Arcana who views the bruises can attempt a [[/check skill=arcana dc=18]] check to understand its significance. A character who speaks Aklo makes this check with Advantage. On a success, the character notes that the bruises form words related to some dream-traveling rituals, including the word “Leng.”

Either of these clues points to the involvement of a malevolent extraplanar creature called a denizen of Leng. Leng is a terrifying extraplanar location just past the Dimension of Dreams, where cruel and sinister people called denizens of Leng live. A character who succeeds on a [[/check skill=arcana dc=21]] check realizes the nature of the creature plaguing Dorianna; if the characters obtained both clues, then any character proficient in Arcana realizes the creature’s nature without a check. Though the heroes might identify the source of Dorianna’s trouble, there’s not much they can do for her yet because Ysondkhelir doesn’t ever physically get anywhere near her.

XP Award: Award the characters [[/award 1200xp]] if they discover that a denizen of Leng is involved in Dorianna’s mysterious malady.

Dorianna's Madness.name: Dorianna's Madness
Dorianna's Madness.text:
About the time the characters finish their exploration of the laboratories level and begin to investigate the prison level, Dorianna’s condition gets suddenly worse. She sleepwalks most of the time and is unaware of events around her, as though seeing the world in a hazy dream. Her right hand withers for no discernible reason. Mayor Menhemes takes his daughter to Vandy Banderdash at the Dawnflower Library, but the clerics there can’t aid her.

The characters hear about all of this on their next return to Otari. Everyone else in the Menhemes family is beside themselves with grief. If the characters haven’t previously gained Dorianna’s trust, they can attempt to do so now by making a [[/skill persuasion dc=20]] check. The characters gain no benefit for having the support of Menhemes Manor—Dorianna is beyond caring about her former friends.

The Motley Man

If the characters have Dorianna’s trust, she describes great adventures with the Motley Man in a fantastical land of forests, palaces, and snowfields. The Motley Man told her they would soon be together on their adventures forever, but he wanted her right hand as a token. Dorianna didn’t hesitate to offer it to him, and when she awoke, her hand was withered. She doesn’t consider it a particularly serious loss since her best friend wanted it so much. Dorianna doesn’t know how long it will be until she and the Motley Man are together forever, and this timetable is intentionally left vague so the GM can prompt the players to action without punishing them if they fail to reach Ysondkhelir quickly. They should have, at a minimum, a week before Dorianna vanishes.

Locating Ysondkhelir

Dorianna’s connection to Ysondkhelir is now so strong that the party can discover him through this link. A character proficient in Arcana realizes they can learn more by examining Dorianna’s psychic patterns while she’s dreaming. Doing so takes 8 hours and requires a character proficient in Arcana to make a [[/skill arc 15]] check. With a successful check, the character learns one of the following facts they don’t already know. If the check succeeds by 5 or more, they learn two facts. The character can repeat the check by spending another 8 hours studying Dorianna’s dreams, but if a check fails by 5 or more, the character imagines a false conclusion that encourages the party to explore deeper into the dungeon.

  • • There’s a strong link between Dorianna’s mind and the Dimension of Dreams. A denizen of Leng is strengthening this conduit; unless that creature is destroyed, Dorianna will eventually be drawn wholly into that dimension and lost to the world.

  • • The character gains images of the denizen’s surroundings: a stone chamber with a very old map of the Inner Sea region painted on it across from a map consisting of several tattered pieces of paper that, together, constitute a detailed map of Otari.

  • • The character knows that the denizen of Leng’s name is Ysondkhelir and gains an accurate mental image of him.

  • • The character can use the ruby in Dorianna’s possession to track Ysondkhelir. Doing so allows the character to cast @UUID[Compendium.dnd5e.spells24.Item.phbsplLocateCrea]{Locate Creature} as a ritual. When cast in this way, the spell can be used to track Ysondkhelir even if Ysondkhelir is beyond 1,000 feet of the caster. The ruby can’t be used to target another creature. Even though Dorianna doesn’t care if they take it, the ruby is still linked to her and returns to her each night. The characters must thus return to Otari to recover it each day.

Rewards

@UUID[Item.oPK9sP2JrdxZM00M]{Ruby of Alertness}

After the party defeats Ysondkhelir, the ruby no longer returns to Dorianna and becomes a standard (if unusually shaped) Rod of Alertness. Dorianna swiftly recovers. Mayor Oseph effusively thanks the characters and arranges for each of them to have an Uncommon magic item of their choice ordered from Absalom at his expense. These items take a week to arrive.

XP Award: Award the characters [[/award 1400xp]] for freeing Dorianna from Ysondkhelir’s clutches.

Central Shaft.name: Central Shaft
Central Shaft.text:
The wide spiral staircase continues downward, leveling out long enough to pass by a single door leading east and a hallway leading west to a double door. The space between them has a rounded, cloudy window overlooking a large pool in a natural cavern. A dim orange glow emanates from far below and, with it, a sulfurous stench.

The spiral stairs lead up to the fifth level (area @UUID[JournalEntry.JT0zCcIwsSpKnbB5.JournalEntryPage.GtX8UuzhtARfLdsq]{E1}) and down to the seventh level (area @UUID[JournalEntry.OyNcqrpRClyhr8BJ.JournalEntryPage.2aDFWQZkq3nA7KPT]{G1}). The stairs and the walkway connecting them have a narrow iron handrail to prevent a fall 40 feet down to area @UUID[JournalEntry.OyNcqrpRClyhr8BJ.JournalEntryPage.2aDFWQZkq3nA7KPT]{G1}.

The window is magically transparent stone. As it’s part of Gauntlight’s support, it can’t be damaged. It also can’t be manipulated like the transparent stone elsewhere in the dungeon, as it lacks control glyphs.

Encounter

@UUID[Actor.v9B0hB5sm4YZxebY]{Seugathi Servant} @UUID[Actor.K9Hw43co8fhwmKkM]{Grothlut}

Jafaki knows that controlling this main staircase is the best way to keep Urevian’s troops from invading their territory; it’s also the ideal place to capture new research subjects. The seugathi leader keeps a Grothlut tied to the handrail with a collar and chain. The creature can move anywhere along the walkway in the northern half of the room but no further without unhooking the chain, which the creature isn’t sufficiently intelligent to deduce. There’s also a Seugathi Servant equipped with a Wand of Enemy Detection posted a guard in the alcove in front of the double door.

The seugathi watches for attacks from below, so characters descending from above might catch them off- guard, as the moaning and gibbering from monsters on the landing above aren’t unusual and don’t alert the seugathi. If the seugathi knows someone is coming, they activate their Wand of Enemy Detection, don’t use Mind Fog, and feign friendliness just long enough to put the newcomers at ease. They then try to take the intruders prisoner, fighting to the death, though they retreat through the double door to area @UUID[JournalEntry.KI33EAGPVHP4zyFZ.JournalEntryPage.YNHrEKfNsLjjoQhE]{F2} if they need more space to fight.

The grothlut moans and charges forward when it detects intruders of any kind but loyally follows the seugathi’s commands.

Treasure: The seugathi servant doesn’t give up its Wand of Enemy Detection without a fight.

Reinforcements

Jafaki doesn’t replace the guards. If this landing remains unguarded for more than five days, Urevian sends a cautious Bearded Devil and two Dreshkans up to secure it on behalf of the devils on the floor below. Reduce the number of creatures in areas @UUID[JournalEntry.OyNcqrpRClyhr8BJ.JournalEntryPage.JLM4Hwqvk9V8qvbp]{G3}, @UUID[JournalEntry.OyNcqrpRClyhr8BJ.JournalEntryPage.JCRGIRMAhYyjkSvF]{G4}, @UUID[JournalEntry.OyNcqrpRClyhr8BJ.JournalEntryPage.fK6B6GmATzvRIuh4]{G7}, or @UUID[JournalEntry.OyNcqrpRClyhr8BJ.JournalEntryPage.wemHETiO7mks9Clo]{G15} to account for any new guards Urevian stations here.

Grime Deposits.name: Grime Deposits
Grime Deposits.text:
Rust and grime fill this octagonal chamber. A wide hallway leads out to the south.

A circular shaft in the ceiling leads up 25 feet through the stone to area @UUID[JournalEntry.JT0zCcIwsSpKnbB5.JournalEntryPage.oBe9I7ccu1SIxdsG]{E2}.

World State

@Macro[53JtRrpbTJ3IpCNC]{F2 - Rusty Grate}

If the heroes haven't triggered the pit trap there, the shaft's top is covered with the rusty grate that collapses when moved. If they have, then the broken wreckage of the grating lies in the centre of the room!

You can toggle the tile in the scene by clicking the above macro.

Rocky Cave.name: Rocky Cave
Rocky Cave.text:
The mossy walls of this pebble-strewn cavern extend upward to a ceiling thirty feet high. A wide, rounded window fifteen feet above the floor overlooks this cavern.

Dripping water echoes from the east. The moss on the walls is edible and, in fact, surprisingly tasty.

Encounter

@UUID[Actor.xYlOudjXyTakF1m8]{Earth Elementals (2)}

Belcorra bound two Earth Elementals here, more to keep wandering guests out of her nature preserve than for any other reason. The elementals spring from the walls and floor a few moments after any creature enters this cavern. They have ethereal shackles visible on their limbs, representing their bound nature; the shackles prevent them from leaving this cave, but they can lurk just within the walls and floor. An elemental reduced to fewer than 30 Hit Points retreats into the stone and doesn’t return for several days.

Side Quest

A character proficient in Arcana or Nature realizes that the elementals’ binding is weak and can be undone. This reversal ceremony must be performed in sight of the binding location; the stairs leading up to area @UUID[JournalEntry.KI33EAGPVHP4zyFZ.JournalEntryPage.YNHrEKfNsLjjoQhE]{F2} or the window in area @UUID[JournalEntry.KI33EAGPVHP4zyFZ.JournalEntryPage.nywKGONakrYspO83]{F1} make good locations since the elementals can’t attack anyone there. The ceremony takes 4 hours, consumes [[/award 60gp]] of gems, and requires a character to succeed on a [[/check skill=arcana/nature dc=19]] check to enact.

If the ceremony works, the elementals return to their home plane. Before they go, the elementals grant a magical boon to the character who performed the unbinding. That character gains Tremorsense out to a distance of 10 feet for 1 week.

XP Award: Award the characters [[/award 1200xp]] for breaking the binding on the elementals.

Treasure

@UUID[Item.tyKZiT5ao3uz3Cpq]{Diamond}

The elementals buried a diamond given to them as payment for their service. A character who searches the area and makes a successful [[/check skill=perception dc=20]] check finds the diamond; a character who received the magical boon senses the diamond automatically. The diamond is worth [[/award 1000gp]].

Deep Pool.name: Deep Pool
Deep Pool.text:
A rocky shoreline drops steeply into a large pool beneath several stalactites. Five square shafts in the stony ceiling lead upward. To the south, a barrier of transparent stone protects winding raised ledges that run along each side of the cavern. A short bridge, similarly encased in transparent stone, crosses over the pool to connect the two ledges.
