This area functioned as Belcorra’s underground nature preserve. She kept a pair of hydras here, as hydra blood has many applications in alchemy, magic, and fleshwarping. The pool averages 15 feet deep, and tiny subterranean streams refresh its waters.

Jafaki maintains the preserve and two hydras (descendants of the original pair) for the same reasons Belcorra did. He has induced them into a chemical stupor to extend their lives, lower their food intake,and reduce the amount of trouble they cause. When the characters first arrive, one Hydra is sleeping with just its heads above the surface of the water. The other was lured to area @UUID[JournalEntry.KI33EAGPVHP4zyFZ.JournalEntryPage.psfaf5Skhe3bMKsr]{F5} by one of Urevian’s devils.

Exploration

If the characters approach this chamber carefully and succeed on a group [[/check skill=stealth dc=11]] check, the drugged hydra remains asleep. Any character who investigates the hydra and makes a successful [[/check arcana medicine nature 18]] check recognizes that it must be drugged, as hydras normally sleep with only some of their heads at a time. Actions that significantly disturb the water—such as someone falling into the room from above—rouse the hydra.

Encounter

@UUID[Actor.RiKjpztTt7tZbOeo]{Hydra}

Due to its forced alchemical hibernation, the hydra wakes up only gradually. One head awakens when the hydra rolls Initiative, with another head awakening at the end of each of the hydra’s turns. An additional head wakes up each time the hydra takes damage. Heads that are still asleep don’t count toward the hydra’s Reactive Heads trait or Multiattack action.

The hydra defends its territory to the death but doesn’t pursue prey beyond the confines of the cave.

The Deep End.name: The Deep End
The Deep End.text:
The southern end of this cavern is entirely flooded. A walkway encased in transparent stone runs along the eastern wall, ten feet above the water’s surface.

The hydras once kept their nest at the far end of the pool, where the depth dips down to 25 feet. They were temporarily driven out by a devil serving Urevian a few weeks ago, but that reckless devil ended up a meal for the more aggressive of the hydras. The hydra in area @UUID[JournalEntry.KI33EAGPVHP4zyFZ.JournalEntryPage.f7dzsMJc3BAy82zr]{F4 }remains unsettled by the incident and now doesn’t venture into this part of the pool.

An overhang above the deepest part of the pool is pierced by a well capped by a sturdy iron grate. The grate’s bolts are thick and apparently strong, but they’ve been broken from underneath, so the grate lifts off with only a little effort. With a successful [[/check skill=athletics dc=14]] check, a creature in the water can lift the grate and climb up into area @UUID[JournalEntry.KI33EAGPVHP4zyFZ.JournalEntryPage.SEAO53LL3c9WdjdO]{F9}.

Exploration

A character who searches the walkway and makes a successful [[/check skill=investigation dc=15]] check finds a suspicious masonry square near floor level. When pushed like a button, the secret door to area @UUID[JournalEntry.KI33EAGPVHP4zyFZ.JournalEntryPage.fIH3LXVbvaKFJzOc]{F8} swings open.

Encounter

@UUID[Actor.RiKjpztTt7tZbOeo]{Hydra}

Urevian sent an aquatic devil to spy on Jafaki and his plots several weeks ago. The overeager devil tried to lure one of the hydras into a position to attack Jafaki’s minions and accidentally ended up a victim himself. As a result of the vicious combat, the Hydra here is alert, defensive, and has grown two extra heads (for a total of seven). The hydra’s Challenge Rating is 9 ([[/award 5000xp]]).

Treasure

@UUID[Item.byrsQUlEoIiIgf9t]{Fragment of Urevian's Pendant}, @UUID[Item.TL3aCxabiRPgFsSr]{Hydra Nest}

A character searching the water finds a recently severed hydra head in the shallowest part of the water. Something gleams in its teeth: one of five pieces of @UUID[JournalEntry.67686KaEPc6XAlKJ.JournalEntryPage.t9SSGAP5pW2NpkWh]{Urevian}’s pendant, used to open the door into the contract devil’s domain (area @UUID[JournalEntry.OyNcqrpRClyhr8BJ.JournalEntryPage.YSOnwMgSJVzVm31U]{G10}).

The hydra nest at the pool’s deepest point contains the equipment and bones of three long-dead gladiators. The only pieces of salvageable equipment are a set of Mithral Full Plate with lion motifs and a gilded, lion-shaped helm worth [[/award 900gp]].

Dissection Chamber.name: Dissection Chamber
Dissection Chamber.text:
Metal shelves and operating tables hint at this room’s original purpose. Clean bones and bits of rusted metal lie in piles throughout the rest of the room, as though discarded like trash.

Jafaki has dumped garbage in this medical bay for decades. Three shafts in the ceiling lead up to area @UUID[JournalEntry.JT0zCcIwsSpKnbB5.JournalEntryPage.D2f9A4UpjzQmsdNF]{E4}. The lids at the top open easily within the shafts.

Encounter

@UUID[Actor.uQBOJfjtzEXvpLQz]{Ochre Jellies (2)}

Two Ochre Jellies lazily squelch around this chamber, feeding on trash. They move toward any creatures they sense, expecting food; if the characters don’t immediately offer some sort of food, the jellies attack, fighting until destroyed.

Treasure

@UUID[Item.g2AmNJksoO58wGMW]{Dissection Chamber Detritus}

A character who searches through the detritus discovers a large key with an elaborate, four-prong design among the various bits of junk in this room. The key opens one of the locks in the plinth room (area @UUID[JournalEntry.KI33EAGPVHP4zyFZ.JournalEntryPage.4DSWkmCkIZ8iD20I]{F7}).

Amid the jumble of items scoured clean by the oozes’ acid is a Breastplate, a steel Shield, three Daggers, a War Pick, several Caltrops (without a pouch to keep them in), fishing tackle, a Spyglass, seven Iron Spikes, 14 pitons, and 30 feet of Chain.

Plinth Room.name: Plinth Room
Plinth Room.text:
This chamber’s east and west walls feature sharply angled alcoves bearing stone carvings too defaced to indicate what they originally depicted. Two angled plinths stand here, one in the alcove to the east and another in the alcove to the west. A single door leads north; the south wall opposite it bears the outline of a door but no handle or latch.

This mostly destroyed room once held relief art extolling the majesty of Belcorra and Nhimbaloth. All that remains are two plinths, one on both sides of the room, that each bear a unique lock. The door to the south (and the one beyond it) doesn’t open normally; each is functionally a solid stone wall 2 feet thick unless unlocked.

The eastern plinth features a lock with a round keyhole; turning the proper key in this lock opens or closes the northernmost door in the passage to the south (the outline visible in this room) with a grinding noise. The western plinth has four holes clustered together in a metal plate; turning the proper key in this lock opens or closes the southern of the two doors with a loud grinding noise. Without the proper keys, a character can activate one of these tricky locks with a successful [[/check ability=dexterity dc=25]] check using Thieves’ Tools.

Plinth Keys

As described on the @UUID[JournalEntry.huN2s6RInuTublnV.JournalEntryPage.tPPxP1ysQky3lsv3]{Keys} handout, three copies of each key exist scattered around this level.

• The @Item[XMNqir7oUGoFemFM]{Round Key} can be found on a shelf in the old medical supply room (area @UUID[JournalEntry.JT0zCcIwsSpKnbB5.JournalEntryPage.vygkTjkdSwK8uXzB]{E05}) and in the prisoner processing chamber (area @UUID[.JhZf5mGUPNZqZSum]{F10}).

• The @Item[WLO06eLC1Uo8XzBf]{Four-pronged Key} can be found on the floor of the old dissection chamber (area @UUID[.sGI8w7LQqXuwWhHp]{F06}) and in Vischari’s safe (area @UUID[.96tKiXroDGWLKvJk]{F16}).

• Jafaki also carries a copy of each key.

Observation Gallery.name: Observation Gallery
Observation Gallery.text:
Fifteen feet below the ceiling, this gallery traverses all but the east side of a large, bloodstained room with a floor five feet lower than the gallery. A window made of cloudy, transparent stone provides an excellent view of the nearby room while blocking direct access to it. Two rounded observation areas overlook the room from the north; a small room to the south has a small table, an old chair, and stairs leading up.

Belcorra used this walkway to observe her champions closely as she pitted them against various opponents or as they settled disagreements through ritual combat. A magical enchantment in the two rounded observation vestibules transmit sound from the testing ground into this observation gallery, but not vice versa. The table features some pieces of chalk and a few writing slates, upon which the seugathis take notes when observing creatures in the testing grounds.

Stairs near the southwest corner ascend to area @UUID[JournalEntry.JT0zCcIwsSpKnbB5.JournalEntryPage.d7y3Wc10QZ6wZO5P]{E21}.

The northwest door has no visible latches, but the wall next to it features two distinct keyholes: one is a round indentation, and the other is a circular piece of stone with four separate holes. They function identically to the keyholes in area @UUID[.4DSWkmCkIZ8iD20I]{F7}.

The wall at the eastern end of the observation gallery bears faintly glowing magical glyphs. These glyphs simultaneously affect all the transparent stone ringing the gallery and operate as described in area @UUID[JournalEntry.JT0zCcIwsSpKnbB5.JournalEntryPage.84aV9OCD0kfmzpC8]{E9}.

Encounter

@UUID[Actor.v9B0hB5sm4YZxebY]{Seugathi Servant}

A Seugathi Servant observes the two Gibtas Spawn Swarms in the testing grounds (area @UUID[JournalEntry.KI33EAGPVHP4zyFZ.JournalEntryPage.SEAO53LL3c9WdjdO]{F9}) and takes notes on a writing slate. Upon noticing the intruders, they become eager to see how the swarms perform in combat; they retreat as soon as possible to the east end of the gallery to turn the wall ethereal. Once the wall is no longer solid stone, the swarms notice the characters’ presence and join in the fight as the seugathi directs. Keep in mind that, together, they present a difficult encounter for level 6 characters.

Treasure: The seugathi carries a Wand of Wonder that it eagerly employs just to see how the other combatants respond to its unpredictable effects.

Exploration

Two secret doors lead out of this room to the north (to area @UUID[JournalEntry.KI33EAGPVHP4zyFZ.JournalEntryPage.psfaf5Skhe3bMKsr]{F5}) and southeast (to area @UUID[JournalEntry.KI33EAGPVHP4zyFZ.JournalEntryPage.yBAZCPJ2rioIU3Fx]{F20}). A character who searches the correct area and makes a successful [[/check skill=investigation dc=15]] notices the door. Both secret doors operate the same way: a masonry square near floor level depresses like a button and causes the secret door to unlatch and swing open.

Testing Grounds.name: Testing Grounds
Testing Grounds.text:
This twenty-foot-high chamber’s stone floor is heavily stained with blood. A wall of transparent stone separates this room from an observation gallery that rings its north, west, and south sides. The northeast corner features a short stone well, while the room’s south end has a steep, ascending staircase. The room juts out a side hall to the east that ends at a charred circle in the stone with a double door nearby.

This chamber was intended for grudge matches between gladiators; however, it saw equal use in testing the aberrant monsters’ capabilities. Since Jafaki seized control of this level, the room has served only as testing grounds.

The room is 20 feet high from floor to ceiling, and the floor is 5 feet below the observation gallery. Two iron ladders bolted to the north wall ascend the 5 feet to the transparent stone, but they don’t allow access to the gallery unless the characters use the glyphs in area @UUID[JournalEntry.KI33EAGPVHP4zyFZ.JournalEntryPage.fIH3LXVbvaKFJzOc]{F8} to render the stone ethereal.

A sturdy iron grate caps the well in the north. It was built to provide food—normally in the form of defeated combatants cut into chunks—to the hydras in the pool. The grate appears firmly fastened to the stone but easily comes off if tried. The devil that sneaked into area @UUID[JournalEntry.KI33EAGPVHP4zyFZ.JournalEntryPage.psfaf5Skhe3bMKsr]{F5} broke away the grate’s bolts for easy access to the seugathis’ chambers, but it died before venturing into this room.

The steep staircase to the southeast leads up to the gladiators’ mead hall (area @UUID[JournalEntry.JT0zCcIwsSpKnbB5.JournalEntryPage.xVfdltaZZguZ35F1]{E25}). The charred circle in the eastern wing is the other end of the @UUID[Compendium.dnd5e.spells24.Item.phbsplTeleportat]{Teleportation Circle} in the mead hall.

Encounter

@UUID[Actor.Zfw5kA7oWWhof759]{Gibtas Spawn Swarms (2)}

Upon arrival, the characters find two Gibtas Spawn Swarms systematically melting chunks of crystal with their acid at the command of the seugathi in the observation gallery. Hungry for fresh meat, they attack the characters immediately, particularly if they arrive with a dramatic clanging in the Teleportation Circle. The swarms fight to the death and pursue foes that flee. The seugathi in the observation gallery, if present, eagerly takes notes throughout the combat but doesn’t intervene.

Prisoner Processing.name: Prisoner Processing
Prisoner Processing.text:
Anchored shackles and fetters line the north and west walls, and bloodstains obscure the stone floor. At the east and south, two sets of double doors lead out of the room; two steep staircases beside each of them lead somewhere further below.

While Belcorra lived, jailers brought prisoners up the stairs and shackled them to the walls before processing their paperwork on a desk that has long since been removed. These captives were then shuffled into the arena, ready to meet their death for the entertainment of Belcorra’s cheering guests. This room became a frequent battleground during the brief turf war between Jafaki and Urevian. When some degree of peace settled over these levels, Jafaki’s creations still held this room. Two fleshwarps remain on guard.

The stairs descend to area @UUID[JournalEntry.OyNcqrpRClyhr8BJ.JournalEntryPage.f5osZazCn5ra84Jp]{G12}. The hallway to the south gently slopes 10 feet down to the arena.

Exploration

Three stairs down the northern steps, a @UUID[Item.XMNqir7oUGoFemFM]{solitary key} lies forgotten beneath a crusty chunk of dried viscera. A character who searches the stairs and makes a successful [[/check skill=perception dc=10]] check locates it. The key has a round shaft tipped with several teeth of varying length. It opens one of the locks in area @UUID[JournalEntry.KI33EAGPVHP4zyFZ.JournalEntryPage.4DSWkmCkIZ8iD20I]{F7}.

Encounter

@UUID[Actor.zsgW8hHm3JfZUgwF]{Mulventoks (2)}

Two Mulventoks guard this room at the seugathis’ command. The seugathis don’t realize it, but the devils have inflicted an infernal malediction to gradually weaken these guards. They’re both now constantly restless and tense, and they suspect that something is wrong with them, but they remain attentive to their duties and are determined to slaughter anyone who isn’t accompanied by a seugathi. Occasionally will-o’-wisps from other parts of the Abomination Vaults drift by invisibly to feast on their constant and growing fear.

Due to the curse, the mulventoks have Disadvantage on attack rolls and ability checks, as well as on saving throws to avoid or end the @UUID[Compendium.dnd5e.content24.JournalEntry.phbAppendixCRule.JournalEntryPage.93uaingTESo8N1qL]{Frightened} condition, which reduces their Challenge Rating to 4 (1,100 XP).

Warped Brew Tavern.name: Warped Brew Tavern
Warped Brew Tavern.text:
Polished wooden tables, chairs, and a long wooden bar mark this chamber as a tavern. The smell of spilled beer and fried morsels pervades the room. In the southeast corner, an elevated stage overlooks the seating. Doors lead out of this room along all four walls, including a double door to the west that looks to be the main entrance.

Once an elaborate dining hall for Belcorra’s gladiators and guests, this area has, over the years, taken on the function of a tavern for fleshwarped creatures, those waiting to undergo fleshwarping, and a few rare visitors. It has had its current name—the Warped Brew Tavern—for more than a century. Due to Jafaki’s general lack of discipline, many of this level’s denizens come here to drink, gamble, argue about who’s next to go under the seugathis’ knives, and listen to Shadow Malice, the resident band.

The door to the southwest opens onto a steep stairway that leads up to area @UUID[JournalEntry.JT0zCcIwsSpKnbB5.JournalEntryPage.84aV9OCD0kfmzpC8]{E9}. When the poltergeists there started flinging debris down the stairway, the patrons stopped using it, except as a garbage disposal. In addition to being Difficult Terrain, a creature that moves more than 10 feet on the stairs on a turn must succeed on a [[/check skill=acrobatics dc=13]] check or fall @UUID[Compendium.dnd5e.content24.JournalEntry.phbAppendixCRule.JournalEntryPage.QxCrRcgMdUd3gfzz]{Prone}.

Tavern Patrons

@UUID[Actor.5F42ZxYVqUTYEyZS]{Lallizanx}, @UUID[Actor.KSFGGxU3qxYJzWpe]{Morlock Scavengers (2)}, @UUID[Actor.V73Oqm1EL1KOoXOl]{Morlock Engineer}, @UUID[Actor.bsTPkBWaFAFAMkKV]{Morlock Cultist}

Five creatures are usually found in the tavern: a female Drider named Lallizanx, flipping through a book filled with crudely drawn drow erotica; two Morlock Scavengers playing a card game called Towers; a Morlock Engineer tending bar; and a Morlock Cultist complaining to the bartender about having to wait so long for her fleshwarping. There’s a 1 in 4 chance that the tavern’s band, Shadow Malice, is playing; the GM can determine this randomly or just decide whether the band is playing when the characters arrive.

Lallizanx is ostensibly a bouncer but cares little what happens in the tavern. The morlock patrons hope to be chosen for fleshwarping in the near future, and even the morlock bartender looks forward to becoming like the powerful dreshkans who come here from time to time.

Everyone here assumes that intruders from the surface, like the characters, have come to start a fight. If the characters display peaceful intentions, these patrons keep a close eye on them but resume their business. The bartender has only a few drinks available but sells them to the characters at inflated prices.

Lallizanx threatens any character who persists at bothering her, insisting that she be left alone. The morlock bartender gives only a halfhearted attempt to prevent the characters from leaving by either of the doors behind the bar; she doesn’t consider her pay sufficient to stand in the way of well-armed intruders. The morlock patrons all idolize the band Shadow Malice and are certain to bring them up in conversation

If a fight breaks out, the tavern’s urdefhan manager, Vischari, comes from area @UUID[JournalEntry.KI33EAGPVHP4zyFZ.JournalEntryPage.96tKiXroDGWLKvJk]{F16} in 3 rounds to join the battle. Vischari and Lallizanx fight to the death to protect the tavern they consider their home turf, while any morlock reduced to fewer than 10 Hit Points flees. If the members of Shadow Malice are present, they retreat to area @UUID[JournalEntry.KI33EAGPVHP4zyFZ.JournalEntryPage.w7j4LONWc9tgS5ci]{F18} rather than risk injury.

Battle of the Bands

@UUID[Actor.WR07Z6MjvebSHzI7]{Ryta}, @UUID[Actor.HnIyJuqKNOvK7eOJ]{Nox}, @UUID[Actor.VeyuTE1GUJ71oMMn]{Kragala}, @UUID[Actor.uWn6DCzthgUt97d7]{Gulzash}

If the characters seem at all curious about Shadow Malice (regardless of the band’s presence), the morlocks all start chanting the band’s name and “Challengers!” in Undercommon. This might seem like the morlocks intend to set up the characters to fight against the band, but they’re calling for a battle of entertainment, not of weapons. The cries bring Shadow Malice onto the stage, if the band isn’t already there, and Ryta, their vocalist, explains the rules.

"You want to challenge us? Then let’s get to it. We’ll each face off one-on-one. Each pair squares off with some kind of show: music, acrobatic tricks, displays of strength, whatever. Then we perform as two groups—mine then yours—and let the crowd tell us who’s the best overall!”

A band member provides the best solo performance they can by making a Charisma (Performance) check. This check is then contested by the paired character, who makes an ability checking using a relevant skill or instrument, such as Performance, Acrobatics, Athletics, or any other skill the GM deems appropriate to impress the crowd in the tavern. Whichever character scores the highest result wins. Record whether each character wins the contest. The second phase is the group phase. Shadow Malice performs a high-energy musical number, then passes over their instruments for the characters to use (if the characters don’t have any of their own). Unlike the individual contests, this last phase must be a Charisma check using Performance or a musical instrument, not any other skill. If the characters balk, Ryta just grins and says, “This stage is for performers, friend.” One character must attempt a [[/check skill=performance dc=15]] check. One other character proficient in Performance or with any musical instrument can Help with this check as a back-up performer. In addition, the character attempting the Charisma check gets a cumulative +1 bonus for each character who succeeded in the individual phase.

If the characters succeed on this final Charisma check, Ryta acknowledges them as Shadow Malice’s superior on the stage and resolves to leave them alone. Word gets back to Vischari about the characters’ success, and the tavern manager treats them with a modicum of respect. If the characters’ Charisma check succeeds by 5 or more, Ryta gives them the group’s instruments, insisting that the instruments belong in the hands of such talented performers. The other members of Shadow Malice grumble at this decision but sullenly comply.

If the characters fail this final Charisma check, Shadow Malice sees them as being out of their depth and resolves to take advantage by attacking the characters right on the stage. Anyone remaining in the tavern simply watches the fight, considering it a bloody part of the show; if the characters’ Charisma check failed by 5 or more, the patrons join the fight after the first round. In this case, the characters should make a hasty retreat before getting overwhelmed.

XP Award: If the characters participate in the challenge against Shadow Malice, award them [[/award 1200xp]]. If the characters win without resorting to violence, award them an additional [[/award 2000xp]] (up to [[/award 3200xp]] total).

Treasure

@UUID[Item.5Z5JUobL5vbY8E0w], @UUID[Item.rwFHPhqQl1scXnnu]

The gambling morlocks have a total of [[/award 25gp 181sp]], a gold tooth worth [[/award 5gp]], and a perfectly fossilized bass skeleton on the table. Behind the bar, the cash box contains [[/award 58gp 74sp]], and a vial filled with Pale Tincture poison that the bartender uses to poison troublesome patrons.

Kitchen.name: Kitchen
Kitchen.text:
This dirty kitchen features a working stove replete with oil stains, gristle, and the strong aroma of smoke. Alcoves to the north contain meat hooks and large baskets of harvested fungus.

Many creatures that frequent the Warped Brew are evil carnivores who relish the flesh of the living, so the meat hooks often have intelligent creatures dangling from them. There are three such creatures here now. All still live but are unarmed, weakened from their captivity, and desperate to avoid being placed on the menu. The creatures include a deep gnome named Glashdrumdur, a drow named Falxi Orshendiel, and a dwarf named Jedzeli. The heroes find all three of them tightly bound, hanging from meat hooks, and unable to free themselves.

XP Award: Award the characters 1,200 XP for each prisoner they set free and help to reach an exit to the Abomination Vaults.

@UUID[Actor.b6qiHvyx6ymROTBL]{Glashdrumdur}

This grumpy deep gnome Warrior Veteran has been here the longest and is currently Unconscious with 5 levels of Exhaustion. If roused, he’s quick to swear vengeance against the fleshwarped raiders who captured him, but he acknowledges he’s outclassed and prefers to leave the Abomination Vaults behind. He has little to tell the characters.

@UUID[Actor.pFPLCspUfJ2FUMcj]{Falxi Orshendiel}

This young drow Scout Captain is Chaotic Neutral. The most alert when the characters first arrive here, he quickly asks for his freedom. He knows the seugathis have considered transforming him into a drider or feeding him to the patrons here, and he desperately wishes to avoid either fate. He explains that he hails from a small drow settlement deeper underground called Yldaris, but he’s unwilling to give much detail about Yldaris to strangers. He says only that the city welcomes traders and that the characters should visit, peacefully, if they come to the area. Falxi and two other drow were scouting farther from their settlement than usual when urdefhans attacked them; he was knocked unconscious and somehow ended up here. Though selfish, Falxi isn’t evil (nor are the other inhabitants of Yldaris). If the characters let him go, he’ll make his way back to his settlement and might meet them in area I6 later. The characters’ encounter with Falxi should suggest that Yldaris is safe to visit and set the stage for a peaceful encounter with drow living in the lower levels.

@UUID[Actor.uGXTQYuRNtgPt1Pp]{Jedzeli}

This unfortunate dwarf Scout hangs limply on her hook, her right hand missing. She mutters constantly about “the man in colored rags who takes hands.” Other attempts at conversation with her prove unintelligible, and she responds to questions about the “man in colored rags” with increasing distress. Before Ysondkhelir discovered the psychic human girl, Dorianna Menhemes, he amused himself by tormenting Jedzeli’s dreams. With a successful [[/check skill=insight or intelligence (investigation) dc=15]] check, a character who has interacted with Dorianna notices some disturbing similarities with the way Jedzeli mutters about the “man in colored rags.” Helping Jedzeli reclaim her sanity is a long and difficult road outside the scope of this adventure, but Glashdrumdur offers to look out for her if the characters are willing to set them both free and get them someplace where they can leave the dungeon far behind.

Treasure

@UUID[Compendium.dnd-abomination-vaults.av-items-5e.Item.VUjX3Gs4bKyz8rGR]{Sloughing Toxin (3)}

While nothing in this kitchen is suitable for consumption by anyone but perhaps a goblin, a large jar labeled “seugathi tenderizer” is in the bottom of one of the mushroom baskets. The jar contains three doses of Sloughing Toxin.

Level 6 Portal Chamber.name: Level 6 Portal Chamber
Level 6 Portal Chamber.text:
Teleportation Network

Some of the @UUID[Compendium.dnd5e.spells24.Item.phbsplTeleportat]{Teleportation Circles} within the Abomination Vaults form a part of a larger network. By tracing specific patterns on the wall runes, someone could transport everyone in any one of these chambers to one of nine other portal chambers in the Abomination Vaults- so long as the teleportation circles in both the departure chamber and destination have been awakened by the @UUID[Compendium.dnd-abomination-vaults.av-items-5e.Item.H0KYIrtDeeV2pSyC]{Awaken Portal} ritual (area @UUID[JournalEntry.KeWKr2yd8dbppeS5.JournalEntryPage.8X4xF40k06MW0X7q]{C35}).

The nine chambers are areas @UUID[JournalEntry.uMZ0RiCcPSqsx1Nm.JournalEntryPage.537bzfVUpq6XbR9a]{B17}, @UUID[JournalEntry.KeWKr2yd8dbppeS5.JournalEntryPage.vEiow4kU961XNOJp]{C16}, @UUID[JournalEntry.Os5bHdzCDiXgJBQ6.JournalEntryPage.RJf3BCpcVW6d68s7]{D05}, @UUID[JournalEntry.JT0zCcIwsSpKnbB5.JournalEntryPage.LJhOoRqYjj38YWl8]{E18}, @UUID[JournalEntry.KI33EAGPVHP4zyFZ.JournalEntryPage.mDFVGUXY6YDuQWF3]{F13}, @UUID[JournalEntry.OyNcqrpRClyhr8BJ.JournalEntryPage.zTpatmyyb4JvgNCo]{G02}, @UUID[JournalEntry.FwWmtOBFHhvM2gtf.JournalEntryPage.Nak2hUmVOHXBkcR5]{H33}, @UUID[JournalEntry.1vlzl3NJsftNB9Dc.JournalEntryPage.DJKWR2KLTPUi3w6T]{I59}, and @UUID[JournalEntry.yn21bNM6kpV4xRol.JournalEntryPage.JinYTJeYVFBE1uky]{J05}

This circular chamber is plainly used for storage, as it has several large casks stacked along its rounded walls. Dull silver fills the faded runes carved into the stone walls.

This room contains an inert Teleportation Circle like the ones in areas @UUID[JournalEntry.JT0zCcIwsSpKnbB5.JournalEntryPage.LJhOoRqYjj38YWl8]{E18} and @UUID[JournalEntry.OyNcqrpRClyhr8BJ.JournalEntryPage.zTpatmyyb4JvgNCo]{G2}. As with those chambers, this Teleportation Circle must be reactivated with the Awaken Portal ritual to connect it with the Abomination Vaults’ portal network.

XP Award: Award the characters [[/award 500xp]] for activating this portal.

Storage Room.name: Storage Room
Storage Room.text:
Spare chairs and shelves piled with grimy bottles and poorly cleaned dishes fill this storage room.

The patrons of the Warped Brew are served from the filthy dishes here, usually without washing them first, which should make any character reconsider ordering anything to eat in the tavern.

Moldy Supplies.name: Moldy Supplies
Moldy Supplies.text:
Fuzzy pale moss covers the shelves of this room and their contents. Motes of spores drift through the air.

Fungal Rot

Hazard

Fungal rot had started to grow here, leaving it unusable. After months of being left alone, the mold has grown all over the walls. The mold is identical to the fungal rot in area @UUID[JournalEntry.JT0zCcIwsSpKnbB5.JournalEntryPage.iyKMP5yxckkjhl2P]{E15}.

Treasure

@UUID[Item.rNQbYcZpZQ2Kj2Jt]{Congealed Potion of Superior Healing}

A forgotten Potion of Superior Healing in the back of the room has partially congealed over time. A character can drink this potion using a Bonus Action to shake it loose before spending an action to drink it.

Tavern Office.name: Tavern Office
Tavern Office.text:
This messy office features a battered wooden desk with paperwork and ink stains scattered over its surface. The only exit is a door to the south.

This office belongs to the manager of the Warped Brew Tavern, an urdefhan named Vischari. The papers include supply lists, startling recipes for serving different kinds of fungus, and employee pay rates. The chaos of the office belies Vischari’s orderly mind—she knows where everything is here.

Encounter

@UUID[Actor.qoyopMMlRdgPAbXZ]{Vischari}

Vischari is an Urdefhan Brawler who used to make the trip from the urdefhan stronghold deeper in the Abomination Vaults to enjoy the atmosphere in the Warped Brew a few times a year. On one visit, she realized that the seugathis planned to capture and experiment on her the next time she visited the establishment. Rather than leave the tavern she’d come to enjoy, Vischari elected to make herself indispensable by murdering the tavern’s old owner and taking over. She’s proven to be a competent manager, so the seugathis have kept their threats to operate on her to a minimum.

Vischari knows that anyone disrupting the Warped Brew’s operations threatens her livelihood, so she readily attacks surface dwellers who barge in uninvited. If she already knows the characters, such as if they bested the tavern’s band, she instead simply insists they leave before she guts them and serves them in stew.

Treasure

A dented safe under Vischari’s desk is locked with a simple lock, but Vischari— perhaps unwisely—keeps the key in the lock so she can access it easily. The safe holds neat stacks of coins ([[/award 10PP 134GP 279SP 157CP]]) and an @Item[WLO06eLC1Uo8XzBf]{odd key} with an elaborate four-prong design. This is one of the keys that opens a lock in area @UUID[JournalEntry.KI33EAGPVHP4zyFZ.JournalEntryPage.4DSWkmCkIZ8iD20I]{F7}.

Private Dining.name: Private Dining
Private Dining.text:
Placed against the east wall, a disgusting table holds a buffet of smelly fried morsels, gloppy dipping sauce, and spiny mushrooms.

This food is provided for the members of Shadow Malice. Although not poisonous, this buffet isn’t likely to appeal to the palates of surface dwellers. Doors exit to the north and south; the one to the south has the words “Performers Only” written on it in Undercommon.

Dressing Room.name: Dressing Room
Dressing Room.text:
Oversized furniture, certainly intended for rooms larger than this one, has been jammed into this small room. An acrid smell, like burning paint, fills the air.

Creatures

@UUID[Actor.uWn6DCzthgUt97d7]{Gulzash} @UUID[Actor.VeyuTE1GUJ71oMMn]{Kragala} @UUID[Actor.HnIyJuqKNOvK7eOJ]{Nox} @UUID[Actor.WR07Z6MjvebSHzI7]{Ryta}

Shadow Malice’s members hang out in this room when not on stage. The smell comes from a cracked and barely functioning hookah, which the band nevertheless uses to smoke whatever substances they can find.

The four members of Shadow Malice are Gulzash, Kragala, Nox, and Ryta. If encountered here, they insist that the characters leave them alone. If the characters seem up for a challenge but aren’t overtly combative, Ryta challenges them to a battle of entertainment on the Warped Brew’s main stage in area @UUID[JournalEntry.KI33EAGPVHP4zyFZ.JournalEntryPage.ad2vkPdR6V7Jxymf]{F11}. If things come to blows with Shadow Malice, they’re competent and aggressive combatants. Gulzash swings with his battle lute, while Nox fights with their dagger. Kragala and Ryta prefer to cast spells to harass enemies from a distance but can fight in melee: Kragala clubs foes with her drumsticks, and Ryta gnaws at her enemies. If any of them are reduced to fewer than 15 Hit Points, they flee, taking their cherished instrument with them to seek a safer and less troublesome gig elsewhere.

Treasure

@UUID[Item.wGBFIoT7lmOn4nvj]{Theorbo}, @UUID[Compendium.dnd-abomination-vaults.av-items-5e.Item.WBypdkSXc2zQldJL]{Folding Drums}

In addition to their weapons and armor, Shadow Malice members carry a theorbo (a Musical Instrument worth [[/award 30gp]] that weighs 10 pounds) and a set of Folding Drums.

Back Stage.name: Back Stage
Back Stage.text:
Stands for music, a folded velvet curtain, and the wooden cutout of a tree clutter this small space.

Props for the stage are stored here when not in use. Gulzash usually sleeps on the folded curtain.

Exploration

@UUID[Item.XyWh8kkMbksaLdem]{Velvet Curtain}, @UUID[Compendium.dnd5e.equipment24.Item.dmgCloakOfElvenk]

The velvet curtain is in very good condition and worth [[/award 10gp]], although it weighs 40 pounds and smells vaguely of lizard. Folded up within it is a Cloak of Elvenkind spun from gossamer. Anyone searching the room or taking the curtain as loot discovers it.

Lower Observation Deck.name: Lower Observation Deck
Lower Observation Deck.text:
This long chamber is rounded on both ends with a door to the north and a curved wall of transparent stone to the south. A faint stink wafts from a door in the west wall.

This observation area permits an intimate view of the fights in the arena. Since viewing the spectacle is a bit better from the higher arena balconies, usually trainers or fleshwarpers watched the fights here to get a close and detailed view of the action.

Encounter

@UUID[Actor.v9B0hB5sm4YZxebY]{Seugathi Servant}, @UUID[Actor.DnAeqlJRZc5N7hve]{Dreshkans (2)}

A Seugathi Servant observes the shanrigol behemoth in the arena and takes notes in a large tome. Their two Dreshkan bodyguards stand ready to defend them from any trouble. The seugathi frantically protects their research, screeching for the dreshkans to enter melee while the seugathi wields a sword in one tentacle and uses the other to keep their book away from foes.

Treasure: The seugathi carries a Deck of Illusions and a tarnished silver key that unlocks the door to the main laboratory (area @UUID[JournalEntry.KI33EAGPVHP4zyFZ.JournalEntryPage.1UGSUnBhEjOeJhkM]{F25}).

The seugathi’s book contains several sketches of the shanrigol behemoth and notes in Aklo about its nature (it’s undead but with features of aberrations, and it includes parts of, and therefore derives abilities from, driders and urdefhans), its weakness to Radiant damage, and that it’s kept relatively docile in the arena by a steady diet of failed experiments. The book also includes instructions for creating @UUID[Compendium.dnd-abomination-vaults.av-items-5e.Item.fzOSCGAhECarQTfS]{Basic} and @UUID[Compendium.dnd-abomination-vaults.av-items-5e.Item.4qJfnpl2Hyqi0uwo]{Moderate} Necrotic Bombs. The book is worth [[/award 100gp]] to a collector of rare tomes, such as Morlibint.

Spa.name: Spa
Spa.text:
This room bears the rich stink of rot. Doors to four changing stalls prominently appear at the east end of this long hallway. Each door has a makeshift clockwork mechanism attached to it, and the mechanism connects to a lever on the eastern wall through a series of wires and pulleys. The hallway to the west has four wide exits concealed by tattered curtains. Another, thicker curtain blocks the west end of the hall.

The spa kept the gladiators in their best health and entertained visiting guests. None of the seugathis or their minions want to use it. The four tiny changing rooms to the east have wooden doors that stop six inches from the ceiling and floor. The four thinner curtains cover alcoves that served as massage rooms; each now contains only a dilapidated massage table. The thicker curtain conceals the entrance to the sauna (area @UUID[JournalEntry.KI33EAGPVHP4zyFZ.JournalEntryPage.0hOpXdRZnb442AKU]{F22}).

An enterprising morlock engineer rigged a complicated clockwork latching mechanism to turn the changing rooms into very small prison cells. The lever opens all four doors at once, but it then sticks and won’t close them again.

Encounter

@UUID[Actor.LHHgGSs0ELCR4CYK]{Ghouls (2)}, @UUID[Actor.VC7rtYR4hLxwg7WZ]{Ghasts (2)}

The room’s stink plainly originates from the changing rooms. Some of Jafaki’s minions captured, tortured, and imprisoned two Ghouls and two Ghasts here, one in each changing room. The gaps below and above the doors allow the ghasts’ potent stench to escape, but not the undead themselves. They occasionally reach under or above the doors with their claws but can’t harm anyone who isn’t pressed up against a changing room door. If freed, they immediately attack any living creatures they see, so cunning characters might free and use the undead to fight other enemies in the dungeon.

Sauna.name: Sauna
Sauna.text:
This round sauna is constructed entirely from polished stone. A wooden bench lines the circumference of the room, save for a thick curtain over the exit to the east. At the center of the chamber stands a stone pedestal topped with a heavy bronze bowl filled with red-hot rocks. A wooden bucket full of water rests next to the pedestal.

The bowl maintains a magical Evocation effect that keeps the rocks within it constantly heated. The command to turn it off and on is long forgotten. The intense heat in the room gives all creatures in the room a –1 penalty to saving throws against Fire damage or against effects that increase their level of Exhaustion.

Encounter

@UUID[Actor.2K0oJcLauMwyRNZQ]{Murschen}

The brawler Murschen is a rare skulk who enjoys public attention. Once lauded as his town’s best brawler, he started exploring the world in search of fame and wealth and to further his ability to hurt people who consider themselves strong. Eventually, Murschen came with the notion that the seugathis could make him an even better warrior. Jafaki believes Murschen will make an excellent candidate for fleshwarping, so they shower the skulk with treasure and pit him against their finest monstrosities in the testing grounds (area @UUID[JournalEntry.KI33EAGPVHP4zyFZ.JournalEntryPage.SEAO53LL3c9WdjdO]{F9}). He has a magical sigil on his forehead reading “victor” in Aklo, which he bears with evident pride.

Murschen hasn’t yet figured out that the seugathis don’t intend to let him leave once they’ve experimented on him or that their experimentations will likely to result in a tortured existence.

Murschen doesn’t like being outnumbered and therefore doesn’t pick a fight with the characters right away, yet he also doesn’t want to simply let them go. He attempts to make his way past the characters to the lever to release the ghouls and ghasts. Once the undead have softened the characters up, Murschen plans to beat them to death. He doesn’t realize that the undead are just as likely to attack him as the characters. If reduced to fewer than 20 Hit Points, Murschen flees the Abomination Vaults altogether.

Side Quest

Murschen has met the urdefhan brawler Vischari a time or two. If the characters take the time to talk with the skulk, he mentions that he wants nothing more than a one-on-one brawl with her to determine who’s best. Vischari has never taken Murschen’s challenges seriously, and the seugathis consider her too useful as the manager of the Warped Brew to force her into the arena. If the characters agree to set up a match between them, Murschen lets them leave to do so.

Vischari isn’t likely to agree to a fight unless she’s on particularly good terms with the characters (such as if they bested Shadow Malice, either in a performance or in combat). A character who’s on good terms with Vischari must make a successful [[/check skill=persuasion dc=16]] check to convince her to accept Murschen’s challenge. The two set up an exhibition match on the Warped Brew’s stage, wagering Murschen’s medal and silvered dagger against the contents of Vischari’s office safe. The two are evenly matched, so the GM can decide who wins; neither combatant will be in any shape to challenge the heroes in the aftermath. Whether or not the heroes threaten to pounce upon them in this moment of weakness, the victor considers the possibility and offers the spoils from the fight if the characters agree to leave them alone thereafter.

XP Award: Award the characters [[/award 1200xp]] for setting up the grudge match.

Treasure

@UUID[Item.3SijAV78DuJGGY2H]{Murschen's Treasures}

Murschen wears a platinum medal worth [[/award 250gp]]. His other treasure is stashed under a bench: a gold and emerald ring worth [[/award 140gp]], a ruby-encrusted silvered dagger worth [[/award 175gp]], a fine mithral bracelet engraved with the word “champion” in Aklo worth [[/award 200gp]], and a bag filled with [[/award 130gp 90sp]].

Storage Closet.name: Storage Closet
Storage Closet.text:
Cluttered tools, scraps of wood, and furniture are haphazardly stacked in this cramped room.

The seugathis use this area as a storage closet. Only their minds can comprehend why they store things like broken tables, a dismantled clock, a brass kettle with four evenly spaced holes in its bottom, or seven mustard-yellow and moth-eaten bedsheets.

Exploration

A character who searches this area might find useful items hidden among the trash. With a successful [[/check skill=investigation dc=18]] check, the character finds one of the following items. If the check succeeds by 5 or more, the character finds two items. The valuables include:

• An @UUID[Compendium.dnd-abomination-vaults.av-items-5e.Item.H30145kBo5lA3DzU]{Ichthyosis Mutagen}

• A @UUID[Compendium.dnd5e.equipment24.Item.dmgPotionOfGrowt]{Potion of Growth}

• An @UUID[Compendium.dnd5e.equipment24.Item.dmgRingOfJumping]{Ring of Jumping}

• A well-stocked @UUID[Compendium.dnd5e.equipment24.Item.phbtulHerbalismK]{Herbalism Kit} containing [[/award 525gp]] worth of @UUID[Item.xIbNPd2nwsSz5MGa]{rare herbs} which can be used as raw materials to craft potions and elixirs

Torture Chamber.name: Torture Chamber
Torture Chamber.text:
Hellforged Weapons

Weapons forged in the depths of Hell often gain sinister powers. Urevian established a hellforge on the Prison level (area @UUID[JournalEntry.OyNcqrpRClyhr8BJ.JournalEntryPage.AeQmFFVsCUF02tzd]{G5}) and has gifted a few of his favored followers with Hellforged Weapons manufactured there. In the hands of a devil, Hellforged Weapons deal an additional [[/r 1d6]] Necrotic damage. Although worth as much as an ordinary weapon of its kind, Hellforged Weapons exude palpable menace, and upstanding merchants usually refuse to trade in them.

As the characters approach this room, there’s a 1 in 3 chance that one of the Accuser Devils from the room is patrolling the hallway, invisible. If it spots the characters but isn’t detected, it returns to the torture chamber to alert the other devils, who prepare to rush out of the room and attack.

The stone walls of this chamber appear to glisten with blood. An iron maiden stands in one corner, while in the other stands a metal table bristling with nails.

Belcorra felt the natural red stone walls of this room, which appear slick due to water seeping through them, made it an ideal place for a torture chamber. The victims here were usually gladiators in the arena who she felt showed mercy or an insufficient will to fight.

Encounter

@UUID[Actor.4bznEiwsJvInwZwA]{Bearded Devil}, @UUID[Actor.wCsfRovcZMZxSdGm]{Accuser Devils (2)}

Urevian sent a Bearded Devil and a pair of Accuser Devils to secure this floor and prepare for an incursion. The bearded devil keeps several weapons at ready and awaits further orders. An accuser devil occasionally patrols the north corridor. When they spot one of Jafaki’s minions in the corridor, the devils attack, drag the minion here, and torture it to death. The iron maiden currently holds a morlock corpse. A devil reduced to fewer than 15 Hit Points flees back to the prison (invisibly, if possible) and reports on the heroes’ presence to Urevian. They’re then reassigned elsewhere on that level, at the GM’s discretion. The bearded devil wields a Hellforged Glaive. When the devil hits with an attack using the Glaive, the weapon deals an extra 1d6 Necrotic damage.

Treasure

@UUID[Item.UQsHRnNH496sgzAy]{Weapon Racks}

The weapon racks hold another Hellforged Glaive, a Hellforged Dagger, and three Moderate Necrotic Bombs.

Main Laboratory.name: Main Laboratory
Main Laboratory.text:
The door to this chamber is locked with a good-quality lock. A character who succeeds on a [[/check ability=dexterity dc=23]] check using Thieves’ Tools can pick the lock, or it can be unlocked using the key held by the seugathi in area @UUID[JournalEntry.KI33EAGPVHP4zyFZ.JournalEntryPage.yBAZCPJ2rioIU3Fx]{F20}. The characters can force open the sturdy door with a successful DC 25 Strength check.

Books, glass bottles emitting smoke, and clumps of slime fill the shelves that cover the high walls of this chamber. The southern area displays the dissected remains of several creatures, pinned to a wall like rare and unusual specimens. The head of a morlock, somehow kept alive through some mechanical means with tubes and wires connecting to its body, screams a constant hoarse note.

The ceiling of this room is 25 feet high, and its shelves go all the way to the ceiling.

Jafaki does all their best work in this chamber, continuing their existence’s driving purpose: scientifically engineering the most powerful monsters. Jafaki has tried mutagens, fleshwarping, and more bizarre sciences. They even work to make the best of their failures, such as by cultivating the shanrigol behemoth in area @UUID[JournalEntry.KI33EAGPVHP4zyFZ.JournalEntryPage.pPa93mirtnlxQxlr]{F26}.

Disappearing Morlocks: Jafaki is wrapped up in their experiments and projects but nevertheless has an effect on the surrounding dungeon. Every few days, Jafaki calls for one of the morlocks in the Warped Brew Tavern to come here with the promise of being fleshwarped into a dreshkan. The morlocks eagerly come since Jafaki has created the many dreshkans in the Abomination Vaults, but it’s a ruse. Jafaki instead carefully dissects the morlock to add additional living pieces to their current golem project. If the characters come here but retreat, Jafaki continues these gruesome experiments; when the characters return, there should be more morlock parts affixed to the machinery (and fewer morlocks in area @UUID[JournalEntry.KI33EAGPVHP4zyFZ.JournalEntryPage.ad2vkPdR6V7Jxymf]{F11}, if any remained there). If there are no more morlocks, Jafaki starts capturing and dissecting the members of Shadow Malice instead.

Encounter

@UUID[Actor.jE8BEe6pcnGraw2p]{Jafaki}, @UUID[Actor.B7eLG2k7qUo8HU6O]{Drider}

Jafaki and a Drider assistant are nearly always here. Jafaki sends the drider to answer any knock at the door since other seugathis sometimes come by for Jafaki’s guidance. The characters might take advantage of this habit to take the preoccupied researcher by surprise.

If the characters work to force the door open or pick its lock, Jafaki realizes they’re intruders and prepares for a fight. The drider scrambles up to the ceiling while Jafaki casts Fly to stay out of melee reach.

Both of these foes fight to the death—the drider out of loyalty to Jafaki, and Jafaki because they can’t abandon their life’s work.

Treasure: Jafaki carries a Rapier, three Moderate Necrotic Bombs, two vials of Sloughing Toxin, an Ichthyosis Mutagen, a Potion of Greater Healing, a Wand of Lightning Bolts, as well as keys to areas @UUID[JournalEntry.JT0zCcIwsSpKnbB5.JournalEntryPage.bsvsBLUT905lHxD8]{E11} and @UUID[JournalEntry.KI33EAGPVHP4zyFZ.JournalEntryPage.4DSWkmCkIZ8iD20I]{F7}.

Side Quest

Jafaki’s current project is to manufacture a flesh golem with the occult machinery here. They intend to assemble it using the morlock’s head and neatly labeled body parts scattered around the room. A sketchpad bears the instructions for assembly and notes that ambient necromantic energy in the Abomination Vaults will activate the flesh golem. The key to this experiment is the occult machinery keeping its head alive, which focuses this energy. Finishing the golem requires Jafaki’s knowledge and expertise; doing so goes beyond the characters’ capabilities.

The characters can, however, disconnect the machine to end the morlock’s torment. A character can attempt to disconnect this machinery by making a [[/skill 15 arc]] check. On a successful check, the morlock head dies, and the machinery can’t be used again. On a failure, or if the characters simply smash the machine, the morlock head dies, but the invisible energies accumulated within the machine seek another source of stitched skin and meat to animate as a flesh golem. If the characters left the fleshy statue of Belcorra intact in the Temple of the Canker (area @UUID[JournalEntry.KeWKr2yd8dbppeS5.JournalEntryPage.wAoRY1yKOiu1ocVU]{C34}), these errant energies animate it as a @UUID[Actor.sNFBOw4z9KagWUHe]{Flesh Golem}. The flesh golem comes to life with an instinctive drive to find and kill whoever ruined the machine. It always knows the distance and direction to the character responsible and immediately begins pursuit down through the Abomination Vaults. As the golem is far away, it might take hours to catch up to the characters, at the GM’s discretion, but when it does, it fights until destroyed.

XP Award: Award the characters 1,800 XP, as if they’d defeated a flesh golem, for successfully disconnecting the occult machinery.

Treasure

Scattered around the lab are the equivalent of a Healer’s Kit, an Herbalism Kit with rare herbs worth [[/award 500gp]] (suitable as raw materials for crafting potions or elixirs), and a Poisoner’s Kit with ingredients worth [[/award 500gp]] (suitable as raw materials for crafting poisons). None of the items are together, however, and several minutes of investigation are required to assemble them all. The shelves also contain two vials of Antitoxin and a book of Jafaki’s notes with instructions to create Sloughing Toxin and Ichthyosis Mutagen. The book can be sold to Morlibint in Otari for 75 GP. It’s illegal for anyone to buy the Poisoner’s Kit or its ingredients, but if the party has the support of Crook’s Nook, then Yinyasmera can discreetly purchase these items.

Arena Floor.name: Arena Floor
Arena Floor.text:
Dried blood from past combats forms a crust over the sand spread across this arena’s stone floor. Torches illuminate the floor in bright light but hardly reach the walkway ringing the arena high above. Two staircases lead up to this walkway, but a metal portcullis blocks each one.

The site of hundreds of bloody battles, this area entertained Belcorra’s bloodthirsty guests and tested her many gladiators. From these champions, she chose officers to lead her monstrous armies. The portcullises are controlled by a wheel and lever on the balcony above (area @UUID[JournalEntry.JT0zCcIwsSpKnbB5.JournalEntryPage.gPJ4Hrw4cAGuyDqT]{E26}), but a creature can lift a closed portcullis with a successful DC 20 Strength check. The east and west doors are unlocked.

Encounter

@UUID[Actor.mrxDc0fj5t5CvjJQ]{Shanrigol Behemoth}

After the death of hundreds of monsters and gladiators, the arena is imbued with the essence of death. When Jafaki started to dump the scraps from their various failed creations here, the decaying flesh spontaneously arose as shanrigols. The first few times this happened, Jafaki had their driders drag them to the monster holding cells (area @UUID[JournalEntry.JT0zCcIwsSpKnbB5.JournalEntryPage.UgMnFry9Z6qFiRMX]{E3}) for study. Curious about how large these creatures would grow, Jafaki simply made a large pile and assigned one of their seugathis to study its composition and its growth.

Treasure

@UUID[Item.zeCoLddDFpk1s1r0]{Arena Equipment}

A few creatures have attempted to prove their might by fighting the shanrigol—and lost. Their equipment is still scattered in the bloody sand on the floor: a set of Splint Mail, a set of Studded Leather armor, a +1 Longbow, and a Spell Scroll of Spirit Guardians.

Introduction.name: Introduction
Introduction.text:
Chapter Synopsis

The Abomination Vaults’ sixth level served to support the gladiator games in the arena above but also included extensive laboratories for creating increasingly bizarre and powerful abominations. A small team of seugathis pursue their fleshwarping experiments here while resisting encroachment from the devils on the level below. The characters encounter these wormlike monsters, but they also find a strangely civilized tavern in the midst of the dungeon.

The Laboratory

Under Belcorra, the Abomination Vaults’ sixth level was split between support for the arena above and the laboratories that created new and terrible monsters. The two activities weren’t all that separate since the most powerful of the monsters created in the laboratories fought in the arena, where the survivors joined Belcorra’s growing ranks of monsters to assault Absalom. Conversely, failures in the arena became fodder for experiments in the laboratories.

When Belcorra died, the overbearing control of a bone devil named Tarkannah initially kept infighting on this level at a minimum, but some creatures chafed at Tarkannah’s control. The seugathi fleshwarper@UUID[JournalEntry.67686KaEPc6XAlKJ.JournalEntryPage.qrb0F1AQ3iIR7Xni]{ Jafaki} organized a coup and murdered the bone devil, taking control of the entire floor. Since this rebellion, Jafaki has maintained the level as the seugathis’ domain, believing their resources are better spent on the relentless refining of experimentations rather than expanding territory.

Due to Jafaki’s relatively relaxed disposition toward administration, creatures on this level tend to look after themselves. Many are more recent arrivals who have come seeking the seugathis’ skills and are willing to risk experimentation for the chance of becoming stronger. Creatures who haven’t been slated for fleshwarping yet spend most of their time drinking and relaxing in a large chamber that has long served as a tavern called the @UUID[JournalEntry.KI33EAGPVHP4zyFZ.JournalEntryPage.ad2vkPdR6V7Jxymf]{Warped Brew}. The urdefhan Vischari manages the Warped Brew, keeping cooks, bartenders, and even a band on retainer.

Features

Environmental Cues:

Acid pitting on floors and doors, crude graffiti carved into walls, distant shrieks, old bloodstains, squelching noises, stench of acrid chemicals and beer.

This level feels more cramped than the lofty arena level above because of its lower ceilings, which average 10 feet high in halls and 15 feet high in rooms, unless otherwise indicated. None of the rooms on this level have light, as the denizens can all see in the dark. The stone doors have sturdy iron hinges; most can simply be pushed open, which the seugathi do to move around. The smell of acrid chemicals lingers throughout this level, except near the @UUID[JournalEntry.KI33EAGPVHP4zyFZ.JournalEntryPage.ad2vkPdR6V7Jxymf]{Warped Brew}, where the smell of spilled fungus beer predominates instead.

Visitor’s Reading Room.name: Visitor’s Reading Room
Visitor’s Reading Room.text:
This large, cross-shaped chamber contains several long couches, the leather cushions that once adorned them cracked with age. Dead plants lie slumped in planter boxes along the walls, and a long-dry fountain depicting a lighthouse stands in the middle of the room.

Belcorra didn’t allow visitors into her library except in this room and the reading rooms to the north. A librarian would fetch texts for visitors to peruse in comfort. The fountain and plants here have long since dried up.

The stairs beyond the door to the east lead up to area @UUID[JournalEntry.uMZ0RiCcPSqsx1Nm.JournalEntryPage.eAD9hbPpzj5aLBZY]{B16}.

Exploration

Characters can discover the secret door to the south with a successful [[/check skill=investigation dc=15]] or [[/check skill=perception dc=20]] check. The switch to open it is concealed behind a heavy sofa.

Macro: If the players pull aside the sofa and open the door, use the @Macro[iUbfy5VEWndwBFmU]{C1 - Secret Door} macro to toggle the door state and the tile's visibility in one go.

Creature

A unique undead creature dwells in this room today. @UUID[Actor.saEUzIgUtV2AzKhl]{Augrael} is a morlock ghoul exiled by his living kin among the Ghost Queen morlocks above, just as he’s reviled by the ghouls of the Cult of the Canker who occupy this level. As he hasn’t been steeped in the maliciousness or fervor of either group, Augrael is quite calm and collected. When the characters arrive, he greets them cordially but cautiously.

Augrael wants only to dwell within these dungeons, reading and feeding on undead flesh— he has little taste for flesh that was merely once living. He has hazy recollections of how he and the other Ghost Queen morlocks came up from below and fought the ghouls, as the ghoul fever he contracted fragmented his memories. He knows the rough layout of areas @UUID[JournalEntry.KeWKr2yd8dbppeS5.JournalEntryPage.F229BVFENz1ZjmG1]{C1}, @UUID[JournalEntry.KeWKr2yd8dbppeS5.JournalEntryPage.AU1IGoQPqItk9Dms]{C6}, @UUID[JournalEntry.KeWKr2yd8dbppeS5.JournalEntryPage.YhRSOC6JXrOhl9wU]{C10}, @UUID[JournalEntry.KeWKr2yd8dbppeS5.JournalEntryPage.l9NjtV6c0sjeD50H]{C11}, @UUID[JournalEntry.KeWKr2yd8dbppeS5.JournalEntryPage.eOv6LI3wvIuKyyNJ]{C15}, and @UUID[JournalEntry.KeWKr2yd8dbppeS5.JournalEntryPage.tTVIrzNZtjKG1XVb]{C33} since his memories of the morlocks’ flight through these rooms are freshest.

Augrael’s initial attitude to the characters is Indifferent, but he can become Friendly if the characters prove that his chief rival among the morlocks, Graulgust, is dead. The characters can convince Augrael to accompany them as they explore this level with a successful [[/check skill=intimidation/persuasion dc=15]] check (for 1 day plus 1 day per point by which the result exceeds the DC). A failed Intimidation attempt makes Augrael angry and Hostile; he attacks if the heroes don’t depart immediately. Either way, his propensity to glut himself on ghouls the heroes defeat is likely to be both off-putting and macabre.

XP Award: Award the characters [[/award 200xp]] for gaining Augrael as an ally.

Tunnel to Otari.name: Tunnel to Otari
Tunnel to Otari.text:
The Stonescale Warrens

When the Stonescale kobolds took over Otari, they used the buildings above as a sort of camouflage, living in an extensive network of tunnels that connected many of the buildings below ground. Today, this network is a complicated tangle of flooded or collapsed tunnels. Thieves and smugglers from the @UUID[JournalEntry.67686KaEPc6XAlKJ.JournalEntryPage.sdNti6BHkPTeO5fC]{Osprey Club} use some, while others have become the dens of monsters. This one connects the Abomination Vaults to Otari.

Belcorra’s pet purple worm dug this long tunnel for visitors coming from the coast who didn’t want to travel overland. The passage leads several hundred feet under the waters of @UUID[JournalEntry.67686KaEPc6XAlKJ.JournalEntryPage.dMyS4bNbb1diRzow]{Fogfen} to intersect with the Stonescale kobold warrens beneath Otari (which connect to deeper Darklands passages). These warrens ultimately lead to rooms beneath the @UUID[JournalEntry.67686KaEPc6XAlKJ.JournalEntryPage.l16Ah0LKik675YMp]{Otari Fishery}.

Exploration

The secret door to area @UUID[JournalEntry.KeWKr2yd8dbppeS5.JournalEntryPage.F229BVFENz1ZjmG1]{C1} is easier to find from this side—it’s a smooth section of a natural passage. A character can identify it with a successful [[/skill 11 inv]] or [[/check skill=perception dc=13]] check.

Haunted Reading Room.name: Haunted Reading Room
Haunted Reading Room.text:
The cracks around the edge of this door glow faintly with greenish light, like around the door to area @UUID[JournalEntry.uMZ0RiCcPSqsx1Nm.JournalEntryPage.BHmLYQVCwzBneNFu]{B28}.

An ancient, tattered sofa sits against the east wall of this room. The south wall glows and shimmers with ribbons of strange, green light.

This private reading room was the second room in which Otari Ilvashti sought shelter in his desperate final days. As in area @UUID[JournalEntry.uMZ0RiCcPSqsx1Nm.JournalEntryPage.BHmLYQVCwzBneNFu]{B28}, his ghost’s energy yet lingers. When the characters enter this room, the green light forms the message:

“Belcorra fell to the Roseguard, but we never knew of these vaults below...”

A moment later, the words slide off the wall and slither away. If the characters follow, the ribbon creeps back up to area @UUID[JournalEntry.KeWKr2yd8dbppeS5.JournalEntryPage.AU1IGoQPqItk9Dms]{C6} and then past the stairs at @UUID[JournalEntry.KeWKr2yd8dbppeS5.JournalEntryPage.YhRSOC6JXrOhl9wU]{C10}. Here, the ribbon hesitantly climbs the northern stair only to turn around and quickly slither further east. The ghostly light enters area @UUID[JournalEntry.KeWKr2yd8dbppeS5.JournalEntryPage.l9NjtV6c0sjeD50H]{C11}, curls onward to @UUID[JournalEntry.KeWKr2yd8dbppeS5.JournalEntryPage.tTVIrzNZtjKG1XVb]{C33}, and then through the eastern door and down the stairs before fading. The characters can pick up the final clue of Otari’s path in area @UUID[JournalEntry.Os5bHdzCDiXgJBQ6.JournalEntryPage.2GyngLCPk5da2fMK]{D16}.

This spectral manifestation can appear once per day.

Not-So-Private Reading Room.name: Not-So-Private Reading Room
Not-So-Private Reading Room.text:
An ancient sofa with its covering torn open and its stuffing and springs revealed sits against the west wall of this room.

Exploration

This reading room contains much more than meets the eye. Secret doors in the north and south walls, either of which can be found by a character who succeeds on a [[/check skill=investigation dc=18]] check, open into a hidden hall around the room. A character who searches the wall above the couch and who succeeds on another [[/check skill=investigation dc=18]] check discovers a peephole. If Belcorra deemed a visitor to be dangerous, her forces ambushed the visitor and brought them through a Teleportation Circle in area @UUID[JournalEntry.KeWKr2yd8dbppeS5.JournalEntryPage.VZPc5GsIN5eRKSVE]{C5b} to be imprisoned in area @UUID[JournalEntry.Os5bHdzCDiXgJBQ6.JournalEntryPage.u6H893WYAlzxntns]{D11}.

Watching Wall

Haunt

The final victim of this room, a spy from Absalom whose intelligence had already brought Belcorra’s activities to the attention of the Roseguard, met his end here. When he put up a fight and Belcorra tried to subdue him, she accidentally killed him instead. She bound the lingering spirit of the paranoid spy into a cruelly poetic magical trap.

An overwhelming feeling of being watched wells up in the minds of those in the room, an instant before an eerie red eye opens in the western wall.

Characters who succeed on a [[/check skill=religion/insight dc=15]] check sense an unquiet spirit as they enter the room, the hair on the backs of their necks standing on end. A character who succeeds on the Religion check also deduces that the spirit is bound by magic and only harmful to those it sees reacting to it. A spell or other effect that can sense the presence of magic, such as Detect Magic, reveals an aura of necromancy around the wall.

A creature that spends more than a few moments in the area triggers the haunt, causing an eerie red eye to open in the center of the western wall and look about the room. When the haunt is triggered, roll Initiative.

On each of their turns, a character can hide from the eye with a successful [[/check skill=stealth dc=15]] check or appear fearless with a successful [[/check skill=deception dc=15]]. Alternatively, a character who makes a successful [[/check skill=religion dc=15]] check can recall and perform a gesture that wards against being seen by the spirit, rendering themselves or another willing creature they touch immune to the haunt’s effects until the haunt activates again. The eye can be attacked (AC 14, 20 Hit Points, Vulnerability to Radiant damage, Immunity to Necrotic and Poison damage) or temporarily dispelled with a Dispel Magic spell.

While the haunt remains active, each round on Initiative count 0, a wave of paranoia washes over all creatures in the area. Each creature makes a [[/save ability=wisdom dc=15]] saving throw. Creatures who have taken precautions (such as hiding from or warding themselves against the eye) or that are immune to the haunt’s effects automatically succeed on the save. On a failed save, the creature takes [[/damage 2d6 psychic average]] damage and has the @UUID[Compendium.dnd5e.content24.JournalEntry.phbAppendixCRule.JournalEntryPage.93uaingTESo8N1qL]{Frightened} condition for 1 minute. A Frightened creature feels a reckless urge to get out of sight. On each of its turns, the creature must take the Dash action to move toward area @UUID[JournalEntry.KeWKr2yd8dbppeS5.JournalEntryPage.AU1IGoQPqItk9Dms]{C6}. At the end of the each of its turns, the target repeats the saving throw, ending the effect on itself on a success.

If the haunt is disabled, it falls dormant until the next midnight. The only way to disable the haunt permanently is to free Lasda Venkervale from area @UUID[JournalEntry.Os5bHdzCDiXgJBQ6.JournalEntryPage.RmFsEEQSD9Ulugwm]{D9}.

XP Award: Award the party [[/award 400xp]] the first time they disable the trap temporarily or trick it into falling dormant early.

Spying Hall.name: Spying Hall
Spying Hall.text:
This plain, angled hall has four alcoves. Each western alcove has a shimmering circle of runes inlaid on the floor. A peephole in the eastern wall allows observation of the room beyond.

In addition to once giving Belcorra a place to spy upon visitors in area @UUID[JournalEntry.KeWKr2yd8dbppeS5.JournalEntryPage.4PltW460esTJLLtr]{C4}, the western alcoves formed a limited teleportation hub independent of the portal chambers. Neither alcove is currently active.

The northwestern alcove (area C5a) once teleported anyone entering it to the hidden alcove in area @UUID[JournalEntry.kDJSn9wbVvjnqYEj.JournalEntryPage.koVFvK0xxQMwKjaW]{A4}, and vice-versa. Since that room was scoured clean of its gem dust and defaced long ago by a determined treasure-hunter, it can’t be restored.

The southwestern alcove (area C5b) once teleported anyone entering it to the silver-lined cage in area @UUID[JournalEntry.Os5bHdzCDiXgJBQ6.JournalEntryPage.u6H893WYAlzxntns]{D11}. This was a one-way teleportation used to capture prisoners. This Teleportation Circle can be reactivated by the @UUID[Compendium.dnd-abomination-vaults.av-items-5e.Item.H0KYIrtDeeV2pSyC]{Awaken Portal} spell found in area @UUID[JournalEntry.KeWKr2yd8dbppeS5.JournalEntryPage.8X4xF40k06MW0X7q]{C35}, so long as that spell is performed at both ends (that is, here and in area @UUID[JournalEntry.Os5bHdzCDiXgJBQ6.JournalEntryPage.u6H893WYAlzxntns]{D11}). Both secret doors are obvious from this side.

Guard room.name: Guard room
Guard room.text:
Thick clouds of white mist fill this room entirely, making it difficult to discern any details.

Encounter

@UUID[Actor.mmSteamMephit000]{Steam Mephits (3)}

Belcorra originally bound a half-dozen Steam Mephits in this room to serve as guardians. Otari killed three of them years ago, but three remain. The monsters can see through the mist they generate with ease, and as soon as they identify intruders, they move to attack, fighting until destroyed. They pursue foes that flee but don’t leave sight of this room.

Exploration

A character who makes a successful [[/check skill=investigation dc=12]] discovers the secret door in the west wall. The secret alcove to the west served as an emergency cache of supplies for the guards on this floor. Most of the supplies were raided during the chaos following Belcorra’s death, but one item of use remains: a @UUID[Compendium.dnd5e.items.Item.L887NdWEP5NqHCrQ]{Potion of Greater Healing}.

Korlok’s Post.name: Korlok’s Post
Korlok’s Post.text:
Hundreds upon hundreds of tiny hash marks mar the walls of this empty room, as if someone had been counting days for ages. To the northwest, an iron door with a barred window sits in the wall, a large but open padlock hanging from the door’s latch.

The second of the two devils Belcorra stationed on the upper levels of the Abomination Vaults stands guard here. The Bearded Devil Korlok takes his post literally, and without any new orders from Belcorra over the past several centuries, he has remained here under her final command to “wait here and let no one out until I come for you.”

She never did.

Encounter

@UUID[Actor.9vvY2wr7HnJoCLEz]{Korlok}

This isn’t the longest posting that Korlok has served, but it’s already starting to grate on his patience. If the characters enter the room, he stands at attention and, in a slightly bored voice, informs them that, as intruders, they are under arrest and should hand over their gear before stepping into the adjoining prison. He fights to the death if attacked, or if any character attempts to leave (which gives him an excuse to leave the room).

Side Quest

The devil is patient and willing to speak to the character for a few minutes if they wish. If they can improve his attitude with a successful [[/check skill=intimidation/persuasion dc=15]], Korlok admits his frustration. The GM might decide that other checks—such as a [[/skill dec]] check—also appease Korlok. He knows Belcorra is dead, but without access to his contract, he can’t study it for a loophole. He suggests a trade—he’ll let the characters go just this once, but the next time they return, he’ll arrest them if they don’t present him with his contract. He isn’t sure where the paper is stored but suspects it’s hidden somewhere in the library.

If the characters present the contract (located in area @UUID[JournalEntry.KeWKr2yd8dbppeS5.JournalEntryPage.E0TcXGYuA92wAB2y]{C37}), Korlok studies it and discovers his service was meant to end if 99 weeks and 99 days passed without a new order from Belcorra. Before he vanishes back to Hell, the thankful devil explains that he knows of other devils in the Abomination Vaults: an accuser devil janitor on the level above and a contract devil named @UUID[JournalEntry.67686KaEPc6XAlKJ.JournalEntryPage.t9SSGAP5pW2NpkWh]{Urevian} on a lower level (who has several other devils in his command). Korlok has nothing but scorn for the janitor, but he makes a point of telling the characters that Urevian is well-known for scrupulously keeping his word.

XP Award: Award the characters [[/award 200xp]] if they learn what Korlok knows without fighting him.

Prison.name: Prison
Prison.text:
An overturned chamber pot lies next to a rectangular patch of fungus that might have once been a mattress in the corner of this room. A skeleton is just visible within the fungus.

The skeleton is all that remains of Belcorra’s first chef, a hapless man who had the misfortune of over-spicing a meal. Perhaps due to some lingering effect of the fastidious chef’s spirit, the fungus here is not only edible but rather tasty.

Twin Stairwells.name: Twin Stairwells
Twin Stairwells.text: This hallway serves as a landing for two staircases: one leading up to area @UUID[JournalEntry.uMZ0RiCcPSqsx1Nm.JournalEntryPage.hOMUDNapQMRjV1kQ]{B2} in the north and the other leading up to area @UUID[JournalEntry.uMZ0RiCcPSqsx1Nm.JournalEntryPage.8qZk6POeK6TgPon4]{B32} in the south. Splintered, rotten wood lies scattered around this hall, left over during the morlocks’ flight from this level.

Main Library.name: Main Library
Main Library.text:
Hundreds of stone shelves are carved into the walls of this wide hallway. While there are many gaps in the collection, a staggering number of books, scrolls, and folios remain. Signs hang above several doors off of this hall. To the south, a violet glow flickers beneath a larger sign.

The books kept here cover a wide range of subjects, and the Cult of the Canker keeps the stacks organized. A character with the luxury of perusing these tomes for 8 hours becomes familiar enough with the library’s organization to gain a +1 bonus to Intelligence checks to research regional history, arcane topics, aberrations, and undead here during downtime.

The signs here are all in Undercommon. The one above area @UUID[.eOv6LI3wvIuKyyNJ]{C15} to the south reads, “Reading Room.” The ones over the smaller doors are labeled as follows: area @UUID[.TukfnGJXQkB3UYSH]{C12} is “Repair Storage,” area @UUID[.Z3iUNrD6kbgazSIY]{C13} is “Workroom,” area @UUID[.jz7V8pdoBnKX4368]{C17} is “Safety” with a carving of leaping flames, area @UUID[.QaUQGVYx5WFwgQgV]{C18} is “Personal Quarters,” area @UUID[.0tLGIjz5j6NrA4uC]{C19} is “Scrivener’s Office,” area @UUID[.AheFAUwUtko3qnDA]{C26} is “Belcorra’s Office,” the hallway leading to areas @UUID[JournalEntry.KeWKr2yd8dbppeS5.JournalEntryPage.QyDogj0m5OoqMtUg]{C30} to @UUID[JournalEntry.KeWKr2yd8dbppeS5.JournalEntryPage.VoqYMxZSwLDn0l4y]{C32} is “North Wing,” and area @UUID[.tTVIrzNZtjKG1XVb]{C33} is “Restricted Collection.”

Encounter

@UUID[Actor.LHHgGSs0ELCR4CYK]{Ghouls (3)}

Three Ghouls all dressed in flowing, pale- blue librarian’s robes work here, both to stand guard and to select or retrieve books for the scriveners or cult leaders to use or repair as needed. They don’t immediately attack the characters but do lick their lips in anticipation while sizing up the characters’ fleshy bits. One ghoul asks the party if they’re here to “donate flesh for the Canker,” hoping the characters are willing to offer body parts to the work in area @UUID[JournalEntry.KeWKr2yd8dbppeS5.JournalEntryPage.wAoRY1yKOiu1ocVU]{C34}. A character foolish enough to agree is expected to lop off an appendage (a finger, toe, or ear will suffice) for the ghouls, who scurry off to area @UUID[JournalEntry.KeWKr2yd8dbppeS5.JournalEntryPage.wAoRY1yKOiu1ocVU]{C34} with the donation. Any other attempt to interact with the ghouls quickly makes them impatient, and they attack. These ghouls fight until destroyed.

If a fight here goes on for more than 4 rounds or is particularly loud, the ghouls from area @UUID[JournalEntry.KeWKr2yd8dbppeS5.JournalEntryPage.eOv6LI3wvIuKyyNJ]{C15} come to investigate and join in.

Side Quest

A character who knows Morlibint of @UUID[JournalEntry.67686KaEPc6XAlKJ.JournalEntryPage.0SO6cXvfRTtHZM6m]{Odd Stories} in Otari (or who succeeds on a [[/check ability=intelligence dc=10]] check when seeing the books) realizes that he would likely be interested in this collection. If a character tells Morlibint about the library here, the wizard eagerly provides a long list of specific titles, publishers, and general themes to seek in the shelves. In this area, along with those of other book-filled rooms nearby, the number of books that can be salvaged and collected for Morlibint are given a weight. A character searching for books in one of these rooms can attempt a [[/check skill=investigation dc=13]] check to sort through the books and secure 10 pounds from the room’s total available book weight.

If your players secure any books in this way, you can use the @Item[SSMdEvSAlggOWV0v]{Valuable Books} item to represent a stack of books totalling 10 pounds, and grant them an additional one for every 10 pounds of books that they retrieve. Morlibint pays [[/award 50gp]] per 10 pounds of books delivered to him in this way.

XP Award

If the characters deliver at least 60 pounds of books to Morlibint, they complete the side quest and gain [[/award 200xp]]. They can sell him more books if they find any.

Treasure

@Item[SSMdEvSAlggOWV0v]{Valuable Books}

The books kept here are of general knowledge and thus of little interest to Morlibint; there are only 10 pounds of books here to gather for him in total.

Repair Materials.name: Repair Materials
Repair Materials.text:
Shelves on the wall here feature iron sorting racks, jars, and all manner of bookbinding tools.

Treasure

@UUID[Item.RC9Zo54VtJxz5Kjt]{Repair Materials}

This room contains repair materials for the upkeep of books. All are too old to be useful. A character searching this room discovers two Spell Scrolls of Mending and a set of Calligrapher’s Tools.

Librarian’s Workroom.name: Librarian’s Workroom
Librarian’s Workroom.text:
The door to this room from area @UUID[JournalEntry.KeWKr2yd8dbppeS5.JournalEntryPage.l9NjtV6c0sjeD50H]{C11} is locked, and its key is inside the room. A character can pick the lock with a successful [[/check dex thief 15]] or force it open with a successful [[/check ability=strength dc=15]], but a failed Strength check alerts the ghost in the room to the characters’ presence.

Three worktables line the walls of this room with a single stool near one of the tables. A skeleton wearing a light blue librarian’s robe lies in a heap beside the stool.

Three specialized benches here are outfitted to bind books, repair pages, and prepare parchment, respectively. The tables and their tools are old and now useless.

Encounter

@UUID[Actor.hia81Ut7fEREbhkq]{Jarelle Kaldrian}

The ghost of the librarian Jarelle Kaldrian still haunts this workroom. Jarelle couldn’t escape the other scholars’ increasingly gruesome schemes, so she retreated into this room, locked the door, and drank a jar of arsenic (used to work with book bindings) rather than be eaten alive. She died quickly and in agony, only to rise soon thereafter as a ghost. Jarelle spends her time pantomiming the act of repairing books. She reacts with anger at any interruption, accusing the characters of murdering Belcorra and ruining her life.

Jarelle’s Fate: Emptying this room of all its tools allows Jarelle to move on to the afterlife.

Treasure

@UUID[Item.MuIp8D1pF5zkjF7R]{Jarelle's Remains}

A search of Jarelle’s remains turns up the key to the door to area @UUID[JournalEntry.KeWKr2yd8dbppeS5.JournalEntryPage.l9NjtV6c0sjeD50H]{C11}, a gold paperweight worth [[/award 10gp]], a set of Eyes of Minute Seeing, and Calligrapher’s Tools.

Librarian’s Bedroom.name: Librarian’s Bedroom
Librarian’s Bedroom.text:
A small, cramped bed is wedged awkwardly into this room, and sagging bookshelves line the walls.

Jarelle once lived here before she took her life in area @UUID[.Z3iUNrD6kbgazSIY]{Area C13}. The books she kept here were mostly duplicates of others found elsewhere in the library, but she viewed them as her private collection.

Treasure

@Item[SSMdEvSAlggOWV0v]{Valuable Books (2)}

There are 20 pounds of books here to gather for Morlibint.

Gauntlight Reading Room.name: Gauntlight Reading Room
Gauntlight Reading Room.text:
