This chamber’s smooth stone walls glisten with moisture despite the air being dry and somewhat stuffy. Several low divans are arranged in a circle and interspersed with low tables stacked with a few books and rotting morsels of decayed flesh. A twisting ribbon of pale violet light stretches between the bare floor at the room’s center and the ceiling above, its points of contact sending creepers of what looks like infected tissue out in a distorted spiral.

As in area @UUID[JournalEntry.uMZ0RiCcPSqsx1Nm.JournalEntryPage.8pbhSFgv71lvCz9M]{B35}, the ribbon of sickly light is a manifestation of Gauntlight’s growing power. This room once served as a reading room for library staff as well as a place where they could directly evaluate Gauntlight’s energies. This eerie light churns in a 5-foot-diameter Cylinder at the room’s center. An Undead creature that ends its turn within the Cylinder regains [[/heal 2d6 average]]{7 (2d6)} Hit Points. Any other creature that ends its turn in the area make a [[/save ability=constitution dc=10]] saving throw. Constructs automatically succeed on the save. On a failed save, the creature takes [[/damage 2d6 necrotic average]] damage. As long as Gauntlight remains at its low-level activation, the light continues to churn, but if the characters rescue Lasda Venkervale from area @UUID[JournalEntry.Os5bHdzCDiXgJBQ6.JournalEntryPage.RmFsEEQSD9Ulugwm]{D9}, the ribbon winks out.

Encounter

@UUID[Actor.LHHgGSs0ELCR4CYK]{Ghouls (2)}

Today, two Cult of the Canker Ghouls relax here with books and snacks. Ripened morlock flesh has been a staple of their diets lately, but the ghouls decide to add adventurer flesh to the menu once they spot the characters. As they fight, any ghoul brought below half its Hit Points moves into the ribbon of light to gain some necromantic healing, shoving a rival ghoul out of the way if necessary.

Exploration

A character who searches the room and makes a successful [[/check skill=investigation dc=15]] check spots the secret door to area @UUID[JournalEntry.KeWKr2yd8dbppeS5.JournalEntryPage.vEiow4kU961XNOJp]{C16} in the curved western wall.

Level 3 Portal Chamber.name: Level 3 Portal Chamber
Level 3 Portal Chamber.text:
Teleportation Network

Some of the @UUID[Compendium.dnd5e.spells24.Item.phbsplTeleportat]{Teleportation Circles} within the Abomination Vaults form a part of a larger network. By tracing specific patterns on the wall runes, someone could transport everyone in any one of these chambers to one of nine other portal chambers in the Abomination Vaults- so long as the teleportation circles in both the departure chamber and destination have been awakened by the @UUID[Compendium.dnd-abomination-vaults.av-items-5e.Item.H0KYIrtDeeV2pSyC]{Awaken Portal} ritual (area @UUID[JournalEntry.KeWKr2yd8dbppeS5.JournalEntryPage.8X4xF40k06MW0X7q]{C35}).

The nine chambers are areas @UUID[JournalEntry.uMZ0RiCcPSqsx1Nm.JournalEntryPage.537bzfVUpq6XbR9a]{B17}, @UUID[JournalEntry.KeWKr2yd8dbppeS5.JournalEntryPage.vEiow4kU961XNOJp]{C16}, @UUID[JournalEntry.Os5bHdzCDiXgJBQ6.JournalEntryPage.RJf3BCpcVW6d68s7]{D05}, @UUID[JournalEntry.JT0zCcIwsSpKnbB5.JournalEntryPage.LJhOoRqYjj38YWl8]{E18}, @UUID[JournalEntry.KI33EAGPVHP4zyFZ.JournalEntryPage.mDFVGUXY6YDuQWF3]{F13}, @UUID[JournalEntry.OyNcqrpRClyhr8BJ.JournalEntryPage.zTpatmyyb4JvgNCo]{G02}, @UUID[JournalEntry.FwWmtOBFHhvM2gtf.JournalEntryPage.Nak2hUmVOHXBkcR5]{H33}, @UUID[JournalEntry.1vlzl3NJsftNB9Dc.JournalEntryPage.DJKWR2KLTPUi3w6T]{I59}, and @UUID[JournalEntry.yn21bNM6kpV4xRol.JournalEntryPage.JinYTJeYVFBE1uky]{J05}

The walls of this circular chamber are decorated with intricate, intertwining runes and shapes carved deep into the stone and filled with shimmering dust. The floor and ceiling are polished to a reflective sheen.

This room contains an inert Teleportation Circle like the one in area @UUID[JournalEntry.uMZ0RiCcPSqsx1Nm.JournalEntryPage.537bzfVUpq6XbR9a]{B17}. Just as with that room, this Teleportation Circle must be reactivated with the Awaken Portal spell hidden in area @UUID[.8X4xF40k06MW0X7q]{C35} before it can be used.

XP Award: Award the heroes [[/award 500xp]] for activating this portal.

Firefighting Supplies.name: Firefighting Supplies
Firefighting Supplies.text:
Several buckets of sand and a number of large barrels crowd this cramped storeroom. A simple wooden case with a closed lid is attached to the back of the door.

The supplies kept here are available to extinguish fires, a significant threat in any library. The barrels once held water but now contain only mildew.

Treasure

@UUID[Item.85fMX0QKM0aqFKK1]{Firefighting Supplies}

The case on the back of the door is latched but simple to open; it holds a pouch of Dust of Dryness containing three pinches of unused powder and three pellets of dried-up water.

Temporary Bunks.name: Temporary Bunks
Temporary Bunks.text:
Three plain beds have been awkwardly stacked against the west wall of this room, leaving space for a single low table heaped with foul-smelling chunks of flesh and bone.

While most servants who toiled in the library kept quarters aboveground, some needed rest during long stretches of research. The ghouls don’t need the beds and simply stacked them out of the way.

Encounter

@UUID[Actor.LHHgGSs0ELCR4CYK]{Ghouls (3)}

This room now serves as a dining room for three Ghouls who are feasting on the remains of a morlock. They attack the characters on sight, but the first one injured flees to area @UUID[JournalEntry.KeWKr2yd8dbppeS5.JournalEntryPage.0tLGIjz5j6NrA4uC]{C19} to recruit Aller Rosk’s aid.

Scrivener’s Workshop.name: Scrivener’s Workshop
Scrivener’s Workshop.text:
While this room might have once served as a writing studio, today its condition has been all but obliterated by dozens of tiny swatches of skinned flesh marked with tattoos. Judging by the workspace on the table in the middle of the room, these tattoos have been placed postmortem, with a swath of pale skin stretched over the desk sporting a half-completed image of a sinister woman.

Aller Rosk is a Cult Tattooist who served as a notary and scribe for Belcorra when he lived. After he died and became a ghoul, his nature and interests shifted, if only slightly. He has developed a unique taste for tattooed flesh. The idea of writing something down and then eating it appeals to the twisted ghoul, and when he isn’t preparing a not-so- fresh morlock for distribution to the other ghouls, he’s here, preparing his latest work on a swath of morlock skin.

Aller’s current project is a depiction of Belcorra in an intricate tattoo form. While he doesn’t intend to eat this one, some part of him knows that this work of art, once he’s done, won’t have a fate any different than numerous others he has created over the years.

Encounter

@UUID[Actor.tOL4rWj2oYWZ4ow2]{Aller Rosk}

Aller is focused on his work and suffers a –2 penalty to Initiative. If interrupted, he seethes and curses, wasting his first action informing the characters about the blasphemous limericks and humiliating odes he’ll be tattooing onto their dead bodies.

Single-minded to a fault, Aller Rosk pursues foes relentlessly once a fight begins and fights until destroyed.

Treasure

@Item[SSMdEvSAlggOWV0v]{Valuable Books}

This room contains 10 pounds of books about tattoo artistry and historical tattoos of interest to Morlibint.

Scrivener’s Office.name: Scrivener’s Office
Scrivener’s Office.text:
The desk in this office has been repurposed into a messy butcher’s block. A shiny silver hatchet is wedged in the top of the desk, and bits of decaying pale flesh lie strewn about the room.

Aller repurposed this office into a makeshift butcher’s shop. Of course, there’s little artistry that goes into the preparation of a morlock body for ghouls to eat, other than a few quick and brutal hacks with a hatchet.

Treasure

@UUID[Item.QZlnE0gsdKrNWQpi]{+1 Handaxe}

The hatchet is a +1 Handaxe.

Food Storage.name: Food Storage
Food Storage.text:
The heaps of slowly decaying bodies hung and stacked here reveal this former bedroom’s current use as a gruesome meat locker.

Five dead morlocks are stored here, their flesh decomposing (aging, to the ghoul palate) somewhat slowly in the cool temperature. There’s nothing of interest in here, but the filthy conditions expose any character who searches the room to blueblisters, flesh-eating bacteria that ghouls find savory when in dead flesh.

Blueblisters

Magical Contagion

This flesh-eating contagion incubates in decomposing meat. A character who succeeds on a [[/check skill=medicine/nature dc=13]] check realizes rotting corpses likely carry this kind of infection.

When a Humanoid comes into contact with rotting bodies or objects contaminated by blueblisters, that creature must succeed on a [/save ability=con dc=12]] or become infected.

It takes 1 day for blueblisters’ symptoms to manifest in an infected creature. Symptoms include painful blue blisters on the skin and gums. The infected creature’s Hit Point maximum is reduced by 3 ([[/r 1d6]]). While its Hit Point maximum is reduced in this way, it makes Strength and Dexterity checks with Disadvantage.

Each time the infected creature finishes a Long Rest, it must make a [[/save constitution dc=12]] saving throw. On a failed save, the creature’s Hit Point maximum is reduced by an additional 3 ([[/r 1d6]]). On a success, the creature’s Hit Point maximum increases by 3 ([[/r 1d6]])., but not beyond its normal value. If the creature’s Hit Point maximum is reduced to 0, the creature dies. If a successful saving throw restores the infected creature’s Hit Point maximum to its normal value, the creature recovers from the contagion.

Elevator Up.name: Elevator Up
Elevator Up.text:
The doors to this room open onto solid stone if the magical elevator beyond is still up at area @UUID[JournalEntry.uMZ0RiCcPSqsx1Nm.JournalEntryPage.VotAVttLzRCeBWqT]{B34}.

This plain, circular room is empty. An image of a moss- caked skull adorns the eastern wall.

The floor of this room is a magical elevator that links to area @UUID[JournalEntry.uMZ0RiCcPSqsx1Nm.JournalEntryPage.VotAVttLzRCeBWqT]{B34} above. If a creature touches Nhimbaloth’s symbol, the floor gradually ascends 30 feet. (If the characters aren’t aware of the secret door in area @UUID[JournalEntry.uMZ0RiCcPSqsx1Nm.JournalEntryPage.VotAVttLzRCeBWqT]{B34}, they might not realize this dead end leads anywhere.) It isn’t possible to crush anything in the elevator; if anything gets in the way of the elevator’s ascent, such as an item stuck in the doorway to the north or south, the elevator simply descends again.

Ghoul Garden.name: Ghoul Garden
Ghoul Garden.text:
A large mound of dark-gray soil lies heaped in the southern half of this room.

The ghouls have converted this one-time office into a garden of sorts by hauling in mounds of swampy soil from the surface.

Encounter

@UUID[Actor.GsrqCDf0Dc9PisEt]{Violet Fungi (4)}

The ghouls have cultivated four Violet Fungi here as a method to “flash season” flesh and to serve as guardians. The fungi are only dangerous to non- ghouls, as they don’t lash out at their undead gardeners.

Canker Shrine.name: Canker Shrine
Canker Shrine.text:
Whatever this room’s original use, today it serves as a horrific shrine. A rotting heap of fleshy material that seems to be composed of equal parts eyes, mouths, and skin lies in a stinking mound in the middle of the room, surrounded by two dozen tiny humanoid effigies crafted out of small bones and tangles of knotted hair.

The mound of flesh is a slowly decaying gibbering mouther—a creature the ghouls revere as the embodiment of “pure flesh.” The effigies arranged around it are representations of each ghoul in the cult. The smell in this room is particularly foul. A creature that isn’t a Construct or Undead that starts its turn in the room must succeed on a [[/save ability=constitution dc=13]] saving throw or have the @UUID[Compendium.dnd5e.content24.JournalEntry.phbAppendixCRule.JournalEntryPage.HWs8kEojffqwTSJz]{Poisoned} condition until the start of its next turn. On a success, the creature is immune to the smell for 24 hours.

Encounter

@UUID[Actor.lMCEVxKkQ7XK6Nid]{Canker Cultists (2)}

Two Canker Cultists are worshipping here, and they become irate if their venerations are interrupted. A character who makes a successful [[/check skill=religion dc=13]] check identifies the cultists’ reverence for the dead gibbering mouther. If a character damages the dead gibbering mouther— intentionally or otherwise—the cultists are shocked and can’t use Bonus Actions or Reactions until the start of their next turn. In retaliation, the cultists focus their attacks on the blasphemer. They fight until destroyed.

Washroom.name: Washroom
Washroom.text:
This bathroom’s commode and tub are caked with dust.

It’s perhaps a blessing that the ghouls have no use for this room. In fact, they rarely ever look in here, so stealthy characters might use it to hide out in the middle of the ghouls’ territory.

Belcorra’s Office.name: Belcorra’s Office
Belcorra’s Office.text:
This office is brightly lit by several glowing lights in a chandelier hanging above a desk and chair. Mirrors hang on the north and south wall, although both are cracked.

The light in this chamber isn’t particularly harmful to ghouls, but the Cult of the Canker doesn’t find the lighting pleasant—further, they view this area and the rooms beyond as the private domain of their patron, Belcorra, and out of respect for her on the day of her return, they’ve left this room and those beyond it untouched. If they discover the characters have entered the area, though, the surviving ghouls pursue them into this room with a righteous fury—as long as any characters are in here, Cult of the Canker ghouls gain a +1 bonus to attack rolls against them.

The western door is locked, and the lock plate is engraved with the stylized image of an open book. This decoration matches an image on one of the keys in area @UUID[JournalEntry.kDJSn9wbVvjnqYEj.JournalEntryPage.l1967pkknJ7ifjTc]{A13}. The keyhole is large enough to look through, but it’s impossible to see anything in the room other than to identify that the room is also brightly lit.

Treasure

@UUID[Item.wJqisLbPb87iAyLf]{Everburning Torch}

The chandelier’s Bright Light comes from a Torch under a @UUID[Compendium.dnd5e.spells24.Item.phbsplContinualF]{Continual Flame} spell socketed into its center. When socketed, the light reflects through many pretty (but valueless) chunks of glass.

Belcorra’s Reading Room.name: Belcorra’s Reading Room
Belcorra’s Reading Room.text:
The door to this room from area @UUID[.AheFAUwUtko3qnDA]{C26} is locked with an oversized lock; its key is on the key ring in area @UUID[JournalEntry.kDJSn9wbVvjnqYEj.JournalEntryPage.l1967pkknJ7ifjTc]{A13}. A character can pick the lock with a successful [[/check dext thief dc=13]] or force it open with a successful [[/check ability=strength dc=16]], but a failed Strength check alerts the fey reading here to the presence of intruders.

This room looks exceptionally comfortable with a thick carpet, bright light from a glowing chandelier, and soothing incense. Two overstuffed lounging chairs sit opposite a low table stacked high with books, while more books sit on a set of shelves to the west. A softly gurgling fountain carved to resemble water leaking from a mossy skull sits in the northwest corner.

This room once served as a private and comfortable place for Belcorra to relax and read, with minor magical trappings like the scent of incense, the bubbling of the fountain, and the Bright Light working together to afford a pleasant reading experience.

Most of the books here concern topics of sacrifice, incorporeal undead, and extinguishing living bodies and souls to create powerful magic items. Other books are tales (often fictionalized) of famous hauntings. The books are old but well-preserved. They can be used just like the books in area @UUID[JournalEntry.KeWKr2yd8dbppeS5.JournalEntryPage.l9NjtV6c0sjeD50H]{C11} to aid in research on these topics, providing a +1 bonus.

Encounter

@UUID[Actor.mmGreenHag000000]{Green Hag}

The room’s comforts are mostly wasted on the current occupant, a Green Hag that recently slipped into the brightly lit room to satisfy her own curiosity. She relaxes in one of the chairs with a book on her knee, periodically cackling and tittering over the book as she annotates its text with a colorful quill. The fey hopes to find a way to harness Gauntlight’s illumination for her own ends, but she has become distracted by the grisly descriptions of ritual sacrifice in an illustrated copy of a sinister text called Pathways of the Worm. She angrily attacks if interrupted; if brought below 20 Hit Points, she casts Invisibility and flees toward area @UUID[JournalEntry.KeWKr2yd8dbppeS5.JournalEntryPage.AheFAUwUtko3qnDA]{C26}. She flees east to plot revenge on the characters, and she’s most likely to do so by allying with the ghouls in area @UUID[JournalEntry.KeWKr2yd8dbppeS5.JournalEntryPage.tTVIrzNZtjKG1XVb]{C33}.

Treasure

@UUID[Item.LXrEVDiVkPizFqJr]{Iron Key} @UUID[Item.wJqisLbPb87iAyLf]{Everburning Torch}, @UUID[Item.7qoj4BsL7sHkZN2a]{Ineffable Hauntings}, @UUID[Item.SSMdEvSAlggOWV0v]{Valuable Books (2)}

Characters searching this room discover an @UUID[Item.LXrEVDiVkPizFqJr]{iron key} bearing a defaced winged eye symbol of the dead god Aroden between two chair cushions. The key unlocks the door to area @UUID[JournalEntry.KeWKr2yd8dbppeS5.JournalEntryPage.QyDogj0m5OoqMtUg]{C30}.

As in area @UUID[JournalEntry.KeWKr2yd8dbppeS5.JournalEntryPage.AheFAUwUtko3qnDA]{C26}, the chandelier incorporates a removable Torch with a Continual Flame spell on it.

A character who succeeds on a [[/check skill=perception dc=15]] check while perusing this collection turns up a slender volume called Ineffable Hauntings tucked inside of a larger book about ghosts. This volume contains a copy of @UUID[Compendium.dnd5e.spells24.Item.phbsplAnimateDea]{Animate Dead} suitable to be copied into a spellbook. It also contains a detailed, academic analysis of the @UUID[Compendium.dnd5e.spells24.Item.phbsplMagicMissi]{Magic Missile} spell. A character who can cast Sorcerer spells can use these notes to replace a spell they know with Magic Missile with 1 day of downtime. A Wizard can, of course, simply transcribe the spell into their spellbook as normal. This book is worth [[/award 400gp]].

Among these tomes are enough texts to present 20 pounds of books to Morlibint.

Private Washroom.name: Private Washroom
Private Washroom.text:
The bathtub and commode in this washroom are surprisingly clean.

Although a minor enchantment to keep this room clean still operates, there’s little of interest here.

Abandoned Guard Post.name: Abandoned Guard Post
Abandoned Guard Post.text: This now-empty room was once the post for one of Belcorra’s personal bodyguards. Nothing remains other than a broken iron stool and a well-used whetstone. The stairs beyond the door to the south lead down to area @UUID[JournalEntry.Os5bHdzCDiXgJBQ6.JournalEntryPage.owO8Ie1yNfI2amxK]{D1}.

Siege Castle History.name: Siege Castle History
Siege Castle History.text:
This room is locked. A character can unlock the lock on this door with the key in area @UUID[JournalEntry.KeWKr2yd8dbppeS5.JournalEntryPage.OJNJc6Fo510Heygw]{C27} or with a successful [[/check ability=dexterity dc=18]] check using Thieves’ Tools. Alternatively, a character can force it open with a successful DC 16 Strength check.

Shelves of books line the walls, while what appears to be a partially completed—or perhaps a partially ruined— sculpture of a sprawling city sits atop a five-foot-diameter circular table.

Encounter

@UUID[Actor.kpKqwbyQWqFd3ws3]{Earth Elemental}

A stony Earth Elemental molded to resemble Belcorra still stands guard in this room. It lumbers to action as soon as anyone enters the room who doesn’t also resemble Belcorra. It doesn’t pursue enemies out of the room but otherwise fights until destroyed.

Exploration

Sculpture

The sculpture on the table is of Absalom, depicted with damage in several areas. A character who succeeds on a [[/check skill=history dc=15]] check confirms that the damage correlates roughly what the city was said to have suffered over the centuries from all the siege attempts it repelled, up until about 500 years ago. It doesn’t include more recent attacks, such as the Red Siege, the Siege of the Ravenous Raja, or the Black Echelon Uprising.

Reference Materials

Most of these books focus on the history of Absalom’s sieges, and while many of them contain contradictory information, the collection as a whole makes cross-referencing it to determine likely fabrications versus truth easier. Anyone perusing these books finds heavy annotations in all of them; taken together, they reveal that a previous researcher was using the books to correlate the failures of prior sieges to ensure the success of a new one. Books in this room can be used just like the books in area @UUID[JournalEntry.KeWKr2yd8dbppeS5.JournalEntryPage.l9NjtV6c0sjeD50H]{C11} to aid in research on the history of sieges of Absalom and on the forces Belcorra considered using (warlocks, devils, aberrations, and undead), providing a +1 bonus to Intelligence checks to research those topics.

Treasure

@Item[SSMdEvSAlggOWV0v]{Valuable Books (3)}

A wealth of books of potential interest to Morlibint can be found here—30 pounds in all.

Unfinished Library.name: Unfinished Library
Unfinished Library.text:
This room’s walls are only partially completed and bear the telltale marks of chisels and picks. Discarded stone-working tools lie against the unfinished walls.

Belcorra planned an expansion wing to house additional tomes that had started to pile up elsewhere in her library, but the project was abandoned when she was slain.

Treasure

@UUID[Item.LvTxsXXxfqEaARNr]{+1 War Pick}

Most of the tools remaining here are mundane picks or parts of Mason’s Tools, but one of them is a +1 War Pick. Anyone proficient with Mason’s Tools immediately recognizes the war pick as a weapon and not a tool.

Furnace room.name: Furnace room
Furnace room.text:
The air in this room feels blisteringly hot, although the source of the heat isn’t apparent. Neither the wooden barrel containing a few iron scoops nor the metal bin with a hatch-like lid seems to be the source.

This room was used to burn refuse that accumulated in the dungeon—more often than not, books Belcorra came into possession of that she found to be useless or dangerous. Originally, the refuse would be loaded into the metal bin; once the hatch was closed, powerful fire magic incinerated the contents, and the ashes were then scooped out and dumped in the swamp.

Vengeful Furnace

Haunt

In the aftermath of Belcorra’s death, a squabble between two scholars concluded in this room when they attempted to burn each other alive. The machine malfunctioned and burned both scholars to ashes. Today, echoes of their souls haunt the room.

Characters who succeed on a [[/check skill=insight or intelligence (religion) dc=15]] check feel an indignant rage rising in their minds as they enter the room. A character who succeeds on the Religion check or a subsequent [[/check skill=investigation dc=13]] check deduces that the feelings belong to haunting spirits. A spell or other effect that can sense the presence of magic, such as @UUID[Compendium.dnd5e.spells24.Item.phbsplDetectMagi]{Detect Magic}, reveals an aura of Evocation magic around the furnace.

When a creature with Intelligence 14 or higher enters area @UUID[JournalEntry.KeWKr2yd8dbppeS5.JournalEntryPage.VoqYMxZSwLDn0l4y]{C32} or any creature touches the furnace, the hatch atop the furnace flips open and disgorges a pair of shrieking, burning ghosts that swirl around the triggering creature, who must make a [[/save ability=intelligence dc=15]] saving throw. On a failed save, the creature feels random memories burn away like pages in a fire. Until it finishes a Long Rest, the creature has Disadvantage on Intelligence ability checks and saving throws, as well as on spell attack rolls.

Once the burning shapes emerge, roll Initiative. The haunt rolls Initiative with a +4 bonus. On its turn, the haunt launches the burning shapes toward one creature in area @UUID[JournalEntry.KeWKr2yd8dbppeS5.JournalEntryPage.VoqYMxZSwLDn0l4y]{C32}, prioritizing the creature that triggered the trap. The furnace makes a ranged attack with a +7 bonus against the target. On a hit, the target takes 3 (1d6) Fire damage and [[/damage 1d10 psychic average]] damage.

As an action, a creature can scare one of the two spirits, forcing it to depart for the afterlife, by making a successful [[/check skill=intimidation dc=13]] check or [[/check skill=religion dc=15]] check. The haunt is disabled permanently when both spirits depart or if the furnace is destroyed (AC 14, damage threshold 10, 30 Hit Points, Vulnerability Cold and Radiant damage, Immunity to Poison and Psychic damage). Unless disabled or destroyed, the haunt can trigger again after 1 hour passes with no creatures in area @UUID[JournalEntry.KeWKr2yd8dbppeS5.JournalEntryPage.VoqYMxZSwLDn0l4y]{C32}.

XP Award: Award the characters [[/award 450xp]] if they permanently destroy the vengeful furnace or dispel the two ghosts within it.

Treasure

@UUID[Item.W5l8MNjGQAvXWNXQ]{Platinum Ring}

The furnace contains ashes that conceal a bit of treasure. A character searching through the ashes turns up the only belonging that survived its owner’s immolation so many years ago—a platinum ring inscribed with a mossy skull worth [[/award 75gp]].

Restricted Collection.name: Restricted Collection
Restricted Collection.text:
Rows of bookshelves run the length of this room, although they’ve been damaged or tipped over in places. Books that once sat on the ruined shelves appear to have been relocated to other shelves. Several doors lead out from this room, but the double door to the north is the most impressive: it’s made of stone, carved with a strange feminine shape rising from the ghost-laced mists of a cemetery of emptied graves.

The bulk of Belcorra’s most valuable tomes were kept here, in a collection that was available to only key scholars and very influential visitors. Much of the damage done to this room is relatively recent, for when the Ghost Queen morlocks emerged into this room from the stairs to the east, they clashed violently with the Cult of the Canker. Both sides suffered losses, but the ghouls won the fight and forced the surviving morlocks to flee west, eventually finding their way to the Servants’ Quarters level upstairs.

The stairs beyond the east door lead steeply down to area @UUID[JournalEntry.Os5bHdzCDiXgJBQ6.JournalEntryPage.2GyngLCPk5da2fMK]{D16}.

Encounter

@UUID[Actor.lMCEVxKkQ7XK6Nid]{Canker Cultist} @UUID[Actor.LHHgGSs0ELCR4CYK]{Ghouls (3)}

A single Canker Cultist and three Ghouls are repairing the shelves as best they can—a task that keeps suffering setbacks due to the decayed quality of the ancient wood. They don’t immediately attack intruders but instead adopt a defensive position around the north door. The Canker cultist then addresses the characters, offering them the chance to have an audience with her high priestess, Nhakazarin. Of course, this offer is a ruse—she hopes to lead the characters to her high priestess only to betray them. If she fails to deceive the characters, she grows frustrated and orders an immediate attack. These ghouls all fight until destroyed.

Exploration

Door Carving

A character who succeeds on a [[/check skill=religion dc=17]] check recognizes the scene on the north double door as the Outer God Nhimbaloth feeding on the spirits who worship her. As Nhimbaloth is mentioned in the texts here, a character who consults the books while researching the door gains the +2 bonus from the library on this Intelligence check.

Bookshelves

The books here cover all the same subject matter as those in area @UUID[JournalEntry.KeWKr2yd8dbppeS5.JournalEntryPage.l9NjtV6c0sjeD50H]{C11}, but are much more useful and better organized. Checks to research about the relevant topics during downtime here have a +2 bonus, rather than +1.

Treasure

@Item[SSMdEvSAlggOWV0v]{Valuable Books (4)}

There are 40 pounds of books here to gather for Morlibint.

Temple of the Canker.name: Temple of the Canker
Temple of the Canker.text:
Soft light illuminates several display cases in this vast room. Once used to display books, the cases stand smashed and empty. Along the curved north wall stands a hideous, towering figure of a woman. The form is composed of hundreds of portions of stitched- together flesh from a variety of different creatures and draped in tattered, filthy sheets. The stench of rot from the statue fills even this large room.

Belcorra once displayed her most important and valuable tomes here. A graveknight named Caliddo Haruvex, one of Belcorra’s distant relatives and a loyal guardian of her treasure vault far below, retrieved the books and returned to the vault with them on Belcorra’s orders. The magical light that once illuminated their display cases remains, rendering this room well-lit.

The immense rotten construction to the north is an incomplete shell akin to a flesh golem. The Cult of the Canker intends for it to serve as a new body for Belcorra once it’s finished. The rotting statue looks ominous but is inanimate… for now.

Encounter

@UUID[Actor.w2N0foudBFcRCaHK]{Nhakazarin}

The high priestess of the Cult of the Canker is a Canker Demagogue named Nhakazarin, a woman who was cruel and sadistic even in life. Born with an infestation of undeath in her soul, she served as one of Belcorra’s many necromantic advisers. After her death, she was the one who galvanized the other servants of this level to prepare for Belcorra’s resurrection.

Nhakazarin spends her time working bits of flesh harvested from morlocks, monsters, and even ghouls into her masterpiece, a 15-foot-tall “statue” of Belcorra made from decaying meat and stained bone. When confronted, Nhakazarin demands the characters abandon their gear and their lives, promising glory with the Canker if they agree to accept ghoul fever and then be locked away in the Author’s Hall (area @UUID[JournalEntry.KeWKr2yd8dbppeS5.JournalEntryPage.usuxpNbIZj0J1B5j]{C38}) until they transform. If the characters refuse, Nhakazarin laughs imperiously and attacks. As she fights, Nhakazarin promises the characters that they’ll join her cult, willingly or not. Once combat begins, she prefers to fight within 5 feet of her statue so she can use Consume Flesh. Nhakazarin wields a Staff of Withering.

Exploration

The secret door to the west is particularly well hidden; a character who searches this area must make a successful [[/check skill=investigation dc=25]] check to find it. None of the ghouls know it’s here, and it’s unlikely that the characters will find it at first. Note, however, that the existence of this secret door (as well as all other secret doors on the upper three levels) is revealed in the blueprints found in area @UUID[JournalEntry.Os5bHdzCDiXgJBQ6.JournalEntryPage.NHY0hh539X658iSG]{D8}.

The Statue

Note the condition in which the characters leave the statue, as it might animate and cause them problems later, based on their actions in area @UUID[JournalEntry.KI33EAGPVHP4zyFZ.JournalEntryPage.1UGSUnBhEjOeJhkM]{F25}.

Secure Collection.name: Secure Collection
Secure Collection.text:
The walls of this small room have built-in shelves. Books line the shelves to the north and south, while a stack of loose scrolls rests on the shelf to the west. A single chair and a small writing desk sit in the middle of the room.

Treasure

Belcorra kept her valuable books in the large chamber to the east, but she stored everything involving her work on Gauntlight and a fair amount on the creation of the Abomination Vaults here. These resources have remained here since her demise, as the ghouls don’t know this room exists.

Belcorra's Journal

The largest book on the northern shelf is a journal that focuses mainly on Belcorra’s hatred of Absalom. It’s written in Aklo, and a character who spends 8 hours reading it learns of her family history, from their exile to poverty and her eventual return to the region to build a lair from which she hoped to exact revenge on the city that disgraced and impoverished her family. The last several pages of the journal document much of her work in building the Abomination Vaults. While the journal doesn’t offer many specific details, it mentions construction of fleshwarping laboratories, arenas where she pitted enemies against monstrous champions for her amusement, prisons, torture chambers, links to the Darklands, and a great temple where “once the Empty Death herself brushed against this fragile world.” Belcorra’s entries often speak of her minions in the abstract, as if bragging about how many have come to serve her in creating the complex, but she only ever mentions one by name: her “amusingly vain” apprentice Volluk Azrinae. One of the last entries describes how this apprentice arrived from “a community of upstart and meddlesome drow below” to serve Belcorra. The notes don’t provide any further information about this drow community.

Gauntlight Blueprints

The stack of loose papers and scrolls contain a wealth of information about @UUID[JournalEntry.67686KaEPc6XAlKJ.JournalEntryPage.efRUYLBH9Kf3CLkX]{Gauntlight}. These papers are written in Aklo; sorting and then reading them takes 8 hours of work, after which the reader can learn about Gauntlight’s functions as if they’d fully researched the device.

Teleportation Network

A folio containing esoteric diagrams is sandwiched between several books on teleportation on the north shelf. The folio details Belcorra’s series of linked Teleportation Circles to quickly move around the Abomination Vaults and notes the importance of using the @UUID[Compendium.dnd-abomination-vaults.av-items-5e.Item.H0KYIrtDeeV2pSyC]{Awaken Portal} spell to activate them should time or mischance deplete them of power. The Awaken Portal spell is included in the notes.

The Whispering Reeds

The largest book in the room, on the southern shelf, is a rare text called @UUID[Compendium.dnd-abomination-vaults.av-items-5e.Item.dy8ggyuCNnRoOIvk]{The Whispering Reeds}. This magical book describes 77 supposed encounters with the Outer Goddess Nhimbaloth and how each encounter left physical or mental scars. The book is heavily annotated in Belcorra’s hand, particularly in areas where themes of Nhimbaloth as an “eater of ghosts” play into the parables and tales.

Scriptorium.name: Scriptorium
Scriptorium.text:
This room is lined with tables divided up into several narrow carrels, with old wooden chairs pushed in against them. Upon these tables, old stacks of paper and tattered books rest amid dry inkwells and brittle writing quills. To the south, a skeleton dressed in shiny-looking chainmail lies slumped on the floor, clutching something in its bony hands.

This room once served as a scriptorium where Belcorra’s scribes worked to transcribe and copy important books.

A character who searches the eastern wall and makes a successful [[/check skill=investigation dc=13]] check finds an empty carrel that folds up to allow access to a secret door leading to area @UUID[.E0TcXGYuA92wAB2y]{C37}.

The skeletal remains to the south were once a drow woman named Chandriu Invisar, director of the scriptorium. Chandriu harbored a poorly hidden adoration for Belcorra’s apprentice, Volluk, and in the days after Belcorra’s death, Chandriu tried to convince him to flee with her to start a new life together somewhere far from the Abomination Vaults. Volluk spurned her, insisting, “Belcorra needs me now in death even more than in life; you should consider the same!” Chandriu returned here in despair, only to be murdered by her disgruntled scribes eager to get out from under her bullying. She grasped for a portrait of her beloved Volluk as she died.

Encounter

@UUID[Actor.3H1rBpUQwTcNd6xZ]{Chandriu Invisar}

As with so many others who had the misfortune to perish in the Abomination Vaults, Chandriu arose as a ghost. She now spends her days floating among the workspaces as if looking over the shoulders of scribes to appraise their work, not realizing that any time has passed at all since the hour before Belcorra’s death. When the characters enter the room, the ghost mistakes them for new scribes and chastises them for their tardiness before ordering them to begin transcribing the old books stored here. Any attempt to do anything other than comply (including simply leaving the room) arouses her anger and prompts her to attack.

If the characters each sit at a carrel and begin to work—or even pantomime working—Chandriu withholds her attack until they stop. She entertains brief questions and discussion from her “scribes,” though, and will answer any questions the characters have, within reason, that don’t make her realize that Belcorra is dead or that she’s a ghost.

Every 10 minutes, she drifts through the secret door to area @UUID[JournalEntry.KeWKr2yd8dbppeS5.JournalEntryPage.E0TcXGYuA92wAB2y]{C37}, and a character who watches and makes a successful [[/check skill=insight dc=8]] check notes that her actions suggest a hidden door (even though she simply passes through the wall). She returns from these short trips to area @UUID[JournalEntry.KeWKr2yd8dbppeS5.JournalEntryPage.E0TcXGYuA92wAB2y]{C37} after a few moments. The characters can safely escape the room during this window; if they do and then return, Chandriu doesn’t remember them at all.

If the characters attack Chandriu, or force her to confront the truth that she’s a ghost or that Belcorra is dead, she cries out in despair, then attacks.

Treasure

@UUID[Item.AH3BjZE3cAB0ACZD]{Scriptorium Books}, @UUID[Item.3UbeJ9qCBH9m63yQ]{Chandriu's Remains}

Books

There are 10 pounds of books here to gather for Morlibint. In addition to these books, the three mentioned in the note in area @UUID[JournalEntry.uMZ0RiCcPSqsx1Nm.JournalEntryPage.LyGMJmON0ZPU7CmT]{B3} (What The Worm Knows, Grave Feasts, and Secrets of the Skull) are located here as well. Morlibint has no interest in these three grim treatises on necromancy, but they can be sold for [[/award 160gp]] each (to someone other than Morlibint, that is).

Chandriu's Remains

A character who searches Chandriu’s remains finds that her chain shirt is in good condition. The object she clutches is a framed portrait of Volluk Azrinae. The portrait captures the drow’s beauty as well as his imperious, vain smirk, both qualities Chandriu adored. His name appears on a tiny gold plaque at the portrait’s base. The work of art has endured the passage of time quite well and is worth [[/award 200gp]], but it might be more immediately valuable to the characters as a way to fight against Volluk (area @UUID[JournalEntry.Os5bHdzCDiXgJBQ6.JournalEntryPage.NHY0hh539X658iSG]{D8}). A character who succeeds on a [[/check skill=investigation or wisdom (perception) dc=11]] check while searching the remains spots a tiny iron key beneath them; this key unlocks the cabinet in area @UUID[JournalEntry.KeWKr2yd8dbppeS5.JournalEntryPage.E0TcXGYuA92wAB2y]{C37}.

Secret Scriptorium.name: Secret Scriptorium
Secret Scriptorium.text:
A worktable covered with blank scrolls and papers sits against the eastern wall of this room, while to the north stands a cabinet with several closed drawers.

Treasure

@UUID[Item.NFVZ7r5mZ7knSkWQ]{Cabinet Contents}

There are five locked drawers in the cabinet. A character can open each one by using the key from area @UUID[JournalEntry.KeWKr2yd8dbppeS5.JournalEntryPage.KDcIKiVRxWGTfQhK]{C36}, by making a successful [[/check dex thief dc=15]], or by succeeding on a [[/check ability=strength dc=12]] to force it open. Several books are stored within—copies of texts produced by scribes and once intended for sale or as gifts to Belcorra’s allies in other lands, all of whom are now dead. There are 20 pounds of books here to gather for Morlibint.

Not all the scrolls on the desk are blank; one tucked beneath the others is an infernal contract. This contract was meant to be stored deeper in the Abomination Vaults, but it never quite made it there. A character who can read Infernal and takes 10 minutes to look over it learns that this is the devil Korlok’s contract that binds him as a guardian. A character who succeeds on a [[/check ability=intelligence dc=13]] check, or who has a law-related background, notes a loophole that can release the devil if the contract is returned to him (area @UUID[JournalEntry.KeWKr2yd8dbppeS5.JournalEntryPage.sVpphDD0gtGtIlFh]{C8}).

Authors’ Hall.name: Authors’ Hall
Authors’ Hall.text:
Long shelves with several chairs drawn up to them ring this room on all sides, save the north. Rancid stains of old blood and decay cake the shelves and floor.

Belcorra’s scribes once used this room to pen new works. The Cult of the Canker now use it as a place to store victims of ghoul fever until they die and arise as ghouls. There are no bodies stored here now, but the characters can find ample evidence of the suffering and death that has occurred here.

Exploration

A character who searches the south wall and makes a successful [[/check skill=investigation dc=14]] check finds a section of shelving that folds down to allow access to a secret door leading to area @UUID[.grfsjSzZmO95qpo7]{C39}.

Guard Room.name: Guard Room
Guard Room.text:
A small alcove, its floor decorated with a silvery circle of inlaid runes, sits in the eastern wall of this empty room.

This room once housed a bound devil who served as one of Belcorra’s guardians, but that creature’s contract expired long ago, releasing her back to Hell. The alcove to the east is a nonfunctional @UUID[Compendium.dnd5e.spells24.Item.phbsplTeleportat]{Teleportation Circle} that, once restored via @UUID[Compendium.dnd-abomination-vaults.av-items-5e.Item.H0KYIrtDeeV2pSyC]{Awaken Portal}, transports those who use it to area @UUID[JournalEntry.KeWKr2yd8dbppeS5.JournalEntryPage.VZPc5GsIN5eRKSVE]{C5b}.

Subterranean Pool.name: Subterranean Pool
Subterranean Pool.text:
The dripping, sloshing sound of water fills this large cavern chamber. The air is cold and damp, and to the east sits a sizable pond. A lazy rivulet of overflow trickles to the north down a sloping tunnel, while a five-foot-diameter opening gapes in the ceiling above the pool’s center.

The pool here is 5 feet deep and was once used as a source of drinking water for these levels; the hole in the ceiling 15 feet above leads up 25 more feet to the well in area @UUID[JournalEntry.uMZ0RiCcPSqsx1Nm.JournalEntryPage.vKXFtG7SrIcibaif]{B23}, while the downward sloping tunnel to the north leads to area @UUID[JournalEntry.Os5bHdzCDiXgJBQ6.JournalEntryPage.PuMBjgCkm2ImMyCh]{D14}.

Encounter

@UUID[Actor.dEAneTvoPuQXZoLR]{Gibbering Mouthers (2)}

A pair of Gibbering Mouthers have dwelt in this cavern for decades. They periodically crawl along the tunnel to area @UUID[JournalEntry.KeWKr2yd8dbppeS5.JournalEntryPage.Xi06PfArAS2ZFqot]{C2} to hunt bats and rats but spend most of their time floating in the pool of water here. They immediately attack intruders and pursue foes as long as they can throughout all levels of the Abomination Vaults. The monsters don’t differentiate between the characters and native inhabitants of the complex, so canny characters might be able to lure the gibbering mouthers into a fight against ghouls, morlocks, or other creatures.

Exploration

Characters searching the pond discover [[/award 190sp 65cp]] under the well opening. These offerings were tossed down here by superstitious servants ages ago in the hopes of warding off ill luck.

Introduction.name: Introduction
Introduction.text:
Chapter Synopsis

Belcorra’s sprawling library level has been transformed from a store of necromantic knowledge into a stronghold for a cult of ghouls. The characters can not only eliminate this vile cult, but also uncover significant information about Belcorra’s interests and plans.

The Library

Environmental Cues:

Books in untidy stacks, dust, looming shelves, musty mold, ruined tools and furniture, sounds of flipping pages, stink as of something rotting in a hidden corner, stuffy air.

The third level of the Abomination Vaults once served as Belcorra’s sprawling library and rooms related to research. The servants and librarians once employed here have become dangerous undead creatures.

Belcorra’s library is unlit except where otherwise noted. Ceilings are 8 feet high in halls and 10 feet high in rooms, although the largest rooms and halls have vaulted ceilings that rise to 12 feet high. Doors are made of wood banded with iron, and many bear signs (described in area @UUID[JournalEntry.KeWKr2yd8dbppeS5.JournalEntryPage.l9NjtV6c0sjeD50H]{C11}) to help scholars find their way.

Ghoulish Librarians.name: Ghoulish Librarians
Ghoulish Librarians.text: The Cult of the Canker is the most widespread faction active in the library. Originally a collection of librarians, caretakers, researchers, and scribes, this loyal staff stubbornly kept working after Belcorra died, focusing their research on finding a way to restore their leader to life. When food stores ran low, rather than risk alerting the Roseguard by making potentially public forays to the surface, the researchers turned to cannibalism. There were plenty of other servants to eat, after all, in the conveniently nearby servants’ quarters. The onset of ghoul fever tore quickly through their ranks, but the researchers were so obsessed that they barely noticed. The scholars’ research now has a distinctly ghoulish bent: they work to gather enough “cankerous flesh” to fuel Belcorra’s full resurrection. The fact that the ghouls’ hunger often compels them to feed on the flesh they’re trying to collect has certainly slowed their progress, but it hasn’t slowed their zeal.

Belcorra’s Dining Room.name: Belcorra’s Dining Room
Belcorra’s Dining Room.text:
A pair of glowing chandeliers illuminates a banquet table surrounded by fancy, high-backed chairs. The table is still set in preparation for a grand meal, but the place settings are scattered and toppled, as are a few of the chairs. Six skeletons in tattered finery lie about the room, some of them clutching their own necks as if they died in agony.

When the Roseguard attacked Gauntlight Keep so many years ago, Belcorra was dining here with representatives of a now-extinct Absalom thieves’ guild, whom she was courting as potential allies. When word came that the Roseguard seemed unstoppable, Belcorra took no chances. She politely excused herself, bade her guests to finish their meal, and magically commanded her chef to poison them all and murder the other servants before taking his own life.

Stairs beyond the north door lead up to area @UUID[JournalEntry.KeWKr2yd8dbppeS5.JournalEntryPage.ct0oaB12kXiKf42Y]{C29}.

Encounter

@UUID[Actor.HBRz8BVLVN9u9Odp]{Corpselights (6)}

The guests died in excruciating pain, but even then they couldn’t escape. All six of them became Corpselights in death. When a living creature other than Volluk enters this room, the corpselights within the skeletons begin to glow, and then the skeletons stagger to their feet and attack. Each time a corpselight is forced out of its corpse, it flees to one of the adjoining rooms (areas @UUID[.5bfMemKThz7OVUOz]{D02}, @UUID[.pnwZz9VrIshgPSMZ]{D03}, or @UUID[.Ez1TchVZQSMOMh9A]{D06}) to claim another corpse and return to the fight.

Treasure

@UUID[Item.haUGWBbJl4QjVtzG]{Guests' Remains}

A search of the guests’ remains reveals [[/award 96gp]] scattered among numerous pockets and a leather and silver bracelet worth [[/award 50gp]].

Kitchen.name: Kitchen
Kitchen.text:
A strange, squat cast-iron stove with no chimney sits in the southwest corner of this room, while to the north, a large oak table covered with cooking utensils sits against a wall. A skeletal body lies slumped at the base of the cupboards along the western wall.

The cast-iron stove is a minor magical item that transmutes smoke welling up from its fire into clean air, but it’s built into the stone of this room and far too heavy to be worth the trouble of moving. The dead body was once Belcorra’s cook, who died by suicide after carrying out Belcorra’s magical command to poison the guests and kill the other servants.

Exploration

A character who searches this room and makes a successful [[/check skill=investigation dc=14]] check spots the secret door to the north. Some cooking utensils are affixed to the wall; manipulating them in the correct order opens the secret door.

Storage.name: Storage
Storage.text:
Cupboards, shelves, and cabinets line the walls of this chamber. A few barrels sit in the middle of the room. Three skeletons lie slumped near the barrel.

The skeletons belonged to three servants who retreated to this storage room before being murdered by the chef. Nothing of value remains.

Wine Cellar.name: Wine Cellar
Wine Cellar.text:
A tall wine rack, its bottles thick with dust after so many years, stands against the north wall.

Treasure

@UUID[Item.RfpTYmBS5rdz2t9J]{Wine Rack}

Nearly all of this wine has gone bad, but with a successful [[/check ability=intelligence dc=13]] check using Brewer’s Supplies, a character notes three well-aged bottles worth [[/award 20gp]] each.

Level 4 Portal Chamber.name: Level 4 Portal Chamber
Level 4 Portal Chamber.text:
Teleportation Network

Some of the @UUID[Compendium.dnd5e.spells24.Item.phbsplTeleportat]{Teleportation Circles} within the Abomination Vaults form a part of a larger network. By tracing specific patterns on the wall runes, someone could transport everyone in any one of these chambers to one of nine other portal chambers in the Abomination Vaults- so long as the teleportation circles in both the departure chamber and destination have been awakened by the @UUID[Compendium.dnd-abomination-vaults.av-items-5e.Item.H0KYIrtDeeV2pSyC]{Awaken Portal} ritual (area @UUID[JournalEntry.KeWKr2yd8dbppeS5.JournalEntryPage.8X4xF40k06MW0X7q]{C35}).

The nine chambers are areas @UUID[JournalEntry.uMZ0RiCcPSqsx1Nm.JournalEntryPage.537bzfVUpq6XbR9a]{B17}, @UUID[JournalEntry.KeWKr2yd8dbppeS5.JournalEntryPage.vEiow4kU961XNOJp]{C16}, @UUID[JournalEntry.Os5bHdzCDiXgJBQ6.JournalEntryPage.RJf3BCpcVW6d68s7]{D05}, @UUID[JournalEntry.JT0zCcIwsSpKnbB5.JournalEntryPage.LJhOoRqYjj38YWl8]{E18}, @UUID[JournalEntry.KI33EAGPVHP4zyFZ.JournalEntryPage.mDFVGUXY6YDuQWF3]{F13}, @UUID[JournalEntry.OyNcqrpRClyhr8BJ.JournalEntryPage.zTpatmyyb4JvgNCo]{G02}, @UUID[JournalEntry.FwWmtOBFHhvM2gtf.JournalEntryPage.Nak2hUmVOHXBkcR5]{H33}, @UUID[JournalEntry.1vlzl3NJsftNB9Dc.JournalEntryPage.DJKWR2KLTPUi3w6T]{I59}, and @UUID[JournalEntry.yn21bNM6kpV4xRol.JournalEntryPage.JinYTJeYVFBE1uky]{J05}

The walls of this chamber are decorated with twisting runes carved into the wall and filled with dull, silvery metal. The floor and ceiling are almost completely covered with large, polished metal discs.

This room contains an inert Teleportation Circle like the ones in areas @UUID[JournalEntry.uMZ0RiCcPSqsx1Nm.JournalEntryPage.537bzfVUpq6XbR9a]{B17} and @UUID[JournalEntry.KeWKr2yd8dbppeS5.JournalEntryPage.vEiow4kU961XNOJp]{C16}. This Teleportation Circle must be reactivated with the Awaken Portal ritual hidden in area @UUID[JournalEntry.KeWKr2yd8dbppeS5.JournalEntryPage.8X4xF40k06MW0X7q]{C35} to connect it to other portal chambers in the dungeon.

XP Award

Award the heroes [[/award 500xp]] for activating this portal.

Washing Room.name: Washing Room
Washing Room.text:
A dusty metal washtub with a small skeleton lying inside stands next to a low shelf in this room.

As the guests in area @UUID[JournalEntry.Os5bHdzCDiXgJBQ6.JournalEntryPage.owO8Ie1yNfI2amxK]{D1} were dying of poison, one of them managed to stab a halfling servant, who staggered into this large dishwashing tub and died. If the skeleton in the tub is disturbed, the tub momentarily appears to be clean and filled with soapy water before returning to its actual dusty state. The scent of harsh dish soap clings for a minute before fading.

Macro

@Macro[yRrjA4MDVSV1ifvW]{D06 - Bath}

This macro will play a short sequence, filling the tub with water as the sound of splashing plays, then reverting back to normal a few moments later.

Disposal Room.name: Disposal Room
Disposal Room.text:
An open metal hatch lies in the floor against this room’s east wall. Storage bins sit to the north and south, each heaped with old bones, broken tools, and lumps of stone.

Several bones in one of the trash bins belong to a human, which a character investigating the bones can easily determine. A servant slipped against a trash bin and died here two days before Belcorra’s last meal in area @UUID[JournalEntry.Os5bHdzCDiXgJBQ6.JournalEntryPage.owO8Ie1yNfI2amxK]{D1}. The other servants simply hefted her body into the bin.

Encounter

@UUID[Actor.k3Lt3bWBadXvlIbG]{Poltergeist}

The spirit of the servant who accidentally died here has returned as a Poltergeist wracked with indignation. It lurks here on the Ethereal Plane, but doesn’t attack unless it’s spotted or someone approaches the lip of the chute. It hurls debris from the trash bins and pushes foes into the open hatch. It fights until destroyed but can’t leave this room. It can be put to rest by disposing of all its remains in a respectful manner, such as by cremating or saying words of blessing over them.

Down the Hatch

The hatch opens into a long chute that leads to the disposal pond at area @UUID[JournalEntry.Os5bHdzCDiXgJBQ6.JournalEntryPage.JNKEdzHec3VixqB8]{D17}. Anyone who enters the chute swiftly slides down to the pond in a rough trip and takes [[/damage 2d6 average bludgeoning]] damage upon landing. Anyone in the chute who doesn’t want to slide down can arrest their fall with a successful [[/save ability=strength/dexterity dc=13]] saving throw (their choice). In either case, a character must succeed on a [[/check skill=athletics dc=13]] check to safely scramble up (or further down) the chute to the room at either end.

Lounge.name: Lounge
Lounge.text:
On the walls of this large chamber hang grisly paintings depicting various spectral beings cavorting among ruined neighborhoods, overgrown swamps, and foggy graveyards. Three large overstuffed chairs pair with small end tables, upon which sit empty wine glasses. To the south stands a cluttered writing desk with its own chair, while a large iron tub to the west is visible between standing screens depicting shadowy marshes.

This large lounge once served as a place for Belcorra to relax, but today it functions as a den for her one-time apprentice, the drow Volluk Azrinae.

Encounter

@UUID[Actor.ZAXuvUW6kl6v3SuW]{Volluk Azrinae}

Unlike most of the denizens who dwelt in the Abomination Vaults in Belcorra’s day, Volluk Azrinae is still alive—after a fashion. After feeding himself to a vat of ritually prepared leeches, he lives on as a hideous swarm of aberrations, a worm that walks. Volluk now resembles a roughly drow-shaped mass composed of hundreds of slithering leeches. He has been working with the voidglutton that now dwells in Belcorra’s old chambers (area @UUID[JournalEntry.Os5bHdzCDiXgJBQ6.JournalEntryPage.nGQeeoAEGLcgnwNz]{D20}) to restore Gauntlight, but he’s frustrated that Belcorra’s ghost doesn’t speak to him directly. Being forced to do his mistress’s bidding through the will of the voidglutton galls the proud occultist.

Volluk is reading at his desk when the characters first arrive. As soon as he notices the characters’ intrusion, he rises up—a squirming, awful mess—and demands to know who they are and why they’ve come. He has little interest in constructive discourse, but if the characters let him talk, he bemoans his current circumstances for a few moments before attacking.

Exploration

Secret Door

A character who searches the room and makes a successful [[/check skill=investigation dc=15]] check spots the secret door in the east wall: a lifelike graveyard painting that swings outward. Every 10 minutes or so, a faint scream issues from the other side of the secret door, though it sounds like it emanates from the picture. After the characters hear the first scream, the DC to find the secret door drops to 10.

Hidden Key

A character who inspects the desk and makes a successful [[/check skill=investigation dc=18]] check locates an @UUID[Item.LJiBdnb79queTNvM]{iron key} in a cunningly concealed niche in one of the desk’s legs. The key opens Lasda’s manacles (area @UUID[.RmFsEEQSD9Ulugwm]{D09}).

Treasure

@UUID[Item.BSdAalMJQAyF3eRu]{Volluk's Desk}

Most papers on the desk are Volluk’s disjointed notes. More usefully to the characters, the papers also include detailed blueprints of the top three levels of the Abomination Vaults, including all secret doors.

Among Volluk’s papers are a Spell Scroll of Comprehend Languages and a Spell Scroll of Worm’s Repast. His spellbook is also here; it contains all the spells in his stat block plus Alarm, Animate Dead, and Create Undead. A Lantern of Empty Light sits on the writing desk. Volluk takes this lantern on his journeys aboveground, where he has unknowingly spawned rumors of a lantern-carrying stranger in and around the Fogfen.

Lasda’s Lament.name: Lasda’s Lament
Lasda’s Lament.text:
The walls of this circular chamber are smooth and pale gray. A flickering, nauseating ribbon of pale, violet light churns in the center of the room. Where the light touches the ceiling, the stone shines as if it were infected flesh. Below, the light bathes a screaming, thrashing dwarf bound to a metal table, his body covered in blisters.

As in area @UUID[JournalEntry.uMZ0RiCcPSqsx1Nm.JournalEntryPage.8pbhSFgv71lvCz9M]{B35}, the ribbon of light is a manifestation of Gauntlight’s growing power. This eerie light churns in a 5-foot-diameter Cylinder at the room’s center. An Undead creature that ends its turn within the Cylinder regains [[/healing 4d8 average]]{18 (4d8)} Hit Points. Any other creature that ends its turn in the area makes a [[/save ability=constitution dc=12]] saving throw. Constructs automatically succeed on the save. On a failure, the creature takes [[/damage 4d8 necrotic average]] damage.

In order to reactivate Gauntlight for its test firing on Otari’s graveyard, Volluk and the voidglutton needed a living creature as an anchor for the light. While others who touch the light suffer Necrotic damage, the light simultaneously heals its anchor as swiftly as it harms them, keeping them in a perpetual state of agony.

This victim is a dwarf named @UUID[Actor.u36SRb3lyB4beHCN]{Lasda Venkervale} (LG male Dwarf Commoner), once the bartender at the @UUID[JournalEntry.67686KaEPc6XAlKJ.JournalEntryPage.OzOCiM2tgNi3nN8f]{Rowdy Rockfish} in Otari. Volluk abducted Lasda just over a year ago while the dwarf was on one of his customary predawn walks from the Rockfish up to the graveyard. Volluk kept Lasda a prisoner in area @UUID[JournalEntry.Os5bHdzCDiXgJBQ6.JournalEntryPage.u6H893WYAlzxntns]{D11} for many months, subjected him to nefarious experiments, and, impressed by the dwarf’s hardiness, decided to use him as Gauntlight’s anchor.

Encounter

@UUID[Actor.wRQ7TZdd0n5UIIao]{Will-o'-Wisps (2)}

The characters can’t focus on rescuing Lasda without first defeating this room’s guardians, two Will‑o’‑Wisps that have been gorging themselves on Lasda’s terror. They’re @UUID[Compendium.dnd5e.content24.JournalEntry.phbAppendixCRule.JournalEntryPage.MQIZ1zRLWRcNOtPN]{Invisible} when the characters first arrive but flare up in an angry, blue glow as soon as anyone attempts to aid the dwarf. They pursue foes who flee but are smart enough to use Vanish and return to the ribbon if they’re likely to be destroyed (such as if reduced below 11 Hit Points). Any surviving will-o’- wisps then invisibly hunt down the characters.

Side Quest

To remove Lasda from the terrible ribbon of energy, the characters must first unlock the four manacles that bind him. The key to these manacles can be found in area @UUID[JournalEntry.Os5bHdzCDiXgJBQ6.JournalEntryPage.NHY0hh539X658iSG]{D8}, or the characters can unlock them with four successful [[/check ability=dexterity dc=16]] checks using Thieves’ Tools (one successful check per manacle). Unless the characters have some means of reaching the locks from a distance, each round a character works to unlock a manacle (by the key or otherwise), that character is exposed to the churning ribbon of necromantic energy.

Once freed and removed from the energy ribbon, Lasda recovers his mobility after a few moments of gasping for breath. He tells the characters the harrowing tale of his imprisonment and gives a partial description of areas @UUID[JournalEntry.Os5bHdzCDiXgJBQ6.JournalEntryPage.owO8Ie1yNfI2amxK]{D1} to @UUID[JournalEntry.Os5bHdzCDiXgJBQ6.JournalEntryPage.u6H893WYAlzxntns]{D11}. The party might have heard of Lasda’s disappearance if they’ve spoken to his worried mother, Brelda, at the @UUID[JournalEntry.67686KaEPc6XAlKJ.JournalEntryPage.OzOCiM2tgNi3nN8f]{Rowdy Rockfish}. If they return Lasda to the Rowdy Rockfish, his mother is overjoyed and presses upon the heroes a family heirloom, a +1 Shield emblazoned with an angry-looking rockfish, as a reward.

Removing Lasda from the ribbon of light causes the necromantic energy here and in areas @UUID[JournalEntry.uMZ0RiCcPSqsx1Nm.JournalEntryPage.8pbhSFgv71lvCz9M]{B35} and @UUID[JournalEntry.KeWKr2yd8dbppeS5.JournalEntryPage.eOv6LI3wvIuKyyNJ]{C15} to vanish. While this prevents Belcorra from firing Gauntlight’s beam upon Otari, the reprieve is only temporary. As the characters will learn from Otari’s ghost, Belcorra continues to prepare Gauntlight for its true purpose far below, so the characters’ job is far from over.

In addition, once Lasda is removed, the haunts on the upper four levels of the Abomination Vaults don’t reset if they’re deactivated or defeated. These effects return if both Volluk and the voidglutton survive and are given several days to find and install a new victim; if they do so, this new victim should be an NPC whose kidnapping spurs the characters into action!

XP Award: Award the characters [[/award 500xp]] for returning Lasda to the Rowdy Rockfish.

Scalathrax Pen.name: Scalathrax Pen
Scalathrax Pen.text:
The floor of this rough-hewn cavern is strewn with bones and scraps of metal and cloth.

All three of the irregular, rocky passages out of this area end in secret doors. All three secret doors are obvious from within this cavern even though each is hidden from the other side.

Encounter

@UUID[Actor.Nkz8Z5TrEqRePGlk]{Scalathraxes (2)}

This cavern once merely connected the southwestern and northeastern wings of the level, but it now serves as a pen for a trio of scalathraxes. One of these creatures has already been transported from area @UUID[JournalEntry.Os5bHdzCDiXgJBQ6.JournalEntryPage.RmFsEEQSD9Ulugwm]{D9} via Gauntlight’s beam to Otari, but the other two Scalathraxes remain here, awaiting a time when Volluk decides to test Gauntlight again. They are poorly fed and attack the characters on sight, pursuing them relentlessly.

Torture Chamber.name: Torture Chamber
Torture Chamber.text:
Three five-foot-square iron cages, the bars lined with spikes on the inside, hang from chains in the middle of this room. Blood-crusted manacles dangle from chains on the west wall. A stout wooden table with more manacles anchored to it stands in the southwest corner, and on it sits a whip made of blood-red leather with a silver handle.

Here, Belcorra imprisoned and tortured those who lacked the qualities she sought for fleshwarping experiments or for arena battles in the levels below. Once she was satisfied her prisoners had nothing left to offer, or once she grew bored, she sent them to area @UUID[JournalEntry.Os5bHdzCDiXgJBQ6.JournalEntryPage.CGaM81kBLtYIxmqu]{D13} for sacrifice. The dwarf bartender Lasda was kept in the central hanging cage for many months after his capture.

The northern cage has silver-lined runes carved into its exterior. This cage is the destination of the inactive Teleportation Circle in area C5b. It can be restored with the Awaken Portal spell and makes for a convenient way to imprison anyone pushed into the alcove in area @UUID[JournalEntry.KeWKr2yd8dbppeS5.JournalEntryPage.VZPc5GsIN5eRKSVE]{C5}, should the party wish to capture a foe in this part of the dungeon.

Encounter

@UUID[Actor.OuimMwM3yFRy5tRK]{Vaulgrist}

A lone, weakened Chain Devil named Vaulgrist has been bound here by Belcorra’s magic for centuries. The interminable years instilled a sense of listlessness and ennui in the torturer, and she rarely even moves about the room any longer.

Vaulgrist’s hope for cruel amusements was briefly rekindled when she had Lasda to toy with, but she’d only just begun a few months of laying the groundwork for his torment when he was taken away. Her frustration culminated in a fight with Volluk and the voidglutton, as her contract was with Belcorra and not them. As punishment, the voidglutton scarred her mind with magical sorrow, amplifying her loneliness and ennui until they became as they are now—almost overwhelming. As a result, Vaulgrist has Disadvantage on attack rolls, ability checks, and saving throws, reducing her Challenge Rating to 6 ([[/award 2300xp]]).

At first, Vaulgrist can hardly stir herself to bother with the characters. She morosely invites them to depart this chamber and never return. There’s no trick here—if the characters simply leave at once, the devil lets them go. If they persist or question her, she sighs in frustration and attacks; she has no interest in talking. She fights until destroyed but doesn’t leave this area.

Exploration

A character who searches the table and makes a successful [[/check skill=investigation dc=14]] check spots a hidden switch on its underside that opens the secret door to the south.

Treasure

@UUID[Item.QoSlmV16LJjcnjc1]{Vaulgrist's +1 Whip}

The whip is a +1 Whip. It was once one of Vaulgrist’s favorite weapons, but she no longer uses it.

The Ghostwalk.name: The Ghostwalk
The Ghostwalk.text:
The ceiling of this wide hall rises to a height of twenty- five feet. Stone sarcophagi carved with tormented and emaciated figures stand upright in alcoves along its walls, one figure on the lid of each sarcophagus.
To the northeast, a fifteen-foot-wide portion of the wall has crumbled away into a series of ledges that drop down into a cavern. Eerie blue lights glow to the north and south of the hall—the light to the south is brighter and constant, while the light to the north flickers softly, instilling in the viewer a subtle, creeping dread.

This long hallway served as a gruesome trophy hall. With the exception of the two northernmost alcoves and the alcove leading to area @UUID[JournalEntry.Os5bHdzCDiXgJBQ6.JournalEntryPage.df69jJ0DznVnWMAb]{D10}, each sarcophagus in this hall contains the defiled remains of one of Belcorra’s enemies, stripped of its gear and dignity and put on display. As soon as anyone steps up to a sarcophagus, its stone lid becomes transparent, providing a view of the long-dead body within. Each corpse is dressed in rags and marked with obviously fatal wounds. Most of these are the remains of long- dead heroes with no significant relation to the story of the Abomination Vaults Adventure Path. The corpses entombed here in their indignities used to be linked to bound ghosts who guarded the hall, but their undead presences have been inadvertently drawn into the magical wall at the south end of this hallway.

A large flight of stairs to the south leads down to area @UUID[JournalEntry.JT0zCcIwsSpKnbB5.JournalEntryPage.GtX8UuzhtARfLdsq]{E1}. For now, progress to the next level is blocked by a shimmering wall of ectoplasm. Now and then, silently shrieking ghosts flit through the swirling mist of this wall. The wide stairwell beyond remains visible yet tauntingly inaccessible. This wall acts as a @UUID[Compendium.dnd5e.spells24.Item.phbsplWallofForc]{Wall of Force} spell and has been “forged” from the agonized souls of the heroes entombed throughout this hallway—their trapped ghosts silently cry out in agony within the wall, pushing against it but unable to leave.

This wall’s creation was an unintended side effect of Gauntlight’s test firing after it had lain dormant for so long. For now, the wall blocks progress deeper into the dungeon. Only the icons of Belcorra’s killers can bring it down, as the ghost of Otari Ilvashti in area @UUID[JournalEntry.Os5bHdzCDiXgJBQ6.JournalEntryPage.J8ggyg2kxws3Sa1h]{D18} can explain.

The collapse in the northeast wall leads to a series of 5-foot-high ledges that drop down to area @UUID[JournalEntry.Os5bHdzCDiXgJBQ6.JournalEntryPage.PuMBjgCkm2ImMyCh]{D14}.

Encounter

@UUID[Actor.sMNqIHHxcVBXG08h]{Wights (2)}

The two northernmost sarcophagi contain traitorous apprentices transformed into Wights. If anyone approaches within 15 feet of them, both lids pop open, and the wights emerge to attack. They relentlessly pursue foes through this level and fight until destroyed.

Exploration

Only one of the sarcophagi is empty, as any character walking the length of this hall can note. The back of this empty sarcophagus contains a secret door leading to area @UUID[JournalEntry.Os5bHdzCDiXgJBQ6.JournalEntryPage.df69jJ0DznVnWMAb]{D10}. A character who searches the empty sarcophagus and makes a successful [[/skill 15 inv]] check discovers the latch to swing the stone back of the sarcophagus open like a heavy door.

Upper Temple of Nhimbaloth.name: Upper Temple of Nhimbaloth
Upper Temple of Nhimbaloth.text:
This vast octagonal chamber is mostly empty. The walls are carved and painted to resemble a sprawling graveyard half- sunken into a swampy morass, yet all the graves in the mural are open and empty. Carved images of shrieking ghosts parade upward and into the hungry pupil of a malevolent eye at the domed apex of this room, thirty feet above. A circular fifteen-foot-diameter platform sits in the middle of the room, raised three feet off the surrounding floor. The platform supports an altar stone made of an irregular slab of rock marked by seven deep indentations, almost as if a huge, seven-fingered hand had gripped the stone with enough force to leave grooves behind. Now and then, a faint blue light flickers and pulses inside one of these indentations. Small objects lie heaped atop the altar.

Exploration

With a successful [[/check skill=religion dc=18]] check, a character can identify this chamber as a shrine dedicated to @UUID[JournalEntry.67686KaEPc6XAlKJ.JournalEntryPage.ohFJrgStEzdvGEEU]{Nhimbaloth}, the Outer God of despair, ghosts, and swamps. Her shrines are often empty of additional furnishings such as statues or benches, symbolizing the emptiness of death itself. Worshipers would typically kneel or prostrate themselves on the stone floor while priests led sermons and sacrifices at the altar.

Encounter

@UUID[Actor.x3eOZvKUginj5Blh]{Flickerwisps (4)} @UUID[Actor.oSQ3Q9tzTohksAtf]{Crawling Hands (4)}

A character who succeeds on a [[/check skill=perception dc=11]] check from the room’s entrance identifies the objects on the altar as four severed hands. These undead guardians scuttle forth to attack when disturbed, or when the characters enter this room. When the four Crawling Hands animate, four Flickerwisps slither out of indentations on the altar’s sides and join in their attack. These creatures don’t surrender or flee. The crawling hands chase foes who flee, but the flickerwisps don’t pursue foes from the shrine. They instead return to their places in the altar when no more foes are present.

Aura of Despair: The entire shrine is infused with an overwhelming sense of despair and hopelessness. A creature that isn’t a Construct or Undead that ends its turn in the room must make a successful [[/save ability=wisdom dc=16]] saving throw or have the @UUID[Compendium.dnd5e.content24.JournalEntry.phbAppendixCRule.JournalEntryPage.93uaingTESo8N1qL]{Frightened} condition for 1 minute. The effect ends early if the creature leaves the room. The creature repeats the saving throw at the end of each of its turns, ending the effect on itself on a success. Once a creature succeeds on the saving throw or the effect ends for it, the creature becomes immune to the shrine’s aura for 24 hours.

Lights from the Altar: The altar produces a new flickerwisp each day at dusk, but no more than four flickerwisps can exist in this chamber at one time. The malevolent aura and flickerwisp generation persist until the characters place the four Roseguard icons atop the altar stone, as directed by the ghost of Otari Ilvashti (area @UUID[JournalEntry.Os5bHdzCDiXgJBQ6.JournalEntryPage.J8ggyg2kxws3Sa1h]{D18}). When the icons are in place, the frightening despair in the room ends, and the altar doesn’t produce any more flickerwisps.

Pavilion.name: Pavilion
Pavilion.text:
This immense cavern is cold and damp. Water drips from condensation above into a large, still lake. Thick patches of moist mushrooms, some nearly four feet tall, grow along the lake’s western shore, while a narrow trickle of water feeds in from a tunnel to the south. A thirty-five-foot-long pavilion made of stone stands in the middle of the lake, elevated ten feet above water level by more than a dozen stone columns. The entire pavilion is encrusted with damp, pale fungus. Two stone bridges arch from the pavilion—one connecting it to a door set in the northern wall and another to a door to the east. A faintly flickering campfire burns in the middle of the pavilion, its smoke curling to the ceiling.

The fungus growing here might look ominous, but it’s harmless. The lake has steep banks that drop away into a nearly uniform depth of 15 feet.

Belcorra built this pavilion as a place to meditate. The denizens of the Abomination Vaults don’t visit here often, as the lingering presence of Otari’s ghost in area @UUID[JournalEntry.Os5bHdzCDiXgJBQ6.JournalEntryPage.J8ggyg2kxws3Sa1h]{D18} subconsciously influences them to stay away. Living creatures (such as the pavilion’s current inhabitants) don’t feel these influences.

Jaul Mezmin

A grizzled, feral-looking man lives in the pavilion. He’s Jaul Mezmin, a violent criminal and murderous werewolf wanted in the town of Otari for the slaying of several locals 30 years ago. Jaul’s last victim was a woman named Ayla Lathenar, wife of @UUID[JournalEntry.67686KaEPc6XAlKJ.JournalEntryPage.jPieo4zoajYJyrbg]{Keeleno Lathenar}, the owner of the Otari Market. Jaul hid in plain sight as one of the druids of @UUID[JournalEntry.67686KaEPc6XAlKJ.JournalEntryPage.ZztVKvKiqxCzfSfA]{Stone Ring Pond} while he committed his murders, but when he was found out, he escaped capture by leaping from the Otari cliffs into the sea. The tides pulled him into the sea caves, leaving him nearly drowned, but over the following weeks, he recovered and found his way here.

Jaul has been living here ever since. His skin is pasty and pale, and he reeks of mushrooms and sour sweat. His only companions over the years have been a series of loyal wolves; when one perishes, Jaul simply makes his way out through the caves to bond with another. At first, he laid plans to return to Otari, but after living in this cave for so many years, Jaul knows no other life.

The characters disrupt that life, though. When Jaul notices them, he staggers up to the edge of his pavilion and howls and barks wildly in an attempt to warn them away. The Dire Wolf at his side accompanies his howls with its own. A character who succeeds on a [[/check skill=history dc=22]] check realizes this man is the killer who disappeared from Otari a generation ago. At the GM’s discretion, a character familiar with Jaul’s legacy can make the roll with Advantage.

Encounter

@UUID[Actor.EN3mp0sVObP8ou3p]{Jaul Mezmin} @UUID[Actor.xj1Qn0VA4H4aKSjW]{Dire Wolf}

If the characters attack him or attempt to enter the pavilion, he assumes his hybrid form and attacks. If the characters hang back, Jaul continues to bark and howl until someone calms him down with a successful DC 18 Charisma (Deception, Intimidation, or Persuasion) check), at which point he stops howling and blinks several times as he remembers that he can talk as well. A few moments later, he calls out in a halting voice, warning the characters that this area is his territory and that they aren’t welcome. His initial attitude is Hostile, and if the characters try to talk to him too much, he grows frustrated and uses his magic to attack from afar. Depending on the questions the characters ask, Jaul might reveal his name or who he is, but it’s likely only a matter of time before the paranoid werewolf loses patience and attacks.

If Jaul is reduced to 30 Hit Points or fewer, he begs for mercy and promises to give the characters a reward if they spare him. This reward is Ayla’s necklace, as described in Treasure below. Characters who show Jaul mercy can get him to talk further; Jaul is somewhat familiar with the eastern half of this level (areas @UUID[JournalEntry.Os5bHdzCDiXgJBQ6.JournalEntryPage.PuMBjgCkm2ImMyCh]{D14} to @UUID[JournalEntry.Os5bHdzCDiXgJBQ6.JournalEntryPage.elYnvao8KPxWdGdp]{D19}). For example, he can warn the party of the shadowy ghost on the island to the south (area @UUID[JournalEntry.Os5bHdzCDiXgJBQ6.JournalEntryPage.J8ggyg2kxws3Sa1h]{D18}) and tell them that if they enter the “nightmare stairs” to the north (area @UUID[JournalEntry.Os5bHdzCDiXgJBQ6.JournalEntryPage.elYnvao8KPxWdGdp]{D19}), they’d do well to keep their eyes closed if they want to ever escape them. If the characters spare Jaul, he uses the sea caves to emerge near Otari and flees the region entirely. Whether or not he resumes his murderous ways is left to the GM to decide.

Treasure: In addition to his Studded Leather Armor and three Daggers, Jaul carries a bejeweled necklace worth [[/award 10gp]] featuring a porpoise and an engraving which reads “Ayla, My Beloved”.

Side Quest

The characters can bring Jaul in, dead or alive, to Otari for a [[/award 50gp]] bounty. If the characters don’t realize who he is right away, allow a character who looks over the inscription on his necklace to attempt a [[/check skill=history dc=13]] check. On a success, the character recognizes the name as Ayla Lathenar, the dead wife of the Otari Market merchant, Keeleno Lathenar. Approaching Keeleno with proof that the werewolf is dead—as the bitter man won’t accept his wife’s murderer remaining alive—earns the characters a 20 percent discount on all purchases at the Otari Market for life.

XP Award: Award the characters [[/award 500xp]] for bringing Jaul to justice and notifying Keeleno.

Twisting Tunnel.name: Twisting Tunnel
Twisting Tunnel.text: Several slippery ledges lead up and out of area @UUID[JournalEntry.Os5bHdzCDiXgJBQ6.JournalEntryPage.PuMBjgCkm2ImMyCh]{D14}, joining a small complex of caverns that stretches between Fogfen and the coast. It was via these tunnels that Jaul Mezmin arrived, and he uses them today to hunt for food. The tunnels connect to the coastline west of Otari in a sea cave that’s underwater even at low tide. The actual contents of these caverns are beyond the scope of this adventure, but they likely contain other predators and dangers. The GM should feel free to expand them if the characters wish to explore them and are in need of additional XP.

Haunted Stairs.name: Haunted Stairs
Haunted Stairs.text:
A staircase leads upward from this narrow landing. The south wall, facing the stairs, flickers and glows with ribbons of eerie green luminescence.

These stairs lead up to area @UUID[JournalEntry.KeWKr2yd8dbppeS5.JournalEntryPage.tTVIrzNZtjKG1XVb]{C33}.

During his flight through the Abomination Vaults, Otari Ilvashti made one of his final stops on this staircase.
