He waited here for only an hour to patch some wounds and regain his courage, then moved on through the door to area @UUID[JournalEntry.Os5bHdzCDiXgJBQ6.JournalEntryPage.PuMBjgCkm2ImMyCh]{D14}, hoping to find an escape route. Unfortunately, he never made it to the sea cave exit, for the enormous otyugh that dwelt in the cavern in those days attacked him at once. Otari was forced to flee south and made it to area @UUID[JournalEntry.Os5bHdzCDiXgJBQ6.JournalEntryPage.J8ggyg2kxws3Sa1h]{D18}. The otyugh was too large to reach him there, but too stubborn to leave, and thus it’s there that Otari finally perished.

As in areas @UUID[JournalEntry.uMZ0RiCcPSqsx1Nm.JournalEntryPage.BHmLYQVCwzBneNFu]{B28} and @UUID[JournalEntry.KeWKr2yd8dbppeS5.JournalEntryPage.LSGUFeDZHwsJMxev]{C3}, Otari’s spiritual energy remains here. When the characters reach this point, another message manifests in the glowing light on the wall.

“Gauntlight is a weapon, built to raze Absalom—it must be brought down!”

After the message is read, the words slide down into a writhing ribbon of footprints that lead into area @UUID[JournalEntry.Os5bHdzCDiXgJBQ6.JournalEntryPage.PuMBjgCkm2ImMyCh]{D14}, then makes a panicked twisting route down through area @UUID[JournalEntry.Os5bHdzCDiXgJBQ6.JournalEntryPage.JNKEdzHec3VixqB8]{D17} and into area @UUID[JournalEntry.Os5bHdzCDiXgJBQ6.JournalEntryPage.J8ggyg2kxws3Sa1h]{D18}.

This spectral manifestation can appear once per day.

Disposal Pond.name: Disposal Pond
Disposal Pond.text:
A rusty metal chute protrudes from the ceiling to the west here, coming to an end over a pool of slimy water. A huge mound of fungus lies under the tube against the west wall, resting in a strangely monstrous shape.

This chute leads up to area @UUID[JournalEntry.Os5bHdzCDiXgJBQ6.JournalEntryPage.n4wmzdIYH9Eu0rVy]{D7}, but it’s slick, requiring a character to make a successful [[/skill 13 ath]] check to climb. If the check fails by 5 or more, the character slides down halfway up and takes [[/damage 1d6 bludgeoning average]] damage. Characters dumped into the pool of water here find it cold and unpleasant, but it’s only 3 feet deep. Fortunately, the immense otyugh once kept here for trash disposal purposes died long ago. Its strangely preserved body lies encased in fungus under the pipe. Anyone who examines the remains of the Huge otyugh can identify it with a successful [[/check skill=arcana dc=17]] check.

Otari’s Doom.name: Otari’s Doom
Otari’s Doom.text:
The water in this area is dark but only 3 feet deep.

A low, rocky isle rises less than a foot above the surrounding water here, its surface covered with a fine layer of pale green mushrooms and mold. At the center of the isle lies a human skeleton dressed in rotten leather armor and clutching a rapier.

The skeleton on the island was once Otari Ilvashti. He survived the battle with Belcorra and a desperate flight through these upper levels of the Abomination Vaults only to become trapped here by the immense otyugh waiting in area @UUID[JournalEntry.Os5bHdzCDiXgJBQ6.JournalEntryPage.JNKEdzHec3VixqB8]{D17}. Already weakened from his ordeal before contracting filth fever from the fight with the otyugh, Otari lingered here on the tiny islet only two days before he perished.

Today, his spirit lingers on, both in the form of the strange, haunting warnings on the walls throughout the Abomination Vaults and as a ghost consumed by two linked desires—vengeance on Belcorra and fear that Gauntlight might yet be used to harm his hometown of Absalom. As the characters draw near, Otari’s ghost rises from his skeleton, appearing much as he did in the late stages of filth fever, albeit with a transparent green shade. Otari can’t leave this area, and since the characters are the first potentially helpful adventurers to visit his haunted remains, he’s eager to provide what aid he can.

Encounter

@UUID[Actor.wRQ7TZdd0n5UIIao]{Will-o'-Wisps (2)} @UUID[Actor.x3eOZvKUginj5Blh]{Flickerwisps (2)} @UUID[Actor.R0EEgMDKcynpAWoa]{Otari Ilvashti}

Before Otari can speak to the characters, two Will‑o’‑Wisps and two Flickerwisps that have tormented him for years dart forth to protect their fear-laden victim. Otari can do little more than warn the characters about the “Eyes of the Empty Death” before the wisps swoop forth to attack.

Once combat begins, Otari Ilvashti provides what aid he can. The aberrations long ago learned to stay out of the ghost’s reach, but Otari uses Infest Shadow against them by momentarily possessing the characters’ shadows.

Once the wisps are defeated, Otari provides the characters with more information about his life and about Gauntlight’s dire awakening, as described below.

Treasure

@UUID[Compendium.dnd-abomination-vaults.av-items-5e.Item.Vju1G9b7XZ2bv91a]{Shadowed Thieves' Tools}

Otari encourages the characters to claim and use his thieves’ tools once he’s done speaking with them. His Shadowed Thieves’ Tools are one of the four icons required to overcome the barrier in area @UUID[JournalEntry.Os5bHdzCDiXgJBQ6.JournalEntryPage.QCU2xefly79ZVBxj]{D12}. His other gear has fallen apart over the centuries since his death; the fact that his thieves’ tools are still in good condition after such a long time should be a clue that they’re magical.

What Otari Knows

Otari's role is to present the tasks necessary to pass the @UUID[JournalEntry.JT0zCcIwsSpKnbB5.JournalEntryPage.5MfX6RVIF7rOroV3]{Spectral Seal} and reach the lower levels of the Abomination Vaults.

Once the heroes encounter Otari's ghost and drive off the wisps that torment him, he relates his tale of woe, as outlined @UUID[JournalEntry.67686KaEPc6XAlKJ.JournalEntryPage.hmllmOvUuS2wnnVT]{here}. He has difficulty remembering much of his life but becomes very emotional if he learns that the other members of the Roseguard survived and founded a town they named after him.

Otari's Fate

Once the characters take on the burden of facing and defeating Belcorra and open the way to the deeper levels of the Abomination Vaults, Otari’s soul is free to travel to its final reward. The GM should ensure he has imparted the above information to the characters before he fades away.

The GM may wish, though, to put a darker spin on things—rather than have Otari’s spirit achieve freedom, it could instead be captured by the @UUID[JournalEntry.yn21bNM6kpV4xRol.JournalEntryPage.a9b40LjI7QwLgirk]{Empty Vault}, the temple of Nhimbaloth at the bottom of the Abomination Vaults. In this case, the characters should learn about Otari’s fate through a vision or nightmare, or perhaps even see his tormented ghost pulled downward against his will by a seven-fingered hand. Otari’s ghost remains trapped in the Empty Vault until the characters finally defeat Belcorra.

The Forever Stairs.name: The Forever Stairs
The Forever Stairs.text:
The walls of this five-foot-wide hallway shimmer and ripple with faint whorls of pale blue energy. A staircase to the west leads upward, and the one to the east leads downward. Both the ascending and descending stairs reach small landings.

While at first glance this hallway might seem unremarkable, it should quickly become clear that something truly strange is going on once the characters start to travel it. The hallway loops back upon itself; for example, if the characters choose to go clockwise, the stairs will always lead upward, but they end up at the same place they started after making a complete circuit. Belcorra created this distorted spatial effect in the early days of her construction of the Abomination Vaults, as she was experimenting with several magical methods of delivering her monsters directly into the streets of Absalom. While she ultimately abandoned spatial warping as too inefficient to be used on a large scale, she kept this warped square hall as a sort of “moat” around her personal quarters.

Exploration

The outside doors to areas @UUID[JournalEntry.Os5bHdzCDiXgJBQ6.JournalEntryPage.CGaM81kBLtYIxmqu]{D13} and @UUID[JournalEntry.Os5bHdzCDiXgJBQ6.JournalEntryPage.PuMBjgCkm2ImMyCh]{D14} are always present, but the alcove and door to area @UUID[JournalEntry.Os5bHdzCDiXgJBQ6.JournalEntryPage.nGQeeoAEGLcgnwNz]{D20} are concealed by an illusory wall created by a @UUID[Compendium.dnd5e.spells24.Item.phbsplMajorImage]{Major Image} spell cast at 6th level. A [[/check skill=investigation dc=18]] can disbelieve the illusion, but the characters might find the wall in other ways. A character who succeeds on a DC Intelligence (Arcana or Investigation) check or Wisdom (Perception) check while investigating the north hallway identify anomalies in the whorls of blue energy that indicate something unusual about that section of the wall.

XP Award: Grant the heroes [[/award 500xp]] the first time they manage to reach area @UUID[.nGQeeoAEGLcgnwNz]{D20}.

Belcorra’s Suite.name: Belcorra’s Suite
Belcorra’s Suite.text:
These four angled rooms have identical basic descriptions; adjust the following as needed to account for the location of any doors in the room. Area D20d also features a plain stone archway in one wall filled with blank stone; this is an inactive portal to the depths of the Abomination Vaults.

A pair of doors provide exits from this room, one of which is set a foot higher than the room’s dusty floor atop a semicircular step.

When Belcorra first began construction of the Abomination Vaults, these chambers served as her personal suite. She lived here for many years while she oversaw the construction of the dungeons both above and below, but once the project was complete, Belcorra abandoned this home for one even deeper. She moved her belongings deep below as well, leaving these chambers abandoned and empty, but when Belcorra became a ghost, her spiritual energy reacted in much the same way Otari’s did by manifesting lingering images within these rooms where she spent so many hours.

As a result, each time the characters step into one of these four rooms, they’re greeted with a brief ghostly image of the room as it once was. Each time, they also see a vision of Belcorra herself within the room. Descriptions of each room’s spectral visions are given below, but chances are good that the characters won’t have time to study the scenes until they deal with this suite’s dangerous inhabitant.

North Room (D20a)

@Macro[WwpFApLBtTEwVg4W]{Vision - A}

This room was once a comfortable sitting room with two chairs and a low end table between them. In the brief vision, Belcorra is meeting with Volluk (as he was in life, a handsome drow). Although the image has no sound, Belcorra is speaking animatedly about something, and Volluk is listening attentively.

East Room (D20b)

@Macro[ZiZZJYiahnOQKS0n]{Vision - B}

Originally a lounge with two plush divans, this room flashes an image of Belcorra relaxing while reading a large tome. A character who succeeds on a [[/check skill=perception dc=13]] check sees that the book is titled The Whispering Reeds (this book is currently in area @UUID[JournalEntry.KeWKr2yd8dbppeS5.JournalEntryPage.8X4xF40k06MW0X7q]{C35}).

South Room (D20c)

@Macro[tNrLnJiGgEFdLIGi]{Vision - C}

A well-set table reveals this chamber to have once been Belcorra’s private dining room. There are two chairs at the table, and one is plainly more ornate than the other. In the image, Belcorra sits alone at the table in the nicer chair, drinking a large glass of wine and enjoying an elegantly plated roast arm that looks disturbingly human.

West Room (D20d)

@Macro[Txz4sUakBGtaxdvo]{Vision - D}

Belcorra’s bedroom features a bed along the west wall. Although the bed is elegantly made, it isn’t very large. In the image, the stone archway to the north shimmers as a portal opens and Belcorra steps through with a cruel smile on her lips and blood dripping from her hands.

Encounter

@UUID[Actor.ceLvlSQsYNORH8oM]{Voidglutton}

A powerful and horrific entity known as a Voidglutton has dwelt within these chambers since Belcorra abandoned it. This is the voidglutton’s lair, allowing it to create certain magical effects while in the area (see sidebar). Unlike many of Belcorra’s minions, the voidglutton came to serve her of its own free will, drawn from across dimensions by echoes of Nhimbaloth’s presence. It volunteered to aid Belcorra as a guardian of the upper shrine (area @UUID[JournalEntry.Os5bHdzCDiXgJBQ6.JournalEntryPage.CGaM81kBLtYIxmqu]{D13}), but once she relocated her personal effects to deeper in the Abomination Vault, it took over these rooms. It basks in the latent fears and pains of the dungeon’s haunts and ghosts.

When Belcorra rose as a ghost, the voidglutton took note and visited her, learning of her plans to reactivate Gauntlight and realizing that it would take time to awaken the dormant artifact. The voidglutton helped Belcorra refine the plans for test-firing Gauntlight and has recently done so with Volluk’s aid (as the characters experienced during the @UUID[JournalEntry.uMZ0RiCcPSqsx1Nm.JournalEntryPage.YJt9K0fOixekSCa6]{Deadtide} event at the beginning of Chapter 2). Since then, the voidglutton has lurked here, understanding that it’s just a matter of time before Belcorra contacts it again to enact the next stage of her plan.

The voidglutton moves from room to room in this area, as it finds the echoes of Belcorra’s spirit soothing. It therefore has an equal chance of being in area D20a, D20b, D20c, or D20d when the characters arrive. It notes the characters’ intrusion immediately, however, and swiftly moves to confront them. The creature has no interest in negotiation; it attacks at once and fights to the death, but it doesn’t pursue characters who flee its lair. If the voidglutton clearly has the upper hand over a group of intruders, it might offer to let most of them flee if they leave it a single survivor for it to torment to death over a few months.

The Voidglutton's Lair

On Initiative count 20 (losing all Initiative ties), the voidglutton can harness the ambient magic in area @UUID[JournalEntry.Os5bHdzCDiXgJBQ6.JournalEntryPage.QCU2xefly79ZVBxj]{D12}, @UUID[JournalEntry.Os5bHdzCDiXgJBQ6.JournalEntryPage.CGaM81kBLtYIxmqu]{D13}, @UUID[JournalEntry.Os5bHdzCDiXgJBQ6.JournalEntryPage.elYnvao8KPxWdGdp]{D19}, or @UUID[JournalEntry.Os5bHdzCDiXgJBQ6.JournalEntryPage.nGQeeoAEGLcgnwNz]{D20} to cause one of the following effects. It can’t do so while it has the Incapacitated condition or if it is otherwise unable to take actions. If surprised, it can’t create any effect until after its first turn in combat. It can’t create the same effect two rounds in a row.

• An illusory memory of Belcorra’s victory over adventurers in the past plays out in a 10-foot-radius Sphere centered on a point the voidglutton can see within 60 feet of it. A creature that starts its turn in the area must succeed on a [[/save ability=wisdom dc=15]] saving throw or has the Frightened condition until it leaves the area. The illusion is short, but it repeats over and over. The illusion vanishes if the voidglutton dies or if it creates a different effect.

• Ectoplasmic webbing fills a 10-foot-radius Sphere centered on a point the voidglutton can see within 60 feet of it. The webs are Difficult Terrain and make the area Lightly Obscured. The webs disappear if the voidglutton dies or if it creates a different effect.

Trophy Vault.name: Trophy Vault
Trophy Vault.text:
This octagonal chamber’s walls are sheathed in a foul- looking, moist webbing made of stringy, semi-transparent slime. The bodies of three creatures have been mounted on the walls in this webbing, as if on display: a lavender- skinned elf, the legless body of a spiderlike humanoid, and a hideous humanoid with transparent flesh.

Belcorra took her treasure with her when she left, but the voidglutton used this place as a den for many years and placed a few of its favorite trophies here— bodies of creatures whose minds it fed upon and found to be particularly delightful, along with some of their potent gear and treasures. The bodies are encased on the walls by the voidglutton’s ectoplasmic webbing and must be cut free before they can be searched. Once freed, the bodies swiftly begin to decay, no longer held in stasis by the effects of the voidglutton’s webs.

Treasure

@UUID[Item.XOd8P7rosl58Uqiv]{Trophy Vault}

A drow outcast from the outpost of Yldaris on the ninth level of the Abomination Vaults wears a Necklace of Prayer Beads with one blessing bead and two curing beads. The upper torso of a drider from the fleshwarping labs on the sixth level carries a vial of Spider’s Sting poison. The body of an urdefhan from the Darklands connecting to the ninth level carries a Rhoka Sword on its back.

Introduction.name: Introduction
Introduction.text:
Chapter Synopsis

The fourth level of the Abomination Vaults was designed as a retreat for Belcorra to relax and to revere her uncaring deity Nhimbaloth. No faction of significance holds sway over Belcorra’s Retreat today. Instead, several powerful individuals claim separate portions of this level. While they don’t present a threat in numbers, these creatures are powerful foes intended to challenge the characters’ might. The most significant ally the characters can acquire is the ghost of Otari Ilvashti, the fallen hero who gave the town of Otari its name.

Environmental Cues:

Cool but comfortable temperature, fine furnishings that are old yet luxurious, haunted house effects such as closing doors or sliding chairs, profusions of fungi, smells of dust and faint spices, spectral visions of rooms as they looked 500 years ago.

Belcorra's Retreat

The fourth level of the Abomination Vaults is one of the smaller ones overall, yet it’s among the finest, as it once served as Belcorra’s personal retreat.

Features

Ceiling height here averages 10 feet in halls and 15 feet in rooms. Unless otherwise indicated, the rooms are unlit. The doors are iron-bound wood; ephemeral spirits gently shut any door left open for more than a minute, though they don’t close any door that has a person or object in the way.

Lower Shaft.name: Lower Shaft
Lower Shaft.text:
The spiral staircase descends to a circular chamber’s red stone floor. Four wide passages lead away in opposite directions, three of them ending at a door. The west passage features the most impressive of these doors, which are fifteen feet high and inscribed with a blazing pentagram. The southwest stairway descends from this room and appears choked with boulders, rubble, and dust.

This chamber provides easy access to the prison’s various cell blocks. Most of the doors leading off this room are unlocked and open easily, except for two described in their respective locations: the secret door to area @UUID[JournalEntry.OyNcqrpRClyhr8BJ.JournalEntryPage.zTpatmyyb4JvgNCo]{G2} is both hidden and locked, and the pentagram-inscribed doors to area @UUID[JournalEntry.OyNcqrpRClyhr8BJ.JournalEntryPage.YSOnwMgSJVzVm31U]{G10} are magically sealed.

The stairs leading downward connect to area @UUID[JournalEntry.FwWmtOBFHhvM2gtf.JournalEntryPage.L9JdFdozxxuly8RY]{H1}, 100 feet below. The currently impassable stairs would take at least a week of labor to clear. This level’s denizens likely won’t give the characters this time without harrying them, so they can’t effectively clear this away while devils and other hostile creatures remain. Urevian agrees to clear this away for the characters if they negotiate with him, as described in area @UUID[.YSOnwMgSJVzVm31U]{G10}.

An Eye on the Shaft: This room doesn’t have any guards, but the bearded devil drilling the unit of grothluts in the @UUID[JournalEntry.OyNcqrpRClyhr8BJ.JournalEntryPage.JLM4Hwqvk9V8qvbp]{Drill Field} to the north is likely to see anyone entering it. That devil exhorts his soldiers to attack.

Level 7 Portal Chamber.name: Level 7 Portal Chamber
Level 7 Portal Chamber.text:
Exploration

A character who succeeds on a [[/check skill=perception dc=25]] check spots the secret door in this room. Pressing a particular stone above it causes the secret door to rotate inward, which a character can deduce with a successful [[/skill 15 inv]] check. It rotates inward only an inch or so when discovered, revealing a combination lock with many metal cylinders. The combination is long lost, but a character can disable the tumblers with a successful [[/check ability=dexterity dc=17]] check using Thieves’ Tools. Otherwise, a character can force it open with a successful [[/check ability=strength dc=20]] check.

Teleportation Network

Some of the @UUID[Compendium.dnd5e.spells24.Item.phbsplTeleportat]{Teleportation Circles} within the Abomination Vaults form a part of a larger network. By tracing specific patterns on the wall runes, someone could transport everyone in any one of these chambers to one of nine other portal chambers in the Abomination Vaults- so long as the teleportation circles in both the departure chamber and destination have been awakened by the @UUID[Compendium.dnd-abomination-vaults.av-items-5e.Item.H0KYIrtDeeV2pSyC]{Awaken Portal} ritual (area @UUID[JournalEntry.KeWKr2yd8dbppeS5.JournalEntryPage.8X4xF40k06MW0X7q]{C35}).

The nine chambers are areas @UUID[JournalEntry.uMZ0RiCcPSqsx1Nm.JournalEntryPage.537bzfVUpq6XbR9a]{B17}, @UUID[JournalEntry.KeWKr2yd8dbppeS5.JournalEntryPage.vEiow4kU961XNOJp]{C16}, @UUID[JournalEntry.Os5bHdzCDiXgJBQ6.JournalEntryPage.RJf3BCpcVW6d68s7]{D05}, @UUID[JournalEntry.JT0zCcIwsSpKnbB5.JournalEntryPage.LJhOoRqYjj38YWl8]{E18}, @UUID[JournalEntry.KI33EAGPVHP4zyFZ.JournalEntryPage.mDFVGUXY6YDuQWF3]{F13}, @UUID[JournalEntry.OyNcqrpRClyhr8BJ.JournalEntryPage.zTpatmyyb4JvgNCo]{G02}, @UUID[JournalEntry.FwWmtOBFHhvM2gtf.JournalEntryPage.Nak2hUmVOHXBkcR5]{H33}, @UUID[JournalEntry.1vlzl3NJsftNB9Dc.JournalEntryPage.DJKWR2KLTPUi3w6T]{I59}, and @UUID[JournalEntry.yn21bNM6kpV4xRol.JournalEntryPage.JinYTJeYVFBE1uky]{J05}

The room’s floor gleams under a thin layer of dust. Runes filled with silver inlay have been carved into the walls.

This room contains an inert Teleportation Circle like the ones elsewhere in the Abomination Vaults (area @UUID[JournalEntry.uMZ0RiCcPSqsx1Nm.JournalEntryPage.537bzfVUpq6XbR9a]{B17}). This Teleportation Circle must also be reactivated with the Awaken Portal spell.

XP Award: Award the heroes [[/award 500xp]] for activating this portal.

Drill Field.name: Drill Field
Drill Field.text:
This chamber’s well-worn floor attests to its constant use. The walls angle up to a ceiling twenty feet overhead. The northern wall has a mine shaft elevator, but a wall of shimmering orange energy blocks the passage leading into it.

Belcorra welcomed her guests from the Darklands here before leading them upstairs for entertainment and refreshments. The chamber’s opulence has diminished over time. Centuries of military drills, sparring, and other abuses have damaged the walls, which are splattered with blood and ichor.

Urevian pulled in favors from infernal contacts to create a permanent, glowing wall of force that blocks the elevator’s shaft and sheds Dim Light throughout the chamber. He has no personal control over the wall. As long as Urevian’s contract with Belcorra remains valid, so does the wall; it disappears immediately if this contract is fulfilled. Details about concluding the deal, and thus dropping this barrier, are presented in area @UUID[JournalEntry.OyNcqrpRClyhr8BJ.JournalEntryPage.YSOnwMgSJVzVm31U]{G10}. The elevator descends 100 feet to area @UUID[JournalEntry.FwWmtOBFHhvM2gtf.JournalEntryPage.4gMUpcEFebuDe1Tf]{H17}; its function is described there, as it’s currently in the lower position.

Encounter

@UUID[Actor.FIoRPHaHdYUPVKdT]{Bearded Devil}, @UUID[Actor.K9Hw43co8fhwmKkM]{Grothluts (5)}

Jafaki doesn’t pay much attention to the many grothluts whom the devils defeated; they assume the devils killed them all. In truth, Urevian’s forces have been training the grothluts to fight on their side against their creators. As they’re mindless creatures, grothlut training is an exceptionally slow process, but the devils have had a lot of time on their hands.

A Bearded Devil is currently drilling five Grothluts here. He uses his magical bracer each day to encourage compliance, and the grothluts now follow his orders even when they aren’t under the devil’s direct control. The devil has become accustomed to (and immune to) the grothluts’ Piteous Moan.

These troops attack as soon as they see intruders, which likely occurs when the characters arrive in area @UUID[JournalEntry.OyNcqrpRClyhr8BJ.JournalEntryPage.2aDFWQZkq3nA7KPT]{G1}, but stealthy characters who succeed on a group [[/check skill=stealth dc=15]] check avoid notice prior to coming into this room.

Treasure: The devil wears a Drover’s Band.

World State

@UUID[Macro.6RFoXgFGwaBWdNIm]{G3 - Infernal Barrier}

When your players are ready to pierce the barrier, this macro will remove the wall and lighting effects from the elevator shaft, allowing them to pass.

Storage Cells.name: Storage Cells
Storage Cells.text:
These rooms stem off a long hall and obviously functioned as prison cells, but the doors stand open. The cells contain stacks of crates, barrels, and quivers full of arrows.

These former prison cells hold barrels of pitch, jugs of lantern oil, fuse cords, flint and steel, and hundreds of arrows—sufficient supplies to destroy a small village.

Only one of these cell doors is locked—that of the isolation cell to the east (area G4a). The accuser devil in this room holds the key; a character can otherwise open the door with a successful [[/check ability=dexterity dc=15]] check using Thieves’ Tools or force it open with a successful [[/check ability=strength dc=17]] check. The supplies within are detailed in “Treasure,” below.

Encounter

@UUID[Actor.uyGxJOnJ1gYwOpy5]{Azvalvigander}, @UUID[Actor.DnAeqlJRZc5N7hve]{Dreshkans (2)}

An Accuser Devil named Azvalvigander is responsible for itemizing all this equipment, which Urevian intends to use against Otari. The fussy Azvalvigander had already checked the inventory twice over and is doing so again to ensure she doesn’t make any mistakes. Two Dreshkans help her with brute labor and attack any intruders they see.

Treasure: Azvalvigander carries one of the five pieces of @UUID[Item.byrsQUlEoIiIgf9t]{Urevian’s pendant}.

Treasure

@UUID[Item.TUZUSTrCUWKq9FtA]{Infernal Armory}

The locked storage room contains valuable, destructive equipment: 10 flasks of Alchemist’s Fire, two Greater Necrotic Bombs, and five +2 Arrows.

Hellforge.name: Hellforge
Hellforge.text:
This chamber’s walls are charred black. Chains hang from the twenty-foot ceiling, suspending shelves of tools or metal ingots. A forge fills an alcove in the north wall; its mouth yawns open, filled with jagged teeth like those of a great beast, and a blazing fire roars inside. Between the beast-forge’s horns, a hole in the ceiling captures the smoke belching from its nostrils. An anvil rests near the forge. The west wall has a trough of sooty water pushed up against it, and weapon racks flank the double doors on the south wall.

This room once served as a torture chamber, but Urevian repurposed it for a more efficient use: creating weapons for his inevitable assault on the surface. The tiny ventilation shaft extends upward hundreds of feet before ending in a large, empty chamber in the earth, where smoke is trapped until it settles.

Encounter

@UUID[Actor.8Iozx4jbIGHxK4yf]{Barcumbuk}, @UUID[Actor.4bznEiwsJvInwZwA]{Bearded Devil}

Urevian assigned forge duty to an erinyes named Barcumbuk, a skilled smith who bristles at having to produce mundane weapons. He derives more pride from the laborious and lengthy process of creating hellforged weapons, so his overall productivity over the centuries has been relatively modest. A Bearded Devil assists him.

The devils realize that the characters must have dispatched Azvalvigander and her bodyguards to get here, and they’re openly appreciative of the exacting accuser devil’s demise. They still attack the party despite being grateful for the murderous service. Barcumbuk fights with his fiery forge hammers, while the bearded devil uses a Hellforged Glaive that deals an extra 1d6 Necrotic damage on a hit in the hands of a devil. The devils fight to the death.

Treasure: The +1 Hellforged Warhammer Barcumbuk wields deals an extra 1d6 Fire damage on a hit for as long as the hellforge exists. Barcumbuk also carries one of five pieces of @UUID[Item.byrsQUlEoIiIgf9t]{Urevian’s pendant}.

The Hellforge

The characters lack the skills to use the evil hellforge as anything but an ordinary forge, but they can certainly destroy it. A character who makes a successful [[/check skill=religion dc=20]] realizes that even a small amount of Holy Water splashed on an infernal forge can destroy it. If the check succeeds by 5 or more, the character also recalls that doing this releases a blast of energy.

If the party splatters the hellforge with Holy Water, it cracks down the middle with a mighty groan. Each creature in area G5 must attempt a [[/save ability=constitution dc=18]] saving throw, taking [[/damage 4d6 average thunder]] damage and [[/damage 4d6 necrotic average]] damage on a failed save or half as much of each damage on a successful one.

XP Award: Award the characters [[/award 1400xp]] for destroying the hellforge.

Treasure

@UUID[Item.cOKpI07e7K79zWzC]{Hellforge Materials}

Special metals Barcumbuk hasn’t gotten around to forging are stacked neatly near the anvil. They include five chunks of cold iron (worth [[/award 10gp]] each), two chunks of silver ([[/award 15gp]] each), and a chunk of adamantine ([[/award 500gp]]).

Guard Chamber.name: Guard Chamber
Guard Chamber.text:
This plain stone chamber contains two sets of double doors, one on the north wall and a second on the south wall. Carvings in tiny script cover the east and west walls.

The guardian here made these carvings to pass the time. Each carving represents a nonsense metaphysical question in Infernal, such as “Who are you if you are no one?” and “When your soul is consumed, do you consume yourself?” The creature likes to pose these types of questions during interrogations to make victims puzzle over the words’ deeper meanings and then feel foolish when they can’t find any.

Zone of Truth: This entire room is under the effects of a permanent @UUID[Compendium.dnd5e.spells24.Item.phbsplZoneofTrut]{Zone of Truth} spell (DC 15) placed by its devil guardian. In addition to the spell’s normal effects, a creature that fails its saving throw against the initial effect and subsequently chooses not to respond to a query from a devil in this room must make a successful [[/save ability=intelligence dc=15]] or take [[/damage 2d6 average psychic]] damage. On a successful Intelligence save, the creature becomes immune to this effect for 24 hours.

Encounter

@UUID[Actor.xjV0TmPNfKR7UcKu]{Iyagian}

A Bone Devil named Iyagian stands watch here at Urevian’s command. Unhappy with serving as a mere guard, yet bound by the contractual terms of service, Iyagian treats their charge very literally. They never warn the devils in the summoning chamber of any trouble and never leave this room, even if they receive telepathic messages from elsewhere (other than from Urevian, whom the bone devil always obeys, or if attacked by someone outside of this room).

If given the chance to talk, Iyagian freely explains their role and offers some of their nonsense meditations for the party to consider. They use the time the characters spend contemplating the questions to ask about why the characters are here, taking advantage of the magic they placed on the room to compel them to tell the truth. Iyagian loses their patience quickly, however, and eventually insists the characters leave them alone or risk their wrath. If combat begins, the bone devil fights to the death.

Summoning Chamber.name: Summoning Chamber
Summoning Chamber.text:
A stairway at the room’s south end leads north to a platform overlooking a cylindrical chamber. Half-melted candles cover a stone altar perched on this platform’s edge. Above the altar, water slowly drips from a crack in the ceiling and onto the platform, the droplets rapidly evaporating in the stifling heat. Six heavy chains suspend a wide metal disk above a magma pool that illuminates the chamber with an orange glow. A fiery pentagram burns atop the disk.

Belcorra commanded urdefhan geomancers to divert a natural magma flow to pool here. She then commissioned the creation of the ritual altar and the summoning circle atop the disk. Belcorra summoned several fiends in this chamber, binding each to her service. The greatest of these fiends was Urevian, and her contract with him gave her access to all the devils who serve beneath Urevian as well.

The ceiling is 20 feet above the doors of this room. As the stairs descend to the platform, the ceiling stays the same height, so it’s 25 feet above the platform. The disk is at the same level as the platform, but the 15-foot gap over magma makes it daunting to reach.

The air in this chamber is magically cooled but still runs hot enough to sap the strength of creatures within it. A creature that spends 1 hour or more in the room must make a [[/save ability=constitution dc=10]] saving throw. On a failed save, the creature takes [[/damage 1d6 average fire]] damage and suffers 1 level of &Reference[Exhaustion]. The 10-foot-deep pool of magma is much more dangerous than the hot air; a creature that enters or starts its turn immersed in the magma takes [[/damage 20d6 fire average]] damage.

Encounter

@UUID[Actor.mmBarbedDevil000]{Barbed Devil}, @UUID[Actor.mmImp00000000000]{Imp}

A Barbed Devil and an Imp are trying to convert the summoning circle into a permanent gate to Hell. Urevian insisted that they not be disturbed and posted the bone devil guard outside this chamber to ensure their privacy while they work.

Concerned more with the theory of extraplanar portals than the application, the devils spend a lot of time discussing their work but haven’t done much to enact it. Furious at the party’s interruption to their discourse, they most likely attack. If, however, any of the characters expresses expertise with summoning—such as summoning creatures in a fight or succeeding on a [[/check skill=arcana dc=18]] check to identify and discuss the magical features of the room—the devils offer to break off combat to discuss the finer points of extraplanar lore. This break is, unfortunately, only temporary. When the devils have learned all they think they can in this discussion, they nod at one another and then attempt to murder the rival scholar.

Treasure: The barbed devil carries a fragment of @UUID[Item.byrsQUlEoIiIgf9t]{Urevian’s pendant}.

The Cracked Ceiling

The crack in the ceiling allows water to drip down from the underground lake directly above (area @UUID[JournalEntry.KI33EAGPVHP4zyFZ.JournalEntryPage.f7dzsMJc3BAy82zr]{F4}). A character who succeeds on a [[/check ability=intelligence dc=15]] check using Nature or Mason’s Tools makes this connection. A character who succeeds on a [[/check skill=arcana/religion dc=15]] deduces that introducing enough water into the room would end the magic of the circle. If the characters widen the crack—a task that requires appropriate tools, the ability to reach the ceiling, and 4 hours spent chipping away the stone— the drips become a trickle, then a flood. The rush of water fills the room with steam and, over a few hours, cools the magma to stone. The summoning circle’s magic is powered by the heat, so cooling the magma deactivates the summoning circle for good.

XP Award: Award the characters [[/award 1200xp]] for destroying the summoning circle.

Isolation Chamber.name: Isolation Chamber
Isolation Chamber.text:
The door to this cell has a note affixed over a small sliding grate at eye level. Written by the imp Szek (see area @UUID[JournalEntry.OyNcqrpRClyhr8BJ.JournalEntryPage.rdvJqjktM8Q2T4cr]{G9}) in Common, Undercommon, and Infernal, the note reads, “Do not disturb if you value your limbs.”

The walls and floor of this chamber are covered in short spikes just long enough to cause discomfort to anyone standing, sitting, or leaning on them.

Once a chamber to detain particularly headstrong or troublesome prisoners, this room has seen very little use until recently.

Exploration

This isolation chamber no longer has a lock, so the door closes but doesn’t latch. Anyone moving the note and sliding the grate aside to look in the cell sees its gug occupant meditating. Unless the characters open the grate silently with a successful [[/check skill=stealth dc=12]] check, the gug awakens from her meditation at this interruption.

Encounter

@UUID[Actor.zq18QX6CBJNeUIgG]{Aulr}

Belcorra recently sent a Gug named Aulr to check on Urevian’s progress. Aulr’s unexpected and unwelcome arrival was one of the intrusions that convinced Urevian to finally block access to the lower levels. Urevian has put off talking to Aulr because he doesn’t really want to renew or revisit his deal with Belcorra. Aulr has grown tired of speaking to Urevian’s underlings and demanded to have her next conversation with Urevian himself. She’s overcome with rage at how she has been treated thus far and spends most of her time meditating to try to keep her calm. If the characters disturb the gug, she mistakes them for yet more lackeys, and her efforts to remain calm shatter. She reacts with sudden and startling violence against “yet more witless minions from the spineless devil.” Aulr allows foes who flee to retreat, but she otherwise fights to the death.

Observation Room.name: Observation Room
Observation Room.text:
This tall chamber reaches a height of thirty feet. Transparent stone makes up the southern wall, which looks into a vast room filled with square, transparent pillars surrounded by a catwalk. A jumble of metal scrap lies against this transparent wall.

While transparent from this side, the southern wall appears opaque from the other side. Strategists could look out over the stasis chamber to the south to select creatures to transport with Gauntlight. The metal scrap used to be a high catwalk to view the stasis chambers in the back of the room, but the gug in area @UUID[JournalEntry.OyNcqrpRClyhr8BJ.JournalEntryPage.Aob08m2bfrkArmJ2]{G8} wrecked it in a fury when Urevian sent a bearded devil to provide a report, rather than coming in person.

Creature: An Imp named @UUID[Actor.I4CpyMUsWfFYdpL5]{Szek} flutters near the ceiling, holding a small notebook and charcoal pencil. She’s making observations about the various prisoners and recommending uses for them in the upcoming invasion of Otari. Sample entries include, “gibbering mouther—ground manipulation could disable or destroy bridges, such as the tavern bridge near river mouth.”

When Szek detects the characters, she turns @UUID[Compendium.dnd5e.content24.JournalEntry.phbAppendixCRule.JournalEntryPage.MQIZ1zRLWRcNOtPN]{Invisible} and attempts to parley rather than fight.

“Close the door! Close the door! I don’t want to get caught talking to you—you’ll get us all tortured. So, surface dwellers, eh? Glad to see you. You’re taking down Urevian, right? Nasty devil. Bad business keeping him around—yup, yup, yup. How about we leave each other alone and pretend we never saw each other?”

Although she’s perfectly happy if the characters leave, Szek will speak to them if broached. Her starting attitude is Indifferent, and she remains Invisible until the characters befriend her, which requires a character to succeed on a [[/check skill=persuasion dc=12]] check or a [[/check skill=charisma (intimidation) dc=14]] check.

Szek is tired of running menial errands for Urevian. She is looking for someone more pliable to serve and hopes to come to an agreement with one of the characters regardless of her attitude toward them. If the characters improve her attitude, she answers their questions.

What Szek Knows

Urevian's Deal

Szek knows that Urevian has some sort of arrangement with Belcorra, but he wants to get out of it, even if it means making a deal to undercut Belcorra’s efforts. She suggests talking to Urevian to find out more, but she knows they’ll need the five parts of a pentagram amulet to open the door to area @UUID[.YSOnwMgSJVzVm31U]{G10}.

Urevian's Amulet

If asked about the pieces’ locations, she speculates that the fragments could be held by the aquatic devil sent to sabotage the laboratories level (area @UUID[JournalEntry.KI33EAGPVHP4zyFZ.JournalEntryPage.psfaf5Skhe3bMKsr]{F5}), Azvalvigander the quartermaster (area @UUID[JournalEntry.OyNcqrpRClyhr8BJ.JournalEntryPage.JCRGIRMAhYyjkSvF]{G4}), Barcumbuk the smith (area @UUID[JournalEntry.OyNcqrpRClyhr8BJ.JournalEntryPage.AeQmFFVsCUF02tzd]{G5}), Iyagian the guard (area @UUID[JournalEntry.OyNcqrpRClyhr8BJ.JournalEntryPage.wOB4cnHVwICglnUc]{G6}, although Iyagian doesn’t have one), the gate-forgers in the pentagram chamber (area @UUID[JournalEntry.OyNcqrpRClyhr8BJ.JournalEntryPage.fK6B6GmATzvRIuh4]{G7}), or the strange Motley Man whom Szek sees sometimes but who terrifies her (she refers to Ysondkhelir in area @UUID[JournalEntry.OyNcqrpRClyhr8BJ.JournalEntryPage.RiUE936phCZx8Hqe]{G18} but doesn’t know his name).

On the floors below

Szek knows that Urevian got tired of visitors from the lower levels and blocked one route with magic and the other route by simply stuffing it full of rubble. She’s certain he could open either easily.

On the floors above

If asked about the higher levels, Szek gleefully admits to participating in a “big fight” between Urevian and the worm-monsters a long time ago. She locked a powerful wizard in his room with just a few pitons and still takes pride in the act. The wizard—Chafkhem in area @UUID[JournalEntry.JT0zCcIwsSpKnbB5.JournalEntryPage.5XJBjPHU2XkIZWtN]{E17}—would be keen to learn that Szek is the one who imprisoned him.

On the prison's layout

As far as the prison level’s layout, Szek has limited information. She knows only about areas @UUID[JournalEntry.OyNcqrpRClyhr8BJ.JournalEntryPage.2aDFWQZkq3nA7KPT]{G1} through @UUID[JournalEntry.OyNcqrpRClyhr8BJ.JournalEntryPage.FzCW2srXAWImPK0v]{G16}, although she’s aware of an angry green spirit in area @UUID[JournalEntry.OyNcqrpRClyhr8BJ.JournalEntryPage.9ggvXDV6BvojMVBZ]{G17}. She has a rough idea of each room’s forces, but she doesn’t know about the traps in areas @UUID[JournalEntry.OyNcqrpRClyhr8BJ.JournalEntryPage.WeTrPKqTCTHIoWRu]{G11} or @UUID[JournalEntry.OyNcqrpRClyhr8BJ.JournalEntryPage.FzCW2srXAWImPK0v]{G16}; in fact, she believes area @UUID[JournalEntry.OyNcqrpRClyhr8BJ.JournalEntryPage.FzCW2srXAWImPK0v]{G16} is haunted.

Urevian’s Domain.name: Urevian’s Domain
Urevian’s Domain.text:
The huge doors to this room are magically sealed and emblazoned with an enormous, glowing pentagram. The pentagram’s center contains a circular indentation about the size of a human hand with five deeper indentations. The characters can discern that some device, like an amulet, fits into the indentation.

Opening the Door

The five @UUID[Item.byrsQUlEoIiIgf9t]{Fragments} of Urevian's pendant are held by:

  • • A severed hydra skull in @UUID[JournalEntry.KI33EAGPVHP4zyFZ.JournalEntryPage.psfaf5Skhe3bMKsr]{F5}
  • • Azvalvigander in @UUID[JournalEntry.OyNcqrpRClyhr8BJ.JournalEntryPage.JCRGIRMAhYyjkSvF]{G4}
  • • Barcumbuk in @UUID[JournalEntry.OyNcqrpRClyhr8BJ.JournalEntryPage.AeQmFFVsCUF02tzd]{G5}
  • • The barbed devil in @UUID[JournalEntry.OyNcqrpRClyhr8BJ.JournalEntryPage.fK6B6GmATzvRIuh4]{G7}
  • • Ysondkhelir in @UUID[JournalEntry.OyNcqrpRClyhr8BJ.JournalEntryPage.RiUE936phCZx8Hqe]{G18}

@UUID[Item.eUe2ZSV28kG8h0l3]{Urevian’s pendant} opens the door, but it’s currently split into five fragments held by his lieutenants. A devil of CR 3 or higher who touches even a single pendant fragment to the door can teleport to the other side. Other creatures must reassemble all five fragments and touch the pendant to the door to open it. After doing so, it’s effectively open for good; Urevian can enact a year-long ritual to recreate the door and the pendant, but he likely won’t do so.

Urevian doesn’t realize it, but a clever user can get the door open with only four pendant fragments by touching them to the door and making a successful [[/check skill=religion dc=17]] check to mimic the unholy energies of the missing fragment. A creature that fails this check takes [[/damage 4d12 fire average]] damage and makes Intelligence and Wisdom ability checks with Disadvantage for 1 hour.

Inside Urevian's Domain

A large chamber of natural stone runs north to south with an enormous stone double door as its only exit. Lit braziers cast strange shadows on the walls and bathe the room in a sinister light. Bookshelves and a sturdy desk, accompanied by neatly rolled-up scrolls and stacks of parchment, fill an alcove to the north.

Urevian has made this room his home, sealed off from the rest of the dungeon so he can work in peace. He fashioned the door for himself, but he had to manufacture a magical pendant for Belcorra so she could bypass it. Shortly before Belcorra’s death, Urevian had the imp Szek steal the pendant back. Urevian broke it into five pieces, giving one to each of his lieutenants. His trusted devils might come and go as they please, but even they know not to bother Urevian unless it’s on official business.

The desks contain reports, inventories, and maps of the surface world, of Gauntlight, and of the surrounding Darklands. Of particular note to the characters are complete maps of the fifth, sixth, and seventh levels of the Abomination Vaults, including all secret doors on those levels. The characters can also find copies of several infernal contracts, the originals of which are safely stored in Hell’s vaults. A character investigating the desk who succeeds on a [[/check skill=history or dc 17 intelligence (investigation) dc=15]] check realizes that Urevian has been keeping tabs on Vol Rajani’s line for generations and that Carman Rajani indeed appears to be Vol’s only surviving descendant.

The contract devil Urevian spends most of his time revising attack plans based on numerous contingencies. He always keeps two Bearded Devil bodyguards nearby to intercept reports from his lieutenants and to keep him from being disturbed. When the characters open the doors, the bearded devils spring forward in defense, but Urevian stops them and greets the party warmly. Read or paraphrase the following.

A ruggedly handsome devil steps forward, the long rolls of parchment hanging from his horns curling up, then unrolling again. “Friends, friends! Weapons away. Truly, I am happy to see you.” The devil turns to the two bearded devil bodyguards with their glaives raised. “Stand down, you two. I doubt they’re arrogant enough to fight us.
“I am Urevian, phistophilus and contracted agent of Belcorra, but I assure you I am no enemy of yours. You seek to vanquish her? Put an end to her murderous spirit, the threat she poses to mortal life, et cetera, et cetera? Then perhaps we can broker a deal—one that greatly benefits both of us with a minimal amount of precious lives lost.”

If the characters have already encountered Szek and made an agreement with her—which Urevian doesn’t really mind—he adds, “You already struck a deal with Szek, so I know it’s not a matter of if, but of what price. Trust me when I say, I’m giving you a deal.” For this conversation, refer to @UUID[JournalEntry.OyNcqrpRClyhr8BJ.JournalEntryPage.dVEJIxBXK6Mr30Cn]{Negotiating with Urevian} for a list of likely questions and Urevian’s responses.

If the characters take Urevian’s offer, he summons a contract for them to sign in blood. Urevian drafts an honest offer: upon his receipt of Carman Rajani (or his soul) from the party, he’ll leave the Material Plane along with all his devils remaining in the Abomination Vaults. His departure immediately removes the barrier in area @UUID[JournalEntry.OyNcqrpRClyhr8BJ.JournalEntryPage.JLM4Hwqvk9V8qvbp]{G3}. Before leaving, if the characters wish, he’ll order his surviving fleshwarps to clear the staircase leading down from area @UUID[JournalEntry.OyNcqrpRClyhr8BJ.JournalEntryPage.2aDFWQZkq3nA7KPT]{G1} to ease passage that way. His departure otherwise doesn’t affect the fleshwarps or other creatures in the prison, leaving the party to deal with those threats. Characters who sign are compelled to work toward delivering Carman to Urevian, as if affected by a level 9 @UUID[Compendium.dnd5e.spells24.Item.phbsplGeas000000]{Geas} spell.

If the characters ultimately decline Urevian’s offer, he sighs in disappointment before saying, “What more should I have expected from mortals?” He then orders his bodyguards to attack. He retreats behind them to cast Fireball before entering melee.

Encounter

@UUID[Actor.Mk6Uo4Vt1HkG9EvL]{Urevian} @UUID[Actor.FIoRPHaHdYUPVKdT]{Bearded Devils (2)}

Convinced they’re better than mere mortals in combat, the bearded devils fight to the death. The more Urevian is injured, the more he tries to convince the characters to accept his deal. However, Urevian breaks off combat only if the characters agree to accept his deal. If he’s slain, the magical barrier in area @UUID[JournalEntry.OyNcqrpRClyhr8BJ.JournalEntryPage.JLM4Hwqvk9V8qvbp]{G3} vanishes, though the stairs remain blocked.

Delivery

If the characters bring Urevian a living Carman Rajani or the gem with Carman’s soul inside, Urevian flicks a hand toward his desk. All the contents magically pack themselves into smaller and smaller boxes, eventually into a single valise that one of the bearded devils picks up. The other takes Carman (or the gem) in a firm grip, and both bearded devils disappear. “It was a pleasure doing business with you,” says Urevian, “I will look you up again, perhaps in a few years or decades. And if you’ve died in that time…well, I can come find you anyway. You’re so delightfully useful. I shall be in touch.”

XP Award: Award the party [[/award 5300xp]] for successfully negotiating with Urevian rather than killing him (if they later kill him, don’t award them XP for doing so).

Nexus.name: Nexus
Nexus.text:
This chamber is shaped like the interior of a large octagonal pyramid. The room has four exits on opposite walls. Bright, blood-red light shines down from the top of the pyramid in a perfect circle on the floor.

Paralyzing Light Trap

Hazard

Urevian constructed a magical trap here to incapacitate invaders and summon reinforcements to capture them. A cone of red light shines in a perfect circle onto the center of floor, leaving a 5-foot-wide walkway around the light. A spell or other effect that can sense the presence of magic, such as a @UUID[Compendium.dnd5e.spells24.Item.phbsplDetectMagi]{Detect Magic} spell, reveals an aura of Abjuration magic radiating from the light.

The first time a creature that isn’t a Devil enters the light, the light expands to fill the entire room. Simultaneously, a high-pitched chime sounds in the barracks (area @UUID[JournalEntry.OyNcqrpRClyhr8BJ.JournalEntryPage.wemHETiO7mks9Clo]{G15}), which is audible in this room as well. With a successful [[/check ability=dexterity dc=18]] check using Thieves’ Tools, a creature can distort the light such that creatures that enter the area don’t trigger the trap. The trap can also be permanently disabled with a successful @UUID[Compendium.dnd5e.spells24.Item.phbsplDispelMagi]{Dispel Magic} spell (DC 14).

A creature that isn’t a Devil that enters the light or that starts its turn there must make a [[/save ability=wisdom dc=16]] saving throw. On a failed save, the target takes [[/damage 1d10 average psychic]] damage and has the &Reference[Paralyzed] condition until the end of its next turn. On a success, the target takes half as much damage only. At the start of a Paralyzed creature’s turn, that creature can choose to deal itself [[/damage 4d10 average psychic]] damage. If it does, the Paralyzed condition immediately ends, and the creature can take their turn as normal.

Once there are no Paralyzed creatures left in the area, the room’s light fades to Dim Light and the trap can’t trigger again until the light returns to full brightness after 1 hour.

XP Award: Award the party [[/award 1800xp]] for disabling the trap.

Reinforcements: When the alarm goes off in area @UUID[JournalEntry.OyNcqrpRClyhr8BJ.JournalEntryPage.wemHETiO7mks9Clo]{G15}, half of the enemies there (one @UUID[Actor.zsgW8hHm3JfZUgwF]{mulventok} and one @UUID[Actor.DnAeqlJRZc5N7hve]{dreshkan}) make their way here immediately. If they haven’t come back in 3 rounds, the other two fleshwarps there realize something must be wrong and come to provide help as well.

Arena Walk.name: Arena Walk
Arena Walk.text:
A long hallway, stretching north to south, ends in a staircase that branches left and right at the southern end. The north and east walls each have a door with small, sliding windows. A raised portcullis at the northeastern end here has metal points crusted with dried blood.

Not all combatants in Belcorra’s arena participated willingly. Prisoners intended for the gladiatorial games were kept here briefly before being sent upstairs to meet their fates. The sliding windows let the characters peek into the cells.

The stairs lead up to area @UUID[JournalEntry.KI33EAGPVHP4zyFZ.JournalEntryPage.JhZf5mGUPNZqZSum]{F10}.

Empty Cell.name: Empty Cell
Empty Cell.text: Dust and cobwebs cover this forgotten cell. The party finds its door unlocked. Since the devils never check it, this cell makes for a safe, if cramped, place to rest.

Imprisoned Bounty Hunter.name: Imprisoned Bounty Hunter
Imprisoned Bounty Hunter.text:
Most of this cell has received very little care in the past several decades, but the manacles on the wall appear carefully polished.

The devils have recently put this cell back into service. A tiefling bounty hunter named @UUID[Actor.GoGNtiHuYycppLPk]{Cynemi} hangs upside down, her ankles bound by the manacles. She looks clearly weakened from ill treatment and neglect.

Through infernal contacts, Cynemi learned that a contract devil named Urevian had offered a high bounty on a specific target. Cynemi made her way here and agreed to retrieve Carman Rajani in exchange for Urevian’s power and influence. However, Carman proved too cunning, hustling Cynemi out of her equipment and leaving her stranded on a leaky boat in the Inner Sea. By the time Cynemi swam back to shore, the time she’d negotiated with Urevian had run out, so Barcumbuk dragged her back. She has been here ever since, fed only irregularly and often hung by her feet. She suspects she has spent months or even years imprisoned. Her manacles open easily, but Cynemi can’t reach them.

Side Quest

Cynemi requires urgent care, as she’s on the verge of death from dehydration. A character must provide Cynemi food and water and succeed on a [[/check skill=medicine dc=18]] check to save her. On a failed check, she dies shortly after the party discovers her. Even if saved, she stays distant and suspicious; her starting attitude is Hostile. A character can improve her attitude with a successful [[/skill 15 per]] check, although the GM might allow other ability checks to get Cynemi to open up. If the party can improve Cynemi’s attitude to at least Indifferent, she shares her story. She emphasizes how urgently Urevian needs to capture Carman Rajani and that the contract devil is willing to cut a deal for just about anything to get him. Regardless of her attitude toward the characters, Cynemi wants their help to get free and far away from here.

Cynemi is a criminal and wanted by Absalom authorities. A character who succeeds on a [[/check skill=history dc=15]] check recalls seeing a wanted poster for her (characters from Absalom have Advantage on this check). Of course, Cynemi doesn’t volunteer this information.

XP Award: Award the party [[/award 1400xp]] for getting Cynemi out of the Abomination Vaults, whether or not the characters place her in their custody.

Treasure: If the characters turn Cynemi over to the Otari Garrison, they earn a [[/award 50gp]] reward. If the characters have the support of the Otari Garrison, Captain Longsaddle gives them an additional [[/award 50gp]].

Barracks.name: Barracks
Barracks.text:
This old prison block has been converted into a makeshift barracks with several shoddy cots pushed into the cells and against the walls. The three cell doors have been chained open. Foot lockers sit near each cot.

Encounter

@UUID[Actor.zsgW8hHm3JfZUgwF]{Mulventoks (2)}, @UUID[Actor.DnAeqlJRZc5N7hve]{Dreshkans (2)}

When not drilling with the bearded devil or performing other menial tasks, the devils’ fleshwarped soldiers relax in this room. They face foes intelligently, with the two Mulventoks entering melee right away and the two Dreshkans fighting from a distance. All these foes fight to the death.

Treasure

The meager footlockers hold almost nothing of value. Each of the seven footlockers contains [[/award 3d6gp]].

Prison Office.name: Prison Office
Prison Office.text:
This old prison office is full of filth and cobwebs. A single door exits to the north.

Exploration

A character who searches this room and makes a successful [[/check skill=investigation dc=25]] check discovers the secret door. If the characters clean the dust and cobwebs from this room first, this DC drops to 20. Tiny cracks form the subtle shape of a manacle and chain on the wall. The spaces between the chain links are buttons that, when pressed, cause the secret door to slide open.

Beyond the secret door, a narrow hallway sports several peep holes filled with one-way transparent stone for spying on prisoners, along with a door to area @UUID[JournalEntry.OyNcqrpRClyhr8BJ.JournalEntryPage.lNmEdSB5CToA5aKq]{G21}. Characters can clearly see the secret doors leading out of this hidden hall (to areas @UUID[JournalEntry.OyNcqrpRClyhr8BJ.JournalEntryPage.FzCW2srXAWImPK0v]{G16} and @UUID[JournalEntry.OyNcqrpRClyhr8BJ.JournalEntryPage.RiUE936phCZx8Hqe]{G18}).

Painful Suggestion Trap

Hazard

The magical trap in this room triggers when a creature steps into the area just south of the northern door. A hidden rune on the floor under the filth, just past the threshold, triggers an ersatz ghost.

With a successful [[/check skill=arcana/investigation dc=20]] check, a character notices distortions in the air that are suggestive of protective magic. A spell or other effect that can sense the presence of magic, such as @UUID[Compendium.dnd5e.spells24.Item.phbsplDetectMagi]{Detect Magic}, reveals an aura of Enchantment magic on the floor. A creature can scratch out the rune without triggering it by making a successful [[/check dex thief dc=17]]. The rune can also be permanently removed with a successful @UUID[Compendium.dnd5e.spells24.Item.phbsplDispelMagi]{Dispel Magic} spell (DC 14).

When a creature other than a Construct or Undead passes over the rune, a frightful moan echoes through the room, and a hoarse telepathic voice shouts, “Get out!” Creatures in the room must attempt a [[/save wisdom dc=18]] saving throw. On a failed save, the creature takes [[/damage 6d10 psychic average]] damage and has the &Reference[Frightened] condition for 1 minute. On a successful save, the creature takes half as much damage only. A Frightened creature must take the Dash action on each of its turns to move as far away from the room as possible. At the end of each of its turns, the creature repeats the saving throw, ending the effect on itself on a success.

Once triggered, the rune vanishes, but it reappears after 1 hour.

XP Award: Award the party [[/award 1800xp]] for disabling the trap.

Stasis Chambers.name: Stasis Chambers
Stasis Chambers.text:
Fifteen transparent pillars fill the center of this thirty-foot- high room. A bright light shines down into the center of each chamber. A catwalk ten feet above the ground circles around the room’s edge without handrails or banisters; at the western side, each end stops at a staircase leading down.

Belcorra kept dangerous creatures in this room prior to teleporting them via Gauntlight’s beam. Each cell is 10 feet square, 20 feet tall, and made of transparent stone. Each creature stands motionless in its own column, held in a state of suspended animation outside the flow of time. The creatures haven’t aged and can’t be affected by any effect from within the normal timestream as long as they stay imprisoned. However, the pillars themselves, which are made of transparent, magically enhanced stone, can be destroyed (AC 21, 75 Hit Points, damage threshold 20).

Occupied Chambers

Ten pillars are occupied. They contain a @UUID[Actor.aD76W2uEQhFFUrom]{Chuul}, a @UUID[Actor.B7eLG2k7qUo8HU6O]{Drider}, three @UUID[Actor.IXen98RbUlbxDWBD]{Gogiteths}, a @UUID[Actor.dEAneTvoPuQXZoLR]{Gibbering Mouther}, a @UUID[Actor.T6vOuhM1KV5Fr75F]{Gibtanius}, and two @UUID[Actor.zq18QX6CBJNeUIgG]{Gugs}. One contains a ghonhatine (a hulking reptilian beast faintly resembling the humanoid lizard it once was) that’s dead because of a flaw in its chamber’s magic. If a character breaks through the stone around one of the creatures, the creature within must make a successful [[/save ability=constitution dc=21]] saving throw or the collapsing stasis effect messily kills it. On a success, the creature returns to normal time and attacks anything in sight until it’s destroyed. (High-challenge rating monsters, such as the gogiteths, pose a serious danger even for level 7 characters!)

Empty Chambers

Of the five empty stasis chambers, two are noteworthy. The northwest chamber is badly blackened, as though from soot from a fire raging inside. After the error with the ghonhatine, Belcorra appointed a hag to oversee this room, knowing that her magical expertise would be invaluable in maintaining the stasis chambers, but she didn’t intend for the hag to perform this job in life. Belcorra imprisoned the hag in this pillar, burned her to death, and bound her spirit as an undead creature called a witchfire. A creature entering a space within 5 feet of this pillar receives a brief telepathic flash of Belcorra burning the hag alive and gains a +1 bonus to saving throws against the witchfire’s spells and magical effects for 1 minute. A creature adjacent to the blackened pillar can also just make out the objects inside it (see “Treasure,” below). The pillar must be smashed open to retrieve them.

The second unusual stasis chamber, in the southwest, looks like the other empty chambers. However, its top and floor are both illusions. An open area below the chamber’s “floor” leads to a 5-foot- wide crawl space to the open trapdoor in Sacuishu’s room (area @UUID[JournalEntry.OyNcqrpRClyhr8BJ.JournalEntryPage.lNmEdSB5CToA5aKq]{G21}).

Encounter

@UUID[Actor.aIDLQY5mBPyxTjZ2]{Witchfire}

The Witchfire that Belcorra created long ago still guards this room. Minutes after anyone enters the area, or immediately if anyone touches any of the pillars, the witchfire materializes and attacks. She’s indiscriminate in who she confronts; local inhabitants who must pass through this room, such as the denizen of Leng, Ysondkhelir, or the devils who report to him, do so quickly and try not to touch anything.

Urevian has tried to make deals with the witchfire time and again, but the witchfire simply won’t listen to him. The contract devil knows that the creatures in stasis are valuable to his invasion plans, so he has postponed his invasion until he figures out how to reliably free them himself, without the witchfire’s assistance.

The vengeful witchfire can’t be reasoned with and, once she engages the characters, fights until destroyed. So long as any creatures in the room remain in stasis, when the witchfire is destroyed, she reforms in [[/r 1d4]] days at the location of the soot- blackened pillar, fully healed.

If any creature casts a spell that affects multiple creatures in the area or casts any spell of level 3 or higher, the spellvoid wisp Sacuishu comes from area @UUID[JournalEntry.OyNcqrpRClyhr8BJ.JournalEntryPage.lNmEdSB5CToA5aKq]{G21} to enjoy the feast of magic and arrives the next round.

Treasure

@UUID[Item.BCrt2lwSH40hIWHZ]{Hag's Belongings}

The soot-blackened pillar still contains two items left behind when the hag died: a Bag of Holding and Cloak of Protection. The Bag of Holding contains a dozen antique clocks, each from a different part of the world. The clocks are worth [[/award 2400gp]] in total.

War Room.name: War Room
War Room.text:
This small chamber features a large map of the Inner Sea painted on the north wall, though the listed countries seem long out of date. A large cushion rests in the room’s southwest corner. On the west wall, overlapping scraps of paper create a much newer map of the town of Otari and the surrounding terrain.

This chamber has seen little use as a war room and has been repurposed for its current inhabitant’s personal agenda, as evidenced by the maps.

Exploration

The paper maps conceal a secret doorway to a hall that connects to area @UUID[JournalEntry.OyNcqrpRClyhr8BJ.JournalEntryPage.FzCW2srXAWImPK0v]{G16}. A character searching this room locates the secret door with a successful [[/check skill=investigation dc=23]] check. If the characters remove the papers, this DC drops to 20. This secret door opens the same way as the one in area @UUID[JournalEntry.OyNcqrpRClyhr8BJ.JournalEntryPage.FzCW2srXAWImPK0v]{G16}. The secret doors leading out of the hidden hallway (to areas @UUID[JournalEntry.OyNcqrpRClyhr8BJ.JournalEntryPage.FzCW2srXAWImPK0v]{G16} and @UUID[JournalEntry.OyNcqrpRClyhr8BJ.JournalEntryPage.RiUE936phCZx8Hqe]{G18}) are obvious from within it.

Belcorra appointed the ageless and mysterious denizen of Leng named Ysondkhelir as her chief strategist. After Belcorra died, Ysondkhelir lost interest in planning troop movements, though he convinced Urevian that he was still doing so and that he would have plans ready by the time the devil chose to march on the surface. Ysondkhelir insisted that Urevian’s accuser devils keep scouting the surface and reporting back to him, which has allowed the denizen to make the exceptionally detailed map found here.

Instead of planning troop movements, Ysondkhelir seeks powerful latent psychics whom he can torment and, by means of eldritch invocations, send physically into the Dimension of Dreams so that other denizens of Leng can make use of them. He has had little success in the last five centuries—not only is true psychic potential very rare, but Ysondkhelir is as likely to drive his victims to insanity as to successfully send them to his extraplanar compatriots. He had most recently manipulated the addled dwarf Jedzeli (area @UUID[JournalEntry.KI33EAGPVHP4zyFZ.JournalEntryPage.fcEo2VAIF0ShGLVB]{F12}). Ysondkhelir abandoned Jedzeli as a lost cause to prey upon Dorianna Menhemes instead, and his schemes with her near completion.

Encounter

@UUID[Actor.8AVy2qIK6vh13sSj]{Ysondkhelir}

Ysondkhelir likes to claim a hand from each creature he corrupts. As he hasn’t ever met Dorianna in person, he instead stole a psychic imprint of her right hand. This imprint allows Ysondkhelir to cast @UUID[Compendium.dnd5e.spells24.Item.phbsplBigbysHand]{Arcane Hand}. When Ysondkhelir casts Arcane Hand in this way, the spell’s duration becomes 10 days, and the spell doesn’t require Concentration. Characters who have met Dorianna recognize the shimmering hand as identical to (but much larger than) her withered right hand. Once Ysondkhelir casts Arcane Hand in this way, he must visit Dorianna’s dreams before he can cast it again.

If the party simply barges in, Ysondkhelir uses the hand to keep foes at a distance as he retreats into the doorway of either adjacent room and out of melee range. He prefers spells that debilitate his foes, such as Eyebite and Hypnotic Pattern.

If the party comes to him with knowledge of Dorianna, the denizen knows his latest plot has put him in significant jeopardy. He attempts to calm the characters and convince them that he’ll release Dorianna from his clutches—an outright lie—if one of them willingly accepts his Leng ruby. A PC can see through this ruse with a successful [[/check skill=insight dc=18]] check. If the party falls for Ysondkhelir’s ruse, he relocates to another part of the prison level and not only continues to afflict Dorianna, but begins tormenting the character who took his ruby as well.

If Ysondkhelir is slain, he eventually reforms in Leng but gives up all his plots on the Material Plane—for now.

Token: You can place the @UUID[Actor.mYVvck7yMxQmCO86]{Ysondkhelir's Arcane Hand} token to track the position and HP of the Arcane Hand.

Restoring Dorianna: Slaying Ysondkhelir frees Dorianna, as described on page 98, and returns her hand to normal. Either destroying or dispelling the Arcane Hand also restores Dorianna’s hand.

Treasure: Ysondkhelir carries a fragment of Urevian’s pendant and a Leng ruby worth 500 GP.

Hand Collection.name: Hand Collection
Hand Collection.text:
A small desk covered in the stubs of burned candles stands against the east wall. The west wall has severed hands from more than a dozen creatures nailed to it, each badly withered and displayed palm outward.

Ysondkhelir performs his research in this room, but it primarily serves as his gruesome trophy hall—it bears the hands of creatures he has corrupted over the years, including Jedzeli’s. He spends hours examining them, mesmerized by the intricate details upon each hand that tell an entire life’s story.

Treasure

@UUID[Item.0M4Sq0NX8xtkW3hS]{Spell Scroll: Dream}

The desk drawer contains a Spell Scroll of Dream.

Ritual Room.name: Ritual Room
Ritual Room.text:
A filthy silk pillow rests at the center of this room, surrounded by a number of unlit candles. Several charcoal depictions drawn directly on the stone walls feature the same teenage girl repeated over and over. A small wooden box sits open in the corner of the room, revealing a few more candles inside.

Ysondkhelir performs his dream rituals here, using his magic to invade and twist Dorianna Menhemes’s dreams. His drawings of her help him to focus on her mind during these rituals.

Treasure

@Item[sECh4YAVtDGnmomm]{Valuable Candles}

The box contains several rare ritual candles worth [[/award 50gp]] in total.

The Secret Void.name: The Secret Void
The Secret Void.text:
The flat, black walls of this chamber reflect an eerie emptiness. An open trapdoor on the floor against the east wall leads to a narrow crawl space.

This chamber was built for a high priest of Nhimbaloth to sleep and meditate in. The concealed entrances grant privacy, and the room’s black walls simulate the void of oblivion granted to those consumed by the Empty Death.

Encounter

@UUID[Actor.3vn9W5SThovdsEnY]{Sacuishu}

Sacuishu, a Spellvoid Wisp and priest of Nhimbaloth, occupies this chamber. The other denizens of this level don’t know she’s here, as she only rarely slips out of this room to sup on the magical energies in the stasis chamber in area @UUID[JournalEntry.OyNcqrpRClyhr8BJ.JournalEntryPage.9ggvXDV6BvojMVBZ]{G17} before returning. When the characters arrive, Sacuishu is likely floating very still near the center of the ceiling, washing the room in a pale, sickly glow and basking in the emptiness. The presence of outsiders in her secret room offends her, and she immediately becomes @UUID[Compendium.dnd5e.content24.JournalEntry.phbAppendixCRule.JournalEntryPage.MQIZ1zRLWRcNOtPN]{Invisible} before casting @UUID[Compendium.dnd5e.spells24.Item.phbsplDarkness00]{Darkness} and attacking. If any of the characters openly carry the tome @UUID[Compendium.dnd-abomination-vaults.av-items-5e.Item.dy8ggyuCNnRoOIvk]{The Whispering Reeds}, Sacuishu is appalled that the sacred book would be in the hands of a nonbeliever and targets whoever carries it.

If reduced to 20 Hit Points or fewer, Sacuishu casts Sanctuary and retreats to area @UUID[JournalEntry.OyNcqrpRClyhr8BJ.JournalEntryPage.JLM4Hwqvk9V8qvbp]{G3}, hoping to make it to the lower levels. As that way is likely blocked, she puts up a last stand there.

Magical Communicator.name: Magical Communicator
Magical Communicator.text:
A bowl of filthy swamp water rests upon a crude altar.

Priests once used this scrying bowl to communicate with Belcorra before it became inactive upon her death. Sacuishu has been trying to reignite its magic now that Belcorra has returned, with only limited success. The first creature to look into the waters of the bowl sees Belcorra’s hateful visage leering back. That creature must make a [[/save ability=intelligence dc=19]] saving throw, taking [[/damage 7d6 average psychic]] damage on a failed save or half as much damage on a successful one. After this initial appearance, Belcorra’s image doesn’t reappear.

Treasure

@UUID[Item.O0uYUbpl2z7FMfPf]{Scrying Bowl}

Lying on the altar next to the bowl is a blue sapphire Elemental Gem. The bowl is worth [[/award 1000gp]] and can be used as the material component for the Scrying spell.

Introduction.name: Introduction
Introduction.text:
Chapter Synopsis

Long ago, Belcorra handed over the prison level to the contract devil Urevian and his infernal minions. They now prepare diligently to invade the surface, and the level is on reasonably high alert. The characters must fight their way through many devils and fleshwarp minions. They might find some surprising allies, including an imprisoned bounty hunter and an imp named Szek who’s eager to make a deal. Here, the heroes can also put an end to the malevolent creature tormenting Dorianna Menhemes. When the party finally meets Urevian, he extends an offer wrapped in a difficult moral choice.

Environmental Cues:

Stench of brimstone, eerie silence, flickering flames, smoke, cell doors, infernal runes carved on surfaces (Urevian has been spying on Carman Rajani and thus knows a little bit about the party. The GM can play up the ominous atmosphere of this level by having some of the characters’ foes call them by their names or predict their general tactics—particularly anything they’ve used or discussed around Carman).

The Prison

The devils repurposed the prison from its original use. They use many cells for storage or in preparation for invading the surface. The ceilings are 20 feet high throughout, and most of the level is illuminated with a dim, red light from flickering flames or glowing diabolic symbols. The doors are all stone bound in iron, and many are locked. As a side effect of pervasive, diabolic influence, all doors flicker briefly with fire around their edges when opened or closed, making sneaking around in the prison level difficult. A character proficient in Religion can utter a brief incantation (which requires no action) when using a door to prevent this effect.

Urevian’s devils have had little contact with the Abomination Vaults’ lower levels, even in less troubled times. He received food from the farm level below to feed his mortal soldiers but cares little for the denizens there or their machinations. Since Belcorra’s return, Urevian has seen an increase in urdefhans, drow, and other creatures parading through the prison level, and he has had enough. He recently blocked the stairs leading down to the lower level with rubble (area @UUID[JournalEntry.OyNcqrpRClyhr8BJ.JournalEntryPage.2aDFWQZkq3nA7KPT]{G1}) and erected a magical barrier across the large elevator opening (area @UUID[JournalEntry.OyNcqrpRClyhr8BJ.JournalEntryPage.JLM4Hwqvk9V8qvbp]{G3}). Urevian knows that his control over these barriers probably gives him some leverage with the characters, too, which further benefits him. He needs them to be his hands on the surface.

Negotiating with Urevian.name: Negotiating with Urevian
Negotiating with Urevian.text:
Urevian sees the characters as an unexpected opportunity and a potential solution. If the characters clear out the Abomination Vaults by slaughtering their way through Jafaki and the seugathis, then all the better for the devil. Urevian has ordered his devils to keep an eye out for the characters, to kill all but one or two, and then bring him the survivors for negotiations. He plans to convince the remaining characters to deliver Carman Rajani to him. Otherwise, he’ll march his army up through the dungeon and destroy Otari.

Who are you?

“I am Urevian, a contract devil of some renown, if I do say so myself.”

What do you want from us?

“Simply put, you are the third-party agents I need to get out of this dreadful place and return home. You see, there is something I want but am not allowed to go and get myself, nor can I employ any infernal agents to retrieve it. No, the hands of a mortal foe of Belcorra must deliver me my prize. My devils are valueless in this regard, as are my fleshwarp soldiers.”

Why does it have to be a mortal foe of Belcorra?

“That is the delight of legalistic contract interpretation. It cannot be me, any of my minions, or any ally of Belcorra’s. The contract was written with the intent that Belcorra alone could give me the prize as my payment. Which, of course, she will not do until I have given her the full measure of service the contract requires. However, a very technical reading means that any of her foes can also provide it—and you have thus far conclusively demonstrated that you oppose her.”

What is it that you want?

“I require the soul of Carman Rajani. In his living body, if possible, though I can make do should he…perish.”

What do you want with Carman's soul?

"I owe the soul of a Rajani to someone much more powerful than myself. It would be… unwise for me to leave the Material Plane without it. Carman is the last descendant of Vol Rajani.”

What will this powerful someone do with Carman's soul?

“I do not know for sure. My contract is just to turn it over. It cost me quite a bit simply to make the deal, but I stand to gain a fair amount of prestige in Hell once it is completed.”

What do we do if he died?

“There is a ritual I know that can summon his spirit out of the River of Souls and back to the place where he died. There it can be captured. If you sign an agreement with me, then I shall teach it to you.”

We can't give you someone's soul. That's evil!

“Is it? I would say it is a lesser evil to turn over the soul of one corrupted individual than to allow an entire town to be destroyed. Far less bloodshed on all sides. I do not want to raze Otari, and I do not want to kill you. However, the contract I have with Belcorra says that as long as I remain within her employ, I must pursue the domination of the surface world and the destruction of her enemies. Once my contract ends, so does my obligation to her. All I need is Carman Rajani’s soul to fulfill the contract.”

How is Carman Rajani corrupted?

“Oh, he is a bastard of a man. His soul is already damned for lying, cheating, thievery, vandalism, destruction of property, arson, abuse of power, blackmail—even a murder. It is quite clear where he is going. You would simply cut out the bureaucracy by giving him to me directly.”

If we hand over Carman, he'll never have a chance at redemption.

“Do you honestly think there is much chance of that? Just recently he burned a library and stole a historical relic in some misguided ploy to win a political office, which he would use only to abuse his power and increase his wealth. If I didn’t need his soul for this specific purpose, I would hire him.”

What do we get out of this arrangement?

“Peace for Otari. I will leave, taking all of my devils with me. When I go, the barrier preventing you from getting to the lower level will disappear. If you would like, I will direct my fleshwarp minions to clear away the blocked staircase, giving you a second way down.” If no one has yet made a deal with Szek, he continues, “I might even be able to broker further agreements between you and myself or one of my devils.”

What further agreements?

Urevian can offer an infernal contract to one character.
