This contract can grant a wide range of abilities and effects, akin to the power of a @UUID[Compendium.dnd5e.spells24.Item.phbsplWish000000]{Wish} spell but fulfilled to the letter by Urevian. To receive any of those benefits, the mortal must willingly sign its true name to the contract, which binds its soul to Urevian and to Hell upon death. The bound mortal can’t be restored to life except by a Wish spell or @UUID[Compendium.dnd5e.classes24.Item.phbclcDivineInte]{divine intervention} (which alerts Urevian). Understanding exactly how Urevian interprets the wording of the Wish requires a character to succeed on a [[/check skill=investigation/religion dc=15]] check, and a character can find any loophole Urevian might have left (at your discretion) with a successful [[/check skill=investigation/religion dc=19]] check. Urevian might instead transfer Szek’s infernal contract to force the imp to serve one of the characters. Szek is happy to serve someone other than Urevian for a change but soon chafes at being unable to indulge in tasks of her own choosing. She does her best to tempt the character who holds her contract toward wickedness and damnation.

We've already defeated your devils; you have nothing to invade with.

“Ah, but I can conscript more devils after I kill you. I am afraid that such an inconvenience is, at best, temporary.”

We'll never make an agreement with you!

“Are you sure about that? Consider carefully. Turning down my offer most likely means your death.” Urevian gestures meaningfully to his bodyguards.

Recovering Carman.name: Recovering Carman
Recovering Carman.text:
How easily the characters can recover Carman depends on his fate in @UUID[JournalEntry.JT0zCcIwsSpKnbB5.JournalEntryPage.h5jpnxksczOaC2Tk]{Chapter 5}.

If they released him, they can likely find him still brooding in Smuggler’s Refuge, as he hasn’t summoned the courage to depart. He certainly won’t go with the characters willingly if they explain what they want with him, but the characters could trick him. If Carman knows what he’s in for, he does his best to flee the area, and the characters probably have to work with Urevian to scry his new location—which the contract devil certainly makes them pay for, one way or another.

If Carman is in jail, the characters can simply fetch him from custody. Longsaddle doesn’t mind turning Carman over to the characters, as they captured him in the first place. If they’re up-front about why they want Carman, Longsaddle is surprisingly agreeable to turning the scoundrel over to the devil (see the “@UUID[JournalEntry.OyNcqrpRClyhr8BJ.JournalEntryPage.7paNQNFfVrMdK8N5]{Asking Advice}” sidebar).

If Carman is dead, the characters must go to the place of his death to trap his spirit. Urevian explains that doing so requires the party to perform a simple ritual (which he can teach them) while holding a specially prepared gemstone (which he also provides). The party must pay for and burn magical incense that costs [[/award 300gp]], and a character must succeed on a [[/check skill=religion dc=15]] check at midnight to draw forth the soul. If the characters call Carman’s spirit, it’s automatically drawn into the gemstone, which they can turn over to Urevian. If the check fails, the incense is wasted, and the characters must wait for another midnight. If the check fails by 5 or more, they accidentally call forth an angry spirit, such as a Wraith.

Asking Advice.name: Asking Advice
Asking Advice.text:
The moral question Urevian poses—whether to turn over Carman Rajani—might not be something the players spend a lot of time considering. Other groups might weigh the question thoughtfully and even seek opinions about what they should do. The NPCs in Otari are split on the matter.

Vandy Banderdash thinks it’s wrong to bargain with a devil using another person’s soul. She believes that everyone deserves a chance at redemption, even Carman Rajani. However, she holds a particular contempt for thieves, as she has never really recovered from the betrayal of her sister stealing from her years ago, so she doesn’t push the characters if they disagree with her position.

Wrin Sivinxi also opposes the deal, as she finds limiting a soul’s freedom to be abhorrent.

Captain Longsaddle is happy to release Carman to the characters so they can turn him over to the devil. He considers this a straightforward way to solve the longstanding problem of someone who’s a proven threat to his town.

For once, Yinyasmera agrees with the guard captain. She has had so many past problems with Carman that she would also like to see him gone, particularly knowing that doing so would save the town she genuinely loves.

Mayor Oseph Menhemes doesn’t take a position but backs whatever choice the characters make, especially if they’ve been helping his daughter. The mayor believes that the characters are capable and trustworthy decision-makers. If his opinion is a tie- breaker, he leans toward showing Carman mercy.

The bookseller Morlibint doesn’t offer a direct opinion but recommends several stories about dealing with devils (virtually all of which turn out very poorly for the mortals involved).

Damp Entrance.name: Damp Entrance
Damp Entrance.text:
Swaths of mildew and mold cover the damp surfaces of this watchtower, appearing as green and black smears on the dull stone walls. The door frames in the walls to the north and south rotted long ago, while a few collapsed chairs lie on the floor amid small heaps of foul-smelling gray lumps. Thick sheets of dusty cobwebs hang from above, obscuring any view of the ceiling.

Once the primary entrance to Gauntlight Keep, this one-story outbuilding is constructed of sturdy stone. The opaque sheets of dusty cobwebs function as a drop ceiling at a height of 7 feet, leaving a 3-foot space between the cobwebs and the stone ceiling above.

Creatures

Three mitflits lurk above the cobwebs but can’t resist a chance to torment and trick the characters once they enter the room below. By crouching down on the planks and vines and peering through the cobwebs, the three mitflits wait unseen until at least two characters have entered the room before calling out in their best imitation of high-pitched pixie voices. The mitflits welcome the characters into the parlor, warn them about the mean bugs that live in the nearby keep, and suggest the visitors partake of the “magic pixie mud” on the floor. Of course, the fact that the mitflits lack any skill at lying and can only speak in Undercommon means that their chances of success are slim, but if they succeed, they’re overcome with guffaws of laughter and can’t help but reveal their presence.

Encounter

@UUID[Actor.E0LCMHVp4sxAbQYa]{Mitflits (3)}

If confronted (either after the characters spot them or fail to fall for their tricks), the mitflits shout in anger and fear. One of them clambers up through the hole in the roof and tries to climb across the vine stretching from areas @UUID[JournalEntry.kDJSn9wbVvjnqYEj.JournalEntryPage.tLAbtqjMjDw2qq1h]{A1} to @UUID[JournalEntry.kDJSn9wbVvjnqYEj.JournalEntryPage.YWWlJBVLGkdNcjxf]{A9} to warn his boss in area @UUID[JournalEntry.kDJSn9wbVvjnqYEj.JournalEntryPage.le4tidRkFqodABe4]{A10}, while the other two throw darts at the characters and shout for them to flee. As soon as any mitflit takes damage, they shriek in fear, cast Bane, and retreat to area @UUID[JournalEntry.kDJSn9wbVvjnqYEj.JournalEntryPage.YWWlJBVLGkdNcjxf]{A9}.

Exploration

Ceiling

The Mudlicker mitflits have rigged a slipshod network of soggy ropes and planks in the space above the cobwebs to clamber around on; a character who makes a successful [[/check skill=perception dc=9]] spots this feature through the webbing. If this check succeeds by 5 or more, the character notices a 3-foot-diameter hole in the roof in the northwest corner, which the gremlins use to come and go.

Strange Lumps

A character who succeeds on a [[/check skill=nature dc=13]] identifies the deposits of stinky gray material as mitflit dung. The mitflits use this room as a latrine as well as an advance guard station.

Treasure

Characters who search the room find six @UUID[Item.6vEnTu29Qy0jJABa]{peridot beads} (one of the mitflits thought they were candy), along with a chipped mitflit tooth in one of the little dung piles. Each bead is worth [[/award 2gp]].

Decrepit Drawbridge.name: Decrepit Drawbridge
Decrepit Drawbridge.text:
A wooden drawbridge, its timbers gray with age and decay, spans the twenty-foot gap between the outbuilding and sprawling ruin on the island. Rusty iron chains hang from the ruin’s northern wall to the drawbridge’s southern side. The chains look ready to fall apart, giving the drawbridge’s structural integrity an extra layer of dubiousness.

Exploration

True to appearances, the drawbridge isn’t safe to cross, especially now that the mitflits have further weakened the structure with some clever undercutting to its supports.

A Small or smaller creature can cross the bridge safely, but Medium creatures must cross one at a time or the bridge collapses with a groaning crash. This dumps everyone on the bridge into the water, which is 4 feet deep. A creature near the ends of the drawbridge when it collapses can use its Reaction to grab onto the ledge by making a successful [[/save ability=dexterity dc=10]]. Climbing up uses 10 feet of movement.

Once the bridge has collapsed, a creature that makes a successful [[/check skill=athletics dc=10]] can clamber up to area @UUID[JournalEntry.kDJSn9wbVvjnqYEj.JournalEntryPage.tLAbtqjMjDw2qq1h]{A1} or @UUID[JournalEntry.kDJSn9wbVvjnqYEj.JournalEntryPage.koVFvK0xxQMwKjaW]{A4} on either side. The sound of the collapsing bridge draws the attention of the mitflits and maggots in area @UUID[JournalEntry.kDJSn9wbVvjnqYEj.JournalEntryPage.koVFvK0xxQMwKjaW]{A4}.

World State

@Macro[IG9T1NXWfBf7YfcX]{A02 - Drawbridge Collapse}

If the heroes collapse the bridge, click on the above macro to toggle the state of the tile- and play a sound effect as it splinters beneath them!

Corpse Pond.name: Corpse Pond
Corpse Pond.text:
Tangles of reeds grow in thick clusters around the edge of this muddy pond. The water appears murky with algae, and the half-decayed body of a three-foot-tall scaly humanoid lies on the pool’s northern bank, half-buried in mud and leaves.

The water of this pond is only 4 feet deep, but an extra few feet of mud below makes it Difficult Terrain to wade through.

Exploration

Vines and creepers festoon the ruins, but a character that investigates this area and makes a successful [[/check skill=nature dc=13]] identifies one long vine as out of place. This vine stretches from the top of the watchtower (area @UUID[JournalEntry.kDJSn9wbVvjnqYEj.JournalEntryPage.tLAbtqjMjDw2qq1h]{A1}) to the north end of the walkway to the northeast (area @UUID[JournalEntry.kDJSn9wbVvjnqYEj.JournalEntryPage.YWWlJBVLGkdNcjxf]{A9}). The mitflits strung this vine up so they could avoid the ground if they wanted to; it won’t support a Medium or larger creature.

Treasure

@UUID[Item.oQrMKmY8JNRjnU2U]{Kobold's Remains}

The corpse on the pond’s north bank is a dead Stonescale kobold. The gear on the kobold’s body is mostly ruined, save for [[/award 4gp]] in one rotten belt pouch and two bags of @UUID[Compendium.dnd5e.equipment24.Item.phbagBallBearing]{Ball Bearings}.

Maggot Training Hall.name: Maggot Training Hall
Maggot Training Hall.text:
Piles of rotting timbers and loose stones lie in heaps throughout this large, L-shaped hall.
Clumps of moss and tangled vines spill down from gaps in the wooden ceiling above each pile of rubble. Several doors lead out to all sides, most barely clinging to their hinges and frames. Debris completely blocks a wooden stairwell that leads up to a large hole in the ceiling. Here and there, the stone walls bear the scars of fire or damage from an ancient battle.

Exploration

Many years ago, the Roseguard—the adventurers who would one day found Otari—confronted Belcorra in this vast room. The fight spilled from here into the servants’ lounge, now a sinkhole (area @UUID[JournalEntry.kDJSn9wbVvjnqYEj.JournalEntryPage.g363pURldvDgwmoc]{A8}), and caused some of the keep’s collapse. A character who investigates this room and makes a successful [[/check skill=arcana dc=13]] confirms that powerful, destructive spells caused some of the damage centuries ago.

Rubble

Most of the doors in this room are easy enough to access, with one exception. The door to area @UUID[JournalEntry.kDJSn9wbVvjnqYEj.JournalEntryPage.IdPksxjraU1gfumW]{A14} is buried in rubble, but a character can clamber up and over the pile of debris with a successful [[/check skill=athletics dc=10]]; from the top, a character can reach the hole in the roof, which leads down into the room beyond. If a character fails this check, a stone near the top comes loose as the climber puts weight on it, and they fall 10 feet.

Secret Door

A secret door opens into a small hidden alcove to the northwest; a character who searches the room and succeeds on a [[/check skill=investigation dc=18]] finds a section of the stone wall that slides aside to access it. The alcove beyond the door has several grooves in the stone, caused by determined scraping. This chamber used to contain a permanent Teleportation Circle that could be activated to connect to area @UUID[JournalEntry.KeWKr2yd8dbppeS5.JournalEntryPage.VZPc5GsIN5eRKSVE]{C5a}, but fortune-hunters found this hidden alcove centuries ago and gouged out all the gemstone powder in the magic runes. The extensive damage drained away the magic and permanently destroyed the Teleportation Circle. A character who succeeds on a [[/check skill=arcana dc=15]] realizes the original purpose of this room and the permanent damage done. This room foreshadows the many other Teleportation Circles in the Abomination Vaults that the characters will be able to reactivate and use.

Encounter

@UUID[Actor.E0LCMHVp4sxAbQYa]{Mitflits (3)}, @UUID[Actor.y9D2wh63pBzIyI7i]{Giant Maggots (2)}

When the mitflits dwelled in the dungeons below, they numbered in the dozens, but their violent eviction by morlocks and attrition from their cruel games has left the band much diminished. Originally, all the Mudlickers lived in this large room; now, only three mitflits remain here.

The Mudlicker leader, Boss Skrawng, has an audacious plan. After discovering the maggots in area @UUID[JournalEntry.kDJSn9wbVvjnqYEj.JournalEntryPage.9kxya2R9NYsSAA4G]{A5} and the giant fly in area @UUID[JournalEntry.kDJSn9wbVvjnqYEj.JournalEntryPage.yyUsiyd1QIMwin1X]{A6}, he ordered his mitflits to start training and breeding more maggots. Once the insects have fully grown, he intends on leading his entire group, mounted on giant fly war steeds, down to Otari to raid and rule.

Three Mitflits are currently engaged in training their first two Giant Maggots, hoping that the pallid creatures will retain their training after they mature into giant flies. None of the gremlins know how long it takes for a maggot to grow up big and strong, but they don’t expect it to be more than a couple of days, or a week at most. Upon sighting the characters, the mitflits immediately order their “pets” forward to attack.

Maggot Nest.name: Maggot Nest
Maggot Nest.text:
A collapsed wooden staircase in the northeastern corner of this room winds up to a moss-shrouded hole. The expanse of the Fogfen is visible through a total collapse in a stone wall to the west. A dead frog the size of a horse lies sprawled in this collapse, its back legs bitten off at the hips.

This massive frog was attacked by Freznelkesh, the dragon lairing in area @UUID[JournalEntry.uMZ0RiCcPSqsx1Nm.JournalEntryPage.ZGby3FkCgaPte0O9]{B19}. The dragon decided she wasn’t interested in the frog’s foul-tasting toxic skin and stopped after gnawing off its legs.

Examining the Frog

@UUID[Item.KGCUmYkrezxwtKB5]{Giant Maggot Eggs}

A character who examines the frog carcass can attempt a [[/check skill=survival/perception dc=13]], or a [[/check skill=arcana dc=15]].

A character who succeeds on the Perception or Survival checks finds five giant maggot eggs. Each egg can be sold to Boss Skrawng for one @UUID[Item.6vEnTu29Qy0jJABa]{peridot} (worth 2 GP).

A character who succeeds on the Arcana check realizes a Medium dragon ate the frog’s legs. If the check succeeds by 5 or more, the character notices residue that identifies the dragon as a green dragon wyrmling.

Fly Pen.name: Fly Pen
Fly Pen.text:
The interior of this watch post still has a wooden ceiling high above, but a thick mound of filth and animal carcasses heaped on the floor make the room anything but inviting.

Exploration

This room’s ceiling is 15 feet high and has a trapdoor leading out onto a small parapet that survived the manor’s collapse. A character who succeeds on a [[/check skill=perception dc=16]] can spot the trapdoor, which can’t easily be seen. With the ladder gone, a character must succeed on a [[/check skill=athletics dc=15]] to climb to the trapdoor

Under Boss Skrawng’s orders, the mitflits captured the cornerstone of their plan to rule Otari—a magnificent, green-and-blue fly the size of a pony that the gremlins call Buzzybuzz. They keep it here believing that the fly can’t escape this room; the mitflits don’t know about the trapdoor, but their fly prisoner found it right away. Buzzybuzz can leave whenever it wants, but the food in this area keeps it satisfied.

In fact, this room is slightly too convenient, as a second giant fly with brown and blue coloration sometimes comes in, too. The two giant flies get along with one another, as there’s plenty of food for both. However, they’ve never both been seen in the room at the same time, so Boss Skrawng and his followers believe there’s only one giant fly. They don’t understand why Buzzybuzz seems to change color from time to time, but they don’t really know that much about giant flies.

Encounter

@UUID[Actor.3DSqfobadad3pA6O]{Giant Flies (2)}

The characters first encounter the green-and-blue Giant Fly when they enter this room, whereas the brown-and-blue fly rests on the parapet above. When any creatures enter, the Buzzybuzz inside the room circles the interlopers, assuming they’ve come to bring it more food. If attacked, the room fly zips out through the trapdoor to seek friendly mitflits in area @UUID[JournalEntry.kDJSn9wbVvjnqYEj.JournalEntryPage.le4tidRkFqodABe4]{A10}, and the other one follows. Any mitflits who see the escape or both flies together become visibly confused.

The giant flies are somewhat loyal to the mitflits, but a determined character can overcome this dedication, if only for a short time. A character who feeds a Buzzybuzz or succeeds on a [[/check skill=animalHandling dc=16]] can improve its attitude. It can carry loads for the party and generally follows them around, but only a mitflit can ride it or train it to carry other creatures. Other creatures can’t steer it and fall off when the fly moves unless they succeed on a [[/check skill=animalHandling dc=16]]. In addition, if the party encounters mitflits while assisted by a fly, a character use an action to attempt a Wisdom (Animal Handling) check contested by the nearest mitflit to order the Buzzybuzz to assist against the mitflits. If no character attempts the check or if the mitflit wins the contest, the fly shakes off anything it carries and does as the mitflit wants until the end of the encounter.

Dining Room.name: Dining Room
Dining Room.text:
Macro

@Macro[tFWg6zQ2ZvSkRUcY]{A07 - Stonescale Spirits}

When the spirits rise for the first time, use this macro to synchronise revealing the token and the light source at once.

The collapsed ceiling at the middle of this room has left a ragged hole in the wooden roof. Rotten tapestries, their designs completely obscured by mold, hang in tatters on the walls between arrow slits and ruined side tables. The remains of a fancy dining table lie mostly pulverized by the fallen ceiling.

Not all the haunts that plague Gauntlight are direct echoes of Belcorra’s legacy. This room served as the communal hall for the Stonescale kobolds before a violent coup tore the group apart and they killed each other. The spirits of the betrayed kobolds linger here to this day.

Haunt

Stonescale Kobolds

When a creature gets up close to the center of the room, a half-dozen ghostly kobolds rise from the rubble in a howling vortex.

As the characters enter the room, those who succeed on a [[/check skill=insight/religion dc=15]] feel an inarticulate confusion rising in their minds. Those who succeed on the Religion check or a subsequent [[/check skill=investigation dc=13]] can deduce that the feelings belong to the unquiet spirits of dead cowards who linger in this world to scare others. A spell or other effect that can sense the presence of magic, such as @UUID[Compendium.dnd5e.spells24.Item.phbsplDetectMagi]{Detect Magic}, reveals an aura of necromancy around the rubble.

When a creature enters a space in the middle of the room that’s either fully or partially filled with rubble, six ghostly kobolds surge out of the fallen debris with eerie yowls. The spirits don’t stir for any creature with Immunity to the Frightened condition. All creatures in area A7 must make a successful [[/save wisdom dc=13]] or have the @UUID[Compendium.dnd5e.content24.JournalEntry.phbAppendixCRule.JournalEntryPage.93uaingTESo8N1qL]{Frightened} condition for 1 minute. While Frightened this way, the creature must use each of its turns to take the Dash action and move in a random direction. At the end of each of its turns, the creature repeats the saving throw, ending the Frightened condition on itself on a success.

Once the kobold spirits emerge, roll Initiative. The haunt rolls Initiative with a +3 modifier. On the haunt’s turn, the spirits swoop together toward one creature in area A7 that has the Frightened condition, instilling feelings of betrayal and confusion. The creature must attempt a [[/save ability=wisdom dc=13]]; on a failed save, the target takes [[/damage 1d10 type=psychic average]] damage and must immediately use its Reaction (if it has one available) to make a melee attack against the nearest creature. On a successful save, the target takes half as much damage and can act normally.

If there are no creatures with the Frightened condition in area A7 when the haunt starts its turn, the spirits return to the rubble. A character can use an action to attempt a [[/check skill=intimidation dc=13]]. On a success, the character scares the spirits into dispersing temporarily. A character can also use their action to attempt a [[/check skill=religion dc=15]] to recall and recite a Draconic prayer for the dead that puts the kobolds to rest for good. Characters who speak Draconic or worship a god of the dead make this check with Advantage.

XP Award: Award the party [[/award 50xp]] the first time they put the spirits to rest temporarily and another [[/award 50xp]] (for a total of [[/award 100xp]]) if they permanently end the haunting.

Treasure

@UUID[Item.jic9sj1kUFIWR3UV]{Scattered Kobold Bones}

With a successful [[/check skill=perception dc=17]] check, the characters find many tiny bones scattered in the rubble. The party can take 30 minutes to clear away the rubble and expose the bodies of the six kobolds whose spirits haunt this room. Destroying the bones or removing them all from this room is another way to permanently put the spirits to rest. The bodies also carry [[/award 30gp 20sp]], two bags of @UUID[Compendium.dnd5e.equipment24.Item.phbagCaltrops000]{Caltrops}, and a vial of @UUID[Compendium.dnd5e.equipment24.Item.dmgSerpentVenom0]{Serpent Venom} with the word “YUM” written on it in clumsy handwriting.

Sinkhole.name: Sinkhole
Sinkhole.text:
Passive Perception

Before they open the door to this room, each character that passes a [[/check passive=true skill=prc dc=10]] check hears the sound of high-pitched squeals and shrieks from within. Any character who specifically listens before entering hears these sounds automatically.

Almost the entire ceiling of this room has collapsed, while below, the floor has crumbled into a ten-foot-deep sinkhole filled with rubble, mud, and glistening patches of fungus. Evidence of ancient damage—burn scars and acid scorch marks—decorate the walls and much of the rubble.

Encounter

@UUID[Actor.E0LCMHVp4sxAbQYa]{Mitflits (4)}

Four Mudlicker mitflits clamber and scurry around below amid the rubble in the sinkhole. They are supposed to be gathering mushrooms and grubs but are currently wrestling over who gets to snack on a particularly bright blue grub. The mitflits take a –2 penalty to their Passive Perception scores and to Initiative as a result of their distraction unless the characters take pains to announce themselves before attacking. The mitflits hurl darts at the characters from below, but a mitflit who runs out of darts or takes any damage focuses on climbing out of the pit and then running away to warn Boss Skrawng in the @UUID[.le4tidRkFqodABe4]{Mudlicker Throne Room}.

Exploration

The ancient battle between the Roseguard and Belcorra came to its destructive end in this room when Belcorra used a last-ditch explosion to try to defeat the adventurers. The resulting collapse swallowed up the group’s rogue, Otari Ilvashti, and trapped him in the dungeon below. Belcorra fled to the lighthouse (area @UUID[JournalEntry.kDJSn9wbVvjnqYEj.JournalEntryPage.JNlpc7pDiBmm5RGj]{A11}) after this failed gambit. As in area @UUID[JournalEntry.kDJSn9wbVvjnqYEj.JournalEntryPage.koVFvK0xxQMwKjaW]{A4}, a character investigating this room who succeeds on a [[/check skill=arcana dc=15]] confirms that a devastating magical battle occurred here long ago.

A character must succeed on a [[/check skill=athletics dc=11]] to climb the sinkhole’s steep slopes. A character who searches the rubble and succeeds on a [[/check skill=investigation dc=15]] spies a semicircular low area of rubble that indicates there is a buried spiral staircase leading downward.

World State

@Macro[GOmXbb8enFk5eicd]{A08 - Stairs}

Clearing the rubble away can take many days, but if the heroes persist, they open the way down to area @UUID[JournalEntry.uMZ0RiCcPSqsx1Nm.JournalEntryPage.CLm67CNpT0gNtor0]{B08} below.

You can use the above macro to toggle the visibility of the tile to reflect this change! Don't forget to hide the corresponding tile in area @UUID[JournalEntry.uMZ0RiCcPSqsx1Nm.JournalEntryPage.CLm67CNpT0gNtor0]{B08} as well.

Walkway.name: Walkway
Walkway.text:
A fifteen-foot stone walkway spans a narrow stretch of swamp water, connecting the ruined keep to a large stone outbuilding. Double doors block each end of the walkway. Standing before the southeast door is a seven-foot-tall skeleton dressed in armor made of gnarled roots, bones, and rusted metal. The skeleton clenches a morningstar in one weathered hand with the weapon’s heavy, spiked tip resting on the walkway at the skeleton’s feet.

Exploration

The skeletal “guard” is nothing more than a statue built by the Mudlickers. It looks frightening but poses no danger; anyone examining it who succeeds on a [[/check skill=investigation dc=12]] notices the wooden struts and crude lashings that keep it together. Any damage dealt to the skeleton causes it to clatter apart loudly, alerting the occupants of area @UUID[JournalEntry.kDJSn9wbVvjnqYEj.JournalEntryPage.le4tidRkFqodABe4]{A10}.

Treasure: The mitflits found the morningstar and were delighted with how well it keeps the skeleton propped up. They don’t know it’s a @UUID[Item.G4NLm4Yv0uCs1z0Z]{+1 Morningstar}.

Mudlicker Throne Room.name: Mudlicker Throne Room
Mudlicker Throne Room.text:
Splintered framing in the ceiling and floor hint that thin wooden walls once divided this stone building’s interior. With those walls demolished, only a single, large chamber remains. Rubble, swamp vegetation, and mud pile in heaps like foul nests, while a larger stack of rubble, sticks, and bones looks almost, but not quite, like a throne. A flattened mound of sand with a few dozen bits of wood and stone stuck into it covers the floor before the throne.

The mitflits chose these old barracks for their commander, Boss Skrawng, to use as a throne hall. Boss Skrawng's fragile throne requires constant upkeep, a task two mitflits perform when they aren’t sleeping in the filthy nests here.

Exploration

Any character looking at the sand before the throne can attempt a [[/check skill=history dc=10]] or [[/check int cartographer 10]]. On a success, the character realizes that the sand represents a crude map of Otari. If the check succeeds by 5 or more, the character also notes several arrows that indicate plans of attack from the direction of Fogfen.

Boss Skrawng is nearly always here, splitting his time between berating other Mudlickers within earshot, playing with his pet giant centipede Bite Bite, sleeping on his throne, or planning attacks on Otari in his sand pile. If Boss Skrawng knows about the heroes in the vicinity, he sits on his throne at attention with Bite Bite at his side, ready to address them. He’s accompanied at all times by two Mitflits, his personal guard

Boss Skrawng knew that it was just a matter of time before heroes from Otari challenged him in his domain, but he seems surprised that it happened before he actually did anything to the town. Unlike the other mitflits, Boss Skrawng speaks Common, and he imperiously demands to know why the characters have come to bother him before he attacked Otari. If he realizes the characters didn’t come to confront him, he pathetically backpedals, insisting that he has no plans to attack and that he’s harmless and friendly. He punctuates this reversal by using his trident to scatter the map of Otari at his feet. Canny characters who lie to Boss Skrawng about their reasons for being here can talk to him and perhaps find out some of what he knows about Gauntlight Keep (see “What Skrawng Knows” below), but it shouldn’t be long before Boss Skrawng’s negligible bravery and greater impatience prompt him to begin his assault on Otari by attacking the party.

Encounter

@UUID[Actor.xAfkUwJYq5JLmSrW]{Boss Skrawng} @UUID[Actor.C7LvY2Xxzm2xRL1M]{Bite Bite} @UUID[Actor.E0LCMHVp4sxAbQYa]{Mitflits (2)}

If combat breaks out, Boss Skrawng orders Bite Bite and the mitflits into melee, but he hangs back to use his blowgun from the Half Cover of his throne. At the end of each of Boss Skrawng’s turns, the throne shakes and shudders dangerously. It doesn’t collapse unless a character attacks it (the throne has AC 10, 5 Hit Points, Vulnerability to Fire, and Immunity to Psychic and Poison damage). If the throne collapses, Boss Skrawng becomes flustered. He immediately falls Prone, can’t take Reactions until the start of his next turn, and sputters and curses in Undercommon for the rest of the combat. Boss Skrawng gives up and begs for mercy if he’s reduced to 5 Hit Points or fewer, but the other creatures here fight to the death to demonstrate their devotion to their leader.

Giant Flies

If one or both giant flies from area @UUID[JournalEntry.kDJSn9wbVvjnqYEj.JournalEntryPage.yyUsiyd1QIMwin1X]{A6} fled, they’re here. Boss Skrawng orders his two mitflit attendants to mount up. They throw darts from the backs of the flies, and the flies provide them Half Cover against attacks made from directly below. If a giant fly’s rider perishes, that Buzzybuzz flees from the ruins altogether.

What Boss Skrawng Knows:

If the heroes can get Boss Skrawng to talk, he has useful information.

Dangers

He knows about all the dangers in areas @UUID[JournalEntry.kDJSn9wbVvjnqYEj.JournalEntryPage.tLAbtqjMjDw2qq1h]{A1} to @UUID[JournalEntry.kDJSn9wbVvjnqYEj.JournalEntryPage.le4tidRkFqodABe4]{A10}, and knows about the “swamp dragon” that lives under the boathouse (area @UUID[JournalEntry.kDJSn9wbVvjnqYEj.JournalEntryPage.D4ufIAvRT4oTGO07]{A16}, the dragon referring to Freznelkesh in area @UUID[JournalEntry.uMZ0RiCcPSqsx1Nm.JournalEntryPage.ZGby3FkCgaPte0O9]{B19}). He also knows about the “bogeys” in the keep, warning the characters about the haunt in area @UUID[JournalEntry.kDJSn9wbVvjnqYEj.JournalEntryPage.ER1vxyKvCoRrV2KZ]{A7} and the glowing “ghosts” in area @UUID[JournalEntry.kDJSn9wbVvjnqYEj.JournalEntryPage.yk1knQyHc25ZSAfE]{A15}.

Mysterious Strangers

He has never visited the outbuilding on the @UUID[JournalEntry.kDJSn9wbVvjnqYEj.JournalEntryPage.HyQFy5izFPrONmJu]{island} to the northwest, as he has seen some strange lights that way that scared him, but he mentions that a boat full of people came to visit it a week ago. They went into the swamp dragon’s cave while the dragon was out, but the dragon returned soon thereafter; Boss Skrawng assumes the dragon ate the people.

On Gauntlight

If asked about Gauntlight’s eerie glow, Boss Skrawng’s eyes get big and he shakes his head, warning the party that the light is the creepiest haunting of them all. He confirms that every night for the past several nights, the lighthouse glows, and he worries that there might be a big ghost up there.

The Lower Floors

Boss Skrawng also confirms that the Mudlickers used to live in a dungeon level beneath Gauntlight Keep, but that a bunch of “mushroom eyed people” (@UUID[JournalEntry.uMZ0RiCcPSqsx1Nm.JournalEntryPage.xScYAcbXPHk9jqau]{morlocks}, although the mitflits don’t know them by that name) chased them up here many nights ago.

Directions

Boss Skrawng can provide a crude map of the first level and a partial map of the second if a character succeeds on a [[/check skill=intimidation/persuasion dc=11]] and supplies him with the means to do so. Alternatively, a bribe of at least [[/award 10gp]] or five giant fly eggs (available in area @UUID[JournalEntry.kDJSn9wbVvjnqYEj.JournalEntryPage.9kxya2R9NYsSAA4G]{A5}) automatically gets Boss Skrawng feeling helpful enough to provide these maps. His map of the first level omits areas @UUID[JournalEntry.kDJSn9wbVvjnqYEj.JournalEntryPage.yGP5XjaIq9ix9ac7]{A12} to @UUID[JournalEntry.kDJSn9wbVvjnqYEj.JournalEntryPage.l1967pkknJ7ifjTc]{A13}, areas @UUID[JournalEntry.kDJSn9wbVvjnqYEj.JournalEntryPage.hX0cKXoIDJT0AIRB]{A19} to @UUID[JournalEntry.kDJSn9wbVvjnqYEj.JournalEntryPage.7svdEIhRQeWmtenl]{A23}, area @UUID[JournalEntry.kDJSn9wbVvjnqYEj.JournalEntryPage.6wFkYYY7f8SqcRy8]{A25}, and all of the secret doors. His map of the second level is much less complete and only shows the areas once dwelt in by the Mudlickers: areas @UUID[JournalEntry.uMZ0RiCcPSqsx1Nm.JournalEntryPage.CLm67CNpT0gNtor0]{B8} to @UUID[JournalEntry.uMZ0RiCcPSqsx1Nm.JournalEntryPage.xx0EOST0kN62qFg3]{B14} and areas @UUID[JournalEntry.uMZ0RiCcPSqsx1Nm.JournalEntryPage.eAD9hbPpzj5aLBZY]{B16} to @UUID[JournalEntry.uMZ0RiCcPSqsx1Nm.JournalEntryPage.ZGby3FkCgaPte0O9]{B19}. He warns the party that a swamp dragon lives in the cave at area B19.

Side Quest:

Boss Skrawng hates the “mushroom-eyed people” and promises the characters a big pile of shiny gems if they go downstairs, kill them all, and defeat their king; he describes the king as a “magic priest mushroom-eyed guy who can hurt your brain just by looking at you.” Boss Skrawng doesn’t actually have any shiny gems, and if the characters do his quest and return with proof, he realizes that the characters are tougher than the morlocks, and that he made a terrible mistake in promising them treasure he doesn’t have. He offers the handful of beads he has instead (see “Treasure” below), throws himself at the characters’ mercy, and agrees to abandon his plots against Otari forever. If any giant flies from area @UUID[JournalEntry.kDJSn9wbVvjnqYEj.JournalEntryPage.yyUsiyd1QIMwin1X]{A6} survive, Skrawng also offers to train one (or both, if he has become aware that there are actually two of them) to serve as mounts for the characters. His mitflits can also jury-rig exotic saddles that will allow non-mitflits to ride the giant flies. Such saddles can’t be used for other mounts and can’t be sold due to the obviously inferior materials used to craft them. Skrawng might prove of additional use as the GM sees fit as the campaign progresses—for example, the characters could treat the aboveground ruins as a headquarters where the mitflits’ eager assistance provides a modest lifestyle for the party at the usual cost.

XP Award: Award the characters [[/award 100xp]] if they bring Boss Skrawng proof of having slain Graulgust (from area @UUID[JournalEntry.uMZ0RiCcPSqsx1Nm.JournalEntryPage.38sQJNsnOb2GTdn5]{B12}).

Treasure

In addition to his @UUID[Compendium.dnd-abomination-vaults.av-items-5e.Item.3ULqrcWBtzUKxGk4]{Short Trident} and @UUID[Compendium.dnd5e.equipment24.Item.phbwepBlowgun000]{Blowgun}, Skrawng carries a dose of @UUID[Compendium.dnd5e.items.Item.eVbPkYjpl29RE2uW]{Basic Poison} and 5 @UUID[Item.6vEnTu29Qy0jJABa]{peridot beads} he snatched from other mitflits. Each bead is worth [[/award 2gp]].

Gauntlight Base.name: Gauntlight Base
Gauntlight Base.text:
The characters find the southern door stuck, but they can attempt a [[/check ability=strength dc=15]] to force it open. Once opened, it falls to sodden pieces. It can also be destroyed by attacks (AC 12, 5 Hit Points, Vulnerability to Fire damage, Immunity to Poison and Psychic damage) if the characters instead choose to force their way in. The western door has a 1-foot-square window set with iron bars, and it opens normally.

The smooth walls of this circular room are painted a light gray with no indication of seams between blocks of stone. A set of iron stairs winds upward along the curved walls before terminating at a trap door in the ceiling nearly a hundred feet above. A red bloodstain glistens on the floor in the room’s center, as though a human-sized creature bled to death on the floor very recently, despite there being no body in sight.

Nearly five centuries ago, the Roseguard finally defeated Belcorra in this room, but only after she’d trapped one of their own in the dungeons below. As she died, Belcorra’s spirit was drawn down into the depths of the Abomination Vaults, but the bloodstain she left on the floor remains, as fresh as the day she fell. The fragment of her spirit that still lives within the stain maintains its apparent freshness and activates as a haunt each night.

The iron stairs creak and sway alarmingly but are quite sound despite their unstable appearance. As part of Gauntlight’s structure, the stairs can’t take damage as long as Belcorra’s ghost remains active, so the characters can’t collapse the stairs even if they want to. The stairs wind up 90 feet to a locked bronze trap door leading to the cupola in area @UUID[JournalEntry.kDJSn9wbVvjnqYEj.JournalEntryPage.6wFkYYY7f8SqcRy8]{A25}. A character can open the door by succeeding on a [[/check thief 20]] to pick the lock, or by using the key hidden in area @UUID[.l1967pkknJ7ifjTc]{A13}.

Blood of Belcorra

Haunt

The haunt in this room can activate only at night. A character who has seen a depiction of Belcorra elsewhere in the Abomination Vaults recognizes the haunt’s appearance; otherwise, a character who succeeds on a [[/check skill=history dc=20]] can confirm the bloody spirit’s identity. The use of a @UUID[Compendium.dnd5e.spells24.Item.phbsplLegendLore]{Legend Lore} spell also reveals this information.

When a creature ends its turn in the room at night, a bloody image of Belcorra arises that emits a soul-draining light and then inhales blood from living creatures in the room.

During daylight hours, the blood isn’t only fresh, but still warm. A character looking over the bloodstain who succeeds on a [[/check skill=perception dc=10]] notices periodic ripples. With a successful [[/check skill=insight/religion dc=10]], a character can sense otherworldly malice emanating from the stain and recognize it as the focus of a haunting. With a successful [[/check skill=investigation/religion dc=14]] check, a character can deduce that the bloodstain’s ripples are consistent, and that the slick red surface appears to be the top of a deep pool from which something deeper is attempting to emerge, despite that the surface below is obviously solid and shallow. A spell or other effect that can sense the presence of magic, such as @UUID[Compendium.dnd5e.spells24.Item.phbsplDetectMagi]{Detect Magic}, reveals an aura of necromancy around the stain.

When a creature ends its turn in area A11 at night, a ghastly image of Belcorra, seemingly composed of fresh blood, rises from the bloodstain on the floor and rotates in place like a lighthouse beacon. Beams of cold, blue light shine from the bloody Belcorra’s eyes and open mouth, causing blisters and decay to spread across any flesh they fall upon. Each creature that isn’t a Construct or Undead in a 30-foot Emanation originating from the center of area A11 makes a [[/save ability=constitution dc=14]]. On a failed save, the target takes [[/damage 2d4 type=necrotic average]] damage and has the @UUID[Compendium.dnd5e.content24.JournalEntry.phbAppendixCRule.JournalEntryPage.uDogReMO6QtH6NDw]{Blinded} condition until the end of its next turn. On a success, the creature takes half damage only.

Once the image emerges, roll Initiative. The image rolls Initiative with a +6 modifier. On its turn, the bloody image opens its mouth and appears to inhale, drawing blood from the body of one creature within 90 feet. The creature makes a [[/save ability=constitution dc=10]]. On a failed save, the target loses [[/damage 1d4 average]] Hit Points due to blood loss, and its Hit Point maximum is reduced by an amount equal to the damage taken. This reduction lasts until the target finishes a Short or Long Rest. The target dies if this effect reduces its Hit Point maximum to 0. On a successful save, the target takes half as much damage, and its Hit Point maximum isn’t reduced.

Once the characters know there’s a haunting, they also realize that the magical blood is its focus and can be wiped away with effort. The bloodstain can be attacked (AC 15, 30 Hit Points, Immunity to Poison damage, Resistance to Bludgeoning and Piercing damage, Vulnerability to 34 Radiant damage), or a character can scrape it away with a successful [[/check thief 18]] (or other appropriate tools). A character can use an action to recall and recite a prayer against evil ghosts by making a successful [[/check skill=religion dc=15]]. Characters who worship a god of the dead make the check with Advantage. On a success, the character temporarily disables the haunt.

If the haunt is disabled or the stain is wiped away, the bloody phantom of Belcorra sprays upward in a spiral, splattering the trap door to area @UUID[JournalEntry.kDJSn9wbVvjnqYEj.JournalEntryPage.6wFkYYY7f8SqcRy8]{A25}, above, before draining upward through its keyhole. This reduces the DC of the Dexterity check to pick the lock to [[/check thief 18]]. At the next sunrise, the blood drains back down to this room and the haunt becomes active again, though it’s still unable to trigger until nightfall. The haunt is destroyed permanently once Lasda Venkervale is rescued from area @UUID[JournalEntry.Os5bHdzCDiXgJBQ6.JournalEntryPage.RmFsEEQSD9Ulugwm]{D9}.

XP Award: Award the party [[/award 200xp]] the first time they temporarily disable the hazard.

Belcorra’s Office.name: Belcorra’s Office
Belcorra’s Office.text:
The ceiling has collapsed in the southwest corner of this room. The walls bear several shelves, but the books and papers once kept here have rotted to ruin long ago due to exposure to the elements, as have the wooden desk and chair in an alcove to the northeast.

Exploration

A character searching this room who succeeds on a [[/check skill=investigation dc=15]] locates the secret door in the east wall, where a shelf rotates to become the door’s handle. Beyond, a flight of stairs leads down to area @UUID[JournalEntry.uMZ0RiCcPSqsx1Nm.JournalEntryPage.MY61uS4Lk2va9xoZ]{B06}.

Treasure

A character searching the desk finds a hidden drawer that has fallen partially open, revealing a pair of still-potent potions Belcorra stashed here: a @UUID[Compendium.dnd5e.equipment24.Item.dmgPotionOfClimb]{Potion of Climbing} and a @UUID[Compendium.dnd5e.items.Item.L887NdWEP5NqHCrQ]{Potion of Greater Healing}.

Belcorra’s Sanctum.name: Belcorra’s Sanctum
Belcorra’s Sanctum.text:
This triangular room might have once seemed comfortable, but after years of rain and exposure to the elements through the two arrow slits in the northwestern wall, the room’s divan, armoire, and tapestries have fallen to decay.

Exploration

Belcorra maintained this private room to relax and constructed a secret entrance to the shrine to easily access it.

A @Item[jDszN0s4ucrnNhc9]{Rusted Ring of Keys} sits under the divan, and any hero Searching this room finds it. Rust has ruined six of its iron keys, but two bronze keys remain usable: the one decorated with a lighthouse unlocks the trap door to Gauntlight's cupola (area @UUID[.6wFkYYY7f8SqcRy8]{A25}), while one decorated with a book unlocks the door to Belcorra's private reading room (area @UUID[JournalEntry.KeWKr2yd8dbppeS5.JournalEntryPage.OJNJc6Fo510Heygw]{C27}).

A tapestry formerly concealed a secret door, but it rotted and fell long ago, making the door slightly easier to find. A character searching this room who succeeds on a [[/check skill=perception/investigation dc=15]] locates it, leading into a small area that connects to the shrine. Characters can easily spot the second secret door within this space, as described in area @UUID[.yk1knQyHc25ZSAfE]{A15}.

Centipede Kennel.name: Centipede Kennel
Centipede Kennel.text:
The ceiling of this room has fallen in two places. A smaller collapse destroyed a flight of stairs that once led up to the now-ruined upper floor. A larger collapse has mostly buried the southern double door, leaving a hole in the roof that’s partially blocked with several crossed timbers. A second double door to the north has a stone face carved with skulls caked with tangles of moss.

This room once served as a kennel for the Mudlickers’ first significant acquisition—a giant centipede Boss Skrawng calls Bite Bite. The mitflits pen it in here only when Boss Skrawng isn’t around (or if he has been defeated), so it’s normally encountered in area @UUID[JournalEntry.kDJSn9wbVvjnqYEj.JournalEntryPage.le4tidRkFqodABe4]{A10} with him. A Small or smaller creature can clamber through this tangle unimpeded. It’s Difficult Terrain for a Medium creature. A Large creature must succeed on a [[/check skill=acrobatics dc=15]] to squeeze past the fallen timbers or use an action to make a [[/check ability=strength dc=15]] to clear a path through them.

Investigation

Although the tangles of moss growing on the skull carvings seem like part of the overgrowth prevalent throughout the ruin, they actually belong to the original design. The mossy skull is the religious symbol of @UUID[JournalEntry.67686KaEPc6XAlKJ.JournalEntryPage.ohFJrgStEzdvGEEU]{Nhimbaloth}, the Outer God of ghosts, despair, swamps, and will-o’-wisps, whom Belcorra reveres as her patron. Nhimbaloth’s lore is rare and hidden, however, so a character must make a successful [[/check skill=religion dc=20]] to identify the mossy skull as Nhimbaloth’s symbol. Although fledgling heroes might not recognize evidence of Nhimbaloth, Wrin Sivinxi in town knows of the sinister Outer God and can enlighten the characters if they report their findings to her.

Nhimbaloth's Shrine.name: Nhimbaloth's Shrine
Nhimbaloth's Shrine.text:
The air in this large chapel feels colder and damper than elsewhere in the ruins. Condensation beads on the walls and runs in rivulets across the countless skulls carved into the stone. A moldering human corpse lies slumped against a wall, his hands wedged into a crack as if he died trying to pry a brick loose. Three short flights of steps lead upward to a wider chamber to the north, where a semicircular dais supports an altar of white stone. Beyond the altar loom four stained-glass windows, each twenty feet tall and depicting four haunting scenes of ghosts rising from overgrown graveyards toward a four-pointed orange star in the sky above.

Belcorra made no secret of her faith in @UUID[JournalEntry.67686KaEPc6XAlKJ.JournalEntryPage.ohFJrgStEzdvGEEU]{Nhimbaloth}, and she maintained this sizable shrine to the sinister entity both as a place to worship and as an intimidating place to meet visitors. The shrine has an ominous atmosphere, as if something large and distant were watching through the stained glass windows. A character can identify this room as a shrine to the malevolent deity Nhimbaloth with a successful [[/check skill=religion dc=20]] check.

The corpse to the south lies slumped next to the secret door leading to area @UUID[.l1967pkknJ7ifjTc]{A13}. Once a human man, this thief snuck into the temple through the secret door months ago in search of treasure, only to find himself outclassed by the two corpselights lurking in this room. He perished just before he could reopen the secret door to escape. The thief left the door slightly ajar with the rotating skull that opens it still slightly turned, so the characters can easily spot this secret door and how to open it

Encounter

@UUID[Actor.HBRz8BVLVN9u9Odp]{Corpselights (2)}

Two long-dead acolytes of Nhimbaloth have decomposed into little more than mossy skeletons sprawled along the eastern edge of the large chamber to the north, initially out of sight of anyone entering from the south. They’re far from harmless, however, as they harbor eerie creatures called corpselights. The corpselights rise when the characters approach the northern chamber. They fight until destroyed but don’t pursue characters who flee the shrine. The first corpselight to fall and take on its wisp form animates the corpse of the dead thief at the secret door if it’s still available—or in an even darker turn, animates a dead character!

Treasure

@UUID[Item.eEom6pE3xHINFjIl]{Thief's Remains}, @UUID[Item.kEoqNeq7U4cJhKf8]{Acolytes' Remains}, @UUID[Item.ydQRUYKEG9NRQZgb]{Shrine Compartment}

The thief’s corpse bears several items of value, including a Rapier, four Daggers, and a silver ring worth [[/award 5gp]].

The acolyte skeletons have little remaining that hasn’t rotted or rusted away to uselessness over time, with two exceptions—one has a gold tooth worth [[/award 5gp]], while the other still wears a Holy Symbol amulet around its bony neck.

A character searching the altar who succeeds on a [[/check skill=investigation/perception dc=15]] finds a secret panel on its northern side, which conceals a shallow nook containing two Spell Scrolls of @UUID[Compendium.dnd5e.spells24.Item.phbsplCureWounds]{Cure Wounds} and a Spell Scroll of @UUID[Compendium.dnd5e.spells24.Item.phbsplLesserRest]{Lesser Restoration}.

Ruined Boathouse.name: Ruined Boathouse
Ruined Boathouse.text:
A character who takes a close look at the doors to this boathouse notices that one of them has been forced open and then carefully closed again within the past couple of weeks.

The southern portion of this stone-walled building has collapsed into rubble, exposing what remains of a boathouse to the elements. Tools, stores of lumber, and a partially built rowboat within have fallen to disrepair. The remains of a relatively fresh campfire smolder faintly.

The campfire was left here by a group of thieves from Otari—a band from @UUID[JournalEntry.67686KaEPc6XAlKJ.JournalEntryPage.sdNti6BHkPTeO5fC]{Crook’s Nook} who came here a few weeks ago after hearing rumors of treasure stashed in a cavern under the island. They entered area @UUID[JournalEntry.uMZ0RiCcPSqsx1Nm.JournalEntryPage.ZGby3FkCgaPte0O9]{B19} below only to get in over their heads when the morlocks imprisoned them.

Ruined Pier.name: Ruined Pier
Ruined Pier.text:
Much of this wooden pier has collapsed into the swamp, leaving about ten feet of moldy, soggy boards slumped against ancient wood pilings. A rowboat tied to a piling looks much more recently built.

The rowboat, left here by the Crook’s Nook thieves, is in good condition. The heroes can use it to navigate the waters around the ruins.

Exploration

The rowboat, left here by the Crook’s Nook thieves, is in good condition. The party can use it to navigate the waters around the ruins. Characters searching the rowboat find two things. The first is a stash of pastries—smoked salmon in a fish-shaped doughy exterior; a character who succeeds on a [[/check ability=intelligence dc=10]] recognizes the “fishcakes” as those sold at the Crook’s Nook in Otari. The second is a carving of a flying bird decorating the inside near the bow. A character who succeeds on a [[/skill history dc=12]] or who knows Thieves’ Cant recognizes the carving as the mark of the Osprey Club, Otari’s thieves’ guild, which can be contacted at Crook’s Nook.

If the party comes here after dark, the flickerwisp near the @UUID[.qECJHfd2gZwY8I8Y]{Old Pier} across the water flickers in an attempt to lure them closer, as described in that area.

An opening under the pier leads to area @UUID[JournalEntry.uMZ0RiCcPSqsx1Nm.JournalEntryPage.ZGby3FkCgaPte0O9]{B19}. At the GM’s discretion, the wyrmling dragon Freznelkesh might venture out and spot the heroes while they’re nearby.

World State

@UUID[Macro.jfwi0h09EQF9b5f9]{A17 - Opening Beneath the Pier}

If your players discover the passage to area @UUID[JournalEntry.uMZ0RiCcPSqsx1Nm.JournalEntryPage.ZGby3FkCgaPte0O9]{B19}, use this macro to enable a scene region that will allow them to transition to that scene by moving their tokens to the base of the pier!

Side Quest

Should the heroes visit Crook’s Nook and ask about the boat, Yinyasmera admits that four of her “employees” went missing several days ago. She promises a [[/award 15gp]] reward per employee if the characters can find out what happened to them and bring them back.

One is already dead (area @UUID[JournalEntry.uMZ0RiCcPSqsx1Nm.JournalEntryPage.xx0EOST0kN62qFg3]{B14}), while the other three are prisoners of the morlocks (area @UUID[JournalEntry.uMZ0RiCcPSqsx1Nm.JournalEntryPage.NyCn35Bdz6gaubNu]{B24}).

XP Award: Award the party [[/award 25xp]] for each Osprey Club member they find and return to Crook’s Nook.

Apprentice Island.name: Apprentice Island
Apprentice Island.text:
A low wooden bridge spans a watery gap between the larger island and a smaller one. A single-story stone building sits amid the thick reeds and rushes growing on the smaller island.

The building on this islet was originally the home of Belcorra’s apprentice, a drow named Volluk Azrinae. Volluk no longer lives here, but he still serves Belcorra in the chambers deep below, having transcended from the limitations of his humanoid form to become a monstrous creature known as a worm that walks—he now resides in area @UUID[JournalEntry.Os5bHdzCDiXgJBQ6.JournalEntryPage.NHY0hh539X658iSG]{D08}.

Spookywisp.name: Spookywisp
Spookywisp.text:
The exterior door to this room is stuck, requiring a character to succeed on a [[/check skill=athletics dc=13]] to force it open.

This study features several bookshelves, a desk, and two chairs. The books and objects here lie in disarray, with torn pages strewn haphazardly across the room as though ripped out and tossed aside in handfuls.

Volluk once pursued his studies and met with Belcorra for lessons in this room.

Creature

@UUID[Actor.SFpMOxBwiS529dJk]{Tangletop}

Today, a mischievous Sprite named Tangletop—a puckish waif whose eponymous blonde hair is in a constant state of frizzy disarray upon his head— occupies this chamber. Despite his comical appearance, Tangletop fancies himself a spooky sort of fey. He has only tiny little wings on his back and can’t fly, but he has the following additional action:

Spellcasting. Tangletop casts one of the following spells, requiring no Material components and using Intelligence as the spellcasting ability spell save DC 12):

  • At Will: @UUID[Compendium.dnd5e.spells24.Item.phbsplDancingLig]{Dancing Lights}, @UUID[Compendium.dnd5e.spells24.Item.phbsplMending000]{Mending}, @UUID[Compendium.dnd5e.spells24.Item.phbsplMinorIllus]{Minor Illusion}, @UUID[Compendium.dnd5e.spells24.Item.phbsplPrestidigi]{Prestidigitation}

  • 1/Day: @UUID[Compendium.dnd5e.spells24.Item.phbsplHoldPerson]{Hold Person}

As soon as Tangletop notices the party approaching, such as if they try to force open the door, he quickly slips into hiding under the desk before calling out in a deep voice. He claims to be a dangerous “wispy-ghost” named “Spookywisp.” He then casts @UUID[Compendium.dnd5e.spells24.Item.phbsplDancingLig]{Dancing Lights} to create what he hopes the party will mistake for a will-o’-wisp, floating the light up in the air and casting @UUID[Compendium.dnd5e.spells24.Item.phbsplMinorIllus]{Minor Illusion} to project his voice from the light.

Tangletop arrived here only a few days ago, but he made short work ripping through the room’s contents, finding nothing of interest. He moved on toward area @UUID[JournalEntry.kDJSn9wbVvjnqYEj.JournalEntryPage.7svdEIhRQeWmtenl]{A23}; there, the shiny spyglass entranced him before the soulbound doll that guards it chased him off. Faced with an actually scary creature, Tangletop retreated to this room to plot methods of securing the “shiny” for himself. The characters give him that method—see “Side Quest” below.

If the party attacks or confronts him with violence, Tangletop shrieks in fear and flees toward the @UUID[.7svdEIhRQeWmtenl]{Lens Workshop}, hoping to lure the characters into that room so that they inadvertently end up destroying the soulbound doll. If they do, he tries to steal the “shiny” therein before fleeing the ruins forever.

Side Quest:

If the characters speak to Tangletop, either in person or via his persona as Spookywisp, the sprite explains to them that he wants the “shiny” in the room to the southwest. He warns the characters that a mean blank-faced doll with bird wings will try to stop them from getting the “shiny” but promises to tell them three secrets he learned about the area if they bring him the “shiny.” Asked to describe the “shiny,” Tangletop frustratingly says, “It’s shiny, I said! You’ll know it when you see it!” Pressed further, he rolls his eyes and describes it as a “sparkling glowing tube that I want, want, want!”

The “shiny” refers to the unfinished bejeweled spyglass kept on display in area @UUID[JournalEntry.kDJSn9wbVvjnqYEj.JournalEntryPage.7svdEIhRQeWmtenl]{A23}. If the characters retrieve and hand it over, the sprite reveals what he recently learned from the books here. First, this building used to belong to someone named Volluk Azrinae. Second, Volluk was an apprentice to someone else named Belcorra, and even though this Volluk seemed mean and dangerous, Belcorra seemed much worse! Finally, the spooky magic lighthouse can do more than just shine an eerie light; it can also shoot a beam full of ghosts! (This last description is Tangletop’s interpretation of the second painting in area @UUID[JournalEntry.kDJSn9wbVvjnqYEj.JournalEntryPage.OYCvTEvFFpv8zEql]{A22}, but it isn’t far from the truth).

XP Award: Award the characters [[/award 50xp]] for turning the shiny over to Tangletop and learning what he knows.

Repair Storage.name: Repair Storage
Repair Storage.text:
Shelves laden with tools, lumber, and planks line the walls of this ten-foot-square storage room.

These supplies were used for upkeep throughout the upper works of Gauntlight Keep. Volluk formerly functioned as a groundskeeper and managed repairs, and he often called upon Belcorra’s other servants as needed for these jobs.

Exploration

@Item[zlanzgKmTDu2xKvL]{Large Silver Key}

Characters searching this room discover a large silver key worth [[/award 10gp]]. This key unlocks the door to @UUID[JournalEntry.uMZ0RiCcPSqsx1Nm.JournalEntryPage.hOMUDNapQMRjV1kQ]{Volluk’s Workshop} on the floor below.

Stairwell.name: Stairwell
Stairwell.text: Moss and fungus coats these stairs, which lead down to area @UUID[JournalEntry.uMZ0RiCcPSqsx1Nm.JournalEntryPage.OmLsmbwPtNMw7csF]{B01}. From the state of the growth, clearly no one has gone this way for a long time.

Hall of Portraits.name: Hall of Portraits
Hall of Portraits.text:
A series of four paintings hang on the northwestern wall of this hallway, although layers of mold and decay have severely damaged them.

The 5-foot-tall paintings along the wall have sustained irrevocable damage over time and due to moisture dripping down from leaks in the roof above. They all share the same style, as Volluk painted them all long ago.

The first painting is enormous, nearly 7 feet tall and almost as wide. It’s a landscape that depicts the city of Absalom in flames with ghosts rising from the city streets between the burning buildings. It bears a bronze plaque that reads, “So Shall the Fools Suffer.”

The second is nearly as large as the Absalom painting. It depicts Gauntlight Keep as it appeared before its upper floors collapsed. The lighthouse rises above the stately keep into the night sky, with its beacon emitting a pale blue light in which ghostly faces sneer and grimace. Its bronze plaque reads, “Let the Light Shine Forever.”

The third picture is a portrait that once depicted Volluk in the workshop but is now completely shredded behind the mold. Volluk destroyed it after becoming a worm that walks. Its plaque reads, “The Artist at Work.”

The fourth and final portrait is smaller and circular, and set into a large wooden frame painted a dull gold color that has faded away over time. This portrait depicts a smirking woman dressed in a red gown with a high collar—an image of Belcorra herself. Its plaque reads, “The Lady of the Light.” Long ago, Volluk scratched the following sentences, written in Aklo (a language spoken by evil fey and otherworldly monsters, of which Deep Speech is a dialect), into the stained stone next to this last painting: “I serve you still! You shall be avenged!”

Lens Workshop.name: Lens Workshop
Lens Workshop.text:
This once-elegant workshop has fallen into shambles. Soggy strings of dripping moss hang through cracks in the wooden domed roof above. Below it, a literal carpet of broken glass glitters dangerously. Workbenches and shelves, armatures and displays—all formerly used in crafting or repairing immense lenses for a lighthouse—lie in ruins. Only a bejeweled spyglass sitting on a display rack on the southern wall has survived the devastation.

Volluk caused most of this destruction. After Belcorra’s death, he hid in the swamp while he waited for the Roseguard to leave. When he returned, he was filled with such guilt over his cowardice that he destroyed this workshop in a fit of fury.

Encounter

@UUID[Actor.kzX588Hjb3w4QPOj]{Mister Beak}, @UUID[Actor.mmAnimatedFlying]{Flying Sword}

Volluk created several constructs to aid him and his mistress in their day-to-day jobs, but the raven-headed, raven-winged Soulbound Doll he called Mister Beak was one of his favorites. Neither the most powerful nor the most helpful, Mister Beak held the soul of his devoted servant, a goblin named Borbo, a fact that once ensured the tiny construct’s place at Volluk’s side. Mister Beak has since repaired the other construct Volluk left here: a Flying Sword.

Today, Mister Beak remains abandoned here, waiting forever for a creator who has moved on to other tasks and an entirely new body. Mister Beak hasn’t lost hope, and when the characters enter the room, he stands up from the slumped mound in the room’s center and asks in a warbly voice, “Is Master Azrinae coming back?” Regardless of the characters’ answer, Mister Beak realizes none of them are or know its creator; he leaps into the air on flapping wings to attack in a frustrated fury. He also orders the flying sword to join in the attack. The flying sword obeys Mister Beak’s orders and has no will of its own. Both fight until destroyed.

Treasure

@Item[81IBK1HJESDCKkiG]{Bejeweled Spyglass}

The bejeweled spyglass tube, although unfinished and missing its lenses, would’ve been among Volluk’s finest creations. Even in his rage, he couldn’t bring himself to smash this work of art. The spyglass tube is the “shiny” that Tangletop seeks. If the characters keep it instead, they can sell it for [[/award 250gp]].

Soul Focus

Mister Beak's soul focus gem is located on his back, nestled between his wings. The gem is worth [[/award 5gp]] but might prove more valuable as a potential source of information if the heroes place it in the partially completed soulbound doll in @UUID[JournalEntry.uMZ0RiCcPSqsx1Nm.JournalEntryPage.hOMUDNapQMRjV1kQ]{Volluk’s Workshop} on the floor below. Mister Beak’s soul focus gem retains the doll’s memories even after its destruction.

Old Pier.name: Old Pier
Old Pier.text:
This old wooden pier has partially collapsed into the swamp, and the portion that remains above water looks ready to follow the rest at the slightest touch.

The pier is as dangerous as it looks; anyone stepping onto it causes the entire pier to give way and fall into the 3 feet of water beneath it. The sucking mud beneath the water’s surface makes the area Difficult Terrain. A creature that leaves a 5-foot space of mud must make a successful [[/check skill=athletics dc=10]] or its movement ends immediately after leaving that space as it wastes time pulling free of the mud.

Macros

@Macro[lTRp4OBk4ueE63AE]{A24 - Pier Collapse}, @Macro[Rjype0R8A2jawF7b]{A24 - Flickerwisp Reveal}

Pier: If the heroes collapse the pier, click on the Pier Collapse macro above to toggle the state of the tile- and play a sound effect as it splinters beneath them!

Glow: The Flickerwisp's Glow ability means that, although invisible, it generates bright light. There is a light placed at the end of the pier which you can use to lure the heroes onto the weakened section without revealing the creature's token- at least until it's ready to strike!

Once the Flickerwisp is revealed to be a creature, simply run this macro to make its token visible, while hiding the placed light.

Encounter

@UUID[Actor.x3eOZvKUginj5Blh]{Flickerwisp}

While will-o’-wisps are among the swamp’s most notorious and feared predators, they aren’t the only fear-feeding creatures of their kind. Other wisps can be found in areas where Nhimbaloth’s influence is strong, the least of these being the flickerwisp. A single Flickerwisp dwells amid the rotting ruins of this old pier.

When the flickerwisp notices the party nearby, it begins to glow and writhe, appearing alternately as a string of flickering fireflies or a rippling ribbon of light just above the gaping hole in the pier. Anyone who steps onto this section runs the risk of falling through, and the flickerwisp quickly attacks anyone who gets stuck. It fights to the death. Even if the characters don’t encounter the flickerwisp here, they might have to contend with it if their intrusion into Gauntlight’s @UUID[JournalEntry.kDJSn9wbVvjnqYEj.JournalEntryPage.6wFkYYY7f8SqcRy8]{cupola} pulls the creature into a fight with them.

Gauntlight Cupola.name: Gauntlight Cupola
Gauntlight Cupola.text:
The locked trap door in the floor of this room leads down to the @UUID[.JNlpc7pDiBmm5RGj]{Gauntlight Base}.

Rows of black metal bars encase this circular chamber like a cage. Shimmering waves of force flicker between the bars, giving the illusion that softly glowing glass encases this entire area. The floor to the north has an iron trap door; otherwise, this room appears empty save for a human-sized encasement of glass and iron that flickers and glows with an unsettling, almost nauseating pale blue shimmer—Gauntlight’s lantern!

Encounter

@UUID[Actor.x3eOZvKUginj5Blh]{Flickerwisp}

Hazard: If the party enters this area after defeating the Blood of Belcorra haunt in area @UUID[.JNlpc7pDiBmm5RGj]{A11} below, that below, that blood has slithered and flowed over Gauntlight’s lantern. As the characters enters the chamber, it erupts into an image of Belcorra just like that magic trap did, but it also summons forth a minor wisp (as below) to feed on the interlopers. This encounter can repeat as often as the party continues to trigger and defeat the haunt in area A11 below, but not more than once per night. If no flickerwisps remain in the ruins, none respond to the summons

Creature: If it hasn’t been destroyed, the flickerwisp in area @UUID[JournalEntry.kDJSn9wbVvjnqYEj.JournalEntryPage.qECJHfd2gZwY8I8Y]{A24} rolls Initiative when the haunt triggers and is teleported into the nearest open space in the cupola at the start of its turn. If the flickerwisp has been slain, instead a corpselight is drawn from elsewhere (such as area @UUID[JournalEntry.kDJSn9wbVvjnqYEj.JournalEntryPage.yk1knQyHc25ZSAfE]{A15} or area @UUID[JournalEntry.Os5bHdzCDiXgJBQ6.JournalEntryPage.owO8Ie1yNfI2amxK]{D1}) along with the skeletal corpse it inhabits. If the party returns here later, when they’re higher level, the GM might decide that the haunt pulls in even more powerful monsters, such as will-o’-wisps or even dread wisps. The party should certainly never find Gauntlight’s cupola to be a safe place!

Introduction.name: Introduction
Introduction.text:
Chapter Synopsis

The upper level of the Abomination Vaults—and the only level aboveground—is the ruin of a large structure called Gauntlight Keep. Although the upper levels of the keep have collapsed into the lower level (filling many of the remaining rooms with rubble), one prominent structure remains: @UUID[JournalEntry.67686KaEPc6XAlKJ.JournalEntryPage.efRUYLBH9Kf3CLkX]{Gauntlight}, a massive lighthouse placed incongruously in the middle of a large swamp called the @UUID[JournalEntry.67686KaEPc6XAlKJ.JournalEntryPage.dMyS4bNbb1diRzow]{Fogfen}. Here, the heroes can encounter hapless but vicious gremlins, dangers left from Belcorra’s day, and evidence that Gauntlight draws upon power from somewhere deep below.

Ruins of Gauntlight

As the heroes approach the ruins of @Scene[3Nat4ImT49niZUdr]{Gauntlight Keep} for the first time, read or paraphrase the following.

The sound of frogs and mosquitoes mixes with water sloshing against muddy shores, all muffled by the ever-present mists that linger in the aptly named Fogfen. As the mists clear, a shadow looms from the cloying swamp vapors- a sprawling ruin of stone and wood squats atop an island in the soggy marsh. The upper floors have largely collapsed, leaving only the stone walls of the ground floor intact. Above these ruins towers an out-of-place monument—a colossal lighthouse whose painted walls and iron-cased crown have resisted the corrosive effects of the surrounding swamp.

While the overgrown trail leads right to area @UUID[JournalEntry.kDJSn9wbVvjnqYEj.JournalEntryPage.tLAbtqjMjDw2qq1h]{A01}, the heroes can access the ruins through other entrances. Along the southern side, waters surrounding the ruins are relatively shallow, but on other sides, the depth ranges from 10 to 15 feet, requiring a boat or swimming to navigate.

Features

Environmental Cues:

Crude graffiti, evidence of prior squatters, mounds of rubble, overgrowth of mold and creeping plants, puddles of standing water, scuttling vermin, splashing water, swampy odors.

With the exception of Gauntlight's cupola, @UUID[JournalEntry.kDJSn9wbVvjnqYEj.JournalEntryPage.6wFkYYY7f8SqcRy8]{A25}, the upper levels of Gauntlight Keep collapsed long ago, even falling to the ground floor in places. Areas denoted as rubble on the map of Gauntlight Keep are open to the sky above and considered difficult terrain. Where the roof hasn't caved in, ceilings are 10 feet high unless otherwise noted. The only illumination comes from whatever sunlight filters in through the constant fog. The doors on this level are all cracked and rotten except where indicated; handling them with any amount of force causes them to split or simply fall off their hinges with a wet splintering sound.

Gauntlight is magically protected from damage, as described @UUID[JournalEntry.67686KaEPc6XAlKJ.JournalEntryPage.efRUYLBH9Kf3CLkX]{here}. This protection has bled into the surrounding ruins somewhat, slowing the usual rate of decay over the past 500 years. Nevertheless, time is inexorable, and the rest of the ruins have suffered in the passage of centuries.

Exploration

As a reminder, the GM should take note of what the players have their characters do as they explore. The GM can ask them to choose from a list of common checks and activities, or ask each player to describe what their character does and decide if their description should allow them to notice things in the areas they pass through. Certain effects are listed in the rooms based on where a character focuses their attention. This might mean investigating for clues that reveal information (typically using the Investigation skill or an Intelligence check), checking the walls for unusual details via Wisdom (Perception) checks, or more specialized tasks like maintaining Concentration on a spell. A single character should generally only be doing one of these things at a time.

The Mudlicker Gremlins.name: The Mudlicker Gremlins
The Mudlicker Gremlins.text:
The main faction active in the ruins is what’s left of a small gang of mitflit gremlins who call themselves the Mudlickers. Led by a large, bearded gremlin named @UUID[Actor.xAfkUwJYq5JLmSrW]{Boss Skrawng}, the Mudlickers believe they once dwelt in “glory” underground. However, the arrival of the much larger and meaner Ghost Queen morlocks forced them out of their homes, and they’ve struggled to regain their footing ever since. Boss Skrawng has thus far formed the inkling of a plan to raise an army of giant insects to take over Otari. He has already exuberantly guaranteed the restoration of Mudlicker glory through this scheme, so the gang loyally follows Boss Skrawng, working hard to keep intruders—like the heroes—out of “their” ruins.

Boss Skrawng's Plan

The Mudlicker leader, Boss Skrawng, has an audacious plan. After discovering the giant maggots in area @UUID[JournalEntry.kDJSn9wbVvjnqYEj.JournalEntryPage.9kxya2R9NYsSAA4G]{A05} and the giant fly in the area @UUID[JournalEntry.kDJSn9wbVvjnqYEj.JournalEntryPage.yyUsiyd1QIMwin1X]{A06}, he ordered his mitflits to start training and breeding more maggots. Once the insects have fully grown, he intends on leading his entire group, mounted on trained giant fly war steeds, down to Otari to raid and rule.

Stairs Up.name: Stairs Up
Stairs Up.text: These tightly spiraling stairs lead up to area @UUID[JournalEntry.kDJSn9wbVvjnqYEj.JournalEntryPage.edLZ3shIoFN8nuur]{A21}.

Volluk’s Workshop.name: Volluk’s Workshop
Volluk’s Workshop.text:
The door to this room is locked. A character without the key from area @UUID[JournalEntry.kDJSn9wbVvjnqYEj.JournalEntryPage.OWxvfpXI9DIvPEM2]{A20} can force open the door with a successful [[/check ability=strength dc=18]] check or pick the lock with a successful [[/check ability=dexterity dc=20]] check using Thieves’ Tools.

Seven square alcoves, each containing strange magical apparatuses or alchemical tools, ring this damp stone chamber. The alcove to the north contains a large glass tank filled with liquid. A goblin’s corpse, clad in outdated servant’s clothing, floats within it. A semicircular worktable covered with tools, moldy papers, and a large open book stands in front of the tank.

Volluk Azrinae once used this chamber as his personal workshop. The worktable in front of the tank holds the bulk of Volluk’s notes. A character investigating these notes who succeeds on a [[/skill arcana 12]] check learns that the workshop was devoted to both construct construction and necromancy. If the check succeeds by 5 or more, the character also deduces the workshop’s emphasis on transferring mortal souls, including into a construct or swarm of vermin.

The goblin in the tank is the preserved corpse of Borbo, once Volluk’s devoted servant. Borbo volunteered his body and soul for a technique that Volluk promised would grant immortality, though being turned into the soulbound doll named @UUID[Actor.kzX588Hjb3w4QPOj]{Mister Beak} wasn’t exactly the immortality that Borbo had in mind. Still, Borbo, as Mister Beak, has thus far remained loyal to Volluk. The corpse is well-preserved in the tank; even if removed, it takes months to decay.

Exploration

A search of the other alcoves reveals little of interest, with two exceptions: a secret door in the southwestern alcove and an incomplete soulbound doll in the northwestern alcove.

Secret Door: The southwestern alcove contains a secret door leading down to @UUID[JournalEntry.KeWKr2yd8dbppeS5.JournalEntryPage.YhRSOC6JXrOhl9wU]{area C10} and from there back up to @UUID[JournalEntry.uMZ0RiCcPSqsx1Nm.JournalEntryPage.8qZk6POeK6TgPon4]{area B32}. A character who succeeds on a [[/skill 14 inv]] check while searching this alcove identifies a toolbox bolted to the wall as attached to some kind of hidden mechanism. When the toolbox is opened and tools within it pulled, the attached secret door opens.

Incomplete Doll: The northwest alcove contains a soulbound doll resembling an armless, legless goblin. It has an indentation in its back the same size as Mister Beak’s soul focus gem (area @UUID[JournalEntry.kDJSn9wbVvjnqYEj.JournalEntryPage.7svdEIhRQeWmtenl]{A23}). Inserting this gem activates the soulbound doll, allowing it to speak but not act or move until its construction is completed. A character might be able to complete the doll with enough work and expense, but Borbo remains an erratic and violent assistant at best.

Speaking to Borbo

If Borbo is “returned” to this body, he wakes quickly and begins to sob, lamenting in Goblin that his master betrayed him. He remains inconsolable until a character can either calm him with a successful [[/check 11 skill=itm/per]] check or until someone places him in a position where he can see his former body in the north alcove. In any of these cases, Borbo finally goes silent and the characters can speak to him in Common, Elvish, or Goblin. Borbo has little useful to say and is prone to fits of self-pity and vitriol toward Volluk, but if the PCs ask the right questions, they can get four key pieces of information from him.

  1. The location of the secret door in this room.
  2. The existence of a secret stash of treasure he hid behind a loose brick in the wall in his old room (area @UUID[JournalEntry.uMZ0RiCcPSqsx1Nm.JournalEntryPage.KSCa8Wx2rSKuzHC1]{B4}).
  3. Master Volluk was a “powerful mastermind drow occultist artist craftsman” who had a relationship with a “book lady down below” and who worked for “Mistress Belcorra, who is very frightening and absolutely none of my business.”
  4. That Master Volluk is vain as well as cruel. If the characters present a nice image of Volluk, such as a painting or illustration, to him and then threaten to destroy it, Volluk loses his composure and makes a tactical error the characters can capitalize upon. Unfortunately, the only painting of Volluk that Borbo knows about is the one in area @UUID[JournalEntry.kDJSn9wbVvjnqYEj.JournalEntryPage.OYCvTEvFFpv8zEql]{A22}, and it’s destroyed. In fact, only one image of Volluk remains in the Abomination Vaults today, and it can be found in area @UUID[JournalEntry.KeWKr2yd8dbppeS5.JournalEntryPage.KDcIKiVRxWGTfQhK]{C36}.

Once the characters have learned all his information, Borbo pitifully asks to be released. If the characters smash the soul focus gem, Borbo’s soul is released to enter the Boneyard. For this act of compassion, Pharasma, goddess of the dead and Lady of Graves, grants the character who destroyed the gem a favor in the form of a momentary, prophetic glimpse of their fate. Although it means nothing now, the next time that character would fail a saving throw by 2 or less, they recall this glimpse and succeed instead.

Volluk’s Chambers.name: Volluk’s Chambers
Volluk’s Chambers.text:
