This room shares features of a bedroom and a study, although the decor is devoid of any touches of personality, as if anything of sentimental value had been removed.

Volluk once dwelt here but has relocated downstairs to area @UUID[JournalEntry.Os5bHdzCDiXgJBQ6.JournalEntryPage.NHY0hh539X658iSG]{D8} after his transformation into a worm that walks. A search of the room turns up a scrap of paper listing the book titles What the Worm Knows, Grave Feasts, and Secrets of the Skull, along with a note at the bottom which reads, “Transcription will take months, but I’ll have these books back to you as soon as possible, my love!”

Borbo’s Room.name: Borbo’s Room
Borbo’s Room.text:
This small room has a long-abandoned straw bed, a dresser with open drawers revealing a jumble of out-of-date servant’s clothing, and a large barrel with a ladle atop it.

This room once belonged to Volluk’s goblin servant Borbo, but it has been abandoned since the goblin gave up his life to become Mister Beak. The clothing matches that worn by Borbo’s corpse in area @UUID[.hOMUDNapQMRjV1kQ]{B2}. The barrel once contained dozens of pickles, but the brine inside evaporated long ago, and the pickles have rotted away.

Exploration

@UUID[Item.tuAs3A2LsmLydtC4]{Borbo's Stash}

A character who searches the room and succeeds on a [[/check skill=perception dc=13]] check finds a loose brick concealing a small stash of treasures Borbo collected: a shard of jade worth [[/award 15gp]], a silver statuette of two succubi worth [[/award 35gp]], and a Potion of Healing. The characters might have learned about this stash from Borbo in area @UUID[.hOMUDNapQMRjV1kQ]{B2}, in which case no check is required to find it.

Volluk’s Machine.name: Volluk’s Machine
Volluk’s Machine.text:
A large metal table fitted with leather straps and iron bands stands in the center of this room. A strange contraption that seems part spyglass and part mechanical drill sits near the head of the table. A sparkling black gemstone glitters in a metal framework built into this machine’s side.

Encounter

@UUID[Actor.k4fVLtVrgIEg9xij]{Bloodsiphon}

One of Volluk’s last creations remains here, a horrific undead guardian created from a giant leech. Volluk called this creature the Bloodsiphon and was amused at how it shriveled up yet remained mobile and violent if denied the blood it craved but no longer required to sustain its life. The bloodsiphon appears to be a giant log of desiccated flesh until anyone disturbs it or approaches within 10 feet, at which point it lurches forth and attacks. It pursues foes throughout areas @UUID[JournalEntry.uMZ0RiCcPSqsx1Nm.JournalEntryPage.OmLsmbwPtNMw7csF]{B1} to @UUID[JournalEntry.uMZ0RiCcPSqsx1Nm.JournalEntryPage.CIFKILBbuCSCgdt8]{B5} but not beyond, otherwise fighting until destroyed.

Exploration

The machine in this room is a sadistic device Volluk crafted ages ago. A character who succeeds on a [[/check skill=arcana/religion) dc=16]] check determines that the device aids in the casting of the @UUID[Compendium.dnd5e.spells24.Item.phbsplCreateUnde]{Create Undead} spell, although it doesn’t provide knowledge of that spell. The drilling device penetrates the skull of a restrained victim while the scope focuses the ritual’s necromantic energies. Using this machine when casting Create Undead allows the caster to imprint a command on the undead that it continues to follow indefinitely, although the creator can’t issue new orders after the control granted by the spell lapses.

Treasure: The @UUID[Item.xzW2AQzClc61ew9C]{black onyx gemstone} in the machine can be pried out easily enough. Doing so renders the device useless, but the gem is worth [[/award 150gp]].

The stairs to the south lead down to area @UUID[JournalEntry.KeWKr2yd8dbppeS5.JournalEntryPage.s64QwcHKFCGC7AR4]{C7}.

Abandoned Guard Post.name: Abandoned Guard Post
Abandoned Guard Post.text:
Three plain wooden chairs sit along the east wall of this otherwise empty room.

Exploration

Belcorra’s lackeys once waited here to perform any tasks she might need. The secret door to the east that leads to area @UUID[.jLBqZVP4Avhb2FXG]{B21} is relatively easy to discover from this side of the room, as the middle chair leans against a section of the wall that pivots slightly outward. The characters can discover this secret door with a successful [[/skill prc 9]] check, although they notice it automatically if they move the middle chair.

A flight of stairs beyond the door to the north leads up to area @UUID[JournalEntry.kDJSn9wbVvjnqYEj.JournalEntryPage.yGP5XjaIq9ix9ac7]{A12}.

Meeting Room.name: Meeting Room
Meeting Room.text:
A long wooden table sits in the center of this room, surrounded by several wooden chairs. Only the chair to the north seems particularly comfortable, although its cracked leather padding is mostly decayed.

Belcorra addressed her serving staff here. No one has been in this room in decades, though; neither the mitflits nor the morlocks know about it. This room (and area @UUID[.MY61uS4Lk2va9xoZ]{B6}) thus serves as a safe place to hide or rest.

The secret door leading to area @UUID[.CLm67CNpT0gNtor0]{B8} is obvious from the north side; anyone approaching this secret door from the north automatically spots it.

Servants’ Rooms.name: Servants’ Rooms
Servants’ Rooms.text:
This large open area is a filthy mess, even beyond the collapse to the south that clogs part of the room with rubble. Half-eaten fish, cat-sized beetles, and bits of waterfowl lie strewn about in a tangle amid gnawed bones of larger creatures.

This large room once served as a common area for servants to relax and take their meals. The southern half of the room (along with the servants’ toilets and bathing facilities) were buried under rubble long ago. The collapsed stairwell to the south once provided access to area @UUID[JournalEntry.kDJSn9wbVvjnqYEj.JournalEntryPage.g363pURldvDgwmoc]{A8} above. The eight unmarked rooms connecting to this area are ruined bedrooms containing nothing of interest.

Exploration

A character searching this area can discover the secret door leading north with a successful [[/check skill=perception dc=21]] check. Pulling an old wall sconce opens the door, which a character can deduce with a successful [[/skill inv 14]] check. None of the morlocks have yet noticed it.

Encounter

@UUID[Actor.KSFGGxU3qxYJzWpe]{Morlock Scavengers (3)}, @UUID[Actor.V73Oqm1EL1KOoXOl]{Morlock Engineer}

The Ghost Queen morlocks lair here. The first time the characters enter this area, three Morlock Scavengers and a Morlock Engineer are present, fiddling with a partially ruined ballista that they dragged, in pieces, from area @UUID[JournalEntry.uMZ0RiCcPSqsx1Nm.JournalEntryPage.jLBqZVP4Avhb2FXG]{B21} (where it once served as a trap). They’re still fascinated by the ballista and take a –2 penalty to Initiative as a result. The morlocks snarl and hiss if they’re interrupted and fight the characters until only two of them remain standing. The surviving morlocks then try to flee to area @UUID[JournalEntry.uMZ0RiCcPSqsx1Nm.JournalEntryPage.38sQJNsnOb2GTdn5]{B12} to warn their king, Graulgust. Unless the characters are hot on the morlocks’ heels, the king sends two Morlock Scavengers to defend area @UUID[JournalEntry.uMZ0RiCcPSqsx1Nm.JournalEntryPage.MT1JRD5WLtzSsUIv]{B10} upon being warned.

Old Office.name: Old Office
Old Office.text:
A desk with a chair sits in the middle of this room, while three empty picture frames hang on the walls.

Belcorra’s majordomo once worked here. The frames used to hold detailed maps of the upper dungeon levels. Volluk took them long ago.

Treasure

@Item[3vlzBbKDkwV5Jpiu]{Intricate Gear}

The curious morlocks scattered the rusted ruins of a clockwork assistant across the floor, which include an intricate gear worth [[/award 30gp]]. A character can remove the gear while preserving its value with a successful [[/tool ability=dexterity tool=tinker 12]] check. On a failure, the gear breaks apart and is ruined.

Trapped Hall.name: Trapped Hall
Trapped Hall.text:
The north and south walls of this hall have been decorated with a bewildering array of timbers, metal parts, gears, bits of broken weapons, and trash.

Belcorra’s majordomo used this room for planning and meetings, but the morlocks have dismantled the furniture here, along with several other scavenged items and devices, to build a gauntlet of traps to defend the approach to their king’s throne room.

Hazards

Four spike launcher traps have been hidden in the walls of this room. Any morlocks encountered in this room can move through it without triggering the spike launchers, as they’re very familiar with the trip lines’ locations, but other creatures must notice each line first before they can avoid it.

XP Award: Award the party [[/award 25xp]] for each of the four spike launchers they disable (up to [[/award 100xp]] total).

Washroom.name: Washroom
Washroom.text:
One wall of this bathroom appears to have been recently gouged out by sharp claws, revealing a rough-hewn tunnel leading west.

This chamber once served as the majordomo’s washroom. The tunnel to area @UUID[.VssoL9XVUnDo49OF]{B13} is the result of erosion over time, widened by the morlocks’ digging.

Graulgust’s Throne Room.name: Graulgust’s Throne Room
Graulgust’s Throne Room.text:
A sofa-like throne made of an old bed mattress, several pieces of reconstructed furniture, and dozens of bones sprawls along the northern side of this room. A narrow rivulet of muddy water trickles from a narrow tunnel to the south and forms a puddle in the room’s center.

Graulgust, a Morlock Cultist and the self-styled king of the Ghost Queen morlocks, has chosen the majordomo’s old bedroom as his throne chamber. He has rebuilt the older furniture in this room into an immense throne of sorts and is attended at all times by a Morlock Scavenger tasked with sharpening Graulgust’s finger and toenails, rubbing his feet, feeding him worms, or whatever else Graulgust demands. Now and then, Graulgust leaves his throne room to patrol the Ghost Queen’s domain and to check up on the Ghost Queen’s shrine (area @UUID[JournalEntry.uMZ0RiCcPSqsx1Nm.JournalEntryPage.xx0EOST0kN62qFg3]{B14}), but the first time the characters visit the dungeon, they encounter him here.

Encounter

@UUID[Actor.KSFGGxU3qxYJzWpe]{Morlock Scavenger} @UUID[Actor.lH2rdwiyOPStkQvZ]{Graulgust}

Graulgust fancies himself something of a worldly diplomat, but since he only speaks Aklo and Undercommon, communication with the characters might be difficult. If he can’t establish communication, Graulgust grows annoyed and sends his morlock servant to fight the characters. Graulgust only steps into the fight once the servant is slain or if he’s attacked directly. If Graulgust is reduced to 15 Hit Points, he howls for his pet Grothlut in area @UUID[JournalEntry.uMZ0RiCcPSqsx1Nm.JournalEntryPage.VssoL9XVUnDo49OF]{B13}. If the slithering monster still lives, it comes to its master’s aid as soon as it can through the tunnel to the southwest.

Any morlock present when Graulgust is slain has the @UUID[Compendium.dnd5e.content24.JournalEntry.phbAppendixCRule.JournalEntryPage.93uaingTESo8N1qL]{Frightened} condition for 1 minute. At the end of each of its turns, a Frightened morlock makes a [[/save 13 wis]] saving throw, ending the condition on itself on a success.

Side Quest

If he can communicate with the characters, Graulgust congratulates them for their bravery in seeking him out and gives them a choice— they can become sacrifices for the Ghost Queen (in which case he directs his morlock servant to kill them), or they can prove their worth to the Ghost Queen by slaying the “water monster” that dwells nearby in area @UUID[JournalEntry.uMZ0RiCcPSqsx1Nm.JournalEntryPage.ZGby3FkCgaPte0O9]{B19} and bringing back its head. If the characters agree, Graulgust allows them to leave the room only via the tunnel to area @UUID[JournalEntry.uMZ0RiCcPSqsx1Nm.JournalEntryPage.gKSMPRQZHVWaoL4d]{B18}, and if they don’t have the wyrmling’s head with them as proof of their deed the next time they meet, Graulgust attacks the characters at once for their failure.

If the heroes return with the wyrmling’s head, Graulgust is delighted that the morlocks now have an easy way out of the dungeon to go foraging. He rewards the characters by giving them the title of “lackeys of the Ghost Queen” and leads them on a stroll through Ghost Queen territory (areas @UUID[JournalEntry.uMZ0RiCcPSqsx1Nm.JournalEntryPage.MT1JRD5WLtzSsUIv]{B10}, @UUID[JournalEntry.uMZ0RiCcPSqsx1Nm.JournalEntryPage.surluLUD8HprMYIw]{B9}, @UUID[JournalEntry.uMZ0RiCcPSqsx1Nm.JournalEntryPage.CLm67CNpT0gNtor0]{B8}, @UUID[JournalEntry.uMZ0RiCcPSqsx1Nm.JournalEntryPage.xx0EOST0kN62qFg3]{B14}, @UUID[JournalEntry.uMZ0RiCcPSqsx1Nm.JournalEntryPage.jLBqZVP4Avhb2FXG]{B21}, and @UUID[JournalEntry.uMZ0RiCcPSqsx1Nm.JournalEntryPage.3prWqGPJfXW7MXX2]{B22}). Once he and the characters reach B22, he offers them a new choice: surrender their gear and become slaves of the Ghost Queen (and be imprisoned in area @UUID[JournalEntry.uMZ0RiCcPSqsx1Nm.JournalEntryPage.NyCn35Bdz6gaubNu]{B24}), or begin a crusade for him against the Cult of the Canker—a group of “heretic ghouls” who must be slaughtered for the glory of the Ghost Queen. If the characters agree to the latter choice, Graulgust sends them downstairs through area @UUID[JournalEntry.uMZ0RiCcPSqsx1Nm.JournalEntryPage.eAD9hbPpzj5aLBZY]{B16} with a command to not return until all of the ghouls lairing down there are slain. If they do so, Graulgust realizes they’re too powerful to simply dispose of; he names them “missionaries of the Ghost Queen” and commands them to leave the morlock areas and never return.

XP Award: If the characters didn’t defeat Graulgust in combat, award them [[/award 100xp]] for bringing him the dragon’s head and another [[/award 100xp]] for returning after clearing out the Cult of the Canker.

What Graulgust Knows

During this time, the characters can speak to Graulgust and learn a bit more about the Abomination Vaults. The morlocks haven’t explored the northern part of this level, but he can inform the characters of the secret door to area @UUID[JournalEntry.uMZ0RiCcPSqsx1Nm.JournalEntryPage.kdk3tW3OgViz0cw5]{B15} and provide a scribbled map of level three (including areas @UUID[JournalEntry.KeWKr2yd8dbppeS5.JournalEntryPage.F229BVFENz1ZjmG1]{C1}, @UUID[JournalEntry.KeWKr2yd8dbppeS5.JournalEntryPage.AU1IGoQPqItk9Dms]{C6}, @UUID[JournalEntry.KeWKr2yd8dbppeS5.JournalEntryPage.YhRSOC6JXrOhl9wU]{C10}, @UUID[JournalEntry.KeWKr2yd8dbppeS5.JournalEntryPage.l9NjtV6c0sjeD50H]{C11}, @UUID[JournalEntry.KeWKr2yd8dbppeS5.JournalEntryPage.eOv6LI3wvIuKyyNJ]{C15}, and @UUID[JournalEntry.KeWKr2yd8dbppeS5.JournalEntryPage.tTVIrzNZtjKG1XVb]{C33}). If asked about deeper levels, Graulgust grows silent, then says, “You are of the surface and do not deserve to know of our homeland.” At the GM’s discretion, if the characters use @UUID[Compendium.dnd5e.spells24.Item.phbsplDetectThou]{Detect Thoughts} or other coercive methods, they might force Graulgust to divulge more information about deeper levels of the Abomination Vaults, but note that the morlocks left these levels a while ago and that much has changed since Belcorra’s return.

Graulgust never speaks the Ghost Queen’s name aloud, and if the characters speak the name “Belcorra” in his presence, he shrieks in religious anger and warns the them never to say her name again. If they do so, he attacks.

Once the characters have secured Graulgust’s trust, the morlock occultist is shocked if they suddenly turn against him. If the characters attack Graulgust at any point after he believes they’re working for him, he’s automatically surprised as he grapples with the fact that he no longer commands obedience.

Grothlut Den.name: Grothlut Den
Grothlut Den.text:
Water drips down the walls of this cavern, particularly along a jumble of dangling pallid roots to the south. Beneath them lies a large, soggy nest of mud and bones.

Encounter

@UUID[Actor.K9Hw43co8fhwmKkM]{Grothlut}

This cavern is the result of years of erosion, and its damp, earthy environs make for a perfect home for the morlocks’ recently acquired pet, a Grothlut fleshwarp. Graulgust rescued the grothlut from a cage deeper in the Abomination Vaults, and today, the aberration dotes on the morlock in the way a loyal dog adores its master. It attacks anyone who enters this cave other than Graulgust, fighting to the death.

Shrine of the Ghost Queen.name: Shrine of the Ghost Queen
Shrine of the Ghost Queen.text:
While this large room was originally a kitchen, the furnishings have been rebuilt and repositioned to create an improvised shrine. The western end of the hall, where a large fireplace for cooking food once stood, now serves as an altar of sorts. A towering statue made of bones, its feminine shape covered in sheets of moldering cloth and hanging moss, looms above a human corpse. A bare spot on the room’s north wall is decorated with mud and blood to depict the same feminine form as the statue.

Exploration

The Shrine

The Ghost Queen morlocks erected this shrine to honor Belcorra, but as the morlocks fear the ghost as much as they revere her, they rarely spend time in this room. They enter only to provide periodic sacrifices—the latest of which was one of the thieves from Crook’s Nook. The body is that of a human man with a bird tattoo on his right shoulder that marks him as a member of the Osprey Club. Anyone who knows Thieves’ Cant recognizes it automatically as signifying membership in the thieves’ guild, as does anyone who makes a successful [[/check skill=intelligence (history) dc=12]] check.

A character who investigates the shrine and makes a successful [[/check skill=religion dc=10]] check surmises that the “divinity” worshipped here isn’t well-known, but that the bloody message on the wall over the secret door is likely meant to illustrate someone of importance to the cult. If the heroes have seen an image of Belcorra, such as the painting in area @UUID[JournalEntry.kDJSn9wbVvjnqYEj.JournalEntryPage.OYCvTEvFFpv8zEql]{A22} or the bloody image from the trap in areas @UUID[JournalEntry.kDJSn9wbVvjnqYEj.JournalEntryPage.JNlpc7pDiBmm5RGj]{A11} and @UUID[JournalEntry.kDJSn9wbVvjnqYEj.JournalEntryPage.6wFkYYY7f8SqcRy8]{A25}, they automatically recognize the statue as a depiction of the same woman.

Secret Door

The secret door in the northern wall is easier to find than most of those in the area, and a character who succeeds on a [[/check skill=investigation dc=13]] check while examining the “painted” decoration notices it. The morlocks discovered this door shortly after they arrived, but the one time they opened it to look inside, they were scared off by the shadow within. They believe this secret door leads to a place sacred to the Ghost Queen. They decorated the wall where the secret door is located to placate their patron and haven’t opened it since.

Treasure

@UUID[Item.mzAVPDyK5om3sZzN]{Shrine Offerings}

While the dead thief has no treasure on him, the morlocks left a pair of valuable offerings strewn around the statue’s base: a bloodstone worth [[/award 10gp]] and a Spell Scroll of Magic Weapon.

Servant's Crypt.name: Servant's Crypt
Servant's Crypt.text:
This five-foot-wide hallway features three square alcoves along each side. Stone sarcophagi stand upright within each. A door leads out to the north.

Belcorra planned to inter her favorite followers in this small crypt. However, due to her high standards and hard-to-please nature, only one servant ever gained the honor of being buried here—her first majordomo.

Encounter

@UUID[Actor.XrmHgbKgcHDi4OnK]{Majordomo}

Today, the majordomo exists as a Shadow, bound to the site in undeath through the combination of her loyalty to Belcorra and Gauntlight’s necromantic energies. She emerges from the central sarcophagus on the west wall to attack anyone or anything that enters this crypt. It doesn’t pursue foes beyond area @UUID[JournalEntry.uMZ0RiCcPSqsx1Nm.JournalEntryPage.kdk3tW3OgViz0cw5]{B15}.

Pantry.name: Pantry
Pantry.text:
Only a few fragments of the shelving that once lined the walls of this pantry remain today.

The morlocks first entered the dungeon’s second level through this room. Most of the gear and shelving once stored here have been scavenged for other projects (most notably Graulgust’s throne). The stairs beyond the northeastern door lead down to area @UUID[JournalEntry.KeWKr2yd8dbppeS5.JournalEntryPage.F229BVFENz1ZjmG1]{C1}.

Level 2 Portal Chamber.name: Level 2 Portal Chamber
Level 2 Portal Chamber.text:
Teleportation Network

Some of the @UUID[Compendium.dnd5e.spells24.Item.phbsplTeleportat]{Teleportation Circles} within the Abomination Vaults form a part of a larger network. By tracing specific patterns on the wall runes, someone could transport everyone in any one of these chambers to one of nine other portal chambers in the Abomination Vaults- so long as the teleportation circles in both the departure chamber and destination have been awakened by the @UUID[Compendium.dnd-abomination-vaults.av-items-5e.Item.H0KYIrtDeeV2pSyC]{Awaken Portal} ritual (area @UUID[JournalEntry.KeWKr2yd8dbppeS5.JournalEntryPage.8X4xF40k06MW0X7q]{C35}).

The nine chambers are areas @UUID[.537bzfVUpq6XbR9a]{B17}, @UUID[JournalEntry.KeWKr2yd8dbppeS5.JournalEntryPage.vEiow4kU961XNOJp]{C16}, @UUID[JournalEntry.Os5bHdzCDiXgJBQ6.JournalEntryPage.RJf3BCpcVW6d68s7]{D05}, @UUID[JournalEntry.JT0zCcIwsSpKnbB5.JournalEntryPage.LJhOoRqYjj38YWl8]{E18}, @UUID[JournalEntry.KI33EAGPVHP4zyFZ.JournalEntryPage.mDFVGUXY6YDuQWF3]{F13}, @UUID[JournalEntry.OyNcqrpRClyhr8BJ.JournalEntryPage.zTpatmyyb4JvgNCo]{G02}, @UUID[JournalEntry.FwWmtOBFHhvM2gtf.JournalEntryPage.Nak2hUmVOHXBkcR5]{H33}, @UUID[JournalEntry.1vlzl3NJsftNB9Dc.JournalEntryPage.DJKWR2KLTPUi3w6T]{I59}, and @UUID[JournalEntry.yn21bNM6kpV4xRol.JournalEntryPage.JinYTJeYVFBE1uky]{J05}

The door to this room is locked, and its key is long lost. A character can force it open with a successful [[/check ability=strength dc=18]] check or pick the lock with a successful [[/check ability=dexterity dc=20]] check using Thieves’ Tools.

The walls of this octagonal chamber are adorned with swirling runes carved into the stone and then filled with dull, silvery metal. The floor is polished smooth, as is the ceiling ten feet above.

Belcorra installed several Teleportation Circles in the Abomination Vaults for swift movement between levels, but over time, their magic has faded. Smaller Teleportation Circles, like those at areas @UUID[JournalEntry.kDJSn9wbVvjnqYEj.JournalEntryPage.koVFvK0xxQMwKjaW]{A4} and @UUID[JournalEntry.KeWKr2yd8dbppeS5.JournalEntryPage.VZPc5GsIN5eRKSVE]{C5}, link to only one area each, but this transit chamber was linked to several others; by tracing specific patterns on the wall runes, someone could transport themselves and everyone in this room to one of several other portal chambers in the Abomination Vaults.

The @UUID[Compendium.dnd-abomination-vaults.av-items-5e.Item.H0KYIrtDeeV2pSyC]{Awaken Portal} spell required to reactivate this @UUID[Compendium.dnd5e.spells24.Item.phbsplTeleportat]{Teleportation Circle}, along with how to use it, is recorded in a folio in area @UUID[JournalEntry.KeWKr2yd8dbppeS5.JournalEntryPage.8X4xF40k06MW0X7q]{C35}. Each linked Teleportation Circle must be individually reactivated with this spell before they can be used—the characters must physically travel to each portal chamber they want to reconnect to the network.

XP Award Award the characters [[/award 500xp]] for activating this portal. The portal chambers allow the characters to move swiftly and easily around the Abomination Vaults as they discover more of them.

Ruined Boat Launch.name: Ruined Boat Launch
Ruined Boat Launch.text:
At the north end of this small cave, the mouth of a swampy, flooded cavern yawns. A few ruined rowboats lie in heaps on this cavern’s floor, strewn next to tangled coils of rope. Remnants of a pulley system hang from the ceiling.

Belcorra’s servants used this area to move supplies from the boathouse (area @UUID[JournalEntry.kDJSn9wbVvjnqYEj.JournalEntryPage.D4ufIAvRT4oTGO07]{A16}) using a pulley system to ferry a floating platform between here and the pier, but that setup fell into disrepair long ago.

Exploration

Several swaths of disturbed earth litter the muddy floor between this cavern and the flooded cavern to the north, as though left by the movement of a large, serpentine creature. A character who investigates the tracks and makes a successful [[/check skill=arcana dc=12]] check realizes they were left by a Medium dragon. If the check succeeds by 5 or more, the character realizes it was a green dragon wyrmling.

Flooded Cavern.name: Flooded Cavern
Flooded Cavern.text:
Tangles of roots hang from the low ceiling of this flooded cavern, the roof of which is a mere three feet above the murky water.

During the day, muted sunlight filters into this cavern from an exit to the northwest, but even on rare sunny days, the overhanging pier at area @UUID[JournalEntry.kDJSn9wbVvjnqYEj.JournalEntryPage.zPMrDHV75TJzsGba]{A17} and tangles of dangling roots keep this room dim. The water in the cavern is, on average, 10 feet deep.

Encounter

@UUID[Actor.DX1xNtucLTenn3P3]{Freznelkesh}

A Green Dragon Wyrmling named Freznelkesh has dwelt in this cavern for nearly two years. She’s careful to limit her hunting to Fogfen, so no one in Otari knows she exists. She was out hunting when the @UUID[JournalEntry.67686KaEPc6XAlKJ.JournalEntryPage.sdNti6BHkPTeO5fC]{Crook’s Nook} thieves came through, but she returned soon after and cut off their escape route (leading to their eventual capture by the morlocks).

Freznelkesh is likely to be sleeping in the water in the middle of the cavern, and she swiftly wakes up if she hears the splashing of potential food swimming above. She is aggressive but not suicidal; if reduced to fewer than 10 Hit Points, she flees and doesn’t return for a few days. She pursues foes that flee up into area @UUID[JournalEntry.uMZ0RiCcPSqsx1Nm.JournalEntryPage.gKSMPRQZHVWaoL4d]{B18} or out into the swamp, but she learned the hard way about the dangerous mold in area @UUID[JournalEntry.uMZ0RiCcPSqsx1Nm.JournalEntryPage.FS4EnskC5S91c9RU]{B20} and won’t pursue potential prey there.

Exploration

@UUID[Item.NkH8NrsdNK47wWYm]{Drake's Sea Chest}

The wyrmling stashes what treasure she has gathered from her prey in a sea chest amid a tangle of roots in the southwestern cul-de-sac. A character who succeeds on a [[/check skill=perception dc=12]] check while searching finds the chest among the roots. The dragon’s treasure consists of [[/award 36gp 140sp 430cp]], and a Wand of Magic Missiles.

Moldy Beach.name: Moldy Beach
Moldy Beach.text:
A thick knot of roots hangs from the cavern roof here over a muddy beach. Stone stairs leads up from the beach to the north.

Bog Brown Mold

Hazard

The square just south of the bottom of the stairs, marked with a red box on the map, might appear to contain only some moldy roots but is in fact a patch of bog brown mold.

The mold leeches heat out of the air. A character who makes a successful [[/check skill=perception dc=13]] check notices the mold. With a successful [[/check skill=investigation or wisdom (survival) dc=15]] check, a character notices the faint wisps of cold air emanating from it. A creature that ends its turn within 5 feet of the mold takes [[/damage 1d8 average cold]] damage. If fire is brought within the area, the mold spreads to every adjacent 5-foot square. As it grows, it pulls more heat from its surroundings. Any creature within 10 feet of any part of the patch after it expands makes a [[/check ability=constitution dc=13]], taking [[/damage 2d8 cold average]] damage on a failed save or half as much damage on a successful one.

The mold can’t rapidly expand again for 24 hours. A character can safely remove the mold before it expands by making a successful [[/check skill=survival dc=15]] check.

XP Award: Award the party [[/award 100xp]] for spotting and either bypassing or safely removing the mold.

Workshop.name: Workshop
Workshop.text:
Exploration

Each character with a [[/check passive=true skill=prc dc=11]] score or higher hears metal clanging and wood splintering from within this room before they enter. A character who specifically listens before entering automatically hears these sounds.

This long room smells of rust and grime. Stacks of splintered furniture, pieces of weapons and armor, frayed coils of rope, jagged shards of metal, and other bits of trash lie in heaps along the walls of the room. A cold, unlit forge sits in an alcove to the west. To the north, several heavy timbers are wedged up against a door to keep it shut.

Encounter

@UUID[Actor.V73Oqm1EL1KOoXOl]{Morlock Engineers (2)}

Two Ghost Queen Morlock Engineers toil at assembling a pair of broken ballistae. While the morlocks have the skill to rebuild the devices, they keep incorporating dubious improvements that require restarting their repairs. The engineers quickly realize they can present intruders to mollify Graulgust’s frustration at their slow pace. They prefer to use their projectile launchers from a distance and fight to the death.

The morlocks do their best to capture the characters alive; if they do, they confiscate the characters’ gear and throw the captives in with the thieves in area @UUID[JournalEntry.uMZ0RiCcPSqsx1Nm.JournalEntryPage.NyCn35Bdz6gaubNu]{B24} until Graulgust tells the morlocks what to do with them. Graulgust’s offer to the party is described in area @UUID[JournalEntry.uMZ0RiCcPSqsx1Nm.JournalEntryPage.38sQJNsnOb2GTdn5]{B12}.

World State

@Macro[aWZ3MUXFfN10sQVd]{B22 - Barricade}

Removing the timbers that block the door to area @UUID[JournalEntry.uMZ0RiCcPSqsx1Nm.JournalEntryPage.NyCn35Bdz6gaubNu]{B24} requires an action. Use the above macro when your players dismantle the obstacle!

Well.name: Well
Well.text:
The air in this room is cool and moist. A low stone well sits to the east. Armor, weapons, and tools lie in heaps in the north.

Exploration

This well drops 40 feet down to a large pool of water in a natural reservoir in area @UUID[JournalEntry.KeWKr2yd8dbppeS5.JournalEntryPage.2YRUhNAQ8UYfyHAU]{C40} below. Anyone who leans over the well can attempt a [[/check skill=perception dc=10]] check to hear a strange sound drifting up from below—splashing combined with what sounds like a small crowd. These noises come from the gibbering mouthers that live below, but they remain out of sight of anyone peering down the well. The rope and bucket once used to draw water up from below is long gone, but the metal bracket in the ceiling is strong enough to anchor a rope to support the characters.

Treasure

@UUID[Item.bAToN0Ib1C5G7Rbk]{Osprey Thieves' Gear}

The heap of gear to the north belongs to the prisoners in area @UUID[JournalEntry.uMZ0RiCcPSqsx1Nm.JournalEntryPage.NyCn35Bdz6gaubNu]{B24}. It consists of two sets of Leather Armor, one set of Studded Leather Armor, two Rapiers, one broken Rapier, three sets of Thieves’ Tools, a Potion of Healing, and [[/award 13gp]].

Prison.name: Prison
Prison.text:
Alcoves along the walls of this room might have once served as storerooms, but today, the stone shelves are all empty. The room smells foul.

The foul odor is due to the room’s current use as a prison. Of the four thieves who stole into the dungeon from Crook’s Nook, only three survive— @UUID[Actor.X5VrdEHl829hvoXU]{Gorul Vetters}, @UUID[Actor.p94aKz7KsiAQJscm]{Shad Nunder}, and @UUID[Actor.9rDG1Sxs7pPaS6qM]{Ziskilly Theed} (If the GM needs statistics for these survivors, treat them as Bandits with 2 levels of Exhaustion.)

All three are clad in rags and are suffering from malnutrition and fear. Each bears a bird tattoo on the right shoulder, indicating membership in the @UUID[JournalEntry.67686KaEPc6XAlKJ.JournalEntryPage.sdNti6BHkPTeO5fC]{Osprey Club} The tattoo’s significance is obvious to anyone who knows Thieves’ Cant and to anyone who succeeds on a [[/check skill=history dc=12]] check.

The thieves recount their time as prisoners if asked and are eager to be led out of the dungeon. They thankfully accept their gear (from area @UUID[JournalEntry.uMZ0RiCcPSqsx1Nm.JournalEntryPage.vKXFtG7SrIcibaif]{B23}) if offered, but they only want to return to Otari. If the characters lead them up to the surface, the thieves can safely return to Otari on their own; otherwise, chances are good that a dire fate meets them. On the other hand, Yinyasmera pays well for their safe return; see area @UUID[JournalEntry.kDJSn9wbVvjnqYEj.JournalEntryPage.zPMrDHV75TJzsGba]{A17} for details.

Cleaning Supplies.name: Cleaning Supplies
Cleaning Supplies.text:
Shelves line the walls of this room, each filled with repair tools. A silver-headed cane lies amid a tangle of mops, brooms, and buckets on a shelf to the east.

If the characters make too much noise in here, the devil in area @UUID[JournalEntry.uMZ0RiCcPSqsx1Nm.JournalEntryPage.sqvGeda8OYK1pIzj]{B27} immediately comes to investigate.

Treasure

@UUID[Item.g0AFXH9w450LaBca]{Silver-Headed Cane}

None of these tools are particularly valuable, but even a brief glance is enough to note that they’re all clean and in good condition. The silver-headed cane acts as a scabbard for a concealed Shortsword and is worth [[/award 50gp]]. Any attempt to move it causes several nearby tools (mops, brooms, and buckets, mostly) to clatter down in a noisy pile unless a character succeeds on a [[/skill 11 slt]] check to remove it silently; a character can notice this danger ahead of time with a successful [[/check skill=investigation dc=13]] check.

Clockwork Storage.name: Clockwork Storage
Clockwork Storage.text:
A pair of hulking humanoid objects stand quietly in this chamber, each covered with a thick layer of dust.

These two clockwork assistants once helped maintain this level, but both are broken beyond repair.

Exploration

@UUID[Item.4SN7BGN5c0AYy3dc]{Clockwork Assistants}

With a successful [[/check ability=intelligence dc=14]] check using Investigation or Tinker’s Tools, a character can identify eight gemstones used as bearings deep inside the broken clockworks. These gems are easy to remove once they’ve been identified and are worth [[/award 5gp]] each.

Zozzlarin’s Room.name: Zozzlarin’s Room
Zozzlarin’s Room.text:
The walls of this room have been painted, crudely and almost childishly, to depict a horrific hellscape of burning mountains, rusting cities, and tormented souls.

Belcorra used several bound devils as minions and guardians, mostly in lower levels of the Abomination Vaults. The lesser of the two devils she assigned to the upper levels is a hapless Accuser Devil named Zozzlarin. A chubby, fly-bodied devil, Zozzlarin is bound to this level as an eternal janitor. Zozzlarin is contractually required to spend 18 hours each day in this room, and he has done his best to paint the walls to remind him of home. For the other six hours each day, he’s compelled to buzz out into the surrounding complex to clean and dust. Thanks to Belcorra’s cruel sense of humor, Zozzlarin is required to spend at least three of those hours cleaning the dusty walls and floors of the dungeon with his tongue, but to the hopeless zebub, this indignity is nothing compared to the fact that he has been forced to live here on the Material Plane for much longer than his bargain originally required.

Encounter

@UUID[Actor.Vmmc8ZcyIAZJhA5t]{Zozzlarin}

The frustrated Zozzlarin is quick to attack the characters as a result of his situation since the conditions of his imprisonment allow him to defend the dungeon from aboveground intruders. If reduced to 10 Hit Points or fewer, the devil begs for his life, offering to share a “special memory” as a reward. If the characters agree, the accuser devil uses his Infernal Eye ability to reveal a significant event he witnessed many years ago: Otari Ilvashti’s flight through the dungeon to hide out in area @UUID[JournalEntry.uMZ0RiCcPSqsx1Nm.JournalEntryPage.BHmLYQVCwzBneNFu]{B28}. Zozzlarin doesn’t know this memory’s significance, but it’s the most recent memory he has of other surface-dwellers, so he assumes the characters will find something of interest in it. A character who succeeds on a [[/check skill=history dc=12]] check recognizes the famous adventurer, who was thought to have been killed long ago in the clash against Belcorra.

Haunted Washroom.name: Haunted Washroom
Haunted Washroom.text:
This washroom features an iron bathing tub to the north and a commode to the southwest. The northern wall glows and shimmers with ribbons of eerie green light.

When Otari Ilvashti became trapped in the Abomination Vaults, he did his best to find an escape route. Unfortunately, at that time, many of Belcorra’s dangerous minions still guarded much of this level. He made it to this room, only to collapse from his wounds. Fortunately, the mayhem of Belcorra’s death had thrown the dungeon into chaos, so he wasn’t discovered.

Otari woke some time later, no longer on the edge of death from his ordeal. He crept out of the room and made his way west, through area @UUID[JournalEntry.uMZ0RiCcPSqsx1Nm.JournalEntryPage.7Cs3QciAV15HwrG8]{B31} and eventually to area @UUID[JournalEntry.uMZ0RiCcPSqsx1Nm.JournalEntryPage.FS4EnskC5S91c9RU]{B20}, only to be confronted by an angry and oversized chuul. He discovered the secret door to area @UUID[JournalEntry.uMZ0RiCcPSqsx1Nm.JournalEntryPage.8qZk6POeK6TgPon4]{B32} and fled deeper instead. When Otari finally died in area @UUID[JournalEntry.Os5bHdzCDiXgJBQ6.JournalEntryPage.J8ggyg2kxws3Sa1h]{D18}, his soul remained as a ghost, and the three locations where he hid during his final days became infused with echoes of his spirit. These echoes provide a trail to his remains.

The ghostly energies react to the presence of the heroes. The first time they see the glowing energy, it slithers into letters that read:

“I was Otari... save me from below!”

A moment later, the words slide off the wall and form a green ribbon of light that slithers across the floor like a serpent at a Speed of 25 feet. The characters can follow this ribbon to area @UUID[JournalEntry.uMZ0RiCcPSqsx1Nm.JournalEntryPage.8qZk6POeK6TgPon4]{B32}, where it slithers under the secret door and fades away. The next clue to Otari’s path is in area @UUID[JournalEntry.KeWKr2yd8dbppeS5.JournalEntryPage.LSGUFeDZHwsJMxev]{C3}.

This spectral manifestation can appear once per day.

Hall of Hatred.name: Hall of Hatred
Hall of Hatred.text:
Several wide alcoves adorn the walls of this L-shaped hallway. Each alcove contains a small diorama of the same city facing different perils—a massive fire, a devastating tsunami, a thunderous earthquake, an attack by an enormous tentacled monster, and an invasion of an army of undead.

Exploration

Each of the scenes in the alcoves here depict the city of Absalom in a different fanciful doom from Belcorra’s imagination. The stone dioramas are enhanced with minor illusions: flames flicker, water ripples, and so on. A tiny Gauntlight, as though miles distant, sits at the edge of each scene. Through closer inspection of the final scene, a character who succeeds on a [[/check skill=religion dc=12]] check notes that the undead seem to be rising from Absalom’s graves as Gauntlight’s beam shines upon them.

Dooms of Tomorrow

Hazard

In addition to displaying some of her fantasies about Absalom’s destruction, Belcorra had her apprentice Volluk rig several traps in the hall to punish intruders. One trap is linked to each diorama.

When a creature steps too close, the sounds of devastation rise from the diorama, and a beam of shimmering energy lances outward from the tiny model of Gauntlight.

With a successful [[/check skill=arcana/investigation) dc=15]] check, a character notices the lens of the nearest Gauntlight model tracking their movement. A Detect Magic spell reveals an aura of evocation magic on the model.

When a creature comes within 10 feet of any model of Gauntlight, the trap fires a beam of magical energy at that creature. The trap makes a ranged attack with a +8 bonus. On a hit, the target takes 11 (2d10) damage of a type dependent on which mural the beam originates from—Fire damage from the burning city (a), Cold damage from the tsunami (b), Bludgeoning damage from the earthquake (c), Psychic damage from the monster (d), and Necrotic damage from the undead uprising (e).

Once a lighthouse fires, it can’t fire again for 1 hour. Each lighthouse can be attacked—it has AC 13, 15 Hit Points, and Immunity to Poison and Psychic damage. The magical sensor doesn’t react to any character who sneaks by with a successful [[/check skill=stealth dc=17]] check. A lighthouse’s mirror can also be detached to disable it harmlessly with a successful DC 15 Dexterity check using Thieves’ Tools.

XP Award: Award the party [[/award 25xp]] for each lighthouse that they disable.

War Room.name: War Room
War Room.text:
This large but low-ceilinged room has a cross-shaped table at its center. Ten chairs stand around the table. Thick layers of webbing completely cover the walls, floors, and ceilings of the chamber.

Belcorra once held meetings with her most valued advisors, minions, and conjured allies in this room, usually to plan out her never-realized but oft-imagined assaults on Absalom. The table in the center displays an illusory map of Absalom as it appeared hundreds of years ago, during Belcorra’s life, to aid in her plans, but the spiderwebs in this room obscure this illusion.

Several years ago, an Ettercap named Mimnivix came to this room after entering the dungeon from the swamp. He found the illusory city a delight and fancied himself the “King of the Ghost City,” making the room his lair. After being damaged by a trap in the outer hall, Mimnivix has taken to clambering along the upper reaches of the hall to avoid stepping in front of the traps as he comes and goes on hunting trips, which he times for the hours the dragon is out of her lair at area @UUID[JournalEntry.uMZ0RiCcPSqsx1Nm.JournalEntryPage.ZGby3FkCgaPte0O9]{B19}.

Encounter

@UUID[Actor.ZMr28tFTA5NUcBTi]{Mimnivix}, @UUID[Actor.E4ctF7Fvi3cdkgQq]{Giant Wolf Spider}

When the characters first arrive, the ettercap is squatting atop the table, delighting in yet another examination of his web-caked city. He rises up to full height upon spotting the characters and, in Aklo, greets them by commanding, “Bow down before the King of the Ghost City and present your offerings!” Mimnivix’s inflated ego leaves him expecting any visitors to be potential supplicants bearing gifts. If the characters actually do so, presenting gifts of any sort, Mimnivix is so startled by his own authority that he’s momentarily silent. He then makes further demands of the characters: for more offerings, to polish his claws, and so forth until he tires of their obsequiousness and simply attacks them. If the characters don’t offer gifts or if they refute him at any point, he hisses in frustration and attacks. In combat, he calls his hidden Giant Wolf Spider pet out to ambush the characters and does his best to lure them into one of his two web traps. Mimnivix and his spider fight to the death.

Hazards

Mimnivix has placed two ettercap nooses in the room, as indicated on the map.

Discreet webbing at throat level snags a creature that walks into it. A creature that makes a successful [[/check skill=perception dc=17]] check notices the web. When a creature enters the 5-foot space containing the noose, the trap makes a melee attack with a +7 bonus against that creature. On a hit, the target takes 7 (2d6) Bludgeoning damage and has the Grappled condition (escape DC 13). The noose then pulls the target off the ground. While Grappled, the target loses 3 (1d6) Hit Points from suffocation at the end of each of its turns. A creature can duck under the webbing without triggering the trap by succeeding on a [[/check skill=acrobatics dc=13]] check. A creature can rearrange the webs to render them harmless with a successful [[/check skill=survival dc=14]] check or [[/check ability=dexterity dc=15]] check using Thieves’ Tools. The webbing can be attacked (AC 10, 5 Hit Points, Vulnerability to Fire damage, Immunity to Bludgeoning, Poison, and Psychic damage).

Treasure

@UUID[Item.SiUI1GMmJ2aoGLm2]{Mimnivix's Treasure}

The ettercap has gathered a fairly large stash of “treasure” that he keeps in a bundle of webbing affixed under the table. Most are worthless trinkets, like rusty arrowheads, shiny rocks, bits of glass worn smooth by the surf, or neat seashells, but among the clutter is a leather pouch containing three faintly glowing +1 Sling Bullets and a Necklace of Fireballs with one bead remaining. The cache is visible to anyone who looks in the room without a source of Bright Light or who looks under the table, as the magical sling bullets glow through the webbing.

Reception Room.name: Reception Room
Reception Room.text:
A ruined table and several destroyed chairs lie in a heap in the middle of this room, along with several large bones.

If the characters are following the ghostly trail left by Otari from area @UUID[JournalEntry.uMZ0RiCcPSqsx1Nm.JournalEntryPage.BHmLYQVCwzBneNFu]{B28}, they see the trail dance and flicker around the center of this room where a minotaur’s skeleton is entangled with the ruined furniture. Otari encountered the guardian here and killed it before moving on. Unfortunately, the necromantic influence of Gauntlight has animated these remains.

Encounter

@UUID[Actor.5MVBU86ZRw2ANMQn]{Minotaur Skeleton}

As the characters enter the room, the bones shudder and pull together. This process takes several moments, so swift characters can exit the room before the bones assemble, at which time they fall back into place. If the Minotaur Skeleton completely rebuilds itself, it pulls itself from the wreckage and fights until destroyed—but it doesn’t pursue foes from this room.

Macro: When the skeleton begins to reassemble itself, you can use the @Macro[e7SbhVgzoGNhPHDS]{B31 - Minotaur Skeleton} macro to toggle the visibility of the bones and the skeleton at the same time!

Secret Stairs.name: Secret Stairs
Secret Stairs.text:
Exploration

The characters can spot the secret door at the top of these stairs with a successful [[/skill 15 inv]] check. The secret door opens when the rise on the top step is pushed a certain way. The stairs beyond the secret door lead down to area @UUID[JournalEntry.KeWKr2yd8dbppeS5.JournalEntryPage.YhRSOC6JXrOhl9wU]{C10}.

Punishment Room.name: Punishment Room
Punishment Room.text:
A pair of broken-down instruments of torture lie in half- collapsed heaps on the floor here. To the north slumps a ruined stretching rack, while to the south, a pillory lies fallen on the floor. Rusty tongs and chains, frayed and rotten whips, and other implements lie on tottering shelves that look ready to collapse.

Belcorra used this room to punish servants, or when she was merely bored and needed something to distract her.

Exploration

Little of use remains here, but a character who examines the room and makes a successful [[/check skill=investigation dc=14]] check finds the secret door to the south, which opens when a character sharply pulls a rusted ring on the wall.

Elevator Down.name: Elevator Down
Elevator Down.text:
Exploration

A character who searches this dead end can spot the secret door by making a successful [[/check skill=investigation dc=14]] check. Two wall stones, pushed in unison, cause the door to swing open.

This plain, circular room is empty. A single image of a moss-caked skull adorns the eastern wall.

This floor of this room is a magical elevator that links to area @UUID[JournalEntry.KeWKr2yd8dbppeS5.JournalEntryPage.Y5ErIQKfh97WDP2G]{C22} below. If a creature touches the image of the mossy skull—Nhimbaloth’s symbol—while the secret door is closed, the floor slowly descends 30 feet with a grinding noise. Doors slide up into view to the north and south.

If the secret door is opened while the elevator is in area @UUID[JournalEntry.KeWKr2yd8dbppeS5.JournalEntryPage.Y5ErIQKfh97WDP2G]{C22}, this room is a 30-foot-deep pit.

Gauntlight Basement.name: Gauntlight Basement
Gauntlight Basement.text:
If the characters manage to enter this room before @UUID[JournalEntry.67686KaEPc6XAlKJ.JournalEntryPage.efRUYLBH9Kf3CLkX]{Gauntlight} activates at the beginning of this chapter, then the artifact is already empowered; no ribbon of ghostly energy is currently present, and the GM should amend the following read-aloud text accordingly. After Gauntlight activates, it needs to recharge, so the ribbon of energy returns.

The walls of this circular room are smooth and pale gray. A ribbon of pale blue light coils and slithers through the air, connecting the floor at the center of the room to the ceiling fifteen feet above. The points at which this light touches the stone above and below seethe and writhe, as if the stone itself were suffering from an infection. The desiccated remains of an enormous worm lie slumped around the ribbon, forming a crescent of shriveled and tattered, purple flesh.

One of Belcorra’s favorite pets dwelt in this room, a purple worm she transported into the chamber from the Darklands. For all the creature’s bestial power, it was entirely dependent on Belcorra for sustenance, as the lighthouse’s walls are indestructible. After Belcorra’s death, the worm starved to death.

A character who succeeds on a [[/check skill=nature dc=10]] check identifies the massive remains as belonging to a purple worm; although these creatures are rare and mighty, the body’s shape and the flesh’s pale purple coloration are distinctive. If the check succeeds by 5 or more, the character recalls details of a purple worm’s abilities and realizes the worm starved to death.

The ribbon of ghostly light is a manifestation of Gauntlight’s mounting power. This eerie light churns in a 5-foot-diameter cylinder at the room’s center. An Undead creature that ends its turn within the cylinder regains [[/r 2d6]] Hit Points. Any other creature that ends its turn in the area makes a [[/save ability=constitution dc=10]] saving throw. Constructs automatically succeed on the save. On a failure, the creature takes [[/r 2d6 #necrotic]] Necrotic damage.

As long as Gauntlight remains at its low-level activation, the light keeps churning, but if the characters rescue Lasda Venkervale from area @UUID[JournalEntry.Os5bHdzCDiXgJBQ6.JournalEntryPage.RmFsEEQSD9Ulugwm]{D9}, the eerie ribbon winks out.

Treasure

@UUID[Item.p8Lrw8xwvFZQDsZd]{Duergar's Remains}

A character who digs into the dried worm’s carcass finds the remains of its last meal: a duergar skeleton still clutching a Warhammer that didn’t help him cut his way out of the worm’s gut—at all. The duergar carries a small diamond worth [[/award 25gp]].

Introduction.name: Introduction
Introduction.text:
Chapter Synopsis

The Abomination Vaults’ second level—its highest underground level— harbors several old traps and some fiercely independent denizens who hunt on the surface. It also contains a small tribe of morlocks pushed up from below. Before the heroes get too far into exploring this level, though, Belcorra activates Gauntlight@UUID[JournalEntry.67686KaEPc6XAlKJ.JournalEntryPage.efRUYLBH9Kf3CLkX]{Gauntlight} in a devastating test as she refines the artifact’s power.

Deadtide

While the characters are free to enter the dungeon below the keep as soon as they discover any of its entrances, an important event should take place before they dive too deeply into the Abomination Vaults. It’s best if this event takes place at night while the characters have line of sight to Gauntlight’s cupola, such as when they retreat to rest or perhaps even right after they’ve overcome the dangers in area @UUID[JournalEntry.kDJSn9wbVvjnqYEj.JournalEntryPage.6wFkYYY7f8SqcRy8]{A25}. In any case, the characters should be 2nd level for this event. When the timing is right, begin @UUID[JournalEntry.uMZ0RiCcPSqsx1Nm.JournalEntryPage.YJt9K0fOixekSCa6]{Deadtide for Otari}.

Environmental Cues:

Broken low-quality furniture and tools, cobwebs, distant banging noises, moisture beading on the walls, smells of mold, unpleasant dampness.

Servants' Quarters

The first underground level of the Abomination Vaults once served as quarters for Belcorra’s servants. Here, the workers lived and toiled out of sight from those in Gauntlight Keep above. When Belcorra was killed, the servants here panicked. Some fled, others hid in their rooms, and still others became food for the cannibalistic librarians the next floor down. Today, the servants’ quarters are largely in ruins. Areas are unlit unless otherwise noted, and ceiling heights are typically 8 feet in hallways and 10 feet in rooms. The doors are sturdy wood, swollen shut with moisture.

Children of the Ghost Queen.name: Children of the Ghost Queen
Children of the Ghost Queen.text: The largest faction presently active in the servants’ quarters is a group of morlocks who call themselves the Children of the Ghost Queen. These morlocks once dwelt deep below this level in caverns adjacent to the Abomination Vaults. When Belcorra wakened, they clambered into the higher levels to prepare the way for her, enduring a devastating clash with the Cult of the Canker ghouls and later driving out the Mudlicker mitflits. Belcorra always considered morlocks to be pests (and still does, even as a ghost), but the morlock leader, Graulgust, hopes to change her mind by building her a temple. But, just as Belcorra’s eldritch patron Nhimbaloth cares little about how she’s honored, the morlocks’ Ghost Queen doesn’t care whether these devout morlocks live or die.

Deadtide For Otari.name: Deadtide For Otari
Deadtide For Otari.text:
@UUID[JournalEntry.67686KaEPc6XAlKJ.JournalEntryPage.efRUYLBH9Kf3CLkX]{Gauntlight} isn’t yet fully functional, but enough of its magical power has been restored that Belcorra activates it as a test firing before proceeding with the more involved process of restoring the artifact to full use. She targets Otari’s graveyard, animating the dead within it. The ghost then watches through Gauntlight’s lens, but she can’t do much beyond observe, limited as she is to the site of her haunting deep in the Abomination Vaults. Read or paraphrase the following to begin this event.

Gauntlight shudders, and its light high above suddenly blazes with a sickly, pale blue illumination. This beam arcs south, falling not directly on Otari, but onto the sprawling graveyard located on the settlement’s western edge.

Powerful Visions

@Macro[0C1vnwN5UaW0aWFQ]{Deadtide for Otari}

If you'd like to have some lighting effects to accompany your descriptions, this macro will cause a spectral glow to descend onto the graveyard, visible on either the @Scene[MSHO9s465zhZIuH7]{Landing} or @Scene[lQkXSdxvO9CRxohD]{Otari} scenes.

The light remains fixed on the graveyard and is visible all the way from Gauntlight to the town. There isn’t any way for the characters to impede the beam, as it emanates magically from Gauntlight and can’t be stopped from its origin point except by Belcorra’s will.

As the dead are buried, it takes most of them some time to dig free. Although the characters might hurry directly to the graveyard given the sinister implications of the eerie light, the GM can still run these events as written if the characters first take some time to tend to their wounds or otherwise delay. If the characters take more than a couple of hours to arrive, town guards have already erected a barrier around the cemetery but are afraid to enter the grounds for fear of the occasional lone shuffling corpse that pulled itself free sooner than the others. Dealing with the undead should fall to the characters; if they aren’t self-motivated to enter the graveyard and act the part of heroes, feel free to have an official like Captain Longsaddle, Mayor Oseph Menhemes, or Vandy Banderdash ask them to deal with the situation. If the characters continue to hesitate, the undead might become a bigger problem.

Otari Graveyard.name: Otari Graveyard
Otari Graveyard.text:
The soil of Otari’s graveyard roils and churns in the eerie blue light. Dozens of skeletons and shambling corpses haul themselves free from the ground and rush to the south. Without hesitation, the walking dead plummet over the cliff’s edge to rain down upon the domes of the Dawnflower Library below.

Most of the undead raised by Gauntlight’s beam plummet to their grisly destruction over the cliffs, though a few remain in the graveyard. Yet the damage is done—Otari’s citizens are horrified and panicked. If the characters step into the graveyard to take on the few remaining undead, the fight is an important symbolic stand that the townsfolk soon cling to—this is the characters’ first real step toward being recognized as Otari’s saviors.

Encounter

@UUID[Actor.ro9oVsu1cuCP8OQH]{Skeletons (5)} @UUID[Actor.0plBflWwrCWQO2RO]{Zombies (3)} @UUID[Actor.rsATu823vatRe7QJ]{Otari Guards (4)}

A total of five Skeletons and three Zombies remain active in the graveyard. Each skeleton is unarmed but can make a Claw attack that deals [[/damage 1d4 + 3 average type=slashing]] damage. These foes can be a serious threat to level 2 characters, but canny characters have a number of advantages. The undead are scattered throughout the graveyard, with no one undead within 30 feet of any other, although they quickly move toward any fight or distraction. Stealth and ranged tactics could thin the opposition before the undead can close to melee, and with their foes being scattered, the characters won’t need to deal with large numbers all at once if they’re quick and efficient.

The four nearby town Guards are frightened by the undead and are unlikely to be of much help—they flee if attacked. At the GM’s discretion, and particularly if a character makes a successful [[/check skill=intimidation/persuasion dc=12]] check to jar the guards out of their fear, some of them might fight. Guards can also drag a fallen character to safety. If any guards engage in combat, each begins the encounter with the Frightened condition. Each guard makes a [[/save wisdom dc=12]] saving throw at the end of each of their turns, ending the Frightened condition on themselves on a success.

Abomination's Arrival

Belcorra watches with amusement from afar as the characters deal with the undead. As soon as that fight ends, though, she decides it’s time to test Gauntlight’s primary function: teleporting monsters in among her enemies. Belcorra orders her apprentice Volluk to bring one of the scalathraxes from area @UUID[JournalEntry.Os5bHdzCDiXgJBQ6.JournalEntryPage.df69jJ0DznVnWMAb]{D10} into area @UUID[JournalEntry.Os5bHdzCDiXgJBQ6.JournalEntryPage.RmFsEEQSD9Ulugwm]{D9}. This delay grants the characters a few minutes to recover from the previous fight. Belcorra then focuses Gauntlight’s beam upon the characters’ location. The baleful light’s illumination raises gooseflesh on those it touches and scatters any remaining guards in a panic.

Encounter

@UUID[Actor.Nkz8Z5TrEqRePGlk]{Scalathrax}

An instant after Gauntlight’s beam shines upon the characters, a Scalathrax manifests in their midst—and just as quickly, I goes dark. Each character can attempt a [[/check skill=arcana dc=14]] check to recognize the impending teleportation and avoid being surprised by the scalathrax’s sudden arrival. Once it appears, the scaly, spiderlike aberration attacks, fighting to the death.

Treasure: The scalathrax’s body contains a reservoir of oil, which is of great use to alchemists but is difficult to harvest and preserve. A character proficient with Alchemist’s Supplies or who makes a successful [[/check skill=arcana dc=12]] check recognizes this usefulness upon seeing the dead scalathrax’s body. By spending 10 minutes and succeeding on a [[/check ability=intelligence dc=15]] check using Alchemist’s Supplies, a character can extract 5 pounds of scalathrax oil worth [[/award 100gp]] from a recently killed scalathrax. If scalathrax oil is used as at least half the raw materials cost to craft Alchemist’s Fire or similar items, the crafter can finish the item in 1 day, the saving throw DC of the item increases by 2, and any damage the item deals is doubled the first time it deals damage. Scalathrax oil can be used as Oil but is often considered too valuable for such a mundane purpose.

Dying Light

Once Gauntlight has delivered the scalathrax and gone dark, it will be at least a month before the artifact can return to a point where Belcorra can activate it again. She might do so to animate more undead or teleport another monster into town, either to attack the characters directly or to simply spread panic.

Of course, the townsfolk have no idea about this schedule, and the fear that Gauntlight could shine again at any moment has the citizens terrified. People fear to go outside after dark, and rumors about Belcorra’s return run rampant. Assuming the characters played a key and visible role in defeating the undead and the scalathrax, they’re soon contacted by Mayor Oseph Menhemes, who asks them to do what they can to find out what caused this event and, if possible, prevent it from occurring again. Feel free to have other town notables be present at this time—give the characters a chance to rise to the occasion. In any event, Oseph promises a reward of [[/award 50gp]] per character from the town treasury if they can see to it that Gauntlight never shines on Otari again. (He’ll grant this reward as soon as the characters learn of Belcorra’s plans from the ghost of Otari Ilvashti in area @UUID[JournalEntry.Os5bHdzCDiXgJBQ6.JournalEntryPage.J8ggyg2kxws3Sa1h]{D18}, locate the Gauntlight papers in area @UUID[JournalEntry.KeWKr2yd8dbppeS5.JournalEntryPage.8X4xF40k06MW0X7q]{C35}, or free Lasda Venkervale in area @UUID[JournalEntry.Os5bHdzCDiXgJBQ6.JournalEntryPage.RmFsEEQSD9Ulugwm]{D9}, but he asks them to continue their efforts against Belcorra thereafter.)

Processional.name: Processional
Processional.text:
This long, ten-foot-wide hallway has a vaulted ceiling arching to a dozen feet high. Three broken metal brackets sit on the ceiling: one to the south, one to the north, and one in the middle; however, what the frames once held is unclear. The floor is strewn with pieces of rotten wood and twisted metal. To the north, a pale green light shimmers around a closed door’s frame.

The empty frames used to house small, swiveling ballistae on the ceiling that functioned as traps, but the morlocks have plundered all the components for other makeshift inventions. Only the detritus the morlocks deemed valueless remains.

The green light shining through the door frame to area @UUID[JournalEntry.uMZ0RiCcPSqsx1Nm.JournalEntryPage.BHmLYQVCwzBneNFu]{B28} is evidence of Otari’s spirit. The morlocks don’t approach this light, as they believe it to be a sign of the Ghost Queen’s wrath.

Exploration

The secret door leading to area @UUID[JournalEntry.uMZ0RiCcPSqsx1Nm.JournalEntryPage.MY61uS4Lk2va9xoZ]{B6} is well-hidden from this side, its seams all but invisible cracks in the stone. A character who searches the hall and succeeds on a [[/skill prc 21]] check spots the door.

First Challenge.name: First Challenge
First Challenge.text:
A basin filled with reeds and moss stands in an alcove between doors that lead to the north. Two metal tubes jut into the room from the east, sealed off by some irislike mechanism a foot or so inside the pipe. No opening mechanism is visible. Black stone doors lead south, and a single gray stone door carved with shapes of swirling mist leads west. None of the doors have handles or latches.

The tests begin with the Challenge of Souls through the western door. The metal tubes slant downward and drain into the swamp (area @UUID[JournalEntry.yn21bNM6kpV4xRol.JournalEntryPage.1Ov1191GpaTDBaAE]{J15}). They’re just large enough for a Medium creature to slide down them. If the characters enter here with Lady’s Whisper, the skeleton silently points at the gray door. That door opens with a push, or simply swings aside if someone stands in front of it for a few moments. The doors to the south (AC 17, 60 Hit Points, Immunity to Poison and Psychic damage) and the tubes’ mechanical iris openings (AC 19, 50 Hit Points, Immunity to Poison and Psychic damage) are all shut and don’t open unless Lady’s Whisper wills it.

If the two will-o’-wisps are following the characters, one takes a position above the basin to silently report everything the characters do here to Belcorra.

Passing the Challenge of Souls

When the characters return here having either fed or defeated the dread wisps in area @UUID[JournalEntry.yn21bNM6kpV4xRol.JournalEntryPage.iESpyOXVCFTTGXxk]{J8}, overcoming the Challenge of Souls, Lady’s Whisper opens the doors to the south and leaves them open. A character who succeeds on a [[/check skill=insight dc=20]] check realizes that Lady’s Whisper is offended that the characters passed the test but is keeping this irritation suppressed.

The Proctor

The characters might go along with Lady’s Whisper at first, wondering just what the enigmatic undead is asking of them. After they complete one or two tests, they might decide they don’t want to be judged worthy of Nhimbaloth’s attention after all. This is especially true if they realize that each successful test increases Lady’s Whisper’s displeasure and that the undead plans to kill them.

Lady’s Whisper responds to any preemptive attack by the characters as though expecting it. The undead attempts to fly out of melee reach and cast spells to eliminate the characters. The lurking will-o’- wisps that may have followed from area @UUID[JournalEntry.1vlzl3NJsftNB9Dc.JournalEntryPage.uWdCP78aS1lts5kr]{I64} join the fight as well.

Poisoning Room.name: Poisoning Room
Poisoning Room.text:
At the eastern end of this long room stands a giant jade statue of a cracked and chipped skeleton in a burial shroud. The skull clenches a bundle of swamp weeds in its teeth. Built into the walls are several narrow slits and stone doors.

Exploration

A character who investigates the statue and makes a successful [[/check skill=religion dc=20]] check realizes that this jade statue is one of the rare physical representations of Nhimbaloth.

Long ago, when initiates were brought into this chamber, they were commanded to kneel before Nhimbaloth. When they did, cultists hiding in galleries to the north and south shot poisoned blowgun darts at them. Those who didn’t succumb to poison were considered worthy and could pass into the chambers to the south to be washed and prepared for the next test. Those who succumbed to the poison were taken north to have their souls harvested.

Encounter

@UUID[Actor.BOaM3pAuWl06Q6IZ]{Cultist Specters (6)}

Six cultists have arisen as Specters. They manifest in the shooting galleries with ghostly blowguns, which they use to make Life Drain attacks with a range of 25/100 feet. These blowguns don’t require ammunition, as they shoot ephemeral darts made of the specters’ own ghostly substance. The characters can target a specter on the other side of one of the narrow slits, but the specter has Three-Quarters Cover. If the characters come through the doors into the shooting gallery, the specters pass through the walls to continue their ranged attacks from within the room. The specters fight until destroyed.

Cleansing Chamber.name: Cleansing Chamber
Cleansing Chamber.text:
Two grime-crusted copper tubs, devoid of water, stand against the south wall.

Long abandoned, this chamber was once where initiates who survived the poisoning room were stripped, bathed with swamp water, and then escorted into the worthies’ cave.

Exploration

A character can discover the secret door while searching this room with a successful [[/skill 15 inv]] check. A false stone on the eastern wall must be rotated to pivot open one of the copper tubs and the wall behind it.

Macro: You can use the @Macro[buxrVuDqbnEptMtB]{J3 - Secret Door} macro to toggle the visibility of the door and tile.

Worthies’ Cave.name: Worthies’ Cave
Worthies’ Cave.text:
The ceiling of this natural chamber bears seven holes no larger around than a human finger.

Before the surviving initiates could take the next challenge—the Challenge of Despair—they were subjected to a mind-numbing gas to make the upcoming challenge more difficult.

Exploration

The secret doors here both open the same way: when rotated, a portion of the smooth, flat wall makes the door pivot open. The secret doors are each at the end of short hallways, so they aren’t hard to find. Anyone searching either short hall discovers the secret door and the method of opening it. The doors won’t open, however, if the room’s trap is active, and they must be battered down (AC 17, 60 Hit Points, Immunity to Poison and Psychic damage) for the characters to escape the trap.

Befuddling Gas Trap

Hazard

When both doors are closed and at least one creature is in the room, the trap spews mind-numbing gas through the seven holes in the ceiling.

When both secret doors are closed, seven nozzles hidden within holes in the 15-foot-high ceiling release a poison gas. A character can determine the holes and door are both connected to a trap with a successful [[/check skill=investigation dc=17]] check.

When a door closes, if the other is already closed, gas pours out of the nozzles to fill the chamber. Each creature in the area must make a successful [[/save 17 con]] saving throw or it has the &Reference[Poisoned] condition until it finishes a Long Rest. A creature Poisoned in this way makes Intelligence saving throws with Disadvantage.

Once the gas fills the room, roll Initiative. The trap rolls Initiative with a +8 bonus. On the trap’s turn, the gas intensifies and each creature in the room must repeat the saving throw. A Poisoned creature that fails its save takes [[/damage 8d6 average poison]] damage.

As an action, a creature can attempt to disable the trap’s trigger mechanism by making a [[/tool ability=dexterity tool=thief 22]] check. On a success, the gas is immediately sucked out of the room, and the secret doors at the end of each hall can be opened normally. Alternatively, a creature can use an action to plug one of the trap’s seven nozzles using wax, clay, or a similar substance, but doing so without a suitable material requires a successful [[/check ability=dexterity dc=17]] check using Mason’s Tools, Potter’s Tools, or Thieves’ Tools. If all seven nozzles are plugged, the trap deactivates.

XP Award: Award the characters 2,300 XP for disabling the trap.

Level Ten Portal Chamber.name: Level Ten Portal Chamber
Level Ten Portal Chamber.text:
Encounter

@UUID[Actor.Upf2fOZ6QgGG3seI]{Stone Golem}

As the lowest portal chamber, Belcorra wanted to ensure this room was well-guarded. A Stone Golem is built into the wall, in an open space between the silver-filled runes. It steps forward to attack as soon as anyone who isn’t accompanying Belcorra enters. It fights until destroyed.

Teleportation Network

Some of the @UUID[Compendium.dnd5e.spells24.Item.phbsplTeleportat]{Teleportation Circles} within the Abomination Vaults form a part of a larger network. By tracing specific patterns on the wall runes, someone could transport everyone in any one of these chambers to one of nine other portal chambers in the Abomination Vaults- so long as the teleportation circles in both the departure chamber and destination have been awakened by the @UUID[Compendium.dnd-abomination-vaults.av-items-5e.Item.H0KYIrtDeeV2pSyC]{Awaken Portal} ritual (area @UUID[JournalEntry.KeWKr2yd8dbppeS5.JournalEntryPage.8X4xF40k06MW0X7q]{C35}).

The nine chambers are areas @UUID[JournalEntry.uMZ0RiCcPSqsx1Nm.JournalEntryPage.537bzfVUpq6XbR9a]{B17}, @UUID[JournalEntry.KeWKr2yd8dbppeS5.JournalEntryPage.vEiow4kU961XNOJp]{C16}, @UUID[JournalEntry.Os5bHdzCDiXgJBQ6.JournalEntryPage.RJf3BCpcVW6d68s7]{D05}, @UUID[JournalEntry.JT0zCcIwsSpKnbB5.JournalEntryPage.LJhOoRqYjj38YWl8]{E18}, @UUID[JournalEntry.KI33EAGPVHP4zyFZ.JournalEntryPage.mDFVGUXY6YDuQWF3]{F13}, @UUID[JournalEntry.OyNcqrpRClyhr8BJ.JournalEntryPage.zTpatmyyb4JvgNCo]{G02}, @UUID[JournalEntry.FwWmtOBFHhvM2gtf.JournalEntryPage.Nak2hUmVOHXBkcR5]{H33}, @UUID[JournalEntry.1vlzl3NJsftNB9Dc.JournalEntryPage.DJKWR2KLTPUi3w6T]{I59}, and @UUID[JournalEntry.yn21bNM6kpV4xRol.JournalEntryPage.JinYTJeYVFBE1uky]{J05}

Belcorra added this room to the temple to connect her network of permanent Teleportation Circles. Its door is locked and the key is long lost. A character can force it open with a successful [[/check ability=strength dc=20]] check or pick the lock with a successful [[/check ability=dexterity dc=16]] check using Thieves’ Tools.

Swirling, silver-filled runes adorn the rounded walls of this chamber. Sheets of reflective metal cover the floor and ceiling.

The characters can reactivate this portal chamber and connect it to others throughout the Abomination Vaults, as described in area @UUID[JournalEntry.uMZ0RiCcPSqsx1Nm.JournalEntryPage.537bzfVUpq6XbR9a]{B17}.

XP Award: Award the characters [[/award 500xp]] for using the Awaken Portal spell to reactivate the Teleportation Circle here.

Crematorium.name: Crematorium
Crematorium.text:
Two pools of bubbling magma sit side by side in the center of this large chamber.

This crematorium is extremely hot, although abjurations woven into the stone of this room keep the heat contained within it. Every 10 minutes a creature spends in the room, it takes [[/damage 2d6 fire average]] damage and must make a successful [[/save constitution dc=10]] saving throw or gain 1 level of Exhaustion. A creature that enters the pools of magma or starts its turn there takes [[/damage 20d6 fire average]] damage.

Encounter

@UUID[Actor.Z3J7uGaLmlFRfwPk]{Fire Elementals (2)}

Two bound Fire Elementals have maintained the heat in this room for centuries. They have broken their binding but haven’t yet figured out how to leave the room. They climb from the pits to attack, pursuing intruders and fighting until destroyed.

Soul Extractors.name: Soul Extractors
Soul Extractors.text:
This strange irregular hall features several wide alcoves, each with a standing rack bearing crystals and levers, like bizarre torture devices.

Failed initiates were brought here and strapped to the strange standing racks. These occult machines extracted the initiates’ souls into crystal globes as special glass golems sliced their bodies to pieces. Cultists took these soul-infused globes (which were far too delicate for the blade-handed golems to handle) to the dread wisps in area @UUID[JournalEntry.yn21bNM6kpV4xRol.JournalEntryPage.iESpyOXVCFTTGXxk]{J8}.

Only three occult machines are still functional, and each holds a crystal globe containing the soul of an initiate killed centuries ago. A character investigating a functional machine and succeeding on a [[/skill 17 rel]] check or [[/check skill=arcana dc=19]] check realizes what the globes are and how they were created.

Encounter

@UUID[Actor.eoQgRltsgJWa4aeC]{Ghostglass Golems (4)}

The four Ghostglass Golems remain here and do their best to slice intruders to ribbons. They are not subtle combatants. When they move, they emit a noise like the grinding of old glass, and their greenish glass bodies produce an unsettling glow.

Treasure

@UUID[Item.EHd6QD5xsmf17QFG]{Soul Extractors}

The three crystal globes are each worth [[/award 200gp]] to certain unsavory soul-merchants, such as night hags. If smashed, their fragments are valueless but the soul trapped within travels to the Boneyard and its ultimate reward.

The three functioning machines have some valuable parts. With several hours’ work and a successful [[/check ability=dexterity dc=19]] check using Jeweler’s Tools, Thieves’ Tools, or Tinker’s Tools, a character can strip a machine of rare metals and delicate gears worth a total of [[/award 500gp]]. If this check succeeds by 5 or more, the parts from that machine are worth [[/award 1000gp]]; if it fails by 5 or more, the parts in that machine are ruined and valueless.

Devouring Chamber.name: Devouring Chamber
Devouring Chamber.text:
This large room has a spiny, dust-covered floor. On the far western end is a large stone basin filled with swamp plants.

A thick layer of dust covers the shattered crystal shards littering the floor, evidence of hundreds of initiates’ extracted souls in years long ago. The broken crystal makes the ground Difficult Terrain. A creature walking across the ground makes Dexterity (Stealth) checks with Disadvantage; if the creature is barefoot, it takes [[/damage 1d10 piercing average]] damage for each 5 feet it moves.

Encounter

@UUID[Actor.2TOXR7nKS6xPng2Y]{Dread Wisps}

Three Dread Wisps float here. As extensions of the evil energies of the Empty Vault (area @UUID[JournalEntry.yn21bNM6kpV4xRol.JournalEntryPage.a9b40LjI7QwLgirk]{J20}), these wisps funnel souls released here to that chamber. They can’t return to the Empty Vault, or even leave this room, without more souls.

When the characters arrive, the bobbing wisps demand that the characters gather the crystal globes from the next room and smash them here. They insist that doing to will cause them to vanish, but they don’t reveal that doing so frees them to return to the Empty Vault. One dread wisp winks out for each smashed sphere; the characters might face them again, in the Empty Vault.

If it becomes clear to the dread wisps that the characters aren’t going to comply, they attack in an attempt to kill them and use their souls as the fuel for the Empty Vault instead. The dread wisps gang up on one character at a time, moving on to another when their target is dead. Each character killed in this room allows one dread wisp to wink out immediately.

Stolen Soul: A character who dies in this room has a portion of their soul stolen to power the Empty Vault. The character can be raised as normal but thereafter has Disadvantage on Death Saving Throws for 1 year.

XP Award: Award the characters [[/award 2500xp]] for dealing with these dread wisps and passing the Challenge of Souls.

Second Challenge.name: Second Challenge
Second Challenge.text:
This chamber looks much like the room to the north, except the gray door to the west is carved with frightened faces rather than mist, and there are three metal tubes rather than two. A basin of reeds and swamp water is to the south.

This is where initiates began the Challenge of Despair. The south doors and mechanical iris openings in the tubes are similar to those in area @UUID[JournalEntry.yn21bNM6kpV4xRol.JournalEntryPage.GZNjyAZgRDgPx68z]{J1}. The single door on the west wall is unlocked and leads to the start of the second test.

If Lady’s Whisper is leading the characters through the challenges, it points silently at the western door. The second will-o’-wisp shadowing Lady’s Whisper moves to hover above the basin and silently report the characters’ movements to Belcorra.

Once the characters are through the western door to begin their test, Lady’s Whisper opens the doors to area @UUID[JournalEntry.yn21bNM6kpV4xRol.JournalEntryPage.mNKZFTEUn2ag0OSn]{J14} and awaits the characters there, closing the doors afterward.

Path of Pleasant Memories.name: Path of Pleasant Memories
Path of Pleasant Memories.text:
The walls of this long, narrow hall are momentarily a stark white, but colorful images soon swirl upon them. A door stands at each end of the hall.

Powerful Visions

@Macro[RSuO0bzkA10DXFry]{J10 - Visions}

When the heroes begin to experience the visions described in this room, you can use this macro to enable lighting effects to accompany your descriptions.
