@UUID[Compendium.dnd-abomination-vaults.av-items-5e.Item.3xvMloowowmYbX72]{Battle Lute}: This reinforced lute is suitable for use as a handheld Musical Instrument or for bashing when the crowd turns sour. Its strings are finely braided wire that run along a sturdy metal neck.

@UUID[Compendium.dnd-abomination-vaults.av-items-5e.Item.SjiefF7DbgRPkbyD]{Elven Curve Blade}: Essentially a longer version of the scimitar, this traditional elven weapon has a thinner blade than its cousin.

@UUID[Compendium.dnd-abomination-vaults.av-items-5e.Item.BoQ7pqlX54EHyRcS]{Repeating Hand Crossbow}: This weapon features an ingeniously designed catch mechanism at the top of the flight grove, just in front of the latch, which automatically loads a bolt from a magazine and resets the string each time the weapon is fired. A typical Repeating Crossbow Magazine holds five Bolts.

@UUID[Compendium.dnd-abomination-vaults.av-items-5e.Item.BqcFjpBzMcNqSYN0]{Rhoka Sword}: These dual- bladed swords are commonly used by urdefhan warriors. Shauth Blade: These strange, curved blades are jagged and deadly weapons made of alchemically strengthened teeth of dead urdefhans. They are typically named for the urdefhan whose teeth were forged into the weapon and are often carried (and revered) by that urdefhan’s descendants. If you score a Critical Hit against a creature that isn’t a Construct or Undead while using this weapon, you deal an extra 1d4 Slashing damage. This extra damage isn’t doubled. Urdefhans can train to drink blood through hollow parts of a shauth blade for a moment after hitting.

@UUID[Compendium.dnd-abomination-vaults.av-items-5e.Item.xeWtLPxaZ1hNevXC]{Shauth Lash}: This long metal chain bears hook-like barbs made of alchemically strengthened urdefhan teeth. If you score a Critical Hit against a creature that isn’t a Construct or Undead while using this weapon, you deal an extra 1d6 Slashing damage. This extra damage isn’t doubled. Urdefhans can train to drink blood through hollow parts of a shauth lash for a moment after hitting, and urdefhans hold these weapons with the same reverence with which they do shauth blades.

@UUID[Compendium.dnd-abomination-vaults.av-items-5e.Item.zl5qdRWdWJ0fzTGF]{Starknife}: From a central metal ring, four tapering metal blades extend like points on a compass rose. When gripping a starknife from the center, the wielder can use it as a melee weapon. It can also be thrown short distances.

@UUID[Compendium.dnd-abomination-vaults.av-items-5e.Item.0c4ElbX5TEq2DMke]{Tamchal Chakram}: These circular weapons are among the many strange weapons used by urdefhans. The sharp metal circle contains numerous protruding blades, while an angled central handle provides a grip that spins the weapon as it’s thrown.

@UUID[Compendium.dnd-abomination-vaults.av-items-5e.Item.IOkTpCymE92GViuG]{War Flail}: This large flail has a long shaft connected to a shorter piece of stout wood or metal that’s sometimes inlaid with spikes.

New Weapon Property

Repeating: A Repeating weapon is typically a type of crossbow that doesn’t require reloading as often. These weapons can’t be loaded with individual bolts like other crossbows; they instead require a magazine of specialized ammunition be loaded into a slot in the weapon. Once that magazine is in place, ammunition is loaded automatically each time the weapon is cocked to fire as part of the attack. Each Repeating Crossbow Magazine holds the listed number of pieces of ammunition. When the ammunition runs out, a new magazine must be loaded using a Utilize action. Alternatively, a creature can use a Bonus Action twice (once to remove the old magazine, and once to slot the new magazine in place) on different turns without using a Utilize action.

Lenses and Lattice.name: Lenses and Lattice
Lenses and Lattice.text:
Fulcrum Lenses are unique magical crystals that each contain a sliver of Nhimbaloth’s essence. They are part of a larger set of lenses created to manipulate or even bind the Empty Death; most of the other lenses are long lost and likely destroyed. The Haruvex family came into possession of four lenses, and they knew that bringing them together focused Nhimbaloth’s attention in unprecedented and dangerous ways. Belcorra brought all four lenses to the Abomination Vaults with her, intending to install them in Gauntlight for her ultimate revenge upon Absalom. She also created a special receptacle called the Fulcrum Lattice to hold the lenses so their power could be focused together. Yet she realized the danger of keeping the Fulcrum Lenses too close together until the time was right; she spread them out among loyal groups in the Abomination Vaults’ lowest levels for safekeeping.

If the characters bring the other three lenses to bear against Belcorra, they can draw Nhimbaloth’s dread glare to the sorcerer. Loyal though Belcorra is, she cannot hope to keep her spirit intact when Nhimbaloth gazes directly upon it. The Fulcrum Lenses are more than mere receptacles of Nhimbaloth’s essence. Each grants those who use it a fragment of the Outer God’s power, and only the foolish use them lightly.

Crimson Fulcrum Lens

Wondrous Item, Rare (Requires Attunement)

This concave lens has a drifting crimson cloud within it, resembling slowly swirling blood. While you are attuned to the Crimson Fulcrum Lens, you seethe with malevolent fury you can barely contain and are prone to fits of anger.

The gug Urthagul has the @UUID[Compendium.dnd-abomination-vaults.av-items-5e.Item.WF3e6I09QlkUvQ7u]{Crimson Fulcrum Lens} in area @UUID[JournalEntry.FwWmtOBFHhvM2gtf.JournalEntryPage.f02YPQGkiBbZ0Ijt]{H12}.

Emerald Fulcrum Lens

Wondrous Item, Rare (Requires Attunement)

This concave green lens is pitted and flawed. Its edges are jagged and cut those who don’t handle the lens with care. While you are attuned to the Emerald Fulcrum Lens, your flesh is waxen and pallid.

Khurfel keeps the @UUID[Compendium.dnd-abomination-vaults.av-items-5e.Item.4QgPxHZbRWODhm5v]{Emerald Fulcrum Lens} on his person at all times as a token of his leadership. Although he’s likely to be encountered in area @UUID[JournalEntry.1vlzl3NJsftNB9Dc.JournalEntryPage.ODRXDNm2Z9BgXmTM]{I37}, he might pursue the characters anywhere in the Hunting Grounds.

Ochre Fulcrum Lens

Wondrous Item, Rare (Requires Attunement)

This brownish-orange lens always seems dusty and gritty, even when wet. While you are attuned to the Ochre Fulcrum Lens, lassitude grips you, and you find it difficult to muster the effort for prolonged work

The @UUID[Compendium.dnd-abomination-vaults.av-items-5e.Item.ClXxwOMlEBFbjgdC]{Ochre Fulcrum Lens} is lost in the waters off of the island in area @UUID[JournalEntry.1vlzl3NJsftNB9Dc.JournalEntryPage.zRyrXydUmCGSSpzo]{I41}.

Fulcrum Lattice

Wondrous Item, Uncommon

This silver and copper framework is shaped to hold four focusing lenses, one behind the other, from smallest to largest. It has a socketed base to be mounted into a stand, such as that found in the top of a lighthouse. The Fulcrum Lattice was specifically designed to hold the four Fulcrum Lenses from smallest to largest (ebon, crimson, ochre, emerald), and it hums when within 10 feet of any Fulcrum Lens.

The @UUID[Compendium.dnd-abomination-vaults.av-items-5e.Item.B4ZOpqh9JMDbktaF]{Fulcrum Lattice} is stored in area @UUID[JournalEntry.1vlzl3NJsftNB9Dc.JournalEntryPage.ydFyUm2uTgteYviW]{I58}.

Ebon Fulcrum Lens

Wondrous Item, Very Rare (Requires Attunement)

This strangest and most powerful of the Fulcrum Lenses resembles a chip of smooth obsidian containing three dark glimmers of Nhimbaloth’s essence. Incorporeal and ethereal creatures can touch and hold the lens.

Belcorra keeps only the most powerful lens, the @UUID[Compendium.dnd-abomination-vaults.av-items-5e.Item.51Y44b2yq3K1mQ5h]{Ebon Fulcrum Lens}, with her—indeed, as a ghost, it’s the only one she can carry.

Chapter Synopses.name: Chapter Synopses
Chapter Synopses.text:
Advancement

The characters begin the campaign at 1st level.

Milestone: The characters advance to 2nd level after clearing out most of the Gauntlight Ruins.

@UUID[JournalEntry.kDJSn9wbVvjnqYEj]{Chapter 1: A Light in the Fog}

by James Jacobs

Wrin Sivinxi suspects something dangerous in the ruins of Gauntlight Keep and asks the heroes to investigate the ruins and its strange lighthouse.

Advancement

The heroes should be 2nd level before the @UUID[JournalEntry.uMZ0RiCcPSqsx1Nm.JournalEntryPage.bwT6PloCsffN9m73]{Deadtide for Otari} event.

Milestone: The heroes advance to 3rd level after defeating the Ghost Queen morlocks.

@UUID[JournalEntry.uMZ0RiCcPSqsx1Nm]{Chapter 2: The Forgotten Dungeon}

by James Jacobs

Gauntlight's dread beam animates the dead in Otari's graveyard, and the heroes must help quell the undead uprising and return to the dungeon.

Advancement

The heroes should be 3rd level upon entering the Library level.

Milestone: The heroes advance to 4th level after defeating the Cult of the Canker.

@UUID[JournalEntry.KeWKr2yd8dbppeS5]{Chapter 3: Cult of the Canker}

by James Jacobs

The heroes explore a sprawling library now inhabited by a group of scholarly and sinister ghouls who call themselves the Cult of the Canker.

Advancement

The heroes should be 4th level upon entering Belcorra's Retreat.

Milestone: The heroes advance to 5th level after speaking with Otari's ghost.

@UUID[JournalEntry.Os5bHdzCDiXgJBQ6]{Chapter 4: Long Dream the Dead}

by James Jacobs

After the heroes encounter the ghost of Otari Ilvashti, they receive a dire warning about what lies even deeper in the Abomination Vaults.

Advancement

The heroes should be 5th level before addressing the theft and dream-possession in town.

Milestone: The heroes advance to 6th level after clearing out most of the Arena level.

@UUID[JournalEntry.JT0zCcIwsSpKnbB5]{Chapter 5: Into the Training Grounds}

by Vanessa Hoskins

The heroes recover four icons from Otari's founders to access deeper dungeon levels and meet townspeople with surprising connections to the dungeon.

Advancement

The heroes should be 6th level upon entering the Laboratories level.

Milestone: The heroes advance to 7th level after defeating Jafaki and the seugathis.

@UUID[JournalEntry.KI33EAGPVHP4zyFZ]{Chapter 6: Experiments in Flesh}

by Vanessa Hoskins

In old alchemical laboratories, the heroes can foil a seugathi's schemes.

Advancement

The heroes should be 7th level upon entering the Prison level.

Milestone: The heroes advance to 8th level after dealing with Urevian.

@UUID[JournalEntry.OyNcqrpRClyhr8BJ]{Chapter 7: Soul Keepers}

by Vanessa Hoskins

A contract devil named Urevian must fulfill a centuries-old agreement, but the heroes might strike a deal with the devil to save the town.

Advancement

The heroes should be 8th level upon entering the Farm level.

Milestone: The heroes advance to 9th level after clearing out most of the Farm level.

@UUID[JournalEntry.FwWmtOBFHhvM2gtf]{Chapter 8: Decaying Gardens}

by Stephen Radney-MacFarland

The heroes encounter a strange caligni cult and a cabal of undead gnomes.

Advancement

The heroes should be 9th level upon entering the Hunting Grounds level.

Milestone: The heroes advance to 10th level upon entering the Gate of Nhimbaloth.

@UUID[JournalEntry.1vlzl3NJsftNB9Dc]{Chapter 9: On the Hunt}

by Stephen Radney-MacFarland

In the enormous Hunting Grounds level, the heroes can learn the secret to defeating Belcorra and find the required fulcrum lenses.

Advancement

The heroes should be 10th level upon entering the Temple level.

Milestone: The heroes advance to 11th level after (or, perhaps, just before) defeating Belcorra.

@UUID[JournalEntry.yn21bNM6kpV4xRol]{Chapter 10: To Draw the Baleful Glare}

by Stephen Radney-MacFarland

The heroes explore an ancient temple of the Outer God Nhimbaloth and take the fight to Belcorra once and for all!

Getting Started.name: Getting Started
Getting Started.text:
This module comes packaged with a host of journal entries providing detailed room descriptions, NPC biographies, and other tools. Wherever possible, we will try to link to relevant entries within the journals themselves, so that you've always got useful information at hand. If you've decided to run the Abomination Vaults adventure path, here are some of the useful journals you could read to get started!

Campaign Background

If you'd like to learn more about Otari's past and the history of Gauntlight, the @UUID[JournalEntry.67686KaEPc6XAlKJ]{Adventure Toolbox} contains a timeline of critical dates and events, as well as several pages containing a detailed view of local history and events, as well as detailed biographies for major NPCs. The articles on @UUID[JournalEntry.67686KaEPc6XAlKJ.JournalEntryPage.snj2fGhhuxfAInom]{Belcorra's History} and the @UUID[JournalEntry.67686KaEPc6XAlKJ.JournalEntryPage.RBY8Uu8FDdAjmE4K]{Abomination Vaults} are a good place to start.

The town of Otari as it is today is best presented by the @UUID[JournalEntry.67686KaEPc6XAlKJ.JournalEntryPage.7WZr8QhFOSrHPTgU]{Otari Gazetteer}, and the journal also has a description of each major location in the town, with information about the NPCs that can be found there.

Planning your Game

This journal contains several pages containing useful material to help you to decide how to get started with planning and eventually running your campaign. You can use the table of contents on the left-hand side to navigate to them.

Depending on where you want to start, you could read about the suggested @UUID[.uGgoAibjz5qhnqmL]{Advancement} rules, or consult the @UUID[.8aIgvvxLjsYxB1LS]{Chapter Synopses} for a brief overview of the events of the adventure.

The Using This Module category contains several pages with advice on how to read the journals and how to use the information they contain.

Using this Content

@UUID[.mH6Z1rs7XY2Agp9q]{Encounters} @UUID[.qkriih9KjZ8YA9za]{Exploration} @UUID[.N725007XsfScJ6hd]{Treasure} @UUID[.yJnbkL33UerrQWr9]{Using Audio}

If you ever see a box like this one, that means we have advice about how best to make use of the module and its content. The header will include links to relevant journal articles, items, and so on. For instance, the ones listed here continue this explanation! Click on each one to learn about a different type of box just like this one that you'll see in the journals to come.

Into the Adventure

We've already covered the journals which cover background information on the campaign and general advice on how to use this module. The last set of journals, then, are the actual adventure itself. These journals are organized by chapter, and you can find them in the Journals tab of the right-hand sidebar. The headers in the @UUID[JournalEntry.huN2s6RInuTublnV.JournalEntryPage.8aIgvvxLjsYxB1LS]{Chapter Synopses} page also each link to their corresponding journal.

Each chapter's journal entry contains all essential story and plot events for that chapter, arranged in the same order as they appear in the book. Typically, they start with an overview of that chapter's key plot elements, then go on to include room-by-room descriptions that detail every creature, event, or item that the players might find within.

Beginning the Adventure

The Abomination Vaults Adventure Path focuses primarily on the sprawling dungeon complex, and this campaign begins as the heroes approach the aboveground @UUID[JournalEntry.67686KaEPc6XAlKJ.JournalEntryPage.efRUYLBH9Kf3CLkX]{Gauntlight Ruins} for the first time. Their mutual friend, @UUID[Actor.ZDYMKYZVyR8Fqakp]{Wrin Sivinxi}, has already briefed them about her sighting of a strange glow atop the ruin’s towering lighthouse. From Otari, no one other than Wrin can make out this glow, but if the heroes look up at night from the immediate environs, they can confirm what Wrin’s supernaturally acute eyes picked out from town—the top of the lighthouse does indeed glow a faint, eerie blue after dark.

Of course, you don’t have to start this campaign on the literal front porch of the dungeon—if you wish, you can ease the heroes by roleplaying their initial encounter with Wrin (perhaps as she gives them an astrology reading), or after the heroes spend time in town involving some last-minute shopping or a trip to a tavern. In this case, consult the @UUID[JournalEntry.67686KaEPc6XAlKJ.JournalEntryPage.7WZr8QhFOSrHPTgU]{Otari Gazetteer} or @UUID[JournalEntry.67686KaEPc6XAlKJ.JournalEntryPage.raJDQ95RBqeXxV14]{Wrin's biography}, but the fun doesn't truly begin until the heroes head up the Gaunt Trail to the foreboding ruins in Fogfen!

Content Warning:

While Abomination Vaults contains typical Pathfinder action and adventure, it also presents themes of suicide, ableism, body horror, and human experimentation. Before you begin, understand that player consent (including that of the Game Master) is vital to a safe and fun play experience for everyone. You should talk with your players before beginning and modify descriptions or scenarios as appropriate.

Advancement.name: Advancement
Advancement.text:
Using Experience Points

While each level of the Abomination Vaults is built with the assumption of a group of characters at a particular character level (in each case, the expected character level is the same as the dungeon level), each level holds more than enough encounters for a party to level up. The characters don’t need to explore everything for the campaign to stay on track. Indeed, part of the joy of a large dungeon crawl is the exploration of every nook and cranny, and a party who faces every encounter might gain enough experience points to reach higher levels well before the end of this Adventure Path—and that’s fine! Some later encounters challenge a high-level party well enough, even if the characters have to retreat, rest, and recover less often.

The dungeon provides lots of freedom to explore, particularly in the middle levels, where a massive spiral stair provides easy access. Let the players gauge whether their characters are in over their heads and retreat (or flee!) if the situation demands it.

Some gaming groups prefer to have their advancement happen at natural story breaks, rather than tracking XP for every encounter they overcome. This type of story- based progression can be tricky for a giant dungeon crawl, however, since the characters can move between levels through multiple routes. If as the GM you prefer story-based progression, don’t just allow the characters to automatically level up simply because they quickly reached a lower dungeon level. Consider requiring them to complete specific milestones to level up, as detailed in @UUID[JournalEntry.huN2s6RInuTublnV.JournalEntryPage.8aIgvvxLjsYxB1LS]{Chapter Synopses}.

The final three levels are where the story of the Abomination Vaults comes to its head. It’s critical that the characters discover the three @UUID[JournalEntry.67686KaEPc6XAlKJ.JournalEntryPage.azMqL6C2NvazTcRE]{Fulcrum Lenses} in the lower levels and learn how they work—specifically, how they can permanently destroy Belcorra. Yet Belcorra has more freedom to harry the characters throughout these lower levels, and by the time they face her in the Empty Vault, they’ve earned her ire. With luck, the characters can defeat Belcorra and topple Gauntlight!

Exploration.name: Exploration
Exploration.text:
You should take note of what the players have their characters generally do as they explore. You can find a list of @UUID[Compendium.dnd5e.content24.JournalEntry.phbActions000000]{Actions} in the SRD- or, you can just ask each player to describe what their character does and decide which exploration activity best fits their description.

Exploration Boxes

Certain effects are listed in the rooms based on whether a hero is Investigating, Searching, or performing another exploration activity. These effects are marked by special callout boxes, such as the example below.

Exploration

Searching the Room

A hero that succeeds at a [[/skill prc dc=18]] check while searching the room finds a secret door behind the tapestry hanging on the north wall.

Investigating the Mosaic

A [[/skill arc 20]] check to Decipher Writing reveals that the mysterious script on the northern wall is an old Arcane formula.

Actions

In the exploration callout boxes, the relevant actions you need to look out for will be listed in the header. For example, in this case, we know that if any of our players are performing Perception or Investigation checks, they may learn additional information. These are the most common two exploration activities, but others will also be useful. Of course, you should feel free to reward your players with information, secret doors, or treasure even if they aren't doing the specific exploration activity that's listed!

As you've probably already noticed, as well as being a reference for which activities to look out for, you can also click on these links to see the full rules text of that exploration activity.

Checks

Sometimes these exploration activities will require a roll, as you can see in the above section. Throughout the adventure, most skill checks and saving throws will be presented in this format. By pressing the speech bubble icon next to the button, you can print it to chat, allowing your players to simply click it (with their token selected!) to roll a check. This is quite optional but can be a handy way to tell degrees of success at a glance.

Sometimes, however a character who searches a room will find something as long as they simply spend the time to do so.

Encounters.name: Encounters
Encounters.text:
As they explore the Abomination Vaults, the heroes will inevitably come across foes that must be defeated in order to save Otari- or even Absalom itself! When they do, they enter an encounter.

Encounter Boxes

When reading the area descriptions, you will often come across rooms containing creatures which the players may end up fighting. In those places, encounter boxes such as these will contain all of the information you'll need to run the encounter.

Of course, not every encounter has to end in combat. Many are optional, or provide the heroes with an opportunity for diplomacy. Just because it's in one of these boxes, it doesn't mean that a creature couldn't be reasoned with, or even eventually become an ally!

Encounter

@UUID[Actor.E4ctF7Fvi3cdkgQq]{Giant Wolf Spider}

A terrifying foe hides in wait for unsuspecting passers-by.

The web lurker is hungry, but not reckless. It will run if it realises the heroes are too much for it to take on.

Hazards

There's more than just spiders to worry about- the web lurker has strung up two nooses to catch unwary adventurers!

The creatures involved in each encounter are listed in the header for quick access, and their tokens are already placed for you on the map. The header will also tell you whether an encounter is a hazard, haunt, or similar, as well as the encounter's threat rating and experience budget. Note that while those last two are often related, there are cases where the experience budget will vary slightly from what you might expect- especially when there are simple hazards or extremely weak enemies involved!

The body text includes a description of the creatures' tactics or priorities, as well as other useful information like potential environmental hazards or treasure.

Awarding Experience

Although we provide the numbers for you, as always, it's up to you whether you'd like to allocate the players the total experience value of the encounter, award a specific amount based on threat level, or simply use milestone levelling as detailed in the @UUID[.uGgoAibjz5qhnqmL]{Advancement} journal.

Treasure.name: Treasure
Treasure.text:
As the heroes delve into the Abomination Vaults, they may well unearth valuable treasures or powerful magical items.

As a rule, all of the treasure that your players can obtain will be listed within the journal entry for the area's description. Items obtained through @UUID[.mH6Z1rs7XY2Agp9q]{Encounters} or @UUID[.qkriih9KjZ8YA9za]{Exploration} can usually be found within their respective callout boxes, while other kinds of treasure will have their own box, like this one.

Treasure Boxes

Treasure

@UUID[Compendium.dnd-abomination-vaults.av-items-5e.Item.SjiefF7DbgRPkbyD]{Elven Curve Blade} @UUID[Item.DSJVbn9MptSHXr8g]{Seugathi's Stash}

At the back of the cave sits a glimmering hoard!

Handing Out Items

As you can see, we can link to treasure in two different ways. Links which go directly to items, like the Elven Curve Blade above, can simply be dragged right from the journal onto a player's character sheet. In other cases, especially if there are a great number of different items in one place, we will provide loot containers, like Seugathi's Stash above. They can contain a number of items, and giving these items to your players is as simple as giving the container to their Party actor or an individual Player's character. They will be able to open the loot container and take items directly from it by dragging them into their inventories.

Coin as treasure

Coins are linked in journals using the Award enricher. They will look like this: [[/award 10gp 1d4sp]].

Modifying Treasure

If you plan to modify the items your players will find, or if you're interested in getting an idea of the sorts of items that they may be able to get their hands on, you can look at the list below. This lists all of the permanent and consumable magic items from each chapter, not including treasure items which are only useful in trade. Of course, your players probably won't find every piece of treasure the Abomination Vaults have to offer!

Audio.name: Audio
Audio.text:
This adventure includes more than 70 different playlists to evoke particular moods, give audio clues, or inspire your players to courageous and glorious battle. While the playlists have been carefully organized in the interest of making them intuitive for use, as with all aspects of running an adventure, preparation is key.

To provide the best audio experience for your players, it is important to be familiar with the types of playlists and sounds at your disposal.

Simultaneous Music and Ambience

We did not provide music or pre-set soundscapes for the average combat, but there are musical atmospheres pre-configured for particular map regions. These can be identified with reasonable ease by matching the name to the journal entry for an area. While these entries are not named to match exactly, it should be clear which is which.

Most scenes have several key musical themes tied with ambience tracks, each balanced carefully and set to play simultaneously in order to build the soundscape for that area.

If you find the music or a soundscape is becoming repetitive, the playlist folder "All Floors" contains music and ambiences you can use to bring a different feeling to an area.

Recurring Themes

The playlists provided include, and reuse, a number of recurring themes to let you build auditory reminders for your players. For example, whenever a scene involves Belcorra Haruvex, one of her golems, or a particularly potent remnant of her past, a playlist will begin with "Belcorra Warning". In places where the essence of Nhimbaloth has had an effect, the audio track "What Do We Say to the Empty Death" has likely been left as an ambient sound source on the scene - albeit quiet enough that only the most attentive player should notice it. Throughout the first four floors, Volluk's theme: The Worms March (or Waltz of the Worms) has been woven into the playlists to represent his involvement in that particular sideplot. Making liberal (but subtle) use of tracks like these will help elicit a response in your players when they reach an inevitable combat where the theme is used as they face their foe.

Ambient Sound Sources

 Knowledge Base: Ambient Sounds

Throughout the adventure, each scene has at least two pre-placed ambient sound sources. Usually centered on the Gauntlight Tower. Ambient sound sources give your players audio clues in proximity to their tokens, and it is important as a GM to know when they will be experiencing those sounds. Before your sessions start, take a moment and familiarize yourself with the sounds your players may experience by checking the Ambient Sound Controls.

You can stop an ambient sound source from emanating its sound by right clicking it from the sound layer at any time.

Using Combat Music

While only a few combat audio tracks have been provided for normal combat encounters, there is also a list of 'major encounter' music tracks which can be leveraged in more serious fights. While a number of these have been chosen for specific encounters, we encourage you to create your own combat soundscapes with the tools available. However, use some caution---due to the use of recurring themes as mentioned above, overexposure to particular tracks may have a negative effect on the sound experience for the adventure. Always know what your players are going to hear (and how loudly) before you play it.

Using Ambient Silence

A few key places use playlists that do not come coupled with music, by design. These are meant to give a GM opportunity to use the silence as a cue of danger in and of itself. To maximize impact, you are encouraged to use the pause button on a playlist to bring your players warning of an imminent danger, or a feeling of being watched. 

In the depths of the Abomination Vaults, there are dangers around every corner and sometimes a well placed silence can be enough to make your players consider turning back.

Keys.name: Keys
Keys.text:
Throughout this adventure, the heroes might come across keys they can use to open doors and other locks throughout the dungeon. You can keep track of which keys they have discovered with the items which are linked in the room description journals. However, the key's description won't tell you which doors it opens- only the room it was found in. This is because you may not want to reveal to your players which doors the key opens as soon as they find the key.

Instead, we have collected all of that information into one place on this page. If you'd like, you could also use this handout to keep track of which keys the heroes have and have not yet found.

Foundry Credits.text:
The Abomination Vaults Adventure Path for Foundry Virtual Tabletop was created and produced by a task force of Foundry Virtual Tabletop staff and contractors hand-selected from the Pathfinder community.

Viviane Charlier

Software Development

Special Thanks

The Foundry Virtual Tabletop team would like to express its profound and heartfelt thanks to the development team of the PF2e game system. Their efforts to adapt Pathfinder Second Edition for virtual tabletop play have provided countless fans a place to play and experience Pathfinder at a level of quality unmatched anywhere else. Their adamant refusal to accept payment for their work on the system is a bold statement about the generosity of the Pathfinder community, and we look forward to working together with them for a long time to come.
